Of course, companions in CV much better, than dummies in ER. And so is coop, completely free from cancer invasions. Though, I wish here some kind of arena too for PvP.

While stages are straight forward at first glance, you will noticed, that they are a bit complicated and it requires some time and effort to investigate everything.

I think, Cathedral is a great example of genius level design) I know, many ppl hate it, though))

Also there is similar stage later, but if you apply "switch" road rule, it will be breeze.

What I don't like in game:
- autoaim is terrible. It is crystal clear, when you use great type of swords. ER much better with auto aim. At the same time if you pick manual, very often you still have some weird tracking, that become obvious, when few enemies are trying to attack you. It is like you aim in one direction, but than invisible force move your weapon somewhere else.

- netcode for long distance in coop is terrible too. It is impossible sometimes to dodge in time. But mostly I saw this, when played in the morning, when only players from distant regions are available.

I wish here was base customization, so you can decorate your fortress a bit)

I was really enjoying myself throughout the game BUT as it went on the imperfections of the game started to become more and more visible. Kind of like going to a bar and finding someone attractive just to see how bad the choice was. 
As a matter of fact, the boss which made me write this negative review is Blade Bearer and the Cannoneer.
I strongly respect that Bandai Namco wanted to get some of that Fromsoftware spicy spicy boss recipe, but they failed harder than Plankton stealing recipe from Mr Crabs. This awful duo which was supposed to be another refresh of Orstein and Smough turned out to be worse than throne watchers from DS 2. 
Moreover, as a follow up to my nagging before that, the "imperfections" I mentioned is the whole combat system. As a casual parry enjoyer I thought that parries would be more polished and they would mean anything. Though, parrying basically does nothing. Nice, I see how you wanted to subvert expectations. Nonetheless, if you remember DS1, beware blocking is back. Yep, they did it again. What does it offer you? Well, we designed some bosses in a very specific way because you will not be able to roll enough times, parrying does nothing... so yeah. Just block, hehehe.
Side note: attacks are not well telegraphed, enemy hitboxes are the size of yo-mamma (massive).  
The most infuriating bosses I have seen in a while are compiled into a nothing sandwich which is Code Vein. Do I regret buying / playing it? Nah. It makes me appreciate mid games more. 
On top of that, upgrading weapons feels like nothing is moving forward. By the time you get to aforementioned duo, you have +10 weapon and you need to be rocket scientist to perform this battle even with a companion. Forget about co-op, game is dead. 
I will try to finish this one and come back after getting closer to platinum.

Edit 5 hrs more in this hot mess

1. Finished the game, just because RNG allowed me to do so
2. Thought I would do some side stuff like Depths 
3. I step into wrong neighborhood. 
4. Turned out Bandai Namco just thought Blade Bearer and the Cannoneer were such a banger combo that they would use them again, but in smaller arena 
5. There is also a twist, now the one which is killed first transfers their special powers to their companion. Nice shameless bottom line copy of DS1. 
6. Forgot to mention one whole area looks like Anor Londo, but without any soul or charater. Copy paste land. 
7. I thought I would push myself to get platinum just for the sake of it. 
8. Looking at the quality of this game even Jenga sounds like a more stable construction.

Anime Souls is a soulslike in the worst way possible and anime in the worst way possible.

At first glance, it has the appearance of a soulslike but none of the substance. There is no mystery or intrigue. Levels are boring, dull, a chore to navigate and use the same few textures repeatedly. Despite the severe lack of environmental storytelling, cutscenes go on forever. During these obnoxiously melodramatic and long cutscenes with no self-awareness, either nothing is happening or characters explaining the things that are happening right in front of them. Until this game, I have never wanted to stop playing something because of its story. You can unlock new classes and skills by repairing the memories of the NPCs who all have amnesia and sit through more of the awful plot, but new skills and classes are mostly useless anyway. The game also severely lacks enemy variety and original soundtracks. 

[i] However, you can adjust your character’s breast size and give her heart shaped pupils. [/i]

Behold! Code Vein! A dungeon crawler, Souls combat inspired, with an involving Anime style story. Over the top boss battles, stat balancing, and dungeon looting await. Don't let the Anime style fool you, this game is a whole different animal compared to the games that gave it inspiration. This game gives a whole new meaning to the term "Blood Lust".

A very solid Anime-Style Souls-like.

Combat feels quite impactful and has the right amount of "sluggishness" to it. Equipment-options are exceedingly limited (3 Slots - 2 for Weapons and 1 for your Blood Veil), but there is a wide variety of weapons that do set themselves apart from one another. Particularly some boss weapons with elemental effects feel very unique.

While weapon movesets are VERY basic, the option to combine gifts and passives from various classes (that also differ wildly) ensures that you have a lot of different playstyles at your disposal and you can create a class that wreaks havoc however you see fit. Be it a Greatsword-wielding berserker, an elemental caster or a ranged ichor cannon.

The lore is fairly interesting and the world-building is well done. In terms of the overall story - it is serviceable but definitely nothing to write home about.

If you've played some Dark Souls or Nioh, the standard difficulty is probably not going to be very challenging for you. The addition of a constant companion that can not only draw aggro, but also revive you, paired with the generous i-frames  and mostly heavily telegraphed moves makes it very easy to plough through most bosses.

Regardless of this, Code Vein stands as an above average souls-like and is definitely worth your time.

i find it very hard to say bad things about this game, even though i have mixed feelings about it.

the atmosphere and overall level design is really cool, despite being somewhat confusing at times. the story is great, and even better is the way it's delivered; the whole memory collecting thing is awesome. i usually hate "protagonists without voice lines" (not to be confused with purposefully silent protagonists), but code vein weirdly nails it somehow, probably because the voice acting of the other characters hard carries the cut scenes. the character creation is fantastic, and that's saying something for a bandai game, which also helps keep the interactions interesting.

gameplay-wise it's... complicated. the blood code mechanic is very unique and creative. the problem is that it's supposed to be a soulslike game. why is that a problem exactly? because it's too easy. i hate having to type that out but it's true. the difficulty really hinders the use of the many unique and fun mechanics it presents. the combat really doesn't do a good job at stimulating the player to explore different builds or even learn the core mechanics at all, which for me is a big problem personally. to me the most fun part of soulslike games is being challenged and forced to learn, something that unfortunately doesn't quite happen in code vein. to give it some credit, it's not like the bosses don't have fun mechanics and learning curves, but somehow nothing seems to really deal much damage or pose a significant threat.

in conclusion, it's a good game. you'll have fun playing it, and you'll definitely be engaged in the story. but don't expect the typical soulslike experience as i think most will have a strangely easy time playing, specially for more experienced players.

I'm new to this kind of Souls-like games so I was taken by surprise by the difficulty at the beginning, but in a positive way, you gotta watch out as even a stupid wall can kill you and can't just charge into battle despite being LVL 100 expecting to survive more than a minute or two. The character creation is quite pleasing, the amount of combat-style customization is awesome, the followers you can take with you are actually very useful (looking at you Resident Evil / Skyrim) and there is that feeling of pride after finishing a location without dying (not counting the bosses of course, most kicked my a$$ several times). For most areas there is hardly any music, except when in combat, however, as you progress in the game the boss fights you'll get are accompanied by music that is beyond beautiful, I truly loved the OST in this game. On the bad side, the map designing is frustrating to say the least (gonna have nightmares about the Cathedral for years to come) and I keep thinking the history could have been expanded much more as there are several loose ends even after collecting everything about the world. If there is no sequel I'm going to be very upset to say the least. All things considered I say highly recommended.

I am updating my review to recommend the game after I logged into an even older game today (Resident Evil Revelations) and also experienced new screen tearing issues. Therefore, I think the problem is my computer and not the game. I moved my original complaint to the bottom of this review. 

Although I am not really a fan of Soulslike games, Code Vein was good if I'm being objective about it. The character customization was fun. I was pleasantly surprised to find the story interesting. The writing was not bad, even though it was basically about post-apocalyptic vampire anime waifus and husbandos. There was at least one creative twist, and the characters had believable relationships. The music was good, and so was the voice acting in Japanese. I thought the UI looked minimalist and stylish. Rebinding keys for keyboard and mouse was easy. However, it was annoying that the game chose "E" as a default unchangeable key for interacting with doors/NPCs and even your Haze (souls) if you died and dropped them.

Gameplay was alright. The weapon movesets were limited, but a variety of weapons, "classes", and skills gave way to various playstyles. You aren't locked into one class, so you can open your loadout and change it in the middle of the instance. This encouraged us to try new skills that helped counter certain enemies. The only confusing things were the explanations that lived outside of the game. (But I play Monster Hunter, so...) Every once in awhile, I had to look up what stats do, how the letter grade scaling system worked, the difference between two weapons of the same class, enemy weaknesses, etc. 

I enjoyed the pace of combat. It seemed faster than Dark Souls, but slower than a hack and slash. For me, Normal difficulty was easy to medium with a couple of hard fights. With my friend and the partner NPC, we didn't die too often, but there were a couple of fights in which we died repeatedly. There was also one boss that forced us to go online and check its weakness. The partner seemed to do a lot of damage and helped with diverting an enemy's attention. Some of the maps were so big that I might have gotten annoyed if I wasn't playing with a friend. But then again, I had to do every map twice due to the way co-op only gave the helper more Haze.

***
ORIGINAL COMPLAINT: 

I don't really like Soulslike games, but the irony is that I would have recommended this one if I hadn't just experienced inexplicable screen tearing after playing for 75 hours. I spent the last 3 hours of playtime relearning how to play (I sorta dropped this title 2-3 years ago), changing my builds, troubleshooting graphical issues, and finally beating the end boss. I had been playing with a friend prior. I forget why we stopped right before the final boss, but I didn't like how co-op wouldn't complete the mission for both players. Such is a soulslike, I suppose. 

I had v sync turned off (it never worked for me) and the frame rate capped at the correct rate. Toggling the cap higher didn't do anything, nor did lowering the graphics quality. Nothing was out of the ordinary in my Nvidia control panel. Next, I updated my video card driver, reset graphics to my recommended system settings, and restarted my PC -- which also didn't help. Scratching my head, I tried increasing the frame rate cap above my monitor's actual refresh rate one more time. This somehow made screen tearing less severe, but I still saw it from time to time, even in the second to last final cutscene where something important was happening. If this happened to me in my first 2 hours of the game, then I definitely would have returned it.

Maybe there was an update that went wrong? I noticed a game client version listed on the title screen. During today's session, my game also froze when I had alt tabbed for just a second. I had to kill the app in Task Manager to close it. I also ran into another bug that was already documented in another Steam thread: I couldn't exit the "Receive Items" window when trading with NPCs at home base. That was fixed by giving them my stuff and walking away every time before trying to take the item I wanted from them.

NEW THOUGHTS: 
I already uninstalled the game, so I have no desire to redownload it and test other settings. But I probably should have fiddled around with v sync again.

Anime Dark Souls

"Code Vein" is this game that is routinely claimed to be "anime Dark Souls". It is true that the game makes little bones about its influence while adding an anime coat of paint to the proceedings. But what differentiates it from other soulslikes such as "The Surge", "Hellpoint" and even "Jedi Fallen Order" is that "Code Vein" is developed by Bandai Namco - the very publishers of "Dark Souls", as well as the incoming "Elden Ring". In this context, I like to think "Code Vein" is less like a clone and more like evidence of FromSoftware's influence on Bandai Namco. It's a game that shows what the company assimilated from its time with Hidetaka Miyazaki.

However, the game tries to be more accessible on several fronts, and I have seen people calling it "easy Dark Souls". The game has its share of differences from the real thing, so I would like to address them here.

For starters, the world design of "Code Vein" is a bit different from that of "Dark Souls". While "DS" had these interconnected levels with several paths to each other, the levels of "CV" are more isolated, with usually one path leading in, and one path leading out. And when it seems that you have hit a dead end, it means you have to backtrack to another level, in which a path has just become accessible.

On top of that, you now have a mini-map that marks with a dotted track where you have been, and it will be incredibly useful for you not to walk in circles. At first, when you arrive in a new area, the map will be blank - the track you leave behind will be your only mean of navigation. But in the tradition of Ubisoft games, you reveal more of the map by activating mistles in the levels - the game's equivalent of the bonfires in "DS". The map also pinpoints quest-giving NPCs in the environment: they usually require you to retrieve an object or to kill a monster, and those will be marked on your map as well. Puritans will be horrified by that, but I deeply appreciated the game making things easier for side missions.

Most of the levels are actually fairly short, but they still have that traditional FromSoftware design of having multiple tracks, shortcuts and locked doors. It also pays off to always look down edges: sometimes there's a path underneath them leading to new areas.

The levels are reasonably uncomplicated to solve and navigate... except the hateful Cathedral, which is a massive, unpleasant maze that will drive you mad. I remember when I saw Iron Pineapple's video on YouTube of him playing the game, and the Cathedral was incredibly frustrating for him. When I finally got to the place, all I thought was "oh hell no". At first I tried to solve the place by my own, but when I found myself stuck, I swallowed my pride and looked out for a walkthrough - and you should too. I bet the developers were really proud of designing a level so big and complex, but it's just not fun. Even with the mini-map, since the place has a lot of verticality, and the mini-map is not dimensional like that. Later on, there will also be the Crypt Spire, but at very least it's not that big and complicated.

Then there's the home base, which is not directly connected with the rest of the world. This is a place for you to buy stuff, talk to your fellow companions, upgrade your gear, fight previous bosses, and even to know where to go next: there's a mural with your current objective, so you're never really lost in that world.

Still on the subject of the world, the Depths are these separate levels that are not directly connected to the main world, and can only be accessed at first through a character at your home base, and later by teleportation. These levels seem to be optional, but they do offer rewards, like perhaps better weaponry and more boosts. Unfortunately, they're all designed the same: you have to fetch keys to open a door and fight a boss that you already faced before.

You can have a companion in your adventures. This makes bosses and surprise hordes more bearable. Once again, puritans will scoff at this, but I was very appreciative of it - besides, you can go alone in your quest if you desire so. Different companions have different styles, and they can revive you when you're down by giving you some of their own HP. This makes them more vulnerable, but it gives you a fighting chance - it actually reminded me of the second life mechanic from "Sekiro". Companions are very reliable, but they're also very talky: they always have something to say at whichever circumstance.

Companions actually carry a lot of valuable objects, and the way to get them is a bit more complicated than in a Bethesda game. You have to score points with them, and the way for that is to give them special gift items that can be traded for what they're caring. Unfortunately, however, I found out there's a glitch in the game that would lock me in the trading screen after I got something. This made me sceptical about trading stuff, so you're better off saving the game first by doing a quick visit to the local mistle.

There are plenty of weapons and veils (the game's version of armours) to be found. They can be upgraded, and if you have the right items you can give your weapons extra powers, such as lighting damage or poisonous effects. Another way the game tries to differentiate itself from "DS" is to have what it calls a "blood code". Different codes can give your character different stats and abilities, and they can be changed at anytime.

One thing I really didn't like is that your character is barely visible through most of the game. I took my time in creating my anime character and her clothes, only to discover that when you're outside your home base and into the world at large you always have a mask over your face - and the veil covering your clothes. What were they thinking? It may serve the propose of lore, but its aesthetically unsound and not intuitive.

And now that I mentioned lore, I think the biggest difference between "Code Vein" to the works by FromSoftware is the way it presents its story. Miyazaki has always been economic and minimalist about the way his games tell their stories: there are barely cutscenes in his works, and they only pop out at very important moments. Meanwhile, in "Code Vein", it's like you can't go 40 minutes before you trigger a cutscene. And they're long, with talkative characters exposing the story for us. There will also be these obnoxious moments when you restore vestiges of memories from other characters, as you walk slowly through these dream lands, watch static petrified models, and listen to dialogue in the background. That just sucks.

As for the rest, it's pretty much "Dark Souls". You have your usual lock-on combat, rolling mechanics, boosts for your weapons and yourself, bonfire-like mistles for resting, levelling up and teleportation, backstabs, and a pause menu that doesn't actually pause the game even when you're playing offline by yourself. The game also adopts the posture mechanics of "Sekiro" as well. It is "Dark Souls" simplified for an audience who may have always been interested in the mechanics of the series, but may have been turned off by its difficulty - specially in what concerns traversing the levels.
Real fun especially with coop. I have completed twice. One solo and one coop. Just really wish that you can coop and progress in the story simultaneously otherwise really good game.

Pros:
- The absolute best character creation I've ever seen in my entire life
- Story and themes are super intriguing but I didn't make it far enough to actually rate it properly
- The Blood Code system is amazing and I would LOVE to see more of that in other games. Having the option to pretty much change your class at any point in the game to encourage versatility and build exploration is such a cool mechanic.

Cons:
- Janky as hell. A 2019 game shouldn't be this clunky. Inconsistent backstab, lots of inputs not registering properly resulting in various frustrating situations, inconsistent dodges, etc
- A LOT of enemy attacks have ZERO wind up which makes it virtually impossible to react to some attacks
- Mob density = artificial difficulty and this game has loads of it. Enemies, group composition and bosses don't feel thought of at all. It just feels like they crammed the same enemies everywhere as much as they possibly could and call it a day.
- Controller mapping. As of 2019 there are TONS of soulslike with virtually all the same controls but they somehow decided to just attribute random actions to random numbers with some controller buttons not being remmapable properly so you can't get the usual "Light attacks on R1 and heavies on R2" for some reason

CODE VEIN je akční RPG hra vyvinutá společností Bandai Namco Entertainment. Hra se odehrává ve světě, který byl zasažen apokalyptickou katastrofou, která proměnila většinu populace v upíry. Hráč převezme roli Revenanta, který trpí ztrátou paměti a musí bojovat proti hordám nepřátel, aby odhalil svou minulost.

Hra se vyznačuje kvalitním a detailním výtvarným stylem. Svět CODE VEIN je temný a ponurý, s rozmanitými lokacemi a nepřáteli, což přispívá k atmosféře hry. Grafické provedení je obzvláště pečlivé a oko lahodící. Postavy jsou také dobře navržené, s výraznými tvářemi a oblečením.

Ve hře je důležitým aspektem bojový systém. Hráč může vytvořit vlastní postavu, vybavit ji různými zbraněmi a schopnostmi a poté se pustit do boje proti nepřátelům. Hra nabízí různé styly boje, včetně rychlých útoků a silných úderů, a také různé strategie, které můžete využít při boji s různými druhy nepřátel.

Dalším zajímavým prvkem hry je možnost vzít si s sebou společníka, který vám může pomáhat při boji. Tito společníci mají své unikátní schopnosti a dovednosti, a také příběhové vývoje, které můžete odemknout prostřednictvím interakcí s nimi.

Co se týče příběhu, CODE VEIN nabízí zajímavý a zapojený příběh, který se postupně odhaluje během hry. Příběh je plný intrik a tajemství, a také obsahuje několik dojemných a emotivních momentů.

Jedním z nedostatků hry je příležitostná frustrace v důsledku obtížných soubojů. Některé bossové souboje mohou být velmi těžké a vyžadují trpělivost a opakování. To může být pro některé hráče frustrující a může odradit některé hráče.

Celkově vzato, CODE VEIN je velmi kvalitní akční RPG s atraktivním vizuálním stylem, zajímavým bojovým systémem a poutavým příběhem. Hra je určitě doporučovaná pro fanoušky žánru a pro ty, kteří hledají výzvu ve formě obtížných soubojů.

This Souls-like game is very good.

Graphics: if you like anime graphics then you will likely love the aesthetics. Some of the best visuals I've ever seen for an anime-styled game. Animations are also very smooth and well done. Enemy visual designs are pretty awesome - similarly for bosses. Also, I love the dark fantasy quasi-vampire vibes from the story/setting/environment.

Sound: stellar. Voice acting for all conversations and some notably famous voice actors have been recruited as well. Also, while the companion is following you they will occasionally say something - sometimes what they say is just idle chat but sometimes they things of interest like making you aware of certain interactive objects. Ambience, music, and enemy sounds are good too. They really put a lot of effort into the sound department.

Gameplay: has all the things you love about Souls-like games like parry, block, dodge, light, heavy but in addition also has the concept of ichor to use to cast skills and regaining ichor through various means like drain attacks, back attacks, parry, dodge, block, launch attacks (only when in focused state during combat), and normal attacks as well, so the game encourages skill usage a lot more than most Souls-like games. There are a crazy number of different builds to make because you can equip 4 passives and 8 active skills and you have to find blood codes to unlock them and you have to "master" them if you want to transfer them to a different equipped blood code. There are 3 equip slots: blood code, blood veil (armor), and weapon. You can also enhance your build with one of multiple different companions or choose to tackle the game solo. Backtracking, finding shortcuts, hidden items, finding hidden paths, these are all done well - the map designs are pretty good in my opinion. I also like that the game is not mission-based, but comprised of different maps that you can revisit that retain the shortcuts you've unlocked.

Replay value: high - there are many different builds, there are other gameplay modes/instances that you can combat through outside the story, there's also NG+, etc. that you can replay at either enhanced difficulty or normal difficulty. That is in addition to the fact that the game is very long on its own for just beating the story (about 30 hours).

Difficulty (unpopular opinion): I actually enjoy this game more than the FromSoftware Dark Souls/Elden Ring titles. I feel like the game allows for more variety of playstyles, whether you like dodging, blocking, parry (although I believe you don't benefit from parrying bosses), ranged, melee, glass cannon, tanky playstyles, and, in my opinion, the bosses and enemies are more "fair" (i.e., they don't just blast the arena with large AOE's constantly in every fight and there seems to be less one-shot type damages).

Used to play this one in 2019 (pirated version), really enjoyed it. As Deluxe Edition was on sale recently, decided to run through it one more time and almost 100% it (I really dont't want to do the good ending again, + farming 400 Marks is just useless and boring). 

[b] Story - 5/10. [/b] Not as "wow" as in Dark Souls, but it's fairly easy to understand. 
[b] Gameplay - 6-8/10 [/b] depending on your playstyle. Enjoyable build variety due to a ton of Blood Codes.
[b] Graphics - 6/10. [/b] Not something I'd expect from a 2019 game, but still decent and not eyemelting.  
[b] OST - 8/10. [/b] I liked it. Main theme blows up your ears every time you load the main menu, though. 
[b] Customization - 9/10. [/b] If you like anime, it's a good waifumaker. 
[b] Co-op - 2/10. [/b] No direct way to play with your friends. Bad servers, lags, etc. Play this game solo. 

[b] Summary: 7/10. [/b] If you like the genre, aesthetics and it's on sale - buy and enjoy your 30-40 hours of gameplay, if doing everything you can on the first playthrough.

A """"soulslike"""" with actually zero good bosses. Every single one of them felt clunky, and most of my wins felt random. Area aesthetics repeat constantly, with a small handful of assets making up a majority of every map in the game. Enemies repeat frequently with even the same enemy placements being repeated area after area. I wanted to like this game a lot, but it's just bad.

What I Like:
-Primarily, the graphics. It's pretty, it's gorey, it's the perfect edgy anime vibe.
-The soundtrack is fun to listen to, and you can play piano!
-The story, while confusing, is pretty fun, and different from anything else I've played. 
-Character customization is out of this world! Seriously spent half my time just playing around with customization. 
-The combat is fun, and does require an element of skill rather than button mashing.

What I Don't:
-The multiplayer is horrible. Random match-ups are extremely rare, but playing with your friends is hardly fun at all due to poor handling of cut-scenes/constantly kicking out anyone that isn't the host. I wouldn't normally mind this, but I'm terrible at some of these bosses so I'm now completely stuck since I can't get any support, and can't bother continuing to die on my own.
-While there is a decent story reason for this, I strongly dislike games that require multiple playthroughs to get all the achievements, despite minimal differences in said playthroughs (i.e. having to play every class, despite not every class being suited for every play style).
-Combat can be kind of janky/unpredictable at times, dodging/parrying aren't always reliable.


Overall, I had a really fun time with this game. I am genuinely glad I played it. That being said without a major overhaul of the multiplayer system at a minimum, I wouldn't bother recommending this to anyone. Which means a lot, as I usually play most of my games solo, even with decent multiplayer options. I just feel this game fell short in a lot of important areas, and no amount of brilliance elsewhere could make up for it's glaring issues. It's a pretty niche type of game too, which makes the issues even more obvious.

At the current price tag of $60, this game is a hard no.

Code Vein : By Triple F

"Code Vein", the action RPG developed and published by Bandai Namco, emerges from the shadows as a magnificent symphony of gothic artistry, thrilling combat, and a deep, emotionally charged narrative. Drawing inspiration from the Souls series while infusing it with its own unique flavor, Code Vein stands proudly as a captivating and unforgettable experience.

From the very first frame, "Code Vein" enchants players with its breathtaking visual design. The post-apocalyptic world is gorgeously detailed, a mix of desolate landscapes and grand architecture overtaken by nature's reclamation. The character and enemy designs are an exquisite blend of elegance and darkness, reflecting the game's central theme of vampiric beauty amidst ruin. Each locale is distinct, offering a diverse range of environments that seamlessly weave into the narrative, making exploration a genuinely enthralling journey.

The character creation system is a highlight, allowing players to sculpt their revenant avatars with astonishing precision. From facial features to body types, every element can be tailored to one's liking, resulting in a truly unique protagonist. Further personalization comes from Blood Codes, which function as distinct character classes, granting players access to varied abilities and play-styles. This depth of customization fosters a strong connection between the player and their avatar, enhancing the immersive experience.

Combat in "Code Vein" is a mesmerizing ballet of precision and strategy. Drawing inspiration from the Souls-borne formula, battles are intense and demand a careful balance between offense and defense. The introduction of Blood Veils and Blood Codes adds an innovative layer to the combat, allowing players to drain enemies' blood to enhance their abilities, reflecting the vampire lore beautifully. Weapons feel impactful, and mastering the various skills and combos is deeply rewarding. Moreover, the AI companion system, which grants a partner to assist in battles, adds a layer of camaraderie and tactical depth.

At the core of "Code Vein" lies a narrative that surprises and resonates. The story is not just about survival; it delves into themes of sacrifice, redemption, and the nature of humanity. The game's NPCs are memorable, each with their own tragic tales that weave into the overarching plot. With a world shrouded in mystery, unraveling its secrets is a driving force that keeps players engaged throughout their journey.

The musical score of "Code Vein" complements the visual grandeur impeccably. From hauntingly melodic tunes to pulse-pounding battle themes, the music serves as a vital emotional anchor, heightening the impact of every moment. Voice acting is well-crafted, breathing life into characters and adding emotional weight to their interactions.

While "Code Vein" stands tall as an exceptional RPG, there are minor areas that could benefit from refinement. Occasional frame rate drops and texture pop-ins momentarily disrupt the immersive experience, though they are infrequent and do not significantly detract from the overall enjoyment.

Ultimately, "Code Vein" is a masterpiece that successfully carves its niche in the action RPG genre. It captivates with its gothic beauty, combat finesse, and deeply moving narrative. Fans of challenging games with rich lore will find themselves entranced by the world of Vein and its cast of characters. Bandai Namco has crafted a symphony of darkness and blood that will resonate with players long after the final credits roll. In a sea of games, "Code Vein" shines as a unique gem, a testament to the power of creativity and storytelling in the medium. It stands as a reminder that even in the midst of darkness, beauty and resilience can emerge, and that the bonds formed through struggle can be the most enduring of all.

I really wanted to like this game, but it just didn't click for me. I wasn't invested in the story, and I think I wasn't the target audience for the combat mechanics. If you think this might be for you, try the demo first and see if it clicks for you.

I really wanted to like this game, but it falls short in too many ways. Buy it if it's $5 on sale, but otherwise don't waste your money.

The only enjoyable part of the game were the short stories of the supporting characters, but the main overall story was severely lacking in depth and any explanation. 
If you think the game play mechanics would make up for the story, you'd be disappointed (like me). Sure, it's a difficult game and you'll die lots of times learning the enemies and boss's moves, but once you do it's the same thing for the rest of the game, enemies are literally just re-textured very early on.

Other Annoying Things to Note:
- You pick your character's voice, and they say maybe two lines the entire game. The rest is just an awkward silent camera pan.
- The amount of classes/blood codes is overwhelming, and you'll be grinding forever to unlock everything. 
- The secret ending is a black screen and one word.
CODE PAIN

The good: Gameplay, Build varieties, Music, Artstyle, Background lore* Character creater (anyone you want but anime).
The bad: Story, Level design (especialy the cathedral even if I found it fun), Character development, Character design*, Pacing.

The basic gameplay loop isn't too hard to grasp if you've played a souls-like before, since it's mostly the same with a few modifications and additions to spice things up. Heavy attack, Light attack, dodge, special attack, and stamina management are similar to most other souls likes, though you may need to remap your buttons if you like the souls control scheme. You have a limited pool of MP to use your skills and buffs and can increase it via backstabs, parries, and drain attacks. As well as a focus meter that fills up as you dodge block and parry (it may do something but I never incorperated it in my builds so IDK). You also have the option to play with a Partner AI that can revive you, take agro, and deals some damage, but it always depends on what you do.

Your level gives you a set amount of stat points that are distributed via a "fixed" modifier from your class. These modifiers determine what skills/weapons/veils you can use but you can add any skill to any class as long as the letter is high enough. Veils enable you to do drain attacks and greatly affect your stats and mp gain (ichor). You start off as a blank slate with a handful of skills and classes to start the game, which will be expanded/modified as you play the game and collect more vestiges. This system allows you to have a massive variety of builds without even requiring you to level up. My only problem was the game didn't include any information about how these things worked in the tutorial instead requiring you to learn by trial and error, or just using your eyes.

The music is good for what it's worth it isn't distracting, and does get somewhat exciting when it winds up. It manages to sit in the background as you wander the artistically diverse maps and deal with their "wonderful" gimmicks (sand and water). There are only a handful of songs for each activity, so you end up hearing them very often and depending on the ending you're going for the memory song may or may not get stuck in your head.

The maps are beautiful/interesting with each following its own theme and most of the early game maps are all connected to the city center as a hub. The devs knew what their artstyle was able to do, how the thorns were everywhere and moved the preexisting architecture, created deep crevices in the earth then called the depths (endgame stuff). With the entire region being a near unlivable wasteland with massive glowing vines strangling the the remains of the city. How the crypts look like they're made of bone or wrought earth, impossible stuctures of ice, the burning remains of some shipyard, underground prisions deep within what was once a carpark. The style is consistent, and is really amazing in 4k only being held back by the low resolution textures.

However can't look past the one elephant in the room for this artstyle, this game has a lot of "sexually" charged character designs. I don't mean like how claymore handles it. Most of the men are himbos designed to pander to a few different popular "Hot guy" styles. Most of the women are some form of "dere". All of which are to apeal to the general cliches of "sexy anime women". this extends to the designs of enemies, bosses, NPCs, and the tools for when you create your character. It never gets to full nudity, and the game is indeed rated M for blood partial nudity, and violence however some people have been caught off guard by it. One dude had a 63 comment thread about this SMH. Vampires are sexual monsters to manipulate humans and always have been. They are literally representations of evil and are a type of immoral demon. IDK how people get pressed about stuff like this.

The story and world of this game is inherently absurd and can explain in part both the lore and character design. Simply put you are a special vampire in a world of insane mutated vampires that opress normal vampires and humans on a quest to save everyone from bloodthirst. So you head out to find these bloodbeads that come from some of the queen's leftover power to see if you can use the power you alone hold to awaken the bloodspring source..

The big issue is the fact that they tried to do too much beyond the original premise, and all the mystique of this ruined world get thrown out. You stop feeling like you're uncovering the secrets of the world way too early into the game; it leaves the other themes and fun facts feeling as though they might as well be loading screen exposition. Themes That could greatly benefit the worldbuilding and improve the story: Themes of loss one's self identity. The idea of starting over in a ruined world with an ever dwinding supply. Questioning the morality behind project queen, since they turned a young woman into a mine of material abusing her immortality. Was it right that so many vampires were created from the non-consenting dead, and should humanity as a whole be held responsible.

Instead of exploring the concepts the game introduces it tries to rush character development throgh some extremely awkward cutscenes, yes the one's where you exist. Honestly I was desensitized by the time "The Real Bad Guy"TM made his appearance.

I know I sounded like a real negative nancy when I described the problems with the game but they really didn't bother me too much while I was playing. The story isn't as bad when you focus on the vestiges. There's NG+, and plenty of dungeons for endgame or midgame or whatever. The DLC dungeons are fun and add to the experience if you bother to buy them but they aren't unbalanced. Most importantly have fun with whatever you choose to play, God bless!

This game is indeed anime dark souls. Unfortunately,  this game only has three elements that could potentially set it apart from its mediocrity as a souls-like clone. 

The first element would be the character customisation, with quite an in depth character creator, it is easy to create any of your favourite anime characters and play the game as them. My only complaint would be that there is not a convenient way to import and export your character presets to share with others and play as other presets easily. The only way for you to create characters others have made is to meticulously copy the same settings when attempting to remake the same character. 

The second element is the character customisation of the builds. As the player progresses through the game, you unlock classes which have their own unique stat spreads and passive and active gifts (the games term for spells). The gifts are initially restricted to the specific class to use, but you can "master" the gifts through killing enemies and this unlocks the class restriction on the spells, allowing you to use the mastered gifts on all other classes (outside of a few powerful gifts which are locked to a class no matter what). While some weapons, gifts and armour have a stat restriction, since the stat spreads are tied to the classes, you can just freely swap classes on the fly for no cost meet the stat requirements.  You basically have access to all the builds and can freely switch from one build to another once you have unlocked the required classes and the relevant gifts you want to use. The weapon system is simple as the weapons can be enhanced to +10 with in-game materials, I found that the game gave you enough of the enhancement materials so it would not be a problem if you wanted to try a bunch of weapons. Additionally, in the later areas, when finding new armours and weapons, they come upgraded to the expected baseline(+3,+6 or +9) of your current weapon/armour set so you don't need to enhance them from +1 to +10. 

The last element that is quite important to this genre that the game does deliver on is thankfully the bosses. While the graphics of the game is a bit lacking for the overall experience, the gameplay of the bosses is quite superb for the most part. Outside of a couple outliers, the bosses are all quite fair and challenging as a solo experience. While most of the bosses movesets and attacks start out basic, usually they have a soft phase change halfway through the fight. The base moveset is built upon with small and simple additions that add to a fair but still challenging boss encounter. There are a couple of moves that lack a react-able tell for some bosses, but this is rare enough that was not a source of frustration when learning bosses. Unlike the general enemies, the bosses had minimal reuse outside of one remixed fight. I do know that the depths area just reuse these bosses, but that area seems more like a bonus option side area for you to grind in. When coupled with the build variety and freedom to switch to any build on the fly, learning a boss has never had more options available especially when a boss is giving your specific build a hard time. 

Unfortunately, outside of these 3 factors, everything else in the game is either painfully average or subpar compared to the Fromsoft games. However, as flawed and subpar as this game is, overall, I still had an enjoyable time as the game was what I expected for the most part for a game that seems like Dark souls with an anime aesthetic. Would recommend this game on a heavy sale for anyone who enjoys Souls-likes, the anime aesthetic and the excellent boss gameplay of the genre.

This game is anime Dark Souls, or at least, it tries to be.  While it has similarities to DS with its checkpoint system, lost currency on death, combat, and overall feel of gameplay, it completely fails at actually doing Dark Souls in its own way and at understanding what makes Dark Souls good.  [spoiler] Buccaneer and cannoneer[/spoiler] are an example of this, the fight is basically Ornstein and Smough with guns and even the fight progression is similar to O&S, but it feels closer to RNG than an actual skill based fight.  Most of the bosses in the game feel unfair, even with the AI companion, as they obliterate your HP by pulling out awkward and frustrating moves in an instant that feel terrible to fight against.  Simply put, the bosses are hard, but in a crappy way, not a skill check.

The gameplay outside of the bosses is also pretty frustrating, the enemies either all die far too easily, or are obnoxious to fight against (looking at you [spoiler] Boreal Brutes [/spoiler]).  That wouldn't be as bad if it wasn't just 4 different enemies copy pasted throughout the entire game with maybe one area exclusive enemy per region.  

Speaking of regions, the level design in this game is atrocious.  I have never played a game before where I got angry at seeing new areas until this game.  Everything looks the same, all of the environments are mostly empty of interesting visuals, it's either buildings and rubble, buildings and spikes, buildings and sand, building and water, or buildings and snow caves.  It's generic and once you see one part of a region, you've seen the whole region. 
 
The map design is pretty poor as well, it seems that you've got options in where to go, and which routes to skip if you wish, but then it turns out that you need to explore both routes anyways looking for a ladder, a key, or a door switch because what you need to progress one route, is at the end of another.  It would be better, if you didn't have to backtrack every ten steps for one thing or another, there's too many little roadblocks for the progression to feel fluid.  One area ([spoiler] cathedral of sacred blood [/spoiler])took several hours just to get through because it: had dozens of locked doors, was designed like a maze, had too many dead ends and hidden (but mandatory) routes.  

And on the note of routes, the game was not very clear where to go after each major boss since you would have to go to different already completed areas for the now open pathway (that may have just been me not paying enough attention though.)

The story itself was ok, a bit cliche and predictable, with the typical Anime style and story elements.  It actually told the player the story upfront, so it's a bit easier to follow.

Overall it was not worth my time nor money

TL;DR : Game is 4/10, tries to be Dark Souls, but took the worst parts to 11, don't buy, just get demo for character customization.

bought this game because it was good, had a bit of fun with it. then found out Namco tried to hide the fact this game has Denuvo in it. will buy it for another system instead.

Biggest issue is combat for me, it just feel clunky

Dodge type is based on weight which means you have slow, normal and quick blink(fast). iframes are fine for 1v1 add multiple projectile or multiple enemies and dodge feels awful.

Parry exist but you have to parry before the enemy has attacked but not to soon and not to late. By this i mean it feels off you dont click it when it feels right.

Backstabs is the most consistent mechanic but i dont know when it works and when it wont... get behind enemy click normal attack if you dont get backstab quickly dodge and try again.

Stagger mechanic
This is propaply the biggest reason for the game feeling clunky. So every enemy(not bosses) has a meter that build up from attacks. So you hit something with a big hammer and the enemy wont care until the meter has been completed. Once the meter is full that dosent mean the enemy is powerless, it will stagger for a few moments and then attack again.

Skills and status effects
I would split up skills into 4 categories

-big damage, I Would say this is the most useful to deal with high health enemies
-status effects, not very useful but is usually cheap and low effort
-crowd control/stagger build up, used to knock down trash or build up the stagger on higher health enemies
-buffs, more damage,more defense etc

So most effective method is the backstab on everything that isnt a boss. Does the most damage and is the easiest to pull off.

Level design was fine except one area that the game itself called a maze but it was mostly just infuriating.

Story was fine, nothing to be wow´d

I cant recommend this game since it falls short on everything it is trying to do, its a solid 4/10

"Flawed, but enjoyable" is how I would describe Code Vein. "Anime Dark Souls" is the other descriptor. Code Vein is exactly that, with many of the same parallels - makes sense, as it is developed by BANDAI NAMCO. Traverse areas as a revenant, collect haze to level up or unlock blood code abilities (classes, essentially) and fight difficult bosses. It has a really cool and expansive character creator with a wealth of options, and the game itself has some interesting ideas, but falls a bit flat overall.

So, if you ever played a Souls game before, Code Vein is exactly that, with a few mix-ups thanks to the abilities and blood codes. The game is mostly fun, looks appealing and has a good soundtrack, but it does have a few flaws, namely in terms of balancing and pacing. The story is also a bit confusing and doesn't want to hit right, but most of the voice-acting is well done.

Most of the game is actually rather easy comparatively, but there are a few bosses that will make you tear your hair out as they present huge difficulty spikes. Some are complete pushovers and others, especially later on, can kill you easily in two hits, without giving you any time to react. I played around a bit, but it does not seem like stacking resistances matters all too much; at most, you may be able to tank another hit, but that is about it. It makes some bosses feel super cheap, whereas others are challenging, and some are very easy. That balancing weirdness is also kind of there in the main game, with some areas having very unfair ambushes and strange enemy patterns. Whatever, it's a Souls game.

What also bothered me is the pacing of the game in terms of acquiring abilities and codes. There are a TON of blood codes for no discernable reason. You can "inherit" most abilities by using them for a while, which means you can then transfer them to other blood codes. Technically that means you can create your own class, with every code also having different attribute levels which determine how well you can handle equipment and armor. It is kind of cool and allows for some experimentation, but some blood codes are clearly much better than others, some are very strong and others feel super weak. There are at least 3 dozen, if not more, and there is quite some overlap. 

That diversity does not extend to the weapons, though, as there are only few weapon types. You will quickly find your favourite weapon that meshes with the code you are using, upgrade it to the max throughout the game and that is that.  You constantly gain new blood codes, but chances are that you won't change away from what works for you, and many of them have abilities locked behind finding "vestiges", so it may even take some time for them to become really useful, so may as well stick to what works. For that reason, finding new codes just often seemed somewhat pointless to me. I only switched my code once about halfway through the game.

Then again, it is fun to experiment and find your playstyle, though with so many codes but so few weapon types, it actually feels surprisingly limiting at times. Inheriting the abilities is also a good idea, but can take some time depending on ability, during which you may be switching to a code that is much weaker or not suited to what you are used to, and you will essentially have to "grind" for a bit. Technically this is all optional, but you really don't want to limit yourself to just one code with it's own abilities as you can have up to 8 active and 4 passive abilities.

Anyway, I feel like Code Vein has a lot of cool ideas, but in the end it's "just" Anime Souls with bouncing robertsons (almost every woman has a ridiculous chest size), a wealth of options that end up surprisingly limited, a flat story with meh characters and a generally fun, but partly unbalanced gameplay loop through mostly drab areas - though a few of the areas I actually really liked in terms of creativity and looks. I will still upvote it because it "works" and most of my playtime has been somewhat fun, but I also feel like there was a lot of unfulfilled potential in the game and its mechanics. If you like Souls games, there is no harm to check this one out on a sale.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

[h1]Code Vein - the first souls-like game I've ever played, but somehow, never finished. Not because I got stuck - but because I logged off one day... and then somehow never logged back on.[/h1]

Anime vampires sounds like a fun premise, and I can't deny that it has that little something that keeps you playing, but returning to Code Vein a couple years later I can't stop myself from thinking that every aspect of this game is painfully mediocre.

...Except for the character creator. I liked that.

[h1]Story and gameplay[/h1]

Oh, it's very anime. Code Vein is fairly cutscene heavy and features a lot of characters that will have their time under the spotlight in one way or anohter. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3114405380
The game starts us out as your traditional amnesiac protagonist. You don't know who you are, you really pretty much wake up with no knowledge of the world around you, and it's up to you to unravel what is going on and what the hell you have forgotten, while trying to unscrew the very screwed up world of Code Vein.

Other than being story-heavy, it's your usual souls-like fair - you have your home base with merchants and NPCs, you progress through levels, exploring for materials and upgrades and whatever other collectables on the way, you kill enemies that try to kill you while you do that, and each level finishes off with a boss fight (and a few cutscenes, of course). 

The levels, overall, are pretty boring samey-looking corridors with enemies (and lots of bottomless pits for you to be thrown or roll in), and I wouldn't really say that level design is where the game shines. One level in particular that would give Code Vein players PTSD upon hearing the word "Cathedral".

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3114395877
The enemy variety is pretty low, and you will absolutely meet reskins of enemies you saw in the beginning of the game in late game areas. Combat and boss fights can be quite fun due to the big anime weapons and the cool blood magic abilites, but all the aforementioned factors turn the game towards boring tedium most of the time... So the story cutscenes at least give you a nice feeling of "Woohoo, I progressed!" every time you beat a boss and finish a level. Until you stop finding a reason to keep logging in, that is.

Overall, this game has a tendency of not respecting the player's time in tiny little things that just keep adding up. For example:

One of the main story elements is the fact that our main character has "Void-blood" - meaning we don't have our own blood code (class) that we're bound to, but can absorb blood codes from others. You do this by collecting vestiges to unlock new abilities... and unlocking new gifts is one of the more tedious parts of the game. 

To unlock the power of a vestige, you need to "watch" a memory - a tiny flashback into that character's story. You get ported into a mindscape with decorations and you are locked into slow walking between flashback landmarks. Think Fallout 4 Kellogg's memories, but slower. And with dramatic music. 

The sad thing about this is that you can't speed anything up. You can only skip the memory outright, which, for one, is not very obvious (it's a gameplay section, after all), and of course is not ideal. If you want to actually see the story (which is pretty much the only reason to see this game through), you will have to slog though the painfully slow, scripted walking.

So, now I get to best part - each vestige consists of like 4 or 5 parts. So that's how many times you need to do it for 1 blood code. And there are many blood codes to gain through these vestige shards. You can see how it adds up. Especially if you have a backlog of them.

This vestige + memory mechanic of some characters is also very important for the main story itself and will affect your ending, so you can't just forego it entirely if you want the good end.

[h1]Controls (and a bit on the tutorial)[/h1]

I harbor a thorough dislike for games that like to waste your time with remapping controls because the default ones aren't playable in the slightest. 

And yes, the default PC controls are horrible. Yes-yes, the game was made with controller in mind first (and plays great on the controller - no complaints here), but it doesn't excuse the absolutely baffling [b]` + F(1234etc)[/b] control scheme for gifts that is there by default. How is that even supposed to work? What kind of hands do you think we PC players have?! You can do better. "It's meant for the controller" should stop being an excuse.

What's even more annoying is that the game BEGINS with a "blank space + dummy while a voice explains to you how game work" kind of tutorial (it's literally the first thing that happens after character creation), and now you need to figure out how to remap controls ON TOP of, frankly, all of gameplay mechanics being dumped on you right off the gate instead of fed to you organically through gameplay. 

This sort of tutorials is another pet peeve of mine. One would think they should be a thing of the past since they are just not that helpful. For me, personally, such an approach results in fragmented knowledge. I basically just end up not using the mechanics I did not understand. What that means is when I played Code Vein for the first time, I ended up heavy rolling around with a Zweihander and my boi Yakumo, because thankfully if you have brute force and determination, you don't need any skill.

[h1]Companions[/h1]

In Code Vein, you pretty much always play with an NPC companion. Of course, you can play solo if you want a challenge, but it is quite obvious from the beginning that the game doesn't want you to be alone and is designed with a companion/co-op in mind. You will start off your playthrough with a companion by your side, and as soon as you lose one, you will find another one soon after. 

I spent my whole time playing this game with Yakumo, because him's hot with a big ash sword. And he... can dish it out, oh boy. It sometimes feels like he's carrying all the damage. I haven't tried it, but I wouldn't be surprised that if you played a support character, he could solo the game for you. Some would probably say the game isn't even hard because of this.

On a side note though, when I returned to the game and realised that you can have "quick" movement speed, instead of heavy rolling with a big bonk weapon I decided to dash around with a bayonet. Did you know that if you are shooting at a target, Yakumo will stand between you and that target and block, protecting you from incoming attacks? I didn't, and I found it beyond cute. He's such a sweetheart.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3114305978
[h1]So do we buy it to play around in the character creator, or?[/h1]

Yes. Yes, we do. We buy it on sale. (Like now! 10 euros is a great price for it.) This way you can really close your eyes on the flaws of the game that happens after the character creation screen. 

Yes, it's a big game with some interesting systems that can scratch your souls itch, but the reason it's big is mainly because it's padded out with uninspired levels. If you don't mind that, and are interested in the story, then maybe give it a try.

Gameplay is a bit frustrating but I enjoy the story a lot, there's multiple endings and all of them are packed with emotion while being accompanied by the awesome music design. I played this game fully coop with my friend and we enjoyed it a lot together, so yeah I don't know about the solo experience but I do kinda recommend this game if you like soulslike game. 

I'm definitely looking forward for a sequel, and 100% will definitely will miss Io.

I like this game in every aspect, starting from the character customization, which is very extensive and truly allows us to create characters according to our desires. Although the clothing choices are limited, the soundtrack is amazing – it has a dark and great atmosphere that really immerses me in the game. Meh, at the start it seems promising, like a pretty decent souls clone, but it doesn't hook you in. 

The amount of customization, abilities and all that stuff, makes it hard to get back into it after a few days break. You need to re-learn which npcs sell what, and you aren't slowly introduced to them through quest lines, like you do in games like dark souls 3 or elden ring. The NPCs are... just there, at the start in the main hub. Like the lifeless store fronts that they truly are. With no real rule as to which one of them sells what. A reputation system that's a poor mimic of the one in stardew valley, where you can improve your standing with a particular npc by gifting them things they like, for no real reward, or plot reasons, just so they say that you're a good boi OwO <- see how stupid this shit is, I might shamelessly say that cringe shit as a weeb and a femboy, but a game doing this to me... go fvck yourself, you stupid ass ubisoft feathers

The memory fragment thingies are tedious as hell, just skip them, it's an awful way of story telling anyways, fking retrospectives from characters lives in the form of a walk through a museum, total and utter waste of time, seems like the devs were to some museums a few times, but completely missed the mark when it comes to the idea of what's exciting about that experience. Environmental story telling is poorly executed, like a cheap mimic of fromsoft, it's truly pathetic. Voice actors did a great job tho, it's just that the game designers who worked on this are complete idiots.

The controller layout they chose for the game is so different from dark souls and elden ring, you get reminded that some games do make inputs different just to be different.
Is it better? No. 
Is it worse? Maybe, cuz I didn't like it.
Is different so switching from a good game like elden ring, sekiro, dark souls3 is a chore? Yes.

Tbh. I don't feel like ever trying to get back into it again.
The first few hours are fun, because you're still learning the combat, 
but it gets tedious real fast. 

The combat focuses on spamming the abilities, rather than actual skill, reactions, quick thinking etc. don't worry, skill isn't rewarded in this game, because before you even get the chance to gitgud you will probably quit out of boredom.
It gets unrewarding the more you play, kinda like exploring the environment, which feels like it could have been copy pasted and been more fun to run around, indie games can procedurally generate better maps than what this game offers, and someone had to design this.

It leans heavily into it's anime themes, which might be a good thing for some, but despite me absolutely loving asian culture and anime, it felt out of place.
Like, we're in a post apocalyptic world full of vampires and stuff, and there is just a random hot sprint in the main base. Like, what the fvck? If it was a location somewhere in the game that you find while exploring, it would be so much more rewarding, fun, intriguing etc. put some new npc in there, make it so they have some quest line about purifying the waters, make them open a path to the main base, for seamless travel like in sekiro. see? Was it that hard? No, it wasn't. If you're based on anime, use the anime themes properly to enhance the game, not just throw them in there for the sake of them being in the game. Come on.
The story, themes, story telling, it all feels disjointed. It's chaotic, but not in the good way, in the tedious boring way, the plot twists are poorly executed and you probably won't even notice that a plot twist happened, cuz you couldn't be bothered to pay attention.

If you're too broke to play a proper souls game and you're considering this trash, just play genshin. That chinese anime game that makes money from peoples gambling addictions is in every possible way a better experience, it's still trash, but at least there is no cost of entry, and if you aren't a moron it's completely free. This on the other hand... I want to be paid for my time spent playing it, cuz it feels like a damn chore.

I've put in an embarrassingly amount of time into a game I thought I was going to ultimately dislike. I'm not super big into Souls games, just didn't catch onto the hype of them at the time.. and Elden Ring looked interesting-ish.. but again, burned out on open-world lazy-writing games. SOOO I saw this on a discount and just went with it.. I haven't really gotten into anime games in a loooong time. Last good one was Vindictus, but I despise p2w and I only really liked the combat... so here's to me hoping this game could give me that combat!

This has all the usual tropes.. young girl + big boobs + skimpy clothing to start you off. *SHRUGS* BUT, the game was actually alright. I wanted to scratch the itch of a fast-pace fighting. It actually does that a bit, yeah. Bosses are friggin' brutal in this game and damn satisfying to finally take down on my totally-first-try *coughs usually 6+ tries...*. I could make a cute vampire guy to slay all the things with and totally just stare at all the men to spite the game and its insistence of boobas in my face. 

Decent anime-character creator, though very limited in outfits. Made me a bit sad. The character creator felt one of the most hyped things about the game and it was just fine? Like it wasn't the most amazing thing ever they made it out to be. 

Music/Sound was pretty good, well cept all the opera vocal stuff.. get really tired of anime and their light-hearted music with sadlyrics being classified as 'dark and moody'. Japan really needs to understand 'dark and moody' more. The environments were pretty nice, simple corridor action but I liked it. The sounds were nice and crunchy, especially the finisher moves. Those were a lot of fun visually too! Pulling them off on the other hand will take a lot.. A LOT of practice.. and even then you'll still fail too much. Parry system was just, it was harsh.. doable, but definitely hard. And if you pull it off at the right time on some bosses? Holy hell that was satisfying indeed! ...most of the time you'll probably just get smacked.. but its worth it when it works! 

Overall, I think this guilty-pleasure game is pretty good for the combat alone and if you like to make cute anime boys.. okay and girls too, we know we know.. you guys aren't exactly NOT pandered to. :P Still, it gave me options and I enjoyed that for what it was worth. I admittedly didn't beat the game yet, I got to the last zone and honestly.. I got burnt out after attempting the opera-singer boss lady. She was TOUGH as hell. Guess I shouldn't of insulted the opera lyrics so much.. lol. Still, then I got distracted. I'm sure I'll come back around to this game though to finish it proper like. I did have a lot of fun.

In the end, grab it on a discount and enjoy some pretty anime characters turned evil and biting everything with strange armor-blood powers.. or something. ITS FUN! Crunchy fast-paced combat is fun!

I have mixed feelings about this game. On one hand, the character customization is top notch, the graphical style is relatively unique, and the game controls well. On the other, it's story is uninteresting, it's design is bogged down by numerous questionable design choices, and it contains a difficulty "curve" that equates to climbing up a cliff then jumping back off of it.

Most of the enemies and bosses are jokes. 90% of the time, you'll see any enemy that looks intimidating just to think "Wow, that was it?" to yourself by the end, which will generally take about 3 seconds. The other 10% of the time, you'll be faced with mundane nuisances that serve more as a test of patience than skill. The former unfortunately made up the bulk of the game, boring me in the process. The latter generally involves the game throwing a wave of enemies at you with no consideration as to how these enemies actually function together. Dark Souls often feels hard but fair during a first play-through, while Code Vein can often feel cheap with it's approach in contrast.

The bosses were one of the most disappointing aspects. Most of them were piss easy; I died to each of them once or twice at most. Several times, I achieved easy wins by simply having the boss target me while my partner dealt all the damage. Speaking of partners, the game was clearly designed with them in mind. This is a problem for three reasons. #1: Some partners are clearly better than others. #2: Your reliance upon them means that their inconsistent AI can sometimes screw you over. #3: Boss difficulty is balanced by having your partners draw some of their ire. They either produce AOE attacks that you can't reliably get through, or have attacks with both minimal wind-up and cooldown. It is certainly not impossible to do a solo run, but you have your work cut out for you. Not in a "difficult but reasonable" sort of way, either. It's more of a "I'm going to sit here for the next 10 minutes, slowly chipping away at this damage sponge" sort of situation. On the other end, most of these bosses are easily cheesed merely by having one of the better partners with you.

Stat customization is EXTREMELY shallow. What little can be influenced is mostly influenced by your weapon and armor alone. Leveling up increases the same stats every time, and by a paltry amount per level. Blood Codes fill this hole in the customization in theory, but none of them ever really felt distinct from one another in practice. The most they ever offer you is unique active and passive abilities, which also never really felt like they did much outside of the occasional damage-dealing projectile.

English VA's were horrible and off-putting. As is usual with Japanese produced games, they don't capture the emotions that the context of the story should give. I switched to Japanese VA's with English subs about twenty minutes into the game, because I just couldn't take it anymore. I don't actually understand Japanese aside from the occasional Arigato, so I can't criticize or praise the Japanese VA's. I did, ultimately, find them much more sufferable.

Also, fuck the City of Falling Flames. Mandatory damage, fire walls with bloated hitboxes, crowds of fast enemies huddled together, and your partner AI refusing to provide needed revivals because of said fast enemies keeping them too busy to do so. Everything wrong about the game merged into one area.

Gameplay: 4/10, for reasons listed above.
Controls: 9/10. I saw other negative reviews mention them, but I personally had few problems.
Graphics: 9/10. Art-style is great, and I really dig the early 2000's style edge. Really nice vibe.
Music: 7/10. It's just okay. Don't really remember much of it.
Stability: 2/10. I experienced one crash a significant distance away from a Mistle. Elevators wouldn't function properly and take me to my destination without temporarily lowering the max FPS to 60. It once gave me a blue screen near the beginning of my play-through, forcing me to repair Windows with a USB and reinstall Discord, because it was broken and wouldn't launch. There is no excuse for these issues, especially so many years after this game's initial release.

Overall, I'd give it a 4/10. It's closer to DS2 in quality than 1 or 3. The best part is the character creator at the beginning. The actual game part of this game, though, is incredibly mediocre. If you're so desperate for a new Souls-like that you'll even play a paltry one, get this on sale. A good sale. I'd say it's worth 10 bucks at most, and that's WITH the DLC. Don't pay more than three bucks for that garbage.

If you look at the most popular reviews on the store page, it's full of people giving it undue praise, or the usual unhelpful ones screaming about anime titty and how much they like it. Don't get it twisted, I like titty as much as the next guy, and there's no crime against enjoying flawed games for whatever personal reasons you may have. I genuinely don't understand how Code Vein ever receives it's praise, though, and it's concerning to see so many people ignoring it's faults outright. Steam reviewers just have lower standards, I guess.

It is a shame. That character creator is REALLY good.

Edited in on January 12th, 2023:
Hey, this review is gaining traction and there is one more thing I've found out about. It may be important for people to know, since a lot of eyes seem to be catching this.

It turns out, this game has Denuvo. This is not clarified on the Code Vein store page: You can only find out about it by reading the Terms of Service. You know, that thing you never read because it's long and filled with legal mumbo-jumbo that you probably don't understand.

So yeah, add it to the long list of reasons not to buy this game. It sucks, I was too easy on it.
