Hello friends,

Today i will write a review about the game CODE VEIN. This is a game that involves revenants that are similiar to vampires. Many people compare this game to dark souls, as many aspects of the game has same mechanics as the dark souls games. The character you create has a great selection of customization options, even better when you buy the dlc stuff. They also added new customization options since the game came out, such as holiday items and new emotes to use in the game. Many of the graphic style is similiar to anime looking characters. If you do not like anime looking characters, you may wish to avoid this game. Also, if you want a easier game than dark souls, that is similiar in style to the dark souls games with anime, then this game is your choice to try. Anyways, here are my pro and con points:





PROS:
- A JRPG with similiar mechanics to the dark souls games.
- The difficulty level gets pretty hard very fast, but can be done if careful.
- Great music and nice graphics.
- Very good customization system for making your own character how you want it.
- The ability to mix skills in blood codes to make a build how you want, with many different skills, it is almost infinite how many build you can make depending on the skills you fully learn.
- Variety of different weapons and ability to upgrade them and even add different status effects to them so enemy can be effected by them.
- New game plus modes add more difficult enemies which is similiar when you beat the dark souls story. Each consecutive beaten game increases the difficulty of the game enemies and bosses.
- Works on windows 11 OS.
- Works with controllers. I am using a NEO switch controller.



CONS:

- Sometimes finding a co-op partner to play certain boss areas is very hard. It is recommended to ask on the steam forums to see if anyone can help you, or ask a friend to help you in the game if you can.
- The game sometimes crashes and the internet and servers sometimes crash causing you to lose online play with other people.
- Online play allows you to not fully co-op the game, but only certain parts with a co-op partner. This means you need to reinvite them back everytime you go to new area or want to fight a different boss together.
- Some armor can clip for certain styles of mixing  armors. This means sometimes the armor will clip thru and even go thru the blood mask (veil) and look sloppy. There are settings you can change to prevent this by turning off certain armor pieces in game in settings.


Recommended for a game that is likened to the dark souls game forumula with very good character creator selection and ability to make many different builds using many of the skills you can learn throught the game. Avoid if you do not like anime style jrpg graphics.
The Game is connected to God Eater btw.

Outrageous demand for Exalted Reputation, I'm not gonna spend multiple hours farming a medal 400 times. The devs took the time to patch adding and removing save files but didn't consider the fact that the online community for the game would eventually expire. The game bosses are severely polarizing and genuinely feel inconsistent in difficulty and in damage. Also, to make an extra tid bit of an ending cutscene count as a whole other ending is fucking absurd and a genuine shameful way to make it required. If you like 100% games, this game spits in your face for it. Have fun.

They could have made at least a decent story but instead we get a cheap in every aspect product that even indie devs would be ashamed of

[h1]The world of code vein is truly amazing![/h1]
Hard souls-like game combined with anime like style is perfect for any anime lovers and gamers searching for challange. Beautifull wiews, emotional storyteling and good game mechanics. Just completed it fully and im gonna say, the story will make you cry.
[h2]Story[/h2]
Post apocaliptic world facing with lost onslaught, revenants trying to survive in brutal world, and you trying to beat this one annoying boss. the game's lore have a lot of story to offer and is mostly focused on revealing the truth about the vein. The choices you make have a meaning, and the actually
define ending you will get, out of 3 possible, your [b]actions[/b] will make a difference.
[h2]Music[/h2]
The music in this game is the most marvelous thing you will hear, from the choir welcoming you to the game, to the [b]best ending songs in game industry![/b] The game developers realy did their best making music that gives you thrilling feeling while fighting lost or gets very emotional while experiencing a  revenant's memory.
[h2]Game[/h2]
The game itself may prove to be hard, like... very hard. You need to be cautious even while fighting normal enemies on the map. There may be times where you [b]WILL[/b] rage quit, but trust, everyone was at this point. Forcing you to learn the pattern of the attacks if you really want to defeat enemies you approach, while still trying not to die from sisyphus-like healing. You have wariety of weapons to choose and fair amound of blood codes that are basically classes that you can freely change. So, read the pattern, die, improve your strategy with different class, repeat until it dies.
[h2]Characters[/h2]
Characters in vein world have their own little charm, a responsible leader trying his best, kind defender making sure you are safe, or your own character that you spent multiple hours customizating. Code vein offers rather big amound of customization for your character so creating character you desire is indeed a posibility here. Characters emotions together with their ambiotions and determination to resolve their past selfs creates a feeling where all of them are needed for game's lore.

Finishing it up, the game is a very good choice if you search for challenging games with good story natural enviroment will make you want to stay in the game for a long time. 9/10

Easily one of the best soulslike I've played. The story is rather straight forward, and while I do love the more item description lore methods some games use to tell theirs, this was just way better storytelling. And there is some excellent stuff there. It's also excellent game play wise, with actually fun regular areas and a boss roster that had a meager 2 bosses I dislike. The other 15 are at worst passable, and at times (mainly the endgame) absolutely fantastic. Plus there's a ton of build variety, so it also feels replayable as hell. As bonuses, the game looks pretty good and the music is solid, though admittedly a bit on the weaker end of the genre. My main complaint, and the games main flaw, is that it was surprisingly buggy. Keep the game locked to 60 fps max, otherwise elevators won't work and a certain boss can just straight up become invisible. 
Also don't waste money on the DLCs or deluxe edition, they are absolutely awful and the rest of what deluxe edition offers just isn't worth it.

TLDR: 9/10, a top 3 soulslike for me. Io best girl

[-] they just copied the ds3 swamp but made it shittier (farron keep -> howling pit)
[-] they just copied anor londo but made it much shittier (cathedral of the sacred blood)
[-] the companion system makes the game too easy, especially the fact that your companions can revive you and vice versa
[-] not a lot of fashion options with the blood veils, best you can do is turn them off
[-] writing, story, narrative, characters, etc. all very basic or forgettable
[-] level design is extremely linear and rudimentary. On the micro scale, each level just has one straightforward path with a couple forks off of it that give you items. On the macro scale, there are no side areas or side levels in the game, except arguably your character's memories that you can access from the cathedral. You will never explore and find a path that leads you to a whole level that is out of the way
[-] first half of the bosses are very simple with only a few moves, no mixups or anything (argent wolf, insatiable despot, invading executioner, oliver)
[-] loading screen hallways between areas
[-] no merchants really, just the one at the base
[-] little variety in the weapons
[-] game doesn't save constantly, you might lose progress if you don't exit through the mistle
[-] parrying is very slow and awkward, usually anticipatory instead of reactionary

I like this game. It's not perfect no, however I feel like not enough people gave it an honest try. As a big anime fan I think the story was very well thought out and compelling where it needed to be .  It's combat system takes some getting used to and can be slightly frustrating at times but it's not so bad that the game is unplayable. Furthermore whilst I feel some of the bosses could definitely do with some fine tuning as it feels they just cycle through there different attacks in sequence, most of them still proved very challenging and were compelling in their respective roles. Each character has awesome development and are a joy to interact with. Lets not forget where this game shines particularly well, Character creation! I don't think I've ever seen so many different options available. The only place I'd say it may have been lacking a bit was with the clothing selections, and even then you have the option to decide which particular parts of each different clothing selection you want to be visible on your character! Another thing, Co-op, when it is available considering the current lack of players, is in my opinion better than in ANY Souls/Borne. They have the password system and everything and when in use makes your summons INSTANT, and  I mean INSTANT. Unfortunately with the lack of players finding help via summons w/o pass-code can take a minute but it's not impossible. All and all I really only have positive things to say about this delightfully under rated souls-like!I really think it gets a bad rep for no rational reason! I hope more people will give it a shot! I'm excited to dive into the DLC's tomorrow!

Code Vein is an anime style Souls game that’s very well polished, probably cause it was backed by the same publisher as Dark Souls. It’s also an easier experience compared to FromSoft’s games but can still be a challenging endeavor if you aren’t prepared. The game will appear easy at first but then at the midway point will slap you to the ceiling in difficulty that it’ll be a different game. 

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
It’s a Souls game through and through but it has its own unique mechanics. For one, you only have one piece of armor to deal with and it effects how powerful your backstab is. Second, you have sword skills that use your “bullet” energy and other skills that can be unlocked based on your character’s class. Your character class affects virtually every stat and what abilities you can unlock, and it can be changed on the fly so it gives you a lot of breathing room to try different builds without having to rely on bonfires. Now the most important difference is that there’s always a NPC companion helping you traverse. You could dismiss them but the game is balanced with their help in mind. The bosses are fairly easy as they’ll target whoever is closer to them but once they get half health they start random switching. The companions are fairly competent but if they get occupied by anything they will refuse to help you. The only boss that you’ll find wanting to tear your hair out is one that’s a tag team. That one is a win based in pure luck, doesn’t matter how leveled you are you will die multiple times. It’s the same interconnected world and the same bonfire mechanics so you’ll feel at home if you love FromSofts games. Be warned tho, the game’s invasions are badly balanced. They will 

Not much I can say about story without spoiling it but their are whole sections where you’re going into the memories of important characters and it’s a nice atmosphere. If you’re in the market for a soulslike that’s pretty solid and puts an anime story in the forefront then I’d definitely recommend this. At the end of the day it’s basically faster Dark Souls with anime characters, great combination.

I thought this game was a lot of fun overall, its one of those titles I could have seen being great and just missed the mark. A little disappoint with the rpg elements, and do wish there was more options for character interaction. the level designs were fun to explore and learn about, I'm sad we didn't get more options to explore, the DLC is a nice touch but really should have been part of the base game, and should have offered more then just a few new levels and bosses. overall i'd give it a solid 8/10.  with just a bit more it really could have been something, and just falls short.

The graphics are quite good and anime styled. The audio  is decent. The game as it is does not support ultra wide, but there is a fix you can use that works very well and I used that to play 3440x1440. I made a post on the forum about what I used.
I played the main game and the DLC and it took me 60 hours to complete. The game is addictive for sure, and my keep you up late at night!

This is my first souls like game, and I enjoyed it. However, I have realised this is not my type of game. It requires patience and skill.

Narrative wise, I really liked the story. I apparently got the worst ending possible and I didn't realise there are a possibility of 3. Voice acting was solid. 

Visually this game was really gorgeous. The art team did an excellent job with the set pieces, and the lighting and textures were solid. 

Technically this game was quite smooth, however when you were entering new "zones" the game would take a severe frame dip for a few seconds for I guess things to load in as you are moving. There is also a bug where elevators do not work if you are playing above 100 fps. I was playing locked at 165 fps, and google search let me know that you need to set your game to 60 fps for the elevators to work, and then switch back.

Either way, I cruised through this game only because game play wise, not my cup of tea. There is loads of side content, but I didn't do any of those.

Do pick this up on sale if you are a souls like fan.
play for more than 3 year, finally finish it, due a reason of lack of RAM and storage, this time i'm all out play the game until the end, thank you for the game. Idene out of the game GG

Decent soulslike but janky in some places.

The story is alright but could be more fleshed out and told in a more coherent way.

Excluding the parry mechanic, combat is pretty fun.
Overall just a decent game but nothing special.
Amine

This is an outright weird game. You have to ask yourself why you want to come here first:
(a) You want a Souls-like-game, because you have run out of Souls/Elden-food. Read on.
(b) You want a story, intriguing lore and good world design. Probably look somewhere else.
(c) You are attracted by the ... outward appeal of some game elements. Watch an anime or play an (in-)decent visual novel.

When I had played the tutorial (twice ...) and unto entering the home base, I didn't understand what I was doing and even less why. I would have recommended the game nevertheless on a somewhat neutral stance, if it weren't for Denuvo. It makes the game micro-stutter until you remedy this with a modded configuration file (check the Nexus). There seems to be a decent game buried in here.

The Good
- graphics and world design are beautiful, great really
- Souls-like game mechanics, if you are into that
- good modding scene to remedy the Souls-like mechanics, if you're not too much into that
- customization is awesome

The Bad (design)
- It's a 'developer 101' of how *not* to design (and port) a game.
- PC control scheme out of hell, and some key prompts shown on-screen are wrong.
- Yet again, devs try to emulate controller mechanics on a PC keyboard/mouse lay-out - I mean, there are 10 number keys (and the numbers from 0-9 should not be that hard to understand from a designer's point of view). Just put everything in there and give us a decent lay-out or a wheel and that's it. It has been done countless times.
- The mini-map is too small, and the 'switch display function' is a bad joke.
- No pause function. If nature calls or the pizzaman rings, well, they just have to wait until you reach the next mistle ...
- Realistic, yet ineffective audio design - you have to turn around and face your party members if you want to understand what they are saying.

The Bad (narrative set-up)
- chaotic prologue and reception-protected backgrounds during the first two hours of the game
- incomprehensible objectives
- the developers went to great lengths so that you can neither understand the lore, the characters nor that feeble ruin they call a story (the Queen?, Silva?, the red mist? - what the heck is going on)
- confusing, pseudo-maze like level design that wants to hide linearity
- (this may be subjective) I didn't understand the game mechanics (skills, fighting), even after I watched a walkthrough
- there is A LOT talk about 'blood' for sure

*Update* after beating the game - which I did just to be fair: This game features some really bad game design aspects for a triple-A game. It has atrocious level design, lots of annoying backtracking, a 2D-map for 3D levels with overlaying floors, an unengaging and rather incomprehensible story, tripe dialogue, annoying party member banter, uninspired fetch item/kill enemies side 'quests', obscure leveling mechanics as well as sometimes unresponsive controls. There are also two really enraging bugs that have never been fixed: (1) enemies randomly turn invincible when they are forced out of their animations; (2) after acquiring chromes you cannot leave the menu and have to Alt+F4 out of the game. 'Code Vein' has it all. My vote is a 5/10 - sub-par (4/10), it gets the extra point for its gorgeous world building and (physical) character design.

Game played fine for a few playthroughs, but after a while I started having issues running the game on my Steam deck. After trying various workarounds (changing the proton version, verifying my game files, deleting compatdata folders) Denuvo locked me out of playing the game.

Every 3rd person game should have a FOV adjustment, do you hear me game creators? Every game that has partial or full controller support should have the ability to set your own button layout, wake up game creators ! A great introductory souls-like. Got this game on sale for like $11 and that's totally worth it. $60? however, absolutely not.  Combat - 8/10. Fun to mess around with different weapon types/vestige's. Character customization - 10/10. Lots you can do, and you can simply change your characters look at anytime from the home base. Story - 5/10. Fun concept, just drawn out, too much sob backstory telling from characters for me. World design - 3/10. copy, paste, copy, paste. most "shortcut's" that you open you will never pass through again. Weapons and armor - 6/10. Just needs more. seems like the only thing setting apart most weapons is their damage. making it obvious which one you should pick between two of the same type. enemy design - 5/10. At first they are cool. Then you realize there are like maybe 10 different enemy types for the whole game. by the end some of the enemies are just reskins of previous. 
Overall - 7/10 (at the $11 price point)

there are many simplifications. levelling up in most souls like game presents you options to build towards a suited play style.
rpg like, adding points to your character sheet. (strength, fortitude, etc) in code vein levelling up levels them linearly.
mechanics are quite interesting? instead of weapons giving you special moves, they're on the blood codes.
your play style is dictated by the 'blood code' you choose. i would even say that the whole game goes around the blood code.
its simplifications helped me ease into more serious ones.

still too complicated? if you like meta and death of boredom, add fortification to zweihander, which negates all damage on block.

character editor is one of the best things in this game. not half baked. other than the standard uniforms you can only wear, vast customization in terms of hair, eyes, accessories. it being anime, the only thing that is missing are different body shapes. [spoiler] As a tie-in into the larger God Eater universe, people who have no played God Eater might lose some context but it's overall not that important [/spoiler]
Builds in the game are easy to make and easy to change. you're never stuck with: [i] oh no, I built this but I wanna try this now, so I have to make a new character or reset my stats. [/i]

TL;DR Code Vein ultimately feels like wasted potential; it feels like not enough effort was put into it. The flaws outweigh the pros and the flaws seem determined to kill any kind of fun you're having with the game. Its main flaws are its *awful* level design (every level is either pain and suffering or just extremely uninspired) occasionally jank combat, and the fact that this game has a lot of abilities ("gifts") you can acquire, but the vast majority of them are pretty much useless. On the plus side, you can make your own anime OC, but if you want to do that, download the demo before you buy. If you like what you see, I'd say get it on sale (and ignore the deluxe edition and DLC). If you're a hardcore soulslike fan, nothing about this game will impress you. 

Like every review will tell you, this game is "anime dark souls." Sounds like a dream if you're a fan of both, but in reality, the only real thing it has going for it is that you can create your own anime protagonist; you'll have a lot of fun with character creation. And yet, despite what I just said, I'd still say I "like" the game, but I think it's a shame that more effort wasn't put into it, and its flaws come close to turning my "liking" this game into resenting its existence. 

I'll start with the level design, which is by far this game's biggest flaw. This game's levels were made by someone who takes joy in the suffering of others - either you'll find yourself trudging through a really boring environment or you'll find yourself scrambling through a really painful one that will make you wish you were in one of Miyazaki's swamps (and before you ask, yes, there's a swamp level). The levels themselves look uninspired as well - there's a fire level, a sand level, etc, and that's where the descriptions of those levels end; they are thoroughly unremarkable. So some levels are boring, but what makes others downright painful? 

You may have heard of a certain "Cathedral of Sacred Blood" reading the other reviews, and how much people hate it. Don't worry, you will too if you buy this game. As a cruel joke, this environment is the best looking in the game (imo at least) - it's this massive, beautiful cathedral that when you first see, you just take a moment to pause in awe. Unfortunately, this level represents everything wrong with this game's level design philosophy (or lack thereof). It's tough to describe it unless you play it yourself, but I'll try. In essence, this place is a giant maze where *everything* looks the same. But hey, you have a map, that'll surely help you right? lolno. Your map is useless in this game, mostly because you'll be navigating blindly until you discover certain (and sometimes *hidden*) points in the level, which are the only way to actually fill in your map. The most your map does is give you an idea of where you were 5 seconds ago in any given level, and it does even that poorly. 

Anyway, what really highlights how useless the map is is this cathedral alone - the cathedral itself has a few "floors" for lack of a better term, and your map is unable to tell you what floor you're on, which floor you haven't been to in your character's exact location, or even which floor is which between higher and lower floors. To be blunt, this level is a clusterfuck, and if you already don't like the prospect of a giant maze, you'll be happy to know that this place also has really dangerous generic enemies, "shortcuts" you can open that are completely useless due to usually being right next to a fast travel point anyway, pseudo-platforming despite this game's lack of a jump button where you must fall onto surfaces that are below you in order to progress, and deceptive paths that have holes you can easily fall to your death through if you're running. 

This level is a monument to this game's level design, and obviously I don't mean that in a good way. Most of the other levels are mazes too (albeit slightly less painful) and have nothing interesting about them. Yeah, this game's levels are garbage, and that's me being generous. They are so terrible that they either will, or come close to, destroying any enjoyment you have been having with this game, and that feels like an achievement itself because I can think of no other game, soulslike or otherwise, where *every* level was bad.

Now let me tell you about this game's systems. Basically, leveling up gives you a static increase to your stats - your actual "class" is determined by your blood code and blood veil (armor), both of which make up your actual stats. This means you can be anything you want at any time which is pretty neat - there's no need to respec and you're only limited by what blood codes you have at the moment. What isn't neat is this game's gifts - these are abilities you can learn, either through using a blood code enough and having the gifts equipped for a time, or spending a special currency to unlock them instantly. The former is painful, so you'll likely be using the latter, which means you'll have to sometimes grind for that special currency which drops randomly from enemies, or can be found in one time only set locations. 

Sadly, the majority of abilities you can learn are downright useless no matter what build you are, and others still are highly situational at best. Most of the time they can have their effects replicated through an item, and items themselves are really common. It feels like this game really just wanted to be able to say it had a lot of abilities to choose from. You think you can choose from several gifts, but really there's only a few to choose from because the rest are useless and not worth the currency to learn.

As far the game's combat goes, it's serviceable. However, attacks don't always feel good, mostly because they don't really have weight behind them which just feels weird. Parrying...exists. Poise isn't a stat, as is soulslike tradition. Bosses are typically pretty easy (mostly because of the partner mechanic), but a couple are somewhat difficult and/or cool. That said, in all my playtime of this game, I never really noticed any "patterns" they may have had and I kinda just swung my sword at them until they died. 

Speaking of bosses though, nearly every boss has the same boss theme in this game, and aside from everything else I've said, this is one of those small details that makes me think not a whole lot of effort went into this game. In the game's second act, you'll encounter bosses that have a phase 2, and as they're going into phase 2, the "phase 2" theme will play. For literally every boss. This makes bosses feel...not special. Only a few towards the end of the game get a special theme. The soundtrack for this game isn't terrible, but it definitely needed more tracks. 

As for the story: It's decent, but it takes its time getting to the point. The characters are likable enough too, so those things are alright I guess.

All that said, Code Vein sounded like my dream game (I love anime and souls combat), but in many ways turned out to be a nightmare, and such could be the case for you too. To say I have mixed feelings about this game is an understatement - I like the idea of it, but loathe the execution. 

If you just want to mess with the character creator, you can download the demo and that's the main selling point of the game right there. Otherwise, either pass or buy the base game on sale, as the deluxe edition DLC does nothing but add superbosses, a couple of extra blood codes you get from said bosses, and some armor with no extra story or anything else particularly relevant.
Mediocre yet fun Souls-like. Buy on sale.

I recently immersed myself in the world of a Code Vein game, and it was very exciting. This game takes the traditional souls-like formula and adds a vampiric twist to it. Here's my humble opinion.

First, let's talk about the visuals. Code Vein has an anime charm, and the character designs are gorgeous. The post-apocalyptic world is bleak, but it's a beautifully bleak world, if I may say so. It doesn't strike you as realistic, but it sets you up for a bloody adventure.

The gameplay - well, it's what you'd expect from a game of this genre. It's challenging, and you'll be dying a lot. finding the right bloody code and weapons can be a real trial. But when you finally defeat a boss, you'll feel a sense of satisfaction.

The plot is intriguing, but it won't win a Pulitzer Prize. The main thing is to unravel the mysteries of this vampiric post-apocalyptic world, and it will hook you so much that it won't let you tear yourself away. And this is better than just mindless hack and slash.

Now let's talk about the characters. Your companions on this journey, while lacking the depth of some other RPGs, are interesting enough that you'll grow to love them as you fight side by side. In addition, their abilities can bail you out in difficult battles.

There is some grind involved in the battles, which involves going back to areas to level up and get materials. This may not be the approach for everyone.

Ultimately, Code Vein isn't a game-changer, but it's a fun and steady game that puts a unique spin on the genre. It's a blast! It's akin to a good B-movie that you adore in secret. If you're into the whole souls-like encounter and don't object to a touch of vampire mythology, try it out.

Me: Japan, can we have Dark Souls?
Japan: We have Dark Souls at home.
Dark Souls at home…

Joking aside, from what I have heard through the grapevine Code Vein cannot be Dark Souls, due to Dark Souls being harder.  I kid… mostly, as someone who has never played a Souls Like game before I enjoyed my time with the game, its characters and story.

Does that mean that Code Vein is simply a rung in the ladder to reach Dark Souls difficult?  At a service level yes, one can view Code Vein that way.  I would say, however that Code Vein does put a lot more emphasis on story and characters than what Dark Souls appears to.  While the bosses in Dark Souls do indeed have lore and interest in them the same consideration cannot necessarily be said about the NPC’s or even the player character.

“That is not the point of a Souls like game.”

The above might be mentioned with regards to criticism of me specifically saying the player characters importance.  While a silent, faceless protagonist can work as a simple mechanism to experience the world, having a semi-interesting character and still having a deep world also still works.

If you are looking for a game to tied yourself over between souls like games then Code Vein will indeed work, but even if you are not a souls like fan Code Vein does indeed work and is enjoyable without its obvious comparison.

Real fun soulslike game with cool spells, powers and the ability to change your class at will. My wife and I played this on PS4 a few years back together and did another playthrough now on PC. 
This game is made for coop, so pick it up with a fried or your SO, however as it is weird laggy in some boss fights and not as polished as other soulslike games, you might want to wait for a discount.

As a Souls-like game it does a decent job. It introduces an interesting world and gives you an alright cast of characters to go through it with. The combat has interesting ideas and fun segments, the map design is maze-like and not to my taste but it isn't awful either. The companion system is kinda fun and the blood code system gets pretty interesting by the end of the game with all the options you have. 

That being said, it is also unique in the fact that this game has a heavier emphasis on story. The story itself is fine, but the pacing is awful. You will be forced to walk through very slow story sections in order to understand the story. You can skip it, but then you won't know why anything is happening. The story isn't complex enough to warrant such a hamfisted way of telling the story. You really could have borrowed more from Dark Souls in this aspect. Still, the game is fine as is and worth checking out if you like these styles of games.

The waifu factor and the fact that the character creator lets you make a pretty good OC should be enough to give Dark Souls fans who like anime a reason to try the game.

Very mediocre soulslike filled to the brim with edgy storytelling, melodramatic monologues and weapons double as big as the character. 
Or to sum it up in a question: "What if Dark Souls was anime, but we add vampires and this fanfic of my moody 15y/o brother who has his "xXDarkShadowkillerXx"-phase?"

Either you enjoy this game by taking it 100% seriously and sink into the storytelling or you laugh your ass off by how overly dramatic yet senseless everything is. I did it the second way.

The gameplay is sadly very underwhelming, it's very similar to Dark Souls with dodge rolls, blocks, parrys and abilities, but it barely matters because enemy attacks are often too simple and npc movement is pretty hard to read/predict

pros:
+ edgy as hell, just watch the intro and you know what you're in for. Can be super entertaining
+ beautiful models and environments, also really nicely designed clothes and characters
+ beautiful theatrical music
+ VERY huge character creator (but for some odd reason there's no beards at all. I mean come on, even with a mask you can have some kind of beard)
+ fighting with a sword that is almost double the size of your character is fun

- despite the seemingly big variation of skills and classes, gameplay is quite dull and easy
- levels are just tubes, very boring sadly
- 70% of the game's music is one song that is played over and over and over again. Had to deactivate "music" in the settings after a couple of hours because that "opera voice"-song just kept popping up
- edgy as hell, everybody has a dramatic, dark past, everybody is sad, everybody wears variations of black
- monster designs are extremely dull, your typical spiky anime demons with typical anime demon voices
- there is SO much empty talking with anime trope topics like "what are we living for?" or "I can't forget the past!"
- whenever you recover a memory you have to play a little walking simulator where a small story is told, feels more like little fanfics of ppl being all "uh, my sad past :(". And guess what, every single one of them has the mentioned "opera voice"-song. And there's probably around 40 of those sequences in the game, sooo I hope you like walking sequences! Sadly you need to play those because you receive a skill afterwards. Felt a bit like a mobile game where you have to endure a commercial to get a benefit lateron
- mediocre animations, but that's sadly kind of a standard with games from japan
- tries a bit too hard to be dark souls (ambushes, shortcuts, elemental upgrades increase elemental dmg but decrease the core dmg of the weapon, bonfires, etc etc)


It wasn't really fun, you know, okay-ish, mildly entertaining. If you dig anime styled visuals and soulslikes then you might have a try, but please don't expect much of it, it's more of that kind of game you play when you don't really have anything better to do

I played many souls-like games and this is probably the first time I leave a negative review. I was between 2 options but in the end decided go with negative because some core mechanics are really unreliable which I can not ignore. Yet, buying during a sale wouldn't be a bad option

Pros:
- Flexibility on character design. Player is able to change the character whenever he/she wants
- Dynamically changing blood codes and not limiting player to a class. I really liked this mechanic. You can discover all blood codes and weapons, pick the one that suits you
- Multiple ways to drain. i.e combo drain attacks. This actually lets user to be active and drain during midcombat. So user does not need to wait for an opportunity

Cons:
- I did not like level design. It doesn't feel like neither linear nor open. It is more like a maze. To me, dumping a ton of enemies in a maze between 2 resting points is not a good design. Especially that ... cathedral. Just so annoying. I wanted to quit at that level
- Backstab mechanic is unreliable. It feels like a random event. I am able to backstab randomly, without even trying, in the middle of the combat. When I try to backstab on purpose it fails. Character does a random attack
- Parry is unreliable. This to me maybe the most important mechanic of the game and I still do not know what the parry timing is. Parrying shouldn't be that hard. I tried in training zone to parry and it was successful. I know all monsters have different timings but they still should be predictable or stable.
- Enemies become too repetetive after some point

[h1]Code Vein: A Dark Souls-Inspired Adventure for Anime Lovers[/h1]

In [b]Code Vein[/b], you rise as a vampire and embark on a journey to remember your own past and uncover the mystery of the Red Mist. This hack and slash game combines the fast-paced gameplay of [b]God Eater[/b] with the challenging difficulty and mechanics of the [b]Dark Souls[/b] series, resulting in a unique and enjoyable gaming experience that's both fun and challenging. In this game, you play as a vampire, or Revenant, who has lost their memories. Guided by a mysterious girl in white, you join a group of Revenants to unravel the origins of the Great Collapse.

The gameplay in [b]Code Vein[/b] focuses on hack and slash combat, allowing you to confront enemies head-on and even perform backstab attacks at times. In an attempt to mirror the mechanics of the [b]Dark Souls[/b] or [b]Soulsborne[/b] series, the game introduces a forgiving feature for players new to these types of games: companions. Companions are there to assist you on your journey, particularly in battles, as they can attack and draw enemy aggro, making the game more accessible than many entries in the [b]Soulsborne[/b] series. Most companions can also revive you (and vice versa), but this comes with a cooldown period. While this feature is invaluable, the revival animation takes some time, highlighting the importance of timing.

The presence of companions can be disabled, creating a more challenging solo experience for those seeking greater difficulty. Each companion possesses unique abilities and fighting styles. Some are frontline fighters who draw enemy attention but deal lower damage, while others attack from a distance with guns and gifts (magic), keeping you safe but needing your defense. There are also well-rounded fighters. You can also engage in cooperative play by inviting other players to join your journey, essentially making them your companions. While I personally haven't used this feature, it's worth exploring for those who enjoy cooperative play.

[b]Code Vein[/b] offers a wide range of weaponry, diverse gifts (magic), Blood Codes, and Blood Veils, allowing for nearly limitless customization of your playstyle. Blood Codes primarily determine your stats, which you can focus on when building your unique style. They also unlock gifts associated with that Blood Code, eventually making these gifts accessible to all Blood Codes. Although unlocking all gifts can be somewhat grindy, you can concentrate on unlocking those that align with your desired playstyle. Whether you wish to build a magician vampire capable of ranged attacks, a sword-wielding character dealing heavy close-range damage, or a tank who relies on your companion for damage, the possibilities are extensive.

The game's difficulty and boss battles are manageable for newcomers while providing a satisfying challenge for [b]Soulsborne[/b] veterans. The maps in the game, although at times appearing vast, sometimes feel like reskins of each other. For instance, the Cathedral of the Sacred Blood, while visually striking with its white color scheme, bears a resemblance to Crypt Spire. It's a minor issue, but one that can be bothersome. Fortunately, the game offers plenty to explore. You can discover secret maps and fragments that unlock memories and gifts, making map exploration highly rewarding. The map design also allows for unlocking hidden or blocked paths, reducing the inconvenience of backtracking.

One notable feature worth mentioning is how the story is presented. Throughout the game, you'll come across memory fragments that serve two purposes. Firstly, they allow you to unlock and upgrade Blood Codes for your use. Secondly, they help you recall and experience the past of related characters. The story is portrayed as frozen moments while the accompanying voiceovers narrate the events. Some may find this storytelling approach somewhat boring, but others, including myself, appreciate the uniqueness it brings to the game.

In conclusion, [b]Code Vein[/b] is not without its flaws, but it offers solid and enjoyable gameplay. Some enemies can be challenging, often ganging up on you, but the presence of companions can provide significant assistance. While the base game is highly enjoyable, the DLC content may not be as worthwhile, as it primarily consists of boss reskins with inflated stats.

Great game

a very flawed attempt to make a Souls-like by the team behind the God Eater series, while there are a lot of things i like from this game compared to the Dark Souls trilogy, there are many duds and misinterpretations of things they decided to take inspirations from.

Movement being far too slidy is very bizarre when you're already used to the more snappy movements of the Souls games, no stat allocation (with stats mostly being locked based on classes instead), a very limited weapon types (5 types being one handed sword, Greatswords, Bayonets, Halberds/Lances and Greathammers).

and its DLCs are just very lackluster especially when all 3 combined are more expensive than the base game itself.

the quick access to skills and magics are pretty great though, wish that would be present more often in the genre, but Ichor balancing is pretty bad for certain classes. they should've put passive ichor regen for the heavily ranged classes instead.

Multiplayer seems to be locked to Co-op with no PVP whatsoever, (at least from what i've experienced)

and the game being balanced for players to always have the AI companion is pretty annoying.

all those criticisms and you're probably wondering why i'm still recommending this game

while the game is mired with questionable design choices, for the most part it is still a pretty solid game overall. which puts it above Dark Souls 2 Scholar of the First Sin by default. speaking of which, this game is smart enough to limit their version of Lifegems to just 5 you can carry at any time. 

so yes, better than Scholar of the First Sin.

Graphics: +++
Gameplay: hardly even mediocre

Great graphics, much emphasis on solving mazes.

The combat mechanics, however are terrible. Makes it impossible to play. Mobs always attack the protagonist. they always ignore the accompanying npc. Always. The protag is effectively the pet of the accompanying npc. He has lousy defense, lousy attack power. Very limited ways to upgrade any stats.

Leveling up merely increases stamina and HP, not offensive or defensive prowess.

In boss fights, the camera follows the protag far too close by, depriving the player from an overview of the arena, not adjustable. No maps in combats, a targeting system that takes too much time to operate in combat, characters not responding swiftly enough to directional operations  during combat.

Gifts (aka skills) are unusable in fights because of this. We don't know when the boss is where, and he jumps at us out of nowhere before cast times are over.

The NPC partners are useless, they apply a bad strategy in combat. In boss fights, the one attacked by the boss should defend, while the other deals dps, As soon as the boss turns to the other, the players switch roles. Instead of separating from us when a boss fight starts, the partner follows us, pulling the boss right at us, leaving the both of us to be sitting ducks.

They pull way too little aggro, forcing me to tank while the npc fights the boss.

Having to fight our way through a maze dozens of times to arrive at a boss that 2-hits us because we cannot turn around to block, and when we beat him. the spawn point behind him didn't save.

And then there are the FPS drops and freezes during boss fights.

The game sure has potential, but it was obviously not designed by people who play these kind of games. Too much emphasis on the cuteness-factor.

Pity, for the game surely has potential. Hopefully some dev will get to read this (sending emails to the company is impossible), and use it to improve upcoming versions.

✩°｡⋆ The graphics in this game are visually appealing and the story is interesting. However, there are certain aspects of the game that I both like and dislike, which ultimately led me to stop playing it. Perhaps I will pick it up again in the future. 

 ✩°｡⋆ While the game has its strengths, there are also areas that could use improvement. It seems that the game received a lot of hype for its beautiful graphics and sexualized anime characters. That being said, I would not recommend purchasing it at full price. 

 ✩°｡⋆ The character creation is stunning and the graphics create a beautiful atmosphere. Unfortunately, the gameplay lacks variety and becomes repetitive very quickly. It's like an anime version of Dark Souls on a budget. 

 ✩°｡⋆ Although it was fun at first, it wasn't interesting enough to keep me engaged - even the oversized anime breasts didn't do it for me. 

 ✩°｡⋆ If you decide to try it out, I suggest waiting for a sale, as the graphics are the main appeal rather than the gameplay itself. 

 ✩°｡⋆ While the fighting and visuals of the combat are enjoyable, the gameplay can become stale and repetitive. I'm in the middle whether I recommend this or not.  I do believe it was overhyped at the time.

Code Vein was an interesting journey. The world is very interesting, and the lore is well explained through the vestige system. Only after completing them all, will you understand all of the character's backstories, and how they fit together. The bosses are mostly all well balanced around your first playthrough, forcing you to get good, or grind out some additional levels. You never find yourself completely unable to progress, as there is a weapon and "veil" upgrade system, or alternate "Blood Codes" to try.
The co-op system was enjoyable, but could use some tweaking, as it syncs a higher level player lower even than the person they are coming to aid, and even had times when it would fail while attempting to connect to a friend, which would only be fixed by toggling the online mode off and on again from the main menu.
Of the 3 (4) endings available, playing to earn them adds enough variation to character interaction to keep cutscenes interesting, the "bad" end being vastly different. Overall, it was definitely worth the sale price.

As a Completionist - Be prepared to grind for haze and medals at different times to unlock everything. The co-op medals in particular, requiring an afternoon or 3 of mindlessly killing the same monster, as without having a dedicated partner, this is the only way to reach the end. I also strongly recommend looking up the criteria for each ending after finishing your first playthrough, as missing one thing in particular means an entire additional playthrough with very similar cutscenes until the final 10 minutes of the story.

Code Vein...

I've invested quite some time in it and ultimately, I can say that this game.....isn't really fun which it could have been since the game had potential. 

Firstly, it's an anime game so, trying to make an anime game a souls like isn't too bad of an idea. In fact, it can be wonderful but in Code Vein, the execution is just poor. The most addictive part of a Souls Like is combat. Try playing games like Nioh and Sekiro and you'll realize that even after dying to a boss for the 100th time, you still love the combat. 

But in Code Vein, the combat is the biggest flaw by a long shot. Anime characters are known to be extremely flexible and fluid in terms of combat, even the in-game fighting cutscenes have more depth and fluid movement to the combat style. But the in-game combat we play with.....is so rigid and stiff. 

You have extremely slow movement and extremely slow attacks and these two traits just qualified the game to be a Souls Like. Remove these two and this game just becomes a normal JRPG. It's not as if the enemies or the bosses have complex fighting styles and phases, all of them just literally have the same pattern of attack. The only thing that makes you fall for these attacks is because of the slow and stiff movement. There's literally no other reason other than this. You don't have bosses that can one-shot you or anything like that, in fact, the game is pretty easy. 

Secondly, repetition. The game's style of level designs just doesn't change at all. All you get are new and stylish environments but that's it. The Bosses only have appearance variety. 

Thirdly, the story. The story is pretty decent but it has a poor execution since there are a lot of moments in the game where it feels as if the game is forcing you to face some kind of emotional impact, rather than proper build-ups. 

And that's pretty much all

The game has its pros: Like the character design, the Blood Codes and the Buffs you get with it but a lot of it is simply overshadowed over the main priorities of a Souls Like Game.

generally, i recommend this game. if you like the mechanics of soulslikes, the visual and storytelling styles of anime games and have previous experience with souls games, you will most likely get a lot of enjoyment out of it. still, the game is far from perfect.

[b]the good:[/b]

the game replaces traditional soulslike stats leveling with a "blood code" system. throughout the game you unlock different "blood codes", which you can equip on the fly. you always have one blood code equipped, which determines your stats. this makes it possible to completely change course with your build as you progress through the game and discover more mechanics, equipment, etc. and you don't have that classic soulslike fear of "am i leveling the right stats"

the story of the game, while very stereotypically anime, is overall genuinely intriguing and certain characters and scenes managed to have a genuine emotional impact on me. unlike the souls games, basically all plot is told to the player directly, but that can be a good thing depending on what type of storytelling you enjoy.

the combat feels great. it takes a while to get used to (though, to be fair, this might be more noticeable for me personally because i'm a weirdo who plays soulslikes on a keyboard) but once you do, both normal attacks as well as special abilities feel powerful and just good and fun to use

while i've played a few anime games before, i never really considered myself a big fan of the style. however, this game still had a lot of really beautiful scenery that strongly reminds me of the landscapes you'd see in a dark souls game. and a lot of times it does the "if you can see it, you can go to it" thing really well too.

[b]the bad:[/b]

platforming is abysmal. this is almost irrelevant, as theres barely any sections of the game that require it, but the parts that do have it are a pain. there is no horizontal velocity in the air, so as soon as you drop off a ledge, no matter how much momentum you have, you always drop straight down.

throughout most of the game the level design is great. however, there are individual sections that are just a pain to deal with. the minimap tracking your footsteps and showing you where youve already been helps out a lot, but certain areas hide away the spots where you can activate that minimap in the first place, contributing to their maze-like feel. in two areas in particular (the cathedral and the last area of the game) i wasted so much time just running around aimlessly because i got lost due to tons of path junctions and everything looking the same.

certain enemies are just not fun to beat. while there are some enemies who are simply challenging, which i can appreciate, some are flat out annoying. two examples that immediately come to mind are an enemy who can simply randomly decide to permanently reduce any incoming damage significantly, making it a slog to defeat even with strong weapons. the other example is a bossfight towards the end of the game, which seems like it's mainly up to RNG whether you win or not, due to one of the boss enemies having unrestricted access to AOE attacks no matter where you are in the arena. HOWEVER, note that these types of enemies are most certainly the exception, not the rule.

on a few occasions i've had somewhat major bugs occur. a random crash resetting some of my progress, an unresponsive menu forcing me to exit the game without saving, an item related to a side quest not spawning - nothing super terrible, but annoying to deal with.

[b]in short:[/b]

if you like anime games in terms of style - visually, audio-wise, story-wise - and you have enough experience with soulslike games to know you wont quit when a boss takes up to a few dozen tries: get the game, you'll enjoy it.

First things first: Get this game on sale. It goes on sale often enough. If you do get the game on sale, get the deluxe edition if its also on sale. It comes with some extra cosmetics, an extra blood code (see details below on what a blood code is), an extra partner, and all the DLC.

TL;DR: I give this game a 9-9.5 / 10. Great game.

This is one of my favorite games. I've played through it a total of 15 times so far, some of which were challenge runs like a level 1 run, a non-upgraded rusty pipe run, and a few no partner runs with different themed builds. I'll go over a some of different aspects of the game and describe what I liked/disliked.

Character creation:
Character creation is surprisingly really good. Starting out, it just seems like theres a bunch of presets for everything, but once you get into it, you can make some really cool characters. I've made Hatsune Miku, Ai Hoshino (from Oshi No Ko), Harley Quinn, Amy Rose, and some other characters.

Pros:
- Color choices are good
- Presets look alright
- Accessories are super fun to play around with to get something that looks perfect

Cons:
- Outfit choices are lacking


Story:
I don't have a whole lot to say about the story since I don't want to spoil it. Its a good story. Some parts had me teary-eyed. The characters are all really fun and have their own stories you can choose to look through when collecting certain items.

Pros:
- Good story
- Fun and likable characters with their own stories
- Theres some good character development throughout the story

Cons:
- Some predictable anime tropes
- You have to find the items related to characters' back stories, which means you can miss some stuff.


Gameplay:
The gameplay is very smooth in my opinion. Movement is smooth with the right builds, like dark souls but faster and more fluid. All the weapons are fun to play with and are all viable options. Every weapon is at least a decent choice. Gifts (spells) are plentiful and feel great to use in combat, especially since you have 8 slots for them.

Pros:
- Movement is great
- Lots of fun spells
- Weapons are great

Cons:
- The controls can take a bit to get used to coming from most other souls-like games


Character building:
The character building is great. You are able to change your build at any point in the game provided you have the correct weapons, blood veils, gifts, and blood codes. The blood codes act as a form of class with its own stat scaling, weight limits, and gifts. You can even unlock the gifts from a blood code to use with other blood codes, which can make for some really fun combinations.

Pros:
- Can change build at any time
- With the right combinations, you can use any gift with any blood code

Cons:
- Stat scaling is somewhat confusing. Gear scaling uses letters and gift scaling uses numbers
- Some buff gifts don't really tell the whole story when it comes to what the exact buffs are


Level design:
The levels are alright. For the most part, the areas are quite linear with how you navigate them. You only backtrack a few times in the game. In terms of the setting of the levels, they lack variety. For the most part you're either in a city or a cave, with some variations and exceptions. One of those exceptions (without spoiling it too much) will make you rage.

Pros:
- Can be easy to navigate for the most part.
- Linear

Cons:
- Lack of variety in setting
- Transitions between levels are obvious
- Enemy placement seems to be designed around having an NPC partner/co-op helper, making solo runs more difficult


Bosses:
Whats a good souls-like without good bosses? The bosses in this game definitely deliver. I had fun with every boss, even if I was upset at times (but who doesn't get upset at times with a souls-like?).

Pros:
- Range in difficulty
- The harder bosses feel great to defeat

Cons:
- The difficulty range isn't linear with the game's progression. Some bosses near the beginning of the game are harder than some bosses later
- Like the enemy placement, bosses seems to be designed around having an NPC partner/co-op helper, making solo runs more difficult

OVERALL SCORE: I give this game a 9-9.5 / 10.

As a fan of Soulsborne I recommend this game especially to those who have not played any Soulsborne games (Think Dark Souls, Bloodborne, Elden Ring, etc.)

Compared to those games, combat is easy and is designed around the use of a AI companion. For veterans of this kind of game, I do not recommend rolling solo as the game because the game becomes way too difficult since the enemies are aggressive and are designed around sharing agro.

Combat is fun and fast. The stats and equipment in the game are daunting at first, but after looking some stuff up you can eventually end up getting into it and making a build that fits your play style. 

The game also features one of the best character creators I have ever seen in a video game, evening rivalling Black Desert's character creator.

One thing that maybe a knock for some people is that it does lean heavily to the anime tropes with its characters, dialogue, exposition, and, of course, sexy looking characters with jiggle physics.

But if that last point doesn't phase you (or intrigues you) and you want your first foray into the Soulsborne genre, then I recommend this game. Veterans of the genre wont find much challenge in this game, but I still recommend if you want a more laid back Soulsborne game to play.

**Introduction:**

From the moment I delved into this game, it bore a striking resemblance to Devil May Cry, at least in terms of its premise. My initial motivation for acquiring it was the hope of capturing some of the essence of the Souls series, albeit in a more accessible form. While it doesn't serve as a mere clone, it incorporates fundamental elements reminiscent of the Souls games. Within its world, you'll discover a sanctuary filled with rooms, enigmatic characters seeking refuge, and the gradual unveiling of companions along your journey. Although the cutscenes may not align with my personal preferences, they remain an integral part of the experience.

**Key Points:**

**1. Souls-Like Essence with a Unique Flavor:** This game echoes the essence of the Souls series while infusing its own distinctive character. It offers a familiar sense of exploration, sheltering characters, and the discovery of companions, akin to the Souls games. However, it stands as a unique entity rather than a mere replication.

**2. Cooperative Gameplay Dynamics:** The inclusion of an AI companion adds an intriguing dimension to gameplay. This companion proves invaluable when facing hordes of foes and hastening mission completion.

**3. Genshin Impact Influence with Drawbacks:** Character-wise, the game draws parallels with Genshin Impact. Unfortunately, it occasionally accentuates exaggerated female body proportions, which may prove off-putting for some players.

**4. Value for Money:** Acquired during a sale, this game doesn't feel like a financial misstep. Most levels or chapters feature narrow, maze-like pathways where death lurks at every turn. Persistence is key, as you'll find yourself retracing your steps repeatedly to clear zones and bypass obstructions.

**Conclusion:**

In conclusion, this game intertwines familiar Souls-like elements with its own unique identity, offering an engaging and accessible experience. While it may bear a resemblance to Devil May Cry in its premise, it possesses its own distinct charm. The inclusion of an AI companion enhances the cooperative dynamics of gameplay, but the character design, reminiscent of Genshin Impact with exaggerated proportions, may not appeal to everyone. Acquired during a sale, this title offers value for your investment, but be prepared for labyrinthine level design and a requirement for a good sense of direction to navigate successfully.

Lets start with the negative, cause there isnt much:
The 3 DLCs are terribly handled and basically just reused bosses. One boss per DLC. For 9,99€ per. Worst DLCs ive ever seen.
The game itself can be very complicated to understand with all the Codes you can get and use, which are basically the stats of this game which govern what builds and weapons you can use, and the map layout is sometimes extremly confusing.
The tits. I know im mainly alone with this one, but i just dont like oversexualized animes and games. Which almost was a reason for me to not get it... but im glad i did, because luckily thats really just superficial fanservice and not a topic in the game. But yeah, most men would count this as a positive.

Ye thats about it, now for the positives:
First of all, the best thing about this entire game is the soundtrack. Its one of the best OSTs of any game ever, and i say that as someone who loves From Soft OSTs like Bloodborne, which imo is still the best one ever made, but the one of this game actually comes kinda close, which is ridiculous. Rarely ive cried harder to a song then to "Memory of the Lost" or "Requiem". But most of the songs arent sad, but upbeat, orchestral and epic. And almost every single one is an absolute banger.
Now for the game itself, its all in all just great. The combat isnt Dark Souls level, but closer to it then most souls-likes, its pretty crisp, accurate and fun. Not always ofc, but most times. The weapons are very fun too, there are just enough diffrent ones to have a big enough arsenal to choose from, but not too many to get overwhelmed, and not many same-y ones.
The worldbuilding is fantastic. I would not have expected that from this game. Some locations have obvious references to other games (Anor Londo, if you know you know), but thats fine, theyre not copies or anything. And while some maps can look kinda repetetive after a while, youre probably not long enough in one level to notice too much. Its varied enough to not immidiatley jump out.
And the story... is a bit complicated at first, and you have to search for it, but its actually so darn good... most animes ive seen dont compare. It gets better and better the deeper you dive into it, i can only recommend watching videos about it too to understand more. Not many games made me actually cry, and the OST didnt help either... to make me stop crying that is.

I honestly can say, even if you dont like anime, oversexualized characters, ridiculously big weapons etc., if you like an emotional story, fun combat, great visuals and songs, try it. Especially if you like the God Eater Series, from which this is kind of a spinoff i think? I heard its at least in the same universe.
Right now its -80% off for 9,99€, theres no excuse to not get it right now. But yeah, skip the DLCs. c:

Enjoyable 10/10 - May be biased for RPGs in general, but this has been a joy so far, exhilarating and heart-racing combat. 

Graphics: 7/10
Very good, quite detailed. Not too heavy-load but not too light, perfect for mid-at-best PCs.

Gameplay: 9/10
The blood code and gifts system can be overwhelming at first, but once you spend enough time reading and playing through you can easily get the hang of it. The weapon designs are really good, each and every weapon is unique, with different types of attacks, and yes, each weapon, even the same type of weapons have different attack types. The weapons, they feel solid. You can really feel the heavy hits you're dealing, as well as the hits you take, and DAMN do they hurt. The blocking and parry mechanic can be forgettable sometimes, as you only really dodge most of the time, but taking your time to learn how to use them in the correct situations can give you the edge you need in an important boss fight.

Character Customization 8/10:
Short answer: Yes. 
Long answer: There's A LOT of customization options, and the possibilities are limitless, from hair, eyes (heck, even the pupils), face shape, to your clothes and its colors, and much more. You can spend an entire day customizing your character and you wouldn't even be halfway done (that is, if you care as much as I do about how your character looks). 
Side note: booba size slider 10/10

Story: 9/10
The story is very good, the world-building is phenomenal, and the areas and their backstories are well-made. What I like the most are each character's stories. The game shows you their memories and backstories when you receive their powers/blood codes, and damn they are well-executed. They tell you the story in a way you just can't skip it, they keep it interesting, and they really make you care for the character, no matter how little they matter to the main story (which is rare, most of them have important roles in the story, which I also really like).

Boss Fights/Fights in general: 1000/10
I can't stress enough how much I've had fun just pushing through bosses and fights no matter how much I die, it doesn't even make me mad. You can't be too straightforward in fights because there are things you need to prepare before going in, like choosing the correct skillset, elements, and status effects to give you an advantage, which I really like. Each time you try to fight the bosses you learn something new about the fight, giving you more information and helps you prepare for your next tries. For Small mob/Mini Boss fights, you can't let yourself get caught lacking, because no matter how weak they look, they still pack a punch. I can't count how many times I almost died underestimating mobs and just button mashing them. You have to think of how you're entering a fight, no matter what. Because once you get overwhelmed by multiple mobs, there is no escape, you run out of stamina, get cornered, and get beaten to death. As I've mentioned before, the most important part of the game is preparation, and it's the part I love the most.

Overall: 9/10

This game is a big reason why a simple "yes" or "no" isn't enough for recommendation. I mean, if you like to make anime characters, the character creator alone is worth the asking price. The game itself is rather complicated. It has a number of wonderful ideas. The blood code system needs to be iterated on. There is definitely a phenomenal game that uses this sort of class/stat change on sight mechanic. Giving NPC helpers as difficulty adjusters was also a great idea. The issue is in the execution. For example: healing. Healing in this game comes from one of three sources: regen items, other player's abilities, and self abilities. The abilities either can only heal others directly, or require conditions to work. They tend to also come mid to late game. This means that for a lot of the game, you'll be relying on the regen items. They are slow to use, and do not heal very much. This is a necessity. If they were better, having an npc partner would make the game trivial. However, it makes solo play incredibly frustrating. Getting off a heal is difficult and not very rewarding. Generally, it involves breaking the flow of combat to run away and heal at a distance. So, as long as you are a pro gamer and are doing well, the game's healing system doesn't get in the way of the action. If you get hit it quickly spirals the fight. There are a million little knock on effects like this that plague the game. Ideas that individually make sense, but get very draining very quickly in the actual game. From deceptively wide sweeping attacks to janky backstabs, everything feels uncertain in a way that doesn't gel with this style of game. That said, there are large swathes of the game where these issues die down some, and we can see what Code Vein was attempting. It can get REALLY good at some points. Typically, the knight enemies are interesting and enjoyable. There are whole levels where they shun those awful bug enemies out of the way and just let you have fun for a bit. Honestly, this whole game feels like a rough draft. While I'm only lukewarm on Code Vein itself, I am very intrigued for a sequel. If you like Souls games, I can't promise this one will enamor you, but you'll at least get something out of it.

Game play 7/10
Lore 8/10

Just a quick explanation of why I give the rating for this game play and lore:

I tried only two weapon style, Castor and Two handed Sword melee. Castor is a fun concept but the fact that many other better spell is lock too far back into the game, another issue I have with Castor is the ichor cost to even maintain this class. All I want is, if I want to play Castor, I want to play it fully without all the extra nuance. The nuance which is the bloody annoying drain attack to increase the threshold, and the best part is even with maxing the full threshold, your early spell may not even be enough to finish off a boss. Bayonet is also a terrible weapon itself, when talking about the topic of ichor. The shots can easily block by end game enemy and not only it doesn't deal a ton of damage, it cost ichor which is a shitty resource to maintain. Unlike in dark souls 3 where you can refill your mana with a REFILLABLE flask. 

But why I still give the gameplay 8/10? That is because I managed to clear the game with only a single Zweihander, any souls game where you can just use one big man weapon and beat everything already deserve a 6/10 as base even if everything else sucks. The extra two point also come from the flexibility in swapping passive skill and active skill which give more fun in the combat, along with the replayability that comes with it as you can choose to play with the same difficulty or enhanced difficulty.

As for the lore, I really like the story of the game, it is very simple to understand and I don't need to head on to YouTube to watch 50 minute worth of lore because I don't bother to read the description. I also like the way they implemented the lore, by rewarding the player with parts which can allow you to unlock better gifts after you finish reading memory. You can also skip all of it if you are replaying the game, so that's another +1 in my dictionary.

Overall rating for this game combine, 7.5/10. Many things that can be improved and some that should stay for the future code vein title game. Definitely worth your time and perhaps on a discounted price.

The game is decent but has a hard time standing out from other JRPG. What you'd expect in a JRPG honestly with most of the core elements.

------
Story is alright - a little weird in the beginning. (I won't spoil it)
Some things go unexplained and you have to do your homework on your own to figure out the story than have it shown in-game. Half way through it gets better, but despite it does the plot is predictable where we are going/headed.

------
Environments are great, graphics are good as well, I like the options we have for the characters we make in this game.

------
The difficulty - is nowhere near Dark Souls - I know this because Dark souls is my top 3 most played game on Steam. Most of the bosses in this game I beat on the first or 2nd attempt without knowing what to do.
(At the time of this message, Dark souls is my top 3 most played game over hundreds of hours)

------
The gameplay is alright, the weapon animations are a joke however - all the weapons attack/feel the same you can tell this game was heavily on a budget/rushed for some material.

These are the same publishers who have the game Dark souls under them.
(I even know this because I know some of the tools that was used to make this game.)

------

The content for this game is decent, despite the flaws and obvious traits there. You can sink a lot of hours into it due to the grind of the weapons and searching the environments for clues/areas where to go towards next.

------

Multiplayer is dead for this game - I tried searching every area until I beat the entire game and DLC for open search lobbies or making my own several times before progressing. Nonetheless people can co-op with you but it can only be 1 person to aid on your journey.

------

The game overall is okay, I wouldn't say honestly it is better than other JRPGs out there already, but honestly it has a great concept - but that great concept I tried digging in the gameplay or story - was implemented mediocre making the game yearning for more content/DLC or something more to happen at the end result of it.

Give it a good end-game/extra bosses or more flashbacks, and touching up on some untold parts of the story, and I'll call the game good after that - it never will happen but it is only inches away from becoming something unique.

On the surface it's fine but there's a lot of problems with the game. It tries to be a Souls-like by lacks the tight controls or interesting area design.

A lot of areas feel like interlacing corridors (with the Cathedral being the best example) that feel so artificial and forced. 

Perhaps the best example of the game design issue comes from one of the later bosses. It's a double-boss, clearly inspired by Orstein and Smough from Dark Souls. But in DS the boss fight is very well designed - it teaches the player to handle "gankers" by teaching you the tricks to dealing with two opponents at once, you can use the pillars to block their charges and you can even get a reliable summon for the fight.

Code Vein's version of the fight is worse is every way. The boss's have attacks that hardly telegraph, manipulating the camera to see both at once is almost impossible (meaning the AOEs they sprout underneath you have almost no warning) and the pillars only block your movement and nothing else - they can charge through it and fire their ranged attacks too. 

This kind of issue is rampant in the game - a lot of design choices feel like they're only there because Dark Souls did it, but missing the subtleties that made those elements work in DS. 

When it tries to be it's own thing it seems to do a lot better. Using the vestiges to retell other characters histories was a nice touch, the story has some potential and the character customisation is amazing. It's a shame it's just bogged down by too much garbage outside that.

The combat really is the only major thing the game has going for it but it does that to such a fun degree that it's worth sinking your time into. All and all I'd give it a solid 7.5/10

Very cool aesthetic. Very hard for reasons it shouldn't be. In FromSoftware games, enemies are deliberate and don't suddenly spawn behind you. For whatever reason, that's the hardest part of this game. Boss battles are fun, but at times have mechanics that are simply tedious (like poison debuff @ 2nd major boss.) Controls feel clunky as there's no way to cancel any animation once it's begun, a major setback for gameplay. Enemies can have combos that last 7-8 hits, and when you're fighting one in front of you, 3 more spawn out of nowhere with no warning directly behind you and unleash said minute long combos, making the game more frustrating than it has to be. Still recommended, but get it on sale.

I was feeling certain that I would dislike this game but I ended up falling in love

It's sort of just an anime Dark Souls. I think the thing I like most about this game is that levelling up is just a flat thing for your character instead of different stats like in Dark Souls, this gives total freedom to experiment with whatever you want, you can be a pure dark caster and then swap to a strength build very quickly, just have to change your blood code and veil (single armour piece) and weapon

There's a fun character customiser, though I wish there were more clothing options, I like making NPCs and using their weapon and blood code

You also have an npc ally for the entire game, and they are actually somewhat competent. You can also choose who to take depending on your playstyle or situation, though Yamuko is the best <3

I like this game a lot, but if you're looking for a challenge you might have to make it artificially (IMO, skill varies)
