69 (nice) hours in with 100% completion on every area while still leveling up my characters for ng+, this is my review for code vein: deluxe edition.

first of all, its a souls-like but anime. It certainly have some dark soulsy-vibe to it. I have a lot of fun playing it even after beating the game, mainly because of its "endgame" system that the game have, more on that later. So, what';s the positive and negative side about this game?

Pros:
1) The fighting felt good. Dodging and attacking is smooth making it easier to survive. The animation of each attack is polished as well, and doesn't feel clunky at all.
2) The map design is pretty good. Although it can get bland especially how some areas looks and feel the same, just a ruined city that you happened to be stuck in, so it can get pretty bland. However, it does have some maps that is different from the rest and i'll give a pass for that.
3) The bosses are great with decent telegraphed attack. They can be challenging at times but it doesn't feel unfair until you fight those same bosses without companion. With companion, its like riding a bike. Without companion, its like riding the same bike while a volcano just erupted and you have to dodge its meteor while going down a ramp with 1000 monsters trying to kill you. it was fun.
4) Endgame. While exploring the game, you may find maps from npc questline or scattered all around the world. This is basically dungeons with mini-boss and the main boss, with the main boss being one of the boss you will encounter in the main story. Since those bosses respawn infinitely after you rests at mistle (bonfire), you can test your skill against these bosses. These dungeons will also conatin items and other useful stuff you can get, as well as providing a good haze farm should you need one.


cons:
1) enemy variety is lacking. You can fight one enemy at the start of the game only to find the exact same enemy with more health in the area just before the final boss. A lot of enemies that appear in previous area will appear in the next one, maybe with different abilities and whatnot (example: cathedral knights can teleport while the knights in government outskirst cant BUT they will buff their weapon then hit like a f-ing tank.
2) Maps design. Once again, some maps are great. Unfortunately, it doesn't translate to other maps making it feel very similar in terms of looks (just look at the 2nd area at the start of the game and 2nd area before the final boss. they look and feel the same)
3) Memory. Memory is the way the game tell you about your companion/NPC past. Although it was a unique way to re-tell the event of the past, it can get extremely repetitive as you keep finding vestiges for different NPCs and Companions. It was unique and fun for the first few but quickly become stagnant as you required to do this for one of the endings.

All in all, it was really good despite all the cons i just mentioned, and i found it enjoyable enough that im willing to replay the game for the other endings, If you're a fan of souls-like and would like o play something that can be challenging but still provide some fun with decent story on top of it, then this one is for you.

It's anime Dark Souls.
So if you like both anime and Souls-like games then check it out, download the demo and give it a go. Definitely worth getting during a sale.

If you hate anime, then you better skip this. The story is a overly melodramatic, the character and enemy designs look like they were made by horny teenagers. If this bothers you then you won't have a good time. On the other hand there's no romance, no sex scenes, so if that is what you're looking for, again probably not your thing.

The game differs from Dark Souls in that you can have a partner for the fights. The partner is competent but won't do everything for you. So you still have to master the various gameplay mechanics, simple buttonmashing won't get you through the entire game. The demo has a section where you must fight alone, this will not happen in the main game. However you can choose to fight alone if the game is too easy with a partner.

You gain XP from killing enemies, this can be used to 
1: level up 
2: buy gear (I almost never did, mostly everything you need is just drops)
3: upgrade gear (necessary)
4: unlock class abilities.
Class abilities have two tier unlock, one to use the skill on that class and one to use it on any class. The second requires defeating enemies while that skill is on your toolbar (you don't even have to use the skill). However if you level up too fast then the game won't let you unlock the skill trough gameplay, you have to use items and XP and the items (various Awake upgrades) are somewhat random drops. So it makes sense to level up slowly, once you unlock a new class, grind out the skills in the Depths (smaller maps unrelated to the main story) and then continue. 

When you die then you lose the XP (items and gear luckily remains). XP can be regained if you do a successful corpse run. You might get unlucky and die again before reaching where you died the first time tho. But this is no reason to rage quit at that point. The XP you get grows exponentially over the course of the game. So it might have taken hours to get 100k XP at the beginning of game but at the end of the game it's like 6 enemies within 1 minute of gameplay. So even losing million XP is not that big of a deal (happened to me a couple of times), you will get tons more.

Overall I liked this game, I hope there will be a sequel.

CODE VEIN is a game that I enjoyed playing a lot. It is a game that combines the elements of dark fantasy, anime, and souls-like genres.

CODE VEIN has an engaging and intriguing story that follows the journey of the player and their companions as they explore the ruins of Vein, fighting against the Lost and searching for their memories. It has multiple endings that depend on the player's choices and actions throughout the game. But, honestly, CODE VEIN also has some cliché and cheesy dialogue, some inconsistent and rushed pacing, and some lackluster and disappointing endings that can diminish the impact of the story.

This game has an exciting and fun combat system that allows the player to use various weapons, skills, and blood veils to fight against different enemies and bosses. The game also has a co-op multiplayer mode that allows the player to team up with an AI partner or a friend online to tackle the challenges together. However, CODE VEIN also has some repetitive and bland level design, some annoying and unfair enemies, and some confusing and vague mechanics that can frustrate the player.

Surprisingly, CODE VEIN has a fantastic and varied soundtrack that enhances the mood and tone of each scene. This game has a deep and customizable character creation that allows the player to create their own Revenant and express their personality and style.

Overall, CODE VEIN is a great game that I would recommend to anyone who likes action RPGs, anime, or vampires. It has a lot of potential and charm.
The game of all time

This game has some things to like and dislike about it. The general feeling is "I wish I liked this more". I'll point out some things I felt or noticed while playing it

The character customization is really incredible, but clothing and armor feels very limited. There's very few types of both and you can't really mish mash things to create some unique fashion souls

When it comes to character building, for some reason some souls-likes do this thing where strength builds are absolutely busted, there's a specific build that is hardly playable (in this game it's bayonets) and everything else is mid. The game's difficulty (and thus enjoyability) varies way too much depending on what weapon type you want to use

There are some maps that feel like a drag to explore or even just get by. Also, if you want to play the whole game in co-op with someone you'll have to play every map twice, it really is like dark souls huh. I really like the way coop plays but this alone makes it unenjoyable. Also, co-oping with NPCs shares the same problem with the builds, as there are some NPCs that are significantly stronger than others (Yakumo) 

As for the story, I like it. I don't think it's the game's main selling point but it's fine

In the end I think it's a good game to experience if you like dark souls and anime. I don't regret buying and playing it but the fact that it made me think about regretting it or not says something. I would advise against buying it if you want to do a co-op playthrough with someone unless you and your partner can enjoy each other's company without needing to do something together so the game just becomes a background for you. If you two need to feel actually engaged in something together to have fun it'll be fun and games for like 10 hours until you realize that you'll have to play Cathedral of the Sacred Blood twice

tl;dr Mixed feelings. Some builds can feel severely underpowered and there are huge maze-ish maps, but it can surely be fun and cool at moments. Be careful if you're buying it for the coop

One of the first souls-like games i've ever played. And even tho this game has it's weak moments, the story 
and gameplay was truly amazing. 

Pros:
-Shit ton of customization options, from weapons, classes and abilities, blood veils to suprisingly good character creator,
-Game encourages trying out new classes and changeing gear and playstyles, especially that you can change stuff on the go.
-Really rewarding gameplay, there's high-risk dodgeroll melee backstabs, ranged combat with damaged dealing spells and heavy hitting hammers etc. 
-Coop partner on one hand probably reduces the difficulty but at the same time opens a lot of paths for builds and the game can allow itself to have more complex encounters since (if you didn't let your partner die), you should have somebody there to help you out if you get overwhelmed to save you from getting one shotted or take one enemies aggro,
-Story is fantastic, didn't expect much from a souls-like, but man it was good, the memories you collect create really cool way to tell a story of different characters. 
-the level design is decent,
-Io's boobs,


Cons: 
-Level desing is sometimes confusing, it's not outright bad, the game has a lot of amazing looking places but there's some backtracking and again, confusion on some maps

Again, not much experience in souls-likes, but i thought the game was really great.

i absolutely fucking LOVE this game. The story is top-tier, the only one that's managed to make me genuinely sob in years. it's Souls-like combat but better, because there's a mechanic called Ichor, which allows you to use your buffs and big boy moves and spells and all that cool shit. The environments are perfect, ranging from a ruined city, to a giant cathedral, to a sunken city, to a desert. The characters actually feel like people, and the antagonists feel like people with their own motives as well. the bosses are on par (except the butterfly, fuck the butterfly). also, the character creator is THE BEST CHARACTER CREATOR IN ANY GAME EVER MADE EVER AND I WILL BET MONEY ON THAT. also instead of having boring skill specs, you get things called blood codes, blood codes with their own predetermined stats, like one having A+ in strength and less in other areas, stuff like that. each blood code has their own story about the owner of the blood code, and each one has their own unique abilities and skills, which allows for endless build combinations. the armor also different from other souls-likes, because there are 4 categories: Ogre (fast and dexeterity focused typically), hounds which are more for strength orientated and have higher defense, Spine (or something i forgot i don't use it) which aren't all that great, and thorn, which are mainly intelligence and willpower focused. each time of armor has a different parry window, with the fastest being ogre and the slowest being thorn. each time you parry you can do a drain attack, which gives you a ton of ichor and increases your maximum ichor limit until you touch a mistle (bonfire or grace basically)

Great Animu Souls-like, more on the anime side than the souls-like part. The combat is rather easy with companions and can get a bit more challenging by going "solo". Leveling up is straight forward, you level up without assigning stats. When appliyin a class to the level, the stats are "calculated" so the player has no need to go around minmaxing stats, or making useless builds that cannot be reverted.
The story is par for the course if you played god eater, and the exposition via memory shards is cool.

HONEST REVIEW

At first, it was good, and I was having fun until I reached the first boss. Then it became apparent how unpolished this game is, which is why I can't recommend it to anyone. On the bright side, I did appreciate the extensive character customization, classes, and skill options, which added a bit of enjoyment to the experience. However, I must admit that most of the time, they felt like nothing more than numbers or appearance customization, lacking depth and substance.

Also, I want to apologize to my friend Sato, whom I pulled into this game. I hope he understands that my intention was to share the experience, even though the game fell short of our expectations.

Good looking game with incredible and impressive character customization, but the rest of the game is very poorly executed and severely lacking. Considering how old this game is now, it's ridiculous how buggy and unresponsive it is. The framerate and graphical performance is great (like you'd expect from an Unreal engine game), but the input lag is enormous and purely caused by incompetent design.

I'm not a huge fan of the "50 different classes in 1 character" concept, but it's to be expected since it's quite common in Asian game design. However, since you can mix abilities from the different classes, as they largely only depend on what weapon you use, the whole class idea goes out the window and just becomes a messy way to unlock new abilities. Many other games do this so much better.

During the combat, the main part of the game, there's a massive lag before it begins to play the animation for whatever you press, and while each animation plays it completely ignores all input. This means you very easily get mauled because you're stuck in an animation with no way to defend yourself, and constantly have to consider how long each animation takes when attacking enemies. This is an archaic combat design that does not belong in a modern game. And it does not help that the camera frequently gets shoved into your characters head, so you lose all peripheral vision and have no idea what's happening while you're stabbed in the back by NPCs that are outside the screen. 

My other major complaint is the awful menu layout and the NPCs that will not shut up. When talking to the vendors you first have to wait for them to complete their pointless spiels before the menu opens, which wastes time, since they never have anything relevant to say. 

I did however give up trying to get something out of this game because it keeps locking up when talking to NPCs, mostly during the "receive gift" menu, but I also had it happen during the normal trade menu. And with the non-existent save system it just becomes annoying having to go through the slow animations and pointless conversations repeatedly, just because no one's bothered to bugfix the damn game since it was released on PC 5 years ago

Even the hardest of bosses that online forums love to say is so cheap and hard, all have cheese strats, and dodging is very very lenient (although parrying is kind of bonkers weird sometimes). Just to caution everyone though, it's only "fair" and "easy enough" if you play with companions. The rest of the game is actually smooth sailing once you get the hang of it

At first I thought that Code Vein would be a promising title, especially after knowing that its a combination of two of my favorite genres. "Souls - Like/Games " and " Anime ". It also helped the fact that I heard tons and tons of people praising this game and saying that it was a "Really good game".....That was.....until I got to the 3rd boss, that I realized.....that this game was a try-hard.....and SOULESS carbon copy of a masterpiece known as "Dark Souls" and it lacked the creative mind to not only tell a snooooooze-fest of a so called "story",but also be lazy enough to call this game "Difficult" when the game is built around enemy ganks and enemy spam. 

First, lets get into the positives....

1. Customization - The customization of your main character is amazing and addictive. From so many accessories and colors to choose from, you could literally spend your time and your money in a better way by just making your character in the customization menu for HOURS on end than to be playing this Hit or miss game.

2. Builds - The builds on the other hand, offer a breathe of fresh air from the typical soul series where you have to commit to only ONE build. Instead what you have in Code Vein are these things called " Blood Codes " which are pretty much presets of actual builds like (Tanks, Int, Magic, Drain, Skills, Dex, Range etc.).

Now back to the Negatives that lowered this games potential and made this game a soon to forget experience and an instant uninstall from my Library.

1. Combat - By far the most crucial trait to have in a " Souls - Like " game is the combat. Without good combat, the game is gonna be very lacking and very stale....and it was just that...lacking and stale....While the blood codes did give you diversity in builds, it still didn't matter because the combat was not only clunky, slow, and stupid (Your character hits in the direction it faces + the swipes or overheads are random) , but it also lacked the fluidity and flexibility thanks to the way this game was built. As well as the enemies that didn't make it ANY BETTER. Its as if the devs couldn't decide to either scrap the combat or scrap the enemies, so instead they decided to make an AI system that could solve both problems at once.

2. Difficulty + A.I - Which leads to my next point, the A.I. The A.I is not only OP in the sense that.....idk.... it can dish out insane dmg, tank insane dmg, and also revive you...Multiple times....But is also the MAIN mechanic in which this game is built around. So much so that if you want to even dream of a "challenge". Removing the A.I will literally not make the game harder but extremely BRUTAL. Almost as if you are doing demon bell + Kuros charm or doing a no armor hollow run, because Code Vein likes to give you a "challenge" through enemy spams, enemy ganks, and mistles (bonfires) that are a mile away from each other....so by the time you are at the other mistle. You have either died a million times and finally made it, or you are a PIXEL of health away from seeing death and starting ALL OVER.

3. Bosses - A hero is as good as the villain right? Well yea, but in code vein the V in Villain stands for absolute VIRGINS. Cause either a.) My A.I destroys the Boss b.) The Bosses projectile spams and runs like a pu**y so much that its easy to tell the patterns it has or c.) both....Regardless the bosses are both forgettable and laughable and arent even a threat until you FINALLY reach near end game. But even so my death counter didn't reach higher than 10 on all bosses....and this is a "Souls - Like " in 2019.....

4. Story - At first when I saw Io's stunning "personality" and her habit of doing long stares into nothingness while the camera focused on her "personality" I thought that this game was gonna be a fun "self - aware " anime game or at least a decent anime game like "MGR". (IK not anime like but at least self - aware).....spoiler alert...it wasn't. It was your generic " lets all be friends + we can do it " type story, with cut-scenes and exposition dumps sh*tted all over the place. Like I kid you not, by the time I was on the 4th out of like 15 levels I was already skipping cut - scenes and major plot lines because it had no tension or no risk....it was a by the numbers story with zero progression. EVEN in character development, if any, the only character(s) that had a development was Jack, Yakumo and Io....everyone else had one bad obstacle and then was never ever seen/relevant ever again.

5. Map Design - People like to applaud and give awards to the artists and the writers for characters and story, but also forget the people that focus on environment and map/level design. This too plays an important role in almost any game. Because if the map and/or environment is memorable or awesome. People will have more of a reason to explore much much longer. Unfortunately for those who want to find good reasons to play Code Vein. The only thing you want to find in every level is just the EXIT, but even then..... good luck in finding that sh*t as well because in almost every map the game penalizes you in some way. Whether it be in the bad case of absolute BOREDOM from seeing, the most bland and dull level design ever, Fighting groups of enemy ganks and spam in every section you go because THATS the "difficulty" of Code Vein and/or having your HP/Time/Ichor drained from your character. Because level Design.

6. DLC - Apparently there's DLC for this game, but who cares? When you have to pay 3 installments of 15$ of DLC of re-skins of character skins, bosses, enemies and Blood codes. Especially when you realize all the "DLC" is short and locked in an area called the "Depths" which is short mode in the game where you can collect gear and spend a bare maximum of an hour. I never played it DLC to be fair but I dont have to when ALL the DLC is getting bad rep everywhere and has mostly negative reviews.

Overall.....people can tell you that Code Vein is a "good game with friends"....but isnt every game w/ friends? I mean...friends make EVERYTHING fun, and even in the MOST boring and DIRE situations can friends turn something boring and bad into something great and fun. But when you gotta choose a game to spend time on by YOURSELF, Code Vein reaaaaaally isnt it. Even in the "Souls - Like" Genre, Code Vein never gives you that DESIRE to explore hidden areas and discover secrets that tell a deeper story...like in Dark Souls. Neeeeeever gives you that THRILL in a fight when fighting multiple enemies like in Nioh. Neeeeeever has that TENSION, that each and every boss has in Sekiro where the stakes and fear were high. Neeeeeever has that HYPE like Bloodbourne has when it comes to finishing the game or Neeeeeever had the AUDIENCE that even encouraged people stick around to play the sequel, like in Fallen Order. In the end, if you somehow want something fun. Buy a better game or wait for this game to be on sale if you want this game down bad. If you want an intro to " Soul-likes" you can try out other games that are fun like " SIfu ", " Fallen Order ", or even " Nioh " tbh. and if you still enjoyed this game......more power to you. But this game wasn't anything special. Aside from the fact that it's a " Anime Souls - Like " that tried to be the next " Dark Souls ". Only to fall flat on its face.....

I've played this for around 70 hours and can honestly say the only part I like about this game is the character creator. The story is totally uninteresting, I care for none of these characters or their problems. It doesn't matter at all in the grand scheme of things as the world is normal outside of this "bubble". The locations all suck. the finer build mechanics don't make a whole lot of sense as there's basically 2 really good blood veils and the rest are similar stats.

I find the combat totally unenjoyable, which was the one thing that could have made it tolerable, but there's too much I hate about it. Extremely aggressive enemy scaling makes leveling up pointless against any boss. Hitboxes are enormous, you can dodge roll behind an enemy thrusting a spear forwards and still take the damage from it. I don't even have anything to compare it to, this is the worst case of this I've ever seen. Enemies are way too player biased-meaning I can just run around the boss stage while the AI partner eats at least half of their HP bar. In the event you find yourself at low health, the AI aggro becomes impossible to shake. Coolest thing combat had to offer was the blood veil backstab animations.

Character creator is pretty good but there aren't enough outfit options and the ones that are there all suck, get rid of the high heeled boots and shoes, blood veils should either be colorable or able to be hidden and your anime game is also lacking the keystone animal ears and fangs. Boy what is wrong with you? I bet you thought I wouldn't catch on to you being too lazy to do facial animations either. The Tokyo Ghoul mask thing wasn't an accident (they're butt ugly anyways, just like that stupid slav hat Mia wears). I hate the aesthetic this game has but if they were going for an anime Dark Souls it's not that out of place.

I currently have no desire to replay it, and feel no interest for a sequel. Go ahead and let it die. The only things that kept me playing this are the waifu creator (which is missing a lot of content as it is) and the mods others were so kind to provide. Frankly, I'd rather have God Eater 4 with this game engine under it.

tl;dr: A far-from-perfect title which is a familiarity in terms of gameplay while attempting to change up the formula to mixed results. While having plenty of missteps, the game is worth you're time. But, wait for a sale, as full price really starts to exemplify all of the faults.

Code Vein is a title I've had my eyes on for some time now. I'm a fan of the Souls series and seeing the press around this game and the gameplay being shown off, I was rather intrigued. Though, there were plenty of other titles coming out and, having a backlog already to get through, this one slipped through the cracks. In addition, seeing some negative reviews from people I follow made me not-too-eager to check it out. With that said, I purchased it finally on sale have finally played through it.

For one, the story I felt was a mixed bag. I found some elements of the writing to be quite nice. There were several, simple touches that were done which helped to empathize with your party members along the way. You'll also find items which let you see memories of other characters, whether your party members or people who are mentioned in the story, and it shows where they were prior to their current predicament. While I found these to be a mixed bag, sometimes repeating oneself, overall, I think it did the job nicely. However, as I kept playing, I found the story to be losing track of itself a bit and had hoped they would rein in things a bit, but alas.

The visuals were a bit all over. There were moments which I found the place I was to be quite nice visually. The character designs were alright for the most part, but definitely made me think 'this game is what people joke when saying generic anime designs'. With that said, there was plenty of clipping I found in the game. And as for the character models, I found them to look a bit like plastic. It wasn't all the time, but for some moments, it took me out of the scene for a moment.

The music is nice overall. There isn't all too much to say about it in this section. I found the boss music to be enjoyable, but maybe wish it was a bit more varied. But, good throughout my playthrough.

Now gameplay is a bit more complex for me. Code Vein's formula has been seen before in the Souls games and has been tweaked and varied for quite a while now. The core of what is there is solid enough, but I found the additions that they tried to add not to add up in my playthrough. It's hard to ignore, but I found myself not using everything new the game gave me. For example, during your attack, you can follow-up with your arm which can add +1 to your ichor stock. Also, you can charge it up and, if it hits, adds +2 to it. However, at no point did I find this useful in the slightest as it leaves you quite vulnerable. Ichor is important for abilities you gain throughout your journey, but melee attacking builds it back up so it isn't too big a deal to do this unique attack to build more.

While I did say the core was solid enough, there are hiccups. For one, back attacks are terrible finicky. Sometimes the game would read it correctly, sometimes I would be on their side and get it, or in front even. But nearly 50% of the time, I would get a regular attack, which is fine enough, but isn't what I would be going for. The hit reading can be off and make it hard to see what your range is exactly and, at times, taking damage without realizing it. And lastly, maybe one of the biggest issues: level design. While not everything needs to flow well together, doing so really helps connect me to the world, make me smile as I know where I am. Seeing things become more hot as I approach a fire level, or doing something to help bridge areas together. Code Vein, sadly, uses long connecting hallways to connect areas together. And, even with these, the shifts between areas can be stark and take you out of the experience you're playing in.

Despite all of these critiques, I found myself enjoying Code Vein. The mechanics and writing were good enough to keep me engaged all the while. The music was charming as well, and my curiosity about this game helped me through and I found myself enjoying my time quite a bit. But, the elephant-in-the-room for me is the price. At $60, I cannot recommend this game. At that price, all the flaws I've mentioned, and maybe even more which you may have, really are shown off all-the-more.

However, as I did mine, I still do recommend this game. But pick it up on a sale, if you can. I do believe this to be an interesting title and one which held my interest until the end. While flawed, Code Vein is able to still capture you and take you along on your journey together.

Code Vein offers a fresh interpretation of the Dark Souls formula, executed brilliantly. The gameplay mechanics are highly enjoyable, immersing players in thrilling combat experiences. Although the music falls somewhere in the middle, it may leave some feeling slightly let down. Nevertheless, the boss fights are exceptional, demonstrating meticulous design and strategic challenges. It would have been even more satisfying if my character had engaged in the dialogues, but I understand the developers' intent to enhance player immersion in the story. If you're in search of another Souls-like adventure to embark upon, Code Vein is undoubtedly worth a shot—prepare to be captivated and not let down.

Really great game for people who loves min-maxing build. Even for me, who is not that into min maxing/trying new build.

This game offers you a very easy way to change your build. You can even change it on the fly. Fighting a group of enemies as a mage, and the fighting the boss the next minute as a tank? Maybe it's because you can only partner up with one teammmate at a time and there isn't warm sidequest/interaction with them. But the setting and genre of the game might not be fit to cater to it. Overall the game has really great rpg aspect with satisfying action combat. So go for it if you like that.

Gotta do a pro and con review here:

The good stuff-
1. Surprisingly decent writing for once, at least it's not AWFUL, plus the vestige memory things are neat.
2. Don't really hate any specific character, which is surprising for anime games like this.
3. The gameplay is alright, but weirdly slow.
4. Blood codes (classes) are sorta cool as a concept, and there's like 50 of them.
5. You're basically anime vampires. Your hideout is even an old church.
6. It's a prequel to [spoiler]God Eater[/spoiler], which is supposed to be a secret, but it's kinda obvious with how the weapons look, how some things are named, how some of the enemies look, plus your Drain attacks.
7. Character customization is pretty nice.

The bad stuff-
1. Equipment is SIMPLE. There's a weapon slot, an alternate weapon slot to switch to, and a jacket, which is basically your "drain weapon", not armor. Defensive stats come from both your weapon and your jacket.
2. There's only four passive skill slots, which stinks since there's like 80 to pick from and gives no incentive to unlock more.
3. There's this weird fresnel glow on everything that looks 10x as awful whenever you're somewhere dark.
4. Your chosen class really doesn't change that much.
5. Leveling is almost worthless, some people even suggest avoiding leveling because of how a few mechanics work.
6. Your "estus flask" heals a flat, low amount of health, and only upgrades as you find certain items through the game. In my tank character's case, it takes ALL SIX of my uses to heal me to full and you can't chain-"drink" them.
7. Almost no other sources of healing, minus the "bonfires", so high HP in general is a bad idea. There's like 5 "give your health to your partner" skills though, which is super odd.
8. Upgrading equipment just raises their offensive stats, which is boring to me. You can "evolve" equipment to fudge some numbers out of and into other stats, but that's it.
9. Parrying is finicky, the game doesn't seem to identify what can be parried and what can't be, and since all jacket categories have different parry windows, it's hard to tell when you're supposed to parry. Like, "turn your jacket sleeves into two wolf things and have both bite forward" is one of the parries and no, the parry window isn't when they bite, the parry window is somewhere between the bite and the transformation.
10. I haven't gotten far enough for it, but literally everyone complains about a series of maps of never-ending white castles that you have to explore like a giant maze, and I hear it's completely awful.
11. Poor clothing options in character customization (tons of accessories and hair though). There's six outfits or so, and all you can do is recolor them or toggle certain bits on and off like removing the gloves.
PLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLAAAAAAAAAAAYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY
What if there were a Dark Souls for people who want something to do instead of play the same boss fight over and over until I get lucky and don't die? Well, this is! And this is it!

Ever since dark souls 1, a certain subset of the industry has taken it upon themselves to believe that you can put an invincible dodge roll and some kind of parry and/or/backstab mechanic in to your game, phone in the rest of it and then ship it out in what ever state you want and people will buy it. Still, even acknowledging this is probably not my kind of game, every aspect of this trash heap was fumbled.
the voice acting is horrible, the plot and script are even worse, the environments are ugly and forgettable, there are constant cutscenes, and the combat - that's all you have left if the plot and the visuals are bad, right? - handles like trash. it's also chock full of the worst things from dark souls 1, including stuff that was cut from later games. Watching your character slipping off the map into one of the game's ubiquitous pits during a dash attack and having to backtrack through the entire level all over again because of it is not fun. Watching an enemy fly the wrong way after you successfully dash attacked them and magically end up in that same pit defies logic.
the pc port clearly had no playtesting, because the keybindings are unplayable. You need a hand on the mouse and another on the movement keys (WASD) in order to play, but in order to access items or gifts (which is evidently a huge part of the gameplay) you need to take your hand OFF your mouse and use the arrow keys. Look, you can't do this during a fight. If a game offers keyboard support, I expect the default keybindings to be at least workable.
the 'unique' parts of the game, the stuff that sets it apart from a FromSoft game, are mistakes. the enemies are evidently supposed to be scary, but in practice they're just ugly and goofy looking. It being bandai namco, and seeing the tags, i expected there to be this on some level, but ALL the chicks are wearing super sexy outfits. If it was here or there I'd be like, fine. cool. Nice! but it's literally everywhere, and the outfits are so ugly. And EVERYTHING clips with the character models. the game vaunts its character designer and its photo mode, but the character designer only has a couple things to play with, like the accessories, and while you can move things around the model, you're just going to get clipping. photo mode handles terribly. You get all these pointless poses and filters, but basic things like camera handling and 360 degree motion around the character is missing.
This had high reviews, was on summer sale and was recommended to me. But it looks and controls like playing a ps2 era game with a nude mod. don't get this unless it's literally for free, even if you like the sexy characters. You'll play it for an hour tops. It's a waste of time and money and an eyesore. There are so many games on steam, and all of them are going to try to suck up your time. If you're going to waste your day on anything, don't let it be this.

It was alright.

This game saved my life.

I am 38.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

This game is kind of like Dark Souls. Now, I’m not a big fan of Dark Souls. The Souls games themselves seem soulless and irritating. According to FromSoftware, wandering around for hours getting your face caved in and having no idea what is going on is fun. 

I would disagree.

The good news is this game seems to do everything FromSoftware can’t:
1.	There is a little tutorial at the beginning of the game, and you can access it at any time if for say you haven’t played the game in a while.
2.	Unlike what happened to me in Dark Souls 3 where I failed to pick up the mana bottle, such stupid things aren’t in this game.
3.	Has a clear path on how to get through the game, although some of maps can be kind of confusing to navigate, I didn’t find it too hard to get around. When I did get stuck, I could eventually get unstuck by looking at the map. There is also a map in your main base that always has the current objective on it, so it is somewhat easy to figure out where you need to be.
4.	Sure, I got my face caved in several times. There are some frustrating parts. However, I was able to always overcome the obstacles. I could beat most of the bosses in just a couple of tries. 
5.	I finished the game while intoxicated so most sober people should be able to finish it no problem.
6.	The story is pretty cool, and there is probably more story in the 1st hour than there is in the first 20 hours of Dark Souls 3.
7.	Big titty anime girls. Enough said. This alone is the singular reason to play the game.

The only real issues I ran into:
1.	I guess if you have a screen refresh rate over 60hz the elevators don’t work properly, or they take many minutes to activate after flipping the switch. The fix is to tab out and back into the game, which is really weird.
2.	Some bosses’ models would disappear after certain moves. I would be able to see their weapons and shields, but the model would be gone.
3.	Some times your AI companion is a mongloid and worse than useless.

All and all it’s a good game. Not the best thing I ever played but I did enjoy it none the less. It has made me want to play more games like this and made me realize that games like this can actually be fun. I hope for a sequel.

I expected to love this game. Dark Souls with an anime coat of paint over the top? Finally, a Souls-ish game I can enjoy looking at as much as I enjoy playing. And enjoy the visuals I did — the environments and especially the characters look great. The problem is that while Code Vein looks nice and nails the anime, it really, really disappoints in the gameplay department. And, simply put, that's why I just can't quire recommend it: The game just wasn't very fun to play.

Combat, the meat of a game like this, just feels... off. Player movement feels stiff, with too little ability to cancel animations and too much time spent locked in place when you do basically anything. And while overall attack speed may not be slow compared to Souls games, (hard to say for sure,) at the very least, it feels like your attack animations are far too often outpaced by the speed of enemy attack animations. Like, it's very possible for enemies to initiate attacks AFTER you start an attack and still hit you before your attack hits them. And of course, enemy attacks are soooo much more likely to cause you to stagger than the other way around, and the time it takes to recover from a stagger is very, very consistently just .1 second longer than the time it takes an enemy's next combo attack to hit you, so enjoy eating entire combos whenever you mess up, because enemies in Code Vein love multi-attack strings. And if you have multiple enemies attacking at once, (with their combo attacks ghosting through each other like they don't exist of course, a problem this game shares with the Souls games,) then enjoy likely getting stunlock combo'd to death. In Dark Souls you could probably panic roll out as long as you have stamina, but thanks to Code Vein's stiff controls, that isn't even an option, stamina management won't save you. On top of all that, enemies consistently have longer (and potentially also wider) range to their attacks than it feels like they should have, so expect to get hit when it seems like you should backed off enough until you learn to compensate with extra distance during the traditional combat dance.

And f all those motion and animation issues weren't enough, the camera system makes combat even worse still by being locked too close and/or being locked to an overly narrow field of view. This limitation in total visibility, combined with a lot of common monsters and most bosses being large if not huge, means that at melee range, you probably can't even clearly see the entire monster you're fighting, and therefor can't read its animations properly to optimally anticipate what it's doing. In a more mindless hack and slash combat experience that wouldn't be as much of a problem, but when the design expects you to survive by avoiding most damage through skillful dodging and blocking rather than facetanking, lack of enemy readability is very not cool.

Beyond combat, there are environments to explore, of course, and this game drops the ball there too. Sure, the environments do looks nice, but the actual layouts are always, always, nothing but repetitive narrow twisting hallways. Narrow twisting caves, narrow twisting crumbling city streets, narrow twisting dried up seabed, the only real question is if the narrow path is defined by walls or death falls. Granted, Souls game were kinda weak in this regard too, but even they had somewhat more interesting layouts and shape variety to their environments. And sometimes Code Vein decides to be extra obnoxious by combining narrow paths that all look the same with twisting, multi-level maze layouts that the completely 2d in-game map is almost no help for. Seriously, how anybody thought the Cathedral was a fun or good addition to the experience makes no sense to me, it's a confusing miserable slog of identical walkways that never gets easier to make sense of even the third time through.

So yeah, as far as actual gameplay goes, Code Vein is a less fun, poorly designed version of Dark Souls where it feels like you fail due to bad design rather than your own mistakes. with bland at best, confusing at worst environmental design. Weapon variety is lacking, since weapons of the same type all have nearly identical move sets. The game has elemental weaknesses and different attack types, but aside from "ice dude is weak to fire," there's no clear logic to what is strong or weak to what. Just pick whatever or check online. And while partners are nice in terms of storytelling and making you feel like the rest of the cast actually exists, highly inconsistent partner AI can both be annoying when they're randomly useless and rob you or a feeling of accomplishment when they suddenly decide to kick some butt. The one thing I think Code Vein does better is its magic system, which allows your magic to recharge through combat rather than being limited to a locked amount of uses that only resets at rest points. Personally, I feel like spells either should have been cheaper or you should have been able to regenerate Code Vein's version of MP faster, but still, just about anything is better than the way Souls games typically dole out magic use. I actually used magic in this game for a change.

Also, and maybe this is a very personally specific problem, the game has something like 90 passive abilities and only lets you use 4 of them at once. Even after factoring in that like, half are pretty lame or way too situational, that is still a horrible ratio of total abilities available to total actually usable at any given time. It really grinds my gears when games let you mix and match abilities like that, but only like 4% of your total options at a time. Unlocking new abilities is way less fun when you're already sitting on a pile of dozens of other already unlocked options you already didn't have room to equip. Mastering new Blood Codes would be so much cooler if they somehow could add additional slots instead of just more ability options to the unused pile.

So yeah, Anime Souls is a great anime experience, I strongly compliment the visual design. The artists definitely did their job and did it well. I just wish the game were even half as enjoyable to play as Io or my custom waifu player character were to look at. (Which reminds me, the character creator is pretty good too.) Otherwise, the gameplay itself is just not enough fun for me to wholeheartedly recommend, despite how much I really and truly do wish more success for games with basically any stylized art direction these days. I am so sick of the generic realism most all modern games with any budget go for otherwise. Why did you have to screw up the gameplay so badly, Bamco? Code Vein had the anime styling and was a real game rather than just a visual novel or something. It could and should have been so much greater.

The in game story is what i really enjoy, it tells a cohesive and intrigue story despite pack with anime action, this is also the very first game where Shift make your choice of gameplay having consequences to the overall plot, lore and ending, which to me really a big shift of how I view Japanese anime games. where you can actually get the bad ending. I enjoyed the English dub as they are overall a pleasant experience, I will probably play it again in the original Japanese audio.

This is more like NIOH than to Dark Souls. 
There is an actual story that takes place and is discussed in game.
There are cutscenes and memories to go through that discuss what actually happens in the story.
The characters are with you in a town and will go alongside you , chat, or you can leave them behind to solo maps/bosses. It is your choice.
The game has good art and sound design.
The character builder is far better than most of the Souls/Bourne games as you can place items on a person and use an editor to specifically place things on your person. You can change them in-game without a fee or some B.S. You get a lot of freedom to make your character.
The Parry system is simple and is based on your armor rather than your weapon, so learning the timings is pretty neat.
There are some difficult bosses and normal bosses that don't make you wanna tear your hair out.
The game allows for coop, which is persistent for the area until you beat the boss. You get plenty of time to run around "dungeons" to level grind for souls if you need to and a sauna to replenish some of your souls when you die. 
You get the nice addition of being able to choose from a variety of weapons and can imbue them with status effects. This is pretty good as you can have multiple elements of the same weapon. You can buy the item for imbuing by  speaking to your party members or people in "base" and give them gifts. They give you a weapon or some special item which helps you out. You can do a lot with this. 
There are some challenge things in the DLC, which are cool, and reward you in game for completing tasks.  This got a lot of flak as they really were just one level and a bunch of stuff to earn behind a  hard boss. 
You can put on a maximum of 8 active skills to use, which cost your ICHOR. Your MP/ICHOR bar is increased every map by using specific skills, backstabs, counters, or items. Your profile, like hunter, scout, queen, whatever, have different build stats as well as your armors. This will count towards ICHOR capacity, defenses against damage types, movement speed, and your counter type, etc. This is different than Dark Souls, Elden Ring, and NIOH where every piece of equipment matters in that regard and you stat min/max. This game just levels you up and that scales with your armor/profile. That's about it.  Pretty simple and hands off for you so you can just play your game. 
You get to make some choices in the game and do specific things that change the outcome/ending. So, it is a choice. I won't spoil that. 
Each character you take with you can help you out in combat different ways. Buffs, heals when you're dying or k.o.'ed for a revive, etc. It also doesn't feel as empty of a game. Revisit some areas and other people appear. There is a pretty detailed map that are unlocked by mistles and stuff. There is a very "annor londo" like place that's nuts. There are ambushes in the game. This is a game where you can take your time and it doesn't have to feel super high octane. The boss fights are , of course, a pace you have to follow and learn the attack patterns of, but that's because they're boss fights. It is expected. 
The graphics in this game are great. 
Sound design is nice and weapons/guns don't sound or feel weak.
This is called Anime Souls on the internet a lot for a reason. It is over the top. Yup. 
The lore building in this game is there and told to you as much as it is environmental, a huge step up from Souls where everyone talks to you like they're going to speak in half-riddles or make little sense purposefully . You're playing an anime. You watch people's memories and last moments, whether they are party members or people in the environment who have fallen (and you get their Blood Code). You can skip them too, which is always good. For people who want their meat, they can have it. For the people who skip, they can skip. Everyone's happy. 
Finally, battle is simple and familiar to people of the genre. Blocking doesn't always fully block all damage. Dodging is big. Perfect Dodging gives you a bar which fills up being in "focus mode", which allows you to strike back harder. This game is fully playable mouse+keyboard or controller. I've done both. Lock on is easy to use, as the genre does. Most weapons are viable. There are some end-game builds that are just "the best", which is designed to really help you for NG+ and bosses, among my favorites are HADES and QUEEN. So, grab a friend, slash, shoot, and drain the blood of people. Also, there is a world out there, which you see some part of, but.....  :)

Character creation: Excellent, with a lot of flexibility.

Art/Character design: Excellent. Love the style.

BGM: Great, immersive, and thrilling.

Story: Excellent. Furthermore, each characters' story line adds weight to their own right, making them equally important as the main protagonist. The way the story is being told has its own merits. Not much of a twist in the story, but it went straight to the point without drags and delays. Though I wished there was more side quests to the side characters (or more interactions with them such as recruiting them as Partners) so we get to know them more.

Combat: Acceptable.

Bloodcode system: Unique, fun, and creative. Really loved the customisation you can do with it.

Dungeon design: Good in overall, but can be better because it is quite linear so there isn't much complexity to it. Though I wished the depths can drop more upgrade materials when we farm the bosses so we can play around with the customisation more (without spending so much time on the farming itself, which can be quite demoralising and repetitive).

Monster Design: Unfortunately, bad, as they are repetitive and just a re-skin of the same model.

Difficulty Design: Not good, because the real difficulty comes from the game pouring you with lots of monsters all at once. Not a great idea to increase the difficulty by using numbers.

Overall: Highly recommended to play this game for its Story, Character design, and Art Style. If these points are what you're looking for, then this would be your cup of tea. Probably not the game for veteran players of Soul series or Elden Ring (as it would be like a cheap version of the two from their perspective). A game worth getting and playing.

I wanted to be excited about this game, but it didn't live up to the hype so well. The character creation is great and has a lot to offer, but still seems to miss some marks in my opinion. (i.e no breast slider, no height change, clothing options limited and more than half are unappealing to me). The fighting is kind of solid but still feels either too easy with AI cpu's or too hard at points without (but with souls-like games its always diligence being key). Could take more time to get really into it, but I feel that within this 10 hour mark, I may have seen most all of everything.

Having the blood veils (body armor) be covering up a majority of my created costume and accessories was plain dumb; should of have the option to hide. Had to mod out game to be playable. If I had gotten this game on ps4 or something, would have returned on this point, along with the other gripes. Like was the reason I made all my little choices on my character for no reason? like why can't we change the color of our blood veils? As an anime inspired game, and me being a anime enthusiast (love ecchi, harem, action, comedy stuff, kill me), and aesthetics are a huuuuuuuuge part in an anime lovers life, period.
 
Also the combat system of changing classes and abilities feels too simple in a way where every class begins to feel like the other. My character feels like a puppet of classes, rather than a beefed up powerhouse with nice toys.

EDIT:
Trying to play it again and saying eff it and have the cpu/ai tag along, makes game go faster and it might still be fun to imagine this game as a dark souls game but easier that also plays like a anime rpg game with a party.

I still somehow just don't feel heavily drawn to the game. One aspect is that with the anime theme, the world seems hella bland, dark dreary typical dark souls vibe. Hella typical story with everyone being "already dead" hoping to somehow be alive or something; like it would have been cool to have a fleshed out vibrant anime world and combat system that feels tough like dark souls. (but alas, I did not make this game, makers choice).

Code Vein is a Great game with a few issues. lets address the cons first.

first off if your coming from soulsborne your gonna notice the games combat feels alittle Floaty, it lacks the weight and deliberate impact souls has and sometimes feels like it doesnt control as fluidly.

for those who enjoy deep character building, youll likely have mixed feelings about this, instead of leveling individual attributes like souls does, you will instead swap between a variety of preset stat distributions called Blood codes, having a specific blood code will disctate weight, Strength and dex scaling and the abilities you start out with among other things. however as you get deeper into the game you will be able to mix and match abilities from different blood codes in order to give your build a greater degree of personality. 

the level design can be atrocious, some areas are either increadibly maze like, and everything can look the same at times, often resulting in you getting lost. couple that with unfair enemy placement and you might take issue with exploration.

The game was balanced around the prospect that you will have an NPC companion with you at all times, as a result playing the game solo can feel unnessecarily punishing at times. 

the Game has multiple endings and asa result of a a few above things its easy to lock yourself out of the ending you want if you dont know what your doing.

if you are to look past this however there are upsides. 

this game has a very deep character creator, those creative enough can make no shortage of OCs or anime characters,  and you may spend hours just messing around with what the creator has to offer. 

the game has a simple but well done story that is carried by its cast of memorable characters, and each of said characters have a story in themselves to delve into. 

the OST is amazing, with many memorable tracks that i personally have saved so i may enjoy them whenever i have time. 

graphically this is a beautiful game with a variety of pretty set pieces to look at. 

all in all this journey is one worth taking, and one that can stick with you long after its put down. 8.5/10

I replayed this game many many times with quite a few friends I myself pushed into trying this with me. The coop in this game is phenomenal as it let's you play together from start to finish almost flawlessly and even if you don't have friends to play with dw, you still have an Ai partner that's a really good stand-in (sometimes better than your friends ehm...).

The combat itself is not the smoothest in the business, but the story and the characters more than make up for it. The character editor on the other hand is probably one of the best anime character editors I've seen yet. And speaking of graphics, playing this game really feels like being in an anime, with awesome visual effects, character models, environments and music.

The build variety and the amount of playstyles is also one of the strong suites of this game. You wanna be a teleporting guy with a katana? Or a Hulk with a giant greatsword that throws blood slashes? Or wanna keep your distance and cast spells and shoot from a gun? Well you came to the right game, everything is perfectly viable and hella fun to play.

Even if you are not the biggest Souls-like fan I'd still recommend buying this just for the story itself, you won't be disappointed. And if you are a Souls-like tryhard and an Ai companion or a friend sounds too easy, dw you can still turn them off and bash your head against the wall solo.

I know it's not a perfect game by any means, but for me it has everything it needs to have and much much more.

I wish I read all the bad reviews instead of looking at the recent reviews. 
If you want something to scratch the itches of FromSoft games, go buy Nioh 2 or MonHun instead, much better combat, faster pacing, more depth and actually feels good when you hit something.

As much as I love third person melee combat games, I can not enjoy this game. Small FOV, tight corridor fights (Nioh don't even feel this bad), big weapons obstruct your view, parry feels clunky, stiff animations, I felt no weight when I hit the enemy, all weapons are big and long but their first attack has no forward momentum,  your character doesn't move much when you attack so it feels like you're stuck in one place once you hit the attack button.
I only fought 2 bosses and they felt so boring to fight, only few move sets and all I can do was hit one or two then run, nothing to memorize. The only thing "souls-like" about this game is enemies can kill you in few hits, the combat and boss fights does not feel as good as a soul game.

Edit: After 6 months I decided to give this game one last try. After playing more action games this game feel even worse, the animations are so stiff and janky, there's no satisfaction in killing enemies, it's like hitting a piece of tofu, your weapon just go straight through them with little to no impact. I'm not even try to compare this game with other games at this point, I went in with an open mind trying to find more games with good combat but this game is so disappointed coming from Bandai, if this were an indie game then I could forgive the stiffness but no, it's freaking Bandai, they made countless games before this, Lies of P demo felt better than this and it's their first souls-like game. Never gonna touch this again.

Code Vein is a souls-like, dress-up game directed towards people who really like comically large anime booba.

This game does some things right, but so many wrong that I don't think I can recommend playing this game, unless you are into dress-up games, because the character customization is actually pretty solid in this game. Or maybe if you have played God Eater, since it seems to be connected (I don't know, haven't played that yet). Keep in mind that I have played this game 100% solo and that this review contains a few gameplay spoilers, but no story spoilers whatsoever.

So, I'll start with the positives aspects and end with the negative ones. Here goes:

(+) Alright story. I only finished it, because I was actually interested in how it ends and it has multiple outcomes in the middle and at the end of the story, which I find really neat.

(+) Trying different builds is super easy. Since you don't invest any points into stats when leveling and instead choose your "blood code", switching build and playstyle is as easy as pressing a button. And new weapons you find usually are already upgraded, so you can try them right away (why Elden Ring couldn't do the same is mind boggling to me).

(+) The Soundtrack is surprisingly good, I really liked it.

(+) Good character customization options.


(-) The enemy variety is abysmal. From the top of my head I can think of 6 different enemies, which get slightly changed both visually and gameplay wise throughout the game. Enemies being recycled doesn't have to be a bad thing, but not bringing in completely new enemies from time to time makes it so imo.

(-) My most sincere fck you goes out to the level designer, who littered the game full with those "haha, gotcha!" moments.
You didn't look where you were going for two seconds? Woops! The ground you were on was actually instable :P
Enjoy walking all the way back x3
Additionally we have enemies surprise attacking you constantly and barely visible spike traps in the walls near the end. And my personal nemesis: the cathedral. You will spend half of your playtime just trying to figure out where the fck you're supposed to go and even if you do, it just drags on while you keep seeing the exact same assets over and over again. I will gladly do a hitless Iron Keep run in DS2 before playing through this area again >:(

(-) Build variety seemed very lame, to me at least, but to be fair I didn't really understand how you make a proper build in this game, so I can't say much to that x)

(-) Except for one boss, which I actually somewhat enjoyed despite him feeling kinda unfair at times, the boss difficulty only ranged from dumb-easy to slightly challenging.

(-) From my experience, enemies and bosses randomly change aggro without any reason, so playing a tank build and having your partner be a ranged support is not really viable. And it's just annoying in general. You think it's safe to heal and boom- boss jumped you :P

(-) Bonus: Did they have to give almost every single female character the largest chest I've ever seen in a video game, I don't want to feel like a loser playing this game xd


So, should you play this game?

Give it a try, if you..
• enjoy anime women with big tiddies (spoken in Niko Bellic's voice)
• played God Eater, maybe?
• really like soulsborne games and just need more to satisfy that itch, even if it has to be with mediocre games

Don't give it a try, if you..
• are an average soulsborne fan and are looking for more, good souls-likes


In the end, that's my opinion and if you think the gameplay looked interesting enough to you, then feel free to try it out :)
There are a good amount of fans of this game, so you might just become one of them :3

CODE VEIN is an anime souls-like game that heavily draws upon the mechanics, level design, and even bosses found in the highly acclaimed Dark Souls series. While it doesn't reach the same level of excellence as Dark Souls, it stands out in its own way by introducing new ideas. Departing from the traditional stat point allocation system, CODE VEIN introduces blood codes that can be changed at will. Each blood code comes with predetermined stat distributions and offers gifts reminiscent of the miracles and sorcery found in Dark Souls. These gifts are further divided into two types: Passive and Active, which can be mastered and utilized across different blood codes, enhancing the player's versatility.

The gameplay experience in CODE VEIN mirrors the challenging nature of Dark Souls. The captivating soundtrack, coupled with a engaging story and well-crafted characters, creates an immersive environment that will particularly resonate with anime enthusiasts. However, the level design is a mixed bag, with some areas reminiscent of the intricately interconnected paths found in Dark Souls, while others prove to be poorly conceived and cumbersome to explore.

The cooperative play in CODE VEIN is a truly captivating experience, granting you the opportunity to traverse its world alongside a friend. Bearing similarities to the mechanics found in Dark Souls, the cooperative aspect employs a unique twist. Instead of conventional summon signs, players communicate through signals, allowing a friend to search and seamlessly join forces in your journey.

Unfortunately, I had a disappointing experience during my playthrough. I didn't receive the preorder exclusive blood veil, Venous Claw, that was supposed to be available in the deluxe edition. This omission of in-game items feels unfair and takes away from an otherwise great experience.

Despite its shortcomings, CODE VEIN remains an exceptional souls-like experience, highly recommended for fans of the genre. Its unique blend of anime aesthetics, compelling gameplay mechanics, and engaging narrative make it a worthwhile venture. I highly recommend CODE VEIN if you're looking for a solo or cooperative souls-like game.

Gave up on this game once I got to the Cathedral. The level design just leaves so much to be desired and while the combat is fine, level design is as important as gameplay in games like this. So I just had to quit out of pure boredom.

Is it anime dark souls? Yes and no.

[h1] Combat [/h1]
While the combat is more less the same, the enemies feel different. Most of the level enemies feel like they ended up in the wrong game. What I mean is they are too slow for this game. You can just run up to them, walk around them and backstab them without them doing anything. Boss fights are in theory the same as in DS just dodge until you have an opportunity to attack. I do not think the combat is bad tho, it is just less challenging (at least at the beggining), which makes the game easier to pick up for new players. Although most likely due to the speed of the enemies their damage can be pretty high.

Some enemies have really wierd backstab hitboxes or hitboxes overal (except for the DLC this only happened with purple hollow enemies). Some enemies get backstabbed when you attack from behind their right soulder and some enemies like Boreal Brutes have incredibly small backstab window.

In this game you can be accompanied by an NPC character of your choice (some can enter combat / are found later in the story). You can choose to progress solo but it makes the game way harder especially during some gank fights like invasions or even Ornstein and Smough enhanced. Or you can alternatively play in coop which I did not get the chance to test since I was unable to find coop game when I tried (I was mainly playing the game during late night).

I love blood code system in this game. You do not invest points from level ups in this game. Instead you only gain HP and stamina and stats are redistributed according to your blood code. You can switch blood codes anytime you like (your HP and “mana“ stays the same if the new value is higher or is dropped down to the new cap) making the gampelay more interesting. If you play with a blood code you can always equip Gifts in that codes tree and other Gifts that you have stats to use. Gifts are mastered by you having them in hotbar while beating enemies (later blood codes need higher amount of haze (souls) collected). There are basically 5 types of Gifts: passive, magic, defensive, supportive and physical. You can have up to 4 passive Gifts and they do not have stat requirements so you can basically turn your warrior into mage if you would like. Physical gifts are something like weapon arts although you can use more than one making every weapon good for any type of combat basically.

Mana system in this game is in my opinion very well executed. Your code has predetermined how much maximum “mana“ it has and that is with how much you start from the checkpoint. You can increase this number by either parrying or backstabing enemies and you can refill it by damaging enemies with your weapon (light, heavy and drain attacks only, physical gifts do not count).

[h1] Story [/h1]
This game actually has a story unlike DS. It is post apocalyptic JRPG, so it is what you would expect (or at least I think you would). But the story makes clearing the game meaningful and definitely more enjoyable.

Cutscenes were really nice but pretty long. Before I actually got to move there was like 20 mins of cutscenes to get you into the story. I did not like it at first but I later realized that this game is gonna differ from DS in this aspect [b] a lot [/b].

One thing that made me kind of mad was that the MC said 2 sentences throughout the whole story and that was before the final boss fight. I would not mind if they just used one female and one male voice for the whole dubbing thing. But your character stupidly staring at someone instead of answering their question was awkward.

[h1] Characters and character creation [/h1]
I love character creation in this game. I did not want to make my character look fancy or anything because I bought the game mainly for the gameplay but man... this character creation is awesome. I managed to spend like 20 minutes there.

Each revenant character at your base has some kind of backstory which can be uncovered by collecting Vestiges and giving them to your “guardian“. The problem here is that there is just so many of these that after 3 of them I just started skipping what was in them because they are not well made. Instead of a cutscene or something you are thrown into a black and white world with statues talking, where you are walking super slowly so you accidentally do not run too far (not that you can...). After each related to some character you get the characters thoughts on that memory of theirs which was enough for me and I got the vague idea what was going on.

[h1] Bosses [/h1]

As I said before, Code Vein does not bring as much of challenging contet as Dark Souls. But some of the bosses could very well rival bosses like Nameless King, Ornstein and Smough, Fume Knight in their difficulty even when fighting alongside a partner. I myself have been doing pretty fine until I met Blade Bearer and Cannoneer (aka Ornstein and Smough enhanced). This boss was pretty rough but it was manageable thanks to the companion. But Juzo Mido, the main baddie, who came after that was a bit too much for me. I have spent like 1,5 hour trying to beat him until I somehow luckily managed to beat him. That being said I am probably not gonna try plaing without companion any time soon because I am not prepared to spend 3 hours doing OnS with higher difficulty.

[h1] Depths [/h1]
What is Depths? Depths is a content that is not a part of the story but is a place where you can find some bosses you fought previously, but only if you can beat challenges set by the game.

Overal Depths is a pretty easy contet except for 2 maps. One contains 2 Boreal Brutes [u] as a mini boss [/u], yes as a mini boss. So yeah I spent like 50 minutes on this location while 40 minutes were spent on this mini boss.
The other contains enhanced Cannoneer and Blade Bearer. [spoiler] Enhanced in a way that if one dies the other one buffs themselve [/spoiler].

Then there is Tower of Trials which for some reason does not count towrds achievement goal of exploring the entirety of Depths. Each tower of trials has 6 floors where 1st and 4th are some enemies that you can see ahead of entering the floor, 2nd a 5th are invasions and 3rd and 6th are boss floors. There is no checkpoint anywhere but you get healing a “mana“ reset after defeating the first boss. You can also get some healing stuff from beatin other floors, but it is only 1 per floor if it drops.

[h1] Overal [/h1]
[b] Pros [/b]
+ Blood codes
+ Character creation
+ Nice graphics, be it characters, enemies or locations (with a small exception)
+ Decent story
+ Interesting bossfights
+ Has a map
+ 4 types of ripostes / backstabs according to the veil you have equiped (although riposte and backstab with same veil look the same)
+ You can swap between 2 weapons while only the current one counts towards the weight limit
+ Quick dodge is a dash, not a strage flip like in DS1

[b] Cons [/b]
- I feel like it has lower replayability than DS due to the story focus
- Pretty short, has around 30h of story if you are average player
- The end of the story feels really rushed. There are two bossfights right after each other with final 4 bosses, meaning there are only 3 areas to clear while fighting 5 bosses and one of them should not even be a boss [spoiler] I am not counting The Virgin Born as a single boss since it is just trasnformed Skull King [/spoiler]
- One map is just awful to play, it only has white textures and looks the same everywhere [spoiler] You guessed it, it is Anor Londo reskin aka Cathedral of Sacred Blood [/spoiler]

Overal while I really like the game I feel like 50€ for it, is a bit too much. So I recommend waiting for a sale if you are still interested in purchasing it.

[h1] DLCs [/h1]
Are pretty bad. 1 boss, 2 new blood codes, 4 companion costumes for 2 characters, 3 weapons and veils (reskins with different stats) and some tattoos. Hellifre Knight is a good boss, other 2 suck. Blood codes are decent. Worth 10€ at most.

PS: Happy New Year

8/10, you should buy this game.
