I didn't expect Code Vein to be an amazing game or anything but I also expected at least one or two things about the game to work for me, sadly, it didn't even manage to do that. There's a lot of just, taking soulslike ideas and executing them poorly across the board, with any of its ideas on how to shift the formula around a bit continuously resulting in a worse time on the whole. The worst offender of this is the entire game being designed around having a companion to fight with you, with the encounters being crafted with this in mind. It essentially makes almost every encounter feel like it boils down to just correctly drawing aggro and maybe occasionally dodging as well I guess, since unless you're fighting something really big and bulky, you basically never have to learn anything about it, it's just a dumb punching bag that gets stunlocked to death. 

This reliance on the companion also makes the boss fights fall into a similar category where you only really need to vaguely learn the basics and you'll be good, being able to easily fall back and also deal insane amounts of damage at a time when you both run in simultaneously. It just feels like the game never fully is invested in the idea of you fully learning it, or at least, there are just a lot of mechanics and bits of design that discourage playing it in such a way. The level design in particular was utterly miserable, with the highlights in the first 5 areas or so just coming across as ok at best, while also being put alongside a comically large swamp and the video game equivalent of white room torture that also happens to be in a horrendous labyrinth. The latter feels especially awful to me because of how cheap it looks, everything just being copy pasted white patterned textures as far as the eye can see, not really evoking and sense of atmosphere as much as it evokes the feeling of someone opening up the Unreal Engine for the first time and just messing around.

While I just said that the level design was where this game felt the worst, the writing is near-equally as soul draining. Everything is so verbose, people just endlessly repeating the same boring nonsense and putting you in cutscenes for an agonisingly long time as it's laying out a plot that felt expertly crafted to make anyone hate anime. Nobody shuts up at any point in time either, making it yet another reason why the game being structured around companions sucks, because they never stop talking and incessantly comment on everything, even opening your menu. Horrible experience that felt like purgatory while playing, the game peaked at the character customisation.

2/10

A dark, gritty, anime inspired, souls-like? Absolutely a winner!

Campy, anime vampires that try and save the world. Don't roll up on this game expecting it to be like Dark Souls. Use partners, use Gifts (skills), and don't rely on backstabs too much. The grind isn't too bad once you find areas that net you a bunch of Haze (Souls). Story is your typical anime trope and characters are linear. 

A nitpicks are 1/3 of the level design is literally lo(ooooo)ng hallways and bridges filled with texture maps. The endgame options are pretty fair (new game+ allows you to fallback on your decision in case it's too hard). 

The biggest negative is the 3 DLCs for the Season Pass. The dungeons seemed rushed and the rewards mediocre. My only positive was the Hellknight fight was fair and fun (for me). Frozen Empress was a joke. Lord of Thunder was only extremely annoying if you try and go for the Trail Rewards (30 hit combo w/o taking damage was hell), otherwise his fight was alright.

My recommendation for this game is get the Season Pass + Full Game if it is on Sale or 85% off (like i did)
This game does scratch that Sekirobornesouls itch, but again, do not jump in thinking it is one.

Well, I must admit, I really enjoy this game alot. 

First of all, the top-notch voice acting, particularly from the Japanese voice actors and actresses. It truly enhances the immersive my experience and I feel that every character has their own individual. As always.

The story follows a typical anime-style narrative, where someone aims to become a hero with their 'nakama'. As always, some of female characters are on dual mission: fighting monsters and pushing dress code boundaries!  Well, keep it aside from now. There are bits of the storytelling that aren't explained well and might come across as odd (or maybe I miss it), but overall, I still keep invested on the game. While the pace of the story feels just about right, the 'good' ending doesn't quite satiate my thirst for well-rounded conclusion (yes, it has multiple endings). I wonder, though, if it's just me or if others also share this sentiment. Despite this, from a writing perspective, each ending is really well written. The art and animation are a feast for the eyes, precisely what you'd expect from ufotable. The gameplay is somewhat akin to less intense, anime-style Dark Souls; it's manageable as long as you don't blame your finger for any misclick though. Still, this game beats dark soul on the FEELS department. 

Let's talk about the best part. The soundtracks are truly well done, especially "Memory of the Lost". This haunting melody that resonates while traversing the memories in the vestige sends shivers down my spine every single time! And the way the game melds each vestige memory with this captivating soundtrack leaves me utterly speechless. A total masterpiece!

However, when it comes to the map levels, it's a bit unbalance from my perspective. Some maps have intuitive layout, but others are overly-excessively complicated. The Cathedral of Sacred Blood map takes the crown for complexity.  I mean, I wonder the developer had discussion about how to torture the players without player realizing about it. :') You can search for it if you want with this keyword 'Cathedral Code Vein meme'.

Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who doesn't mind inviting the onion ninjas over from time to time while slashing monster.

Good art design, edgy rock music, an anime-level mixture of depressing setting and hopeful power of friendship. Plus it's an anime Souls-like, akin to Dark Souls 3's level-based design (although admittedly not quite as good as that.)

If you read that and think you'll like this, then you will.

I have three main problems with the game, though. First and most importantly, multiplayer is a bit clunky. I don't see why there is a restriction on it - you can only play multiplayer in an area up until the area's main boss is defeated, but I don't see any good reason for this. Second, the game maps are 2D top-down maps, but the areas feature constant changes in elevation and the map does a horrible job of showing that and it can be very confusing. Third and final, every single outfit in this game WILL clip through your character's hair, including the gas masks that are required for 3/4 of the game. Noticeable in gameplay, and REALLY noticeable in cutscenes where the characters are shown up close. It's even obvious on the other characters, whose hair ALWAYS clips through these dang gas masks.

None of these three things are game-changers for me, but they are still annoying.
Best souls like game of all time ong

This game is incredible! This is my very first souls like game, meaning I didn't have an easy time at first. I played it on my Cousins PS4 and found it on sale, and my only regret is not paying full price for this game. 
This is the first game I have played in a long while that has actual play style diversity. I don't play anything like my cousin and found my own build that works wonders for how I play the game. 
The Anime post apocalypse gothic aesthetic was welcomed as there not a whole lot of game that dare to be that unique. 
There either full sci fi, or full European fantasy or standard zombie apocalypse. This game hits all three brackets all at once and it somehow works. The characters and story are actually compelling if not a bit over edgy at times. Surprisingly I'm not filled with the same rage and disappointment that comes over me when watching most anime now days. 
Except for a few story beats that got really redundant, but those were easily overlooked. 

Overall, I think this game is a great introduction if you're not used to Soul's type games. 
With Triple A dev's sinking left and right, now is a great time to give this game a shot.
Soulslike and Nierlike. Perfect mix!

Initially, I thought this was just an ordinary game like others that focus on adventure and world exploration, similar to Genshin Impact. However, I felt that this one was quite different because it offers a satisfying RPG experience for me, which made me interested and even lost track of time playing this game, haha. I also heard that this game collaborates with "God Eater," which made me even more intrigued. Not to mention, the character customization is also good and not bad because we can modify it according to our preferences or what is commonly known as personal taste. Overall, this game is quite interesting, and up until now, I would give it a rating of 10 out of 1000.

A super fun Souls-Like game that I heavily recommend if you've played a FromSoft title!
It has amazing world design that perfectly mixes well into gameplay with a wide selection of abilities to help create your own, unique build!

The animation, graphics, and lore are all spectacular, and I really enjoy it so far--even being so early into the game!
It's like Dark Souls but anime.

Code Vein is a solid experience overall-and tears many concepts from the Soulslike genre.  It is nowhere near as challenging, however; though there is plenty of depth to be found in the native weapon system.  The anime style is the real draw here; as it confidently and successfully realises a unique style in the genre with some panache.  The game-play is far more linear than a typical souls game, but rather than detract from the format; it deepens its own individual identity while retaining key mechanics of the genre.
The narrative is as high a conceit as one might expect from an anime, but you're likely not coming here for the story.  The game is far more hack and slash than Souls - and less emphasis is placed on precise timing.  Controls are solid in attacks, and while not as satisfyingly visceral as a less cartoonish concept would allow; the control on movement within attack is very satisfying.  I do find the menu navigation is a little sluggish, but merely an observation rather than a complaint.  
Where the game shines for me is the simplistic nature of what it does extremely well - simple maps, rigidly straight forward and rewarding fast encounters.  Clearing an area is a dream for the completionist and obsessive compulsive gamer alike!
Overall, I am a huge fan of Code Vein for its style of gameplay - they also provide a free Demo here on Steam; try it - if you enjoy this experience, the game repeats that formula and scales the threat level for the rest of the game.

I was playing on steam deck so my experience was different.

There was incredible lag and i had to turn all settings down to minimum to get it to not lag. It would crash sometimes so that was kind of annoying. 
In terms of gameplay, the battles are very repetitive and honestly kind of boring. The battles are hard and the difficulty is inconsistent. Personally i don't think the graphics look amazing. It looks like it could be a switch game but its so laggy on steam deck that there's no way it would work.
In terms of story, It was okay i guess. The first boss of the game was kind of confusing. I never knew how the boss became the boss in the first place. The characters are introduced so fast and there are a lot of them.

I personally don't like this game. My thoughts might be because of the fact that i was playing on steam deck but the platform doesn't change the story and battles. I just didn't really like it that much.

I watched the trailer and thought that it would be an interesting game with lots of voice dialogue.
Boy was I wrong...

So I started playing and discovered that the protagonist doesn't talk at all like the other characters (basically a complete mute) during most IF NOT ALL storyline scenes. The most you can expect are gestures and groans.
The movement animation during the gameplay is choppy as well. The combat doesn't feel souls like. It's too easy to be considered soulslike.

Aside from that I think the game is pretty good, but still I decided to give a negative review just so people know that the protagonist has nothing to say in the whole story.

One of the standout features of Code Vein is its dark and visually striking world. Set in a post-apocalyptic future, the game presents a desolate landscape filled with gothic architecture, eerie environments, and a sense of melancholic beauty. The art style and attention to detail create a captivating atmosphere that immerses players in its unique and mysterious setting.

The gameplay in Code Vein focuses on fast-paced and challenging combat. Players assume the role of a Revenant, a vampire-like being with supernatural powers. The combat mechanics are reminiscent of the "Soulsborne" games, requiring precision, timing, and tactical decision-making. Players must learn enemy attack patterns, dodge and parry effectively, and manage stamina to survive the intense battles.

Code Vein introduces a "Blood Code" system, which allows players to switch between different character classes or "Gifts." Each Blood Code grants unique abilities, such as magic spells or enhanced physical attacks, giving players flexibility in tailoring their playstyle. The game also features a companion system, where players can team up with an AI-controlled partner called an "A.I. Buddy" to assist in combat and provide support.

Another notable aspect of Code Vein is its deep character customization options. Players can create their own Revenant character, customizing various aspects such as appearance, gender, voice, and more. The extensive options for personalization allow players to create unique and diverse characters that suit their preferences.

The game's story is presented through a mix of cutscenes, dialogue, and exploration. While the narrative may not reach the heights of some other RPGs, it still offers an engaging and mysterious tale that unfolds as players progress through the game. Additionally, Code Vein features multiple endings, adding replayability and incentive for players to explore different story paths.

Overall, Code Vein offers an engaging and atmospheric action RPG experience. Its dark and visually stunning world, challenging combat, and deep character customization options make it a solid choice for fans of the "Soulsborne" genre. If you enjoy challenging gameplay, immersive environments, and a unique blend of vampire lore and post-apocalyptic settings, Code Vein is definitely worth considering.

Cool game. I haven't finished it yet, but this is what I've learned so far:


- enemies can't stunlock you to death if you stunlock them to death first

- dodge-rolling is cool, dodge-zooming with blue sparkles at your feet is cooler

- huge ass swords are comfy lol weapons for people like me who are too lazy to git gud

- cleavage-jiggle anime freakazoids with technicolor hair and glossy eyes the size of fists are significantly more tolerable when they heal you up to 80% at the verge of certain death; I appreciate this design decision

- with multiple enemies around, the lock-on exists mostly just to troll the player

- Mr. Backstab and I didn't get along at first, but now we're really good friends, and he even told me his secret nickname, Mr. Back-But-Also-Kinda-To-The-Side-Stab

- informing me that there's a ladder I should climb down while I'm in the process of climbing down said ladder is not as helpful of an advice as Louis seems to think; he's still a bro, heals me good

- while the cathedral was obviously architectured by M.C. Escher, it's not quite as awful and confusing as I had expected; it looks like they forgot to texture it, though

- people might call the writing in this game anime cringe, but as someone not at all familiar with the tropes of this genre, I think the story and the characters are pretty cool so far, and the backstory to the world is honestly quite fascinating

- while the character creator is pretty extensive, it's a shame you can't be bald, because most of the hair options look like the protagonist has an additional, invisible companion following him around who's a hairdresser who carefully readjusts each and every single lock in between battles; it's also a challenge to create a male character that doesn't look like he skipped out on puberty

- "What do you want to upgrade?" shouldn't be a line stuck in my head, but it is

Title: CODE VEIN

Code Vein is a thrilling action role-playing game that offers a unique blend of anime-inspired visuals and challenging gameplay. Set in a post-apocalyptic world, the game follows a group of Revenants, vampire-like beings, as they fight to survive and uncover the mysteries of their existence.

One of the standout features of Code Vein is its character customization system. Players have an extensive range of options to create their own Revenant, allowing for a high level of personalization and creativity. The attention to detail in the character designs is impressive, and the overall aesthetic of the game is visually stunning, with a dark and gothic atmosphere.

In terms of gameplay, Code Vein presents a satisfying combat experience. Players are equipped with a variety of weapons and blood-based abilities, which can be customized to suit different playstyles. The combat is fast-paced and requires strategic thinking, as well as well-timed dodges and attacks. It can be challenging at times, but the sense of accomplishment after defeating tough enemies or bosses is incredibly rewarding.

This was my first "proper" soulslike game. Before this my only experience with the genre were games that little people actually call "a soulslike". Those being Hollow Knight and Jedi Fallen Order. So my experience with the genre is next to none and as such YOU should take my opinion with a grain of salt.

So, what is appealing to me about this game and why in god's name am i even leaving a positive review about this otherwise relatively "nothing" game? 

Let's begin with the very first area of the game. You are dumped straight in after a short tutorial that leaves nothing in your head and some exposition cutscenes. You have no idea who you are, what you are doing and why do the women have such big boobs. Going through the first area was quite a challenge for me and i respawned about a dozen times before meeting up with louis. And damn i loved every single second of it. Pressing onwards i beat my first boss and stumbled upon the thing that made me consider getting the full game instead of the demo. The memory vesitges. I absolutely adore this approach to lore dumps and character exposition. The music, the visuals create this nice atmosphere that is, as far as i am aware, unique to this game.

So, what about the full game then? It is a mixed bag for certain.

The combat is your generic souls combat, maybe lacking some things, but i wouldn't know. There is no actual combo system, so you just kinda end up button mashing attacks. There are also 3 defensive options in the parry, block and dodge. Almost noone uses the parry, because of the surprisingly lengthy delay for the actual "parry frames" to begin. Blocking is very build dependant (we will get to that) and dodging is your standart invincibility roll, which you are going to be using 90% of the time. 

The story is your generic anime apocalypse story. If you played god eater, you are gonna find some neat references and lore, but that is about it. However this story isnt plot focused, it is entirely character driven. Are the characters good? Uhhhhhhhhh, maybe, depends on who you ask. The writing is very much all over the place just like this review. But it is all generic anime stuff, if you like that sort of stuff, you will find enjoyment from the characters. (Why does yakumo have a fucking glock)

The music fucks A LOT (it is really awesome and you can totally shred out sometimes). 

The graphics i dont care for, as i am a low end scrub, but the artstyle is pretty nice. Will definetly hold up for a while.

Now if it is such a mixed bag, why bother? The answer is customisation. And god almighty does it have it.

First up the obvious character creator being fucking amazing, especially if you install some extra outfit mods (you do not gain extra outfits for your character by playing the game, sorry)

But what is more important, is the build customization. Half the fun of this game is building your very own build. It goes deeper than just "i use big sword, i use fast sword, i use gun". You see every weapon has stat scaling, but the stats work in an interesting way. You have your standart str, dex, etc. from other souls games, but it is all determined by the class (blood code) that you choose. So you can have a class that has high str for a heavy sword, but maybe it has low fortitude and you can't get the invisibility spell. Well in that situation you can fine pick the perfect class for that, maybe sacrifice some str, but hey you can now shove a giant hammer up someone's ass, which is honestly very much worth it. Those spells i mentioned? They also scale from your class, but you can also amplify your spells with armor. Oh god i forgot armor. Armor determines your mobility, your damage/status resistances, your stagger resistance AND your spell potency. And every armor is balanced with certain aspects being way lower or higher. There are glass cannon fast generalist mages. Tankier damage mages, status resistant defense mages, just tanky stuff in general. Point is you can find a build that you will spend hours perfecting and obsessing over.


So, the TLDR? Awesome customisation and min maxing that is brought down by mediocre combat. 


DLC is optional content like cosmetics, item variations and 3 new areas with unique bosses. The only good one of these is the hellfire knight dlc, which is a strong contendor for the best boss in this game (and definetly the most fun one too). The other 2 are just unfun stat races.

Code Vein is an excellent game that provides an exciting and unique take on the Souls-like genre. One of the standout features of Code Vein is its character customization system. You can choose from a vast selection of abilities, weapons, and character classes to create a unique character that suits your playstyle. The game's combat is fast-paced and challenging, with a variety of enemy types that require different strategies to defeat. 

The game features a 2-player co-op mode that allows you to play with your friends. However, you can only invite another player to help when the boss of the map has not been defeated. One thing worth noting is that if a player dies, the guest will have to reconnect with the host, which can be a bit of a hassle.

I bought this game when it was 80% off, it's such a steal for a game like this.

P.S. Healing animation takes too long (╯°□°）╯︵ ┻━┻
gg

EDIT cause I left some things out before.

Let's first state the obvious: this is not a perfect game. I have seen lots of people's comments complaining how Code Vein is not "Dark Souls, but anime", and they are right, it's not, but it is a very enjoyable game with a lot of shortcommings but some aspects in which it is brilliant. 

The long rant:

CONS:
-I cannot overstate this: the dialogues are so, soooo cringe, and the narrative is so stupid that overshadows what is an underlying very good story
-The abundance of cosmetics for character doesn't makes up for the very limited armor or at least aesthetic clothing (a miss here because it has lots and lots of customisation options)
-The female character design is sexy but borderline hentai
-Items description is stupid and nonsensical sometimes
-A stupid plot twist that adds absolutely nothing to overall value of the experience but doubles up in stupidness
-Annoying cutscenes that don't add depth, they just try to look cool (emphasis on the "try" 'cause is so obvious that ends up not being cool, just annoying)
-Why so many loading screens????
-Little enemy variety
-The ability to change blood codes (builds) on the fly takes away gameplay depth
-The fact that there is a door to DLC content in base game is undeliable proof of the horrible corporate practice of cutting pieces of the game to sell them as DLC's that everyone ends hating, just to make some more bucks

PROS:
-The combat is really, really enjoyable
-Blood codes are a bad choice at first glance, but it turns really fun trying different builds for different areas
-The "training room" is an awesome choice that more games need to have, it lets you actually see and quantify the effects of the gifts you equip with (gifts are abilities: the equivalent of magic and passive augments)
-The story is actually good if you filter all the cringeyness of dialogues; and more than anything, the short character stories are very good (although a different delivery than "memory echoes" would have made them justice)
-Although there is an overuse of enemy reskins, there are some enemies that are such a pleasure to figh: Black Hunters, all the female warriors, specially the Golden and the Queen's Vanguard (except those fatsos that are just big blobs with no depth to their encounters), the Cerberous units
-The Guilded Knight fight is such a beautifully coreographed dance
-Companions (here's a tricky one) can be pretty annoying or an absolute unit by your side, it's a matter of choosing the correct companion for the correct area, plus their abilities must have synergy with your own equipped abilities.
-The combo-based combat: you don't need to always use an ability; dodge, parry and combo the hell out of enemies
-Different Blood Veils have different parry windows and some drain more ichor than others, making them specially useful for ranged attack bluilds ("ichor" is the equivalent of a magick pool, different builds have different limits and consumption effectiveness)
-The fact that you have to earn mastery over gifts by using the different blood codes in battle, which actually forces you to know the benefits of different builds (unless you have enough Awake resources to unlock mastery, which is not possible in your first run)

Conclussion: 70% of this game is trash, but the good parts of it more than makes up for the stupidity of that 70%. Give it a try, you might have a blast

Having played the entire game with a partner, I can safely say this game is worth it. Story is great and the boss fights are fun. It took us 28.7 hours to complete, but it was all worth it. 10/10.

As a non-enjoyer of souls-like games like myself, I'd say Code Vein is a pretty welcome entry into that world. There's a lot of elements in this game that casuals would be pretty happy about.

Hard in some parts but manageable overall (can even turn a little casual with a partner AI or not), great deal of customization and character building, different combat play styles, lots of enemy types.

The level design unfortunately can be poorly made especially with the infamous cathedral map. The presentation of the story through slow, sluggish memory sequences, how you have to collect memory fragments to unlock them and how these are tied to the four different endings is definitely something that felt extremely tedious and badly designed to me.

Overall a fun souls-game, just don't expect a great narrative experience. Fortunately I came here for the gameplay and not so much for the story.

The good:
  - Character art
  - Overall gameplay
  - Boss fights
  - Waves of aggroed monster invasions
  - Weapons
  - Overhead map & path tracking
  - The option to replay some boss-fights in depths
  - Memory walk
  - Voice acting
  - Offline mode
  - NPC co-op (insights)
The bad:
  - Level design
  - UI
  - Ranged classes
  - Repetetive enemies
  - Some dumb enemy AI 
  - Limited arsenal categorized into 4 main groups
  - No atmosphere
  - No pause even in offline mode
  - Main map
  - Disabled skills
  - NPC co-op (makes it too easy)
The ugly:
  - Loading corridors
  - An annoying sound loops in the background

Overall: Recommended for souls or anime lovers

Code Vein is an action role-playing game set in a post-apocalyptic world with its gameplay taking a heavy inspiration from both souls and god eater series.
  Pros:
1) Great unique anime style with fabulous music score by Go Shiina.
2) Decent gameplay with lots of mechanics to utilise. Thanks to the Blood Codes you can create any build you desire at any time with just a bit of resources and time. In addition to that, the game offers a number of companions with their distinctive playstyle and abilities to aid the protagonist on his journey and make it more lively.
3) Decent plot, characters and lore. [spoiler] Also is a God Eater spin off [/spoiler].
4) Various pleasant interactions at Home Base as well as additional gameplay content in the form of DLCs and Depths.
  Cons:
1) Occasional stutters and bugs during some fights with enemies leave an unpleasant aftertaste.
2) Due to the developers pushing the best ending so hard to the player, the direction of some otherwise really dramatic moments turns to some comic relief, which is a real shame.
3) NG+ difficulty philosophy is "One-shot them before they one-shot you", really bad decision which can be truly experienced by going for towers of trials while underleveled.
4) Some awful level design here and there. Can't imagine what might have led them to design Cathedral of Sacred Blood and Crypt Spire as they exist in the game.
5) Having to earn Dweller in the Dark ending two times with minor difference for all achivements is pretty stupid.
  Despite all the criticism it gets on the net, Code Vein is an overall nice game with some strong positive aspects and minor drawback. I believe, it deserves at least one playthrough  and wish for Code Vein to develop into the series with the second part reviewing the downsides of the first game to deliver a better experience.

I enjoyed playing, I'll play it again, for sure. But, there are a few things I would change about the game.

1. The game's difficulty curve is all over the place. It's not like a Souls game (even if that's the joke) in that it's very hard, it's like a Souls game in that you HAVE TO learn HOW to play it. This isn't a hack'n'slash that you can just pick up, no, you have to practice and THAT means there are areas that are harder or easier at random until you learn where they are and how to approach them. I'd prefer if the difficulty ramped up a little more evenly.

2. I wish there was more story to this game as it seems like there was meant to be more in several places.

3. bigger variety of weapons and weapon skills. Do yourself a favor, rely on your personal/gained skills. There's a LOT of magic use in this game. Not saying weapons are uselesss, but you're going to be using your magic skills more than your weapon skills at some point.

OTher than that, I'd love to see another title to follow-up on what this one tried to do.

Code Vein is... an experience. Oddly clunky, very rigid, far from Co-op friendly, a lackluster story and oversexualization of characters, I'm surprised at the amount of enjoyment I got from the game.

Being a souls-like means the game has a very steep learning curve, and the way it teaches you to play is by killing you. Time and time again. Which for me meant that I never really learnt how to play the game. I am a very experienced Dark Souls player, so learning how to time dodges and finding openings to attack came very naturally to me. I didn't beat the game as I dropped it due to losing interest, but I only died 4 or 5 times. I beat the Cathedral of sacred blood as well as the memories, and I'll probably come back to finish the game one day.

But for now, I'll leave it on the shelf. To me, it has the same issue that Dark Souls 2 had, the foundation of the game isn't strong enough. Movement is very slow, making a fast paced, dodge and punish playstyle harder to do than in Souls. Movement isn't 360 degrees and feels very rigid because of it, which is also reflected in attack animations being robotic and rigid.

I think the game would benefit from a remake or an update on a newer engine, for as unlikely as that is for a 4 year old game.

Honestly, this is my favourite game I've played for a while, so I may as well do this. I'll try to answer some questions I've seen people ask when they consider getting into it. 

Difficulty
- It's not that difficult for a Soulslike, but if you're not used to that style of gameplay you might be in for a bit of a learning curve. 
- Most people find that particular bosses are a lot more difficult than others. I beat some of the bosses in one attempt and others took dozens. 
- Sometimes you can figure out gift (ability) combos that cheese the boss easily, especially with a partner. 
- In terms of exploring, there's one area that's particularly bullshit and the rest are a lot more straightforward. 
- Part of the experience is the satisfaction at beating a tough challenge, in my personal opinion. If you don't find it rewarding to try something either repeatedly to learn patterns or from various angles to try different strategies, you might not find this game very rewarding. But you could still probably manage to get through it if you like the other elements. 

Gameplay
- It really doesn't feel the same as Dark Souls, besides having the same basic mechanics. You won't get significantly better at Dark Souls after playing this game unless this was your introduction to reflex-based games and you improved your reaction time. 
- It's not grindy. In fact, overlevelling can be slightly detrimental (but not as much as some people make it out to be). The main focus is finding a good build with your gifts (abilities) and upgrading your weapon and blood veil (gear) in different ways that fit your playstyle. 
- Your core gameplay loop is always the same throughout the game, but there's actually a lot of variation as to how you can play. Rushing in and trying to deplete the enemy's HP within a literal minute versus kiting them with venom - it can feel very different, and it's the most fun if you try every different style, in my opinion. 
- The game likes to reward completionists, as it seems, so be sure to explore every area if you want the best ending (and play through the game a few more times if you want all the endings). They don't seem to want you to rush through things. 

Plot
- People say it's cliché and meme on it for being "weeb souls", so be warned that it does have a lot of edgy anime tropes. But if you enjoy those, like me, you'll enjoy the plot too. 
- I've heard critique that you can pretty much guess the character archetypes as soon as their introductory scenes, but although the characters are indeed somewhat static, they're not too flat as you do uncover hidden sides of them as you discover their backstory through a gameplay mechanic - although, if you're genre-savvy enough, it's true that you may be able to predict them. 
- The fanservice is mainly in the visual designs of the characters and not their personalities, if that's something worth considering for you. 
- This may not be strictly plot, but the areas are beautiful and the cutscenes are nicely animated. Seriously, it's a better visual experience than some anime I've watched. 

Co-op
- Co-op is dogwater. I know it's a Soulslike and not meant to be multiplayer, but please, I just want to chill at the home base with my friends. 
- You cannot play with a friend if you haven't unlocked the area on your end (including on NG+). Or if you've already cleared the boss (Depths don't count, making it the only place you can hang out or farm for Marks of Honour). 
- There's a hard limit of only two PCs and one NPC companion, so if you have more than one friend who plays this game, you'll have to take turns interacting with each other. 
- If you're progressing through the whole game with a friend, beating a boss only counts on the host's side, so you'll have to do each area twice. 

Character Creator
- Literally THE best character creator I've ever seen, the eyebrows alone have more options than my future

Overall, I enjoyed this game because it vibed with my personal interests. Maybe if you're a bit like me, you'll enjoy it too.

Welp. 

I am the target audience for this game. I love vampires, post-apocalypse, anime, and weird horror. I even like souls type games as long as they are not as punishing. Such as Bloodborn being my fav in the genre (haven't played elden ring) AND YET this game gets a thumbs down from me. It's a case of a game having no quality control and getting in it's own way too much.

The vampires or....REVENANTS as they are called here are the whole story reason for why you can die and come back over and over. The story is just plain bad. There is plenty of overly dramatic anime moments but that's not the worst part at all. Aside from being complicated for no reason it also adds a mustache twirling bad guy at the very end for no discernable reason other than to reveal a TWIST that really wasn't needed and to give one of the characters more TRAUMA. lol

The world is very anime destroyed with giant spikes of....??? ripping the city you inhabit asunder. it's never revealed what really caused all the destruction. but hey! it's there and we deal. There's plenty of horror-ish elements in the form of body horror, gore, and general medical malpractice. Also the horror of developers fanservicing the body of characters that look underage. MIA LOOKS LIKE A CHILD Don't @ me.

all of that is pretty sad, but still serviceable for a game. it's the gameplay where it gets a big fat F.

No quality control at all. Hit boxes are all over the place. the camera....oh my god the camera. expect lots of tight corridors with HUGE monsters and the inability to SEE anything either cause the camera is blocked by SOMETHING or it's spinning uncontrollably cause you tried to target something. The starting bosses are insanely hard compared to later bosses which are....just easy? 

There are way too many blood codes (builds) and most of them are entirely useless except for maybe one skill in it. Speaking of skills and abilities and VESTIGAES (yet another mechanic of the game) these are never really explained as to how they affect the story. In fact you'll never know unless you google it or play it again and again yourself. This is my biggest gripe about the game. it doesn't explain anything. it's one thing to not explain the whole souls mechanic again for the 4000th time, but it's another to introduce entirely new mechanics to a game and just assume you'll figure it out. there's got to be a middle ground between treating players with baby gloves or GIT-GUD mentality.

Lastly, I played this game to the end and no one, NOT ONCE, gave Io a fucking t-shirt or sweater to wear over her ripped ass dress in that chilly fucking church. 

0/10

CODE VEIN is an easy game to get into if you're into the Soulsborne genre, all the key mechanics are there. The story is quite enjoyable (in my point of view) and it isn't shoved into your face, you have to dig deep to get to the sweet bits of lore concerning your companions and such.

Oh, did I mention? You have companions in this game, and they're quite fun to play around and experiment with (comes with the added benefit of making you feel less lonely!). The builds you can make are plenty, but not infinite due to how builds work in this game: You earn codes that act as pre-determined builds. You also get stylish armor which you can swap and upgrade as you please.

Character customization is another strength here - half of my time was practically spent making my character, the other half was finishing the game. There are simply so many options to choose from that it makes you struggle.

My only criticism would be the fact that enemies can get repetitive at times - but it is not too important, as they make up for it by varying the move sets just enough to throw you off and force you to adapt.

Not a must play for the Soulsborne fan, but this game will genuinely keep you entertained and make you love it in a matter of an hour or so. I love this game so much, and can't wait for the sequel.

I started playing Code Vein expecting it to be another Souls game but with waifus as a bonus, but boy was I wrong (not about the waifus though, they are fantastic). From the character creator (which I'm sure some people can easily spend over an hour just creating their character) to the atmosphere, visuals and story, everything was fantastic. Speaking of story, Code Vein has undoubtedly the best one among the Souls-like games imo. I suggest trying to find all the [spoiler] vestiges aka memories [/spoiler] to find out even more about the world, your companions, side characters,...
The only (minor) negative thing I can say about this game is that it can be more challenging than regular souls-game mainly because of its (kinda) different approach to classes & builds. For instance, leveling up does not increase your character's damage at all. But after figuring out how they work, there shouldn't be any further issues.

Highly recommended

This is kind of a letdown of a game. The combat is clunky and unreliable regardless of your skill level, the story is spotty and super cliche, the English VAs were so bad and cringe-edgy that I had to swap to Japanese just to tolerate it.

The two things I thought were very good about the game were the character customization (which is strictly cosmetic) and the music. Everything else is either completely mediocre or just bad.

Known bugs: Many will hate on this game because there is a serious glitch in the merchant windows that shows its head when you give multiple gifts to a npc at once then go to try and redeem your trade points for an item. The bug causes you to be stuck in the menu with 0 control input forcing you to ALT+F4. 

However there is an easy way to sidestep this from happening. Once you give all of your gifts, back out of the dialog and go rest at the mistle (It will take a moment for the option to be available due to the effects of the bug) then once you've done that, go back to the npc and trade away without an issue.

DLC: The dlc in this game is honestly a joke, it's just depth maps which are a very short adventure with no story and multiple boss encounters. Perks of this are additional vesitge parts, weapons, mats, etc. However the fact that these are dlc items makes me wish I had just bought the base game rather than spending the few extra bucks for the deluxe. 

All in all, not a bad game. There are two different endings to encounter but I won't spoil anything. Would be cool to see a sequel of this with more content.

Code Vein is an awesome action RPG with amazing anime-style visuals and a captivating story. The game features a diverse range of weapons and abilities that allow for exciting and strategic combat. The character customization is also top-notch, with a wide range of outfits and accessories to choose from. However, some parts of the game can be challenging, and it may take some time to master the combat mechanics. Overall, I highly recommend Code Vein to anyone looking for a thrilling RPG experience!

I have to admit, I’m not a huge fan of Soulslike games, and usually, I’m not very good at them, either, but this has one has been on my radar for a while now. I finally got to play it, and it was quite fun, even though it didn’t change my opinion about this specific genre.

The detailed customisation of your very own anime protagonist was definitely a nice touch (pity that they’re almost completely mute throughout the story…), and in general, I liked most of the characters, as well. The graphics and music/sounds were also cool, and the gothic-postapocalyptic setting was really unique. We also get a surprisingly complex plot with lots of terms and names, so you need to pay close attention to it – and let me tell you, we only scratch the surface of this world here, so there’s lots of stuff left to discover and explain in a potential sequel.

As for the gameplay, if you ever played a similar game, you know what you’re going to get. Don’t expect anything on the level of [i]Dark Souls[/i] or [i]Bloodborne[/i], of course, but still, even if you’re a pro, I believe you’ll find some of the bosses and levels quite challenging, not to mention the (in my opinion) overcomplicated skills system. Maybe it’s just me, but I found the difficulty crazy punishing… By the way, there’s also some replay value with the different endings, collectibles, and extra dungeons. 

I didn’t try the multiplayer features, so I can’t comment on those, but the single-player experience, despite its shortcomings, is something I can recommend to all Soulslike and/or anime fans.

Bought this game because I like soulslikes and I like anime, so I figured this would be a good combo, but I was off the mark.

Firstly, I beat this game without a partner, which is choosing to suffer, so take this review with a grain of salt. With that however, the difficulty is optional, which isn't unique to games but is different for a souls game. The partnership system takes away any intimacy you can have with an enemy, you don't have to learn the intricacies of a boss or the tells of their attacks if your partner can take their aggro and demolish their HP while the boss is aggro on you. It took me 1 try to beat a boss it took 10 tries to defeat solo.

The boss design varies, there were a few fun fights but it is abundantly clear that they allowed flaws in their boss design because the partnership system weighs the fights too heavily in the players favour. There are bosses in this game that have zero tells on their attacks yet the attacks clean out your entire health bar. I have two requirements for souls bosses, and that is: good tells that aren't overly obvious or cruel, and the ability to allow the player to breath to assess their situation every now and then, these bosses are relentless with almost none, to no tells. However, as I said, there were a few fun fights in this game, and some of the bosses could be fixed if you could just remove one horrible attack.

The weapons system is just abysmal, I found a weapon in level 3 that stuck with me the entire game, all weapons are super close in damage regardless of where you find them, the weapons in the end-game level are worse than the early-game ones. Progression is poor, to the point levelling up costs you 100,000 souls or 'haze', but grants you +2 attack.

The only thing I can say about the level design in this game is 'big corridors' and 'destroyed city in different colours', so don't expect much there.

The biggest and most detrimental factor to my enjoyment of this game however, is inconsistency. It is plagued with inconsistency in every facet, to the fact you are fighting enemies from the first level, in the last level, except they have a ton of health, or sometimes attacks land, sometimes they don't, sometimes your magic hits an enemy and stuns them, sometimes it won't, sometimes your weapon reaches the enemy, sometimes it's a toothpick. The enemies may be unique to their environment, or they are the same generic enemies you see everywhere. If you press dodge, 90% of time you will dodge the attack, but the 10% will show its face and kill you at the worst place for it to.

This game caused me a lot of grief, and by the end, I was too committed to put it down, it wasn't a completely bad experience, the title screen blew me away deviously. But, there are good aspects to this game, the unique abilities you have are great when you are allowed to use them creatively, the items were fun and interesting, and the story was great for 3/4ths of the game. All I can say is, buy this game if you're looking for a downgraded anime Dark Souls that you will mess around with, and play with the AI partners, but if you're looking for a decent soulslike, look elsewhere.

-Oyun girişinde karakter tasarım kısmını çok beğendim detaylı ve güzel.
-Oyunun grafiklerini ve sanatsallığını beğendim
-Vuruş hissiyatı ve oynanış güzel
-Sinematik kısımlardaki hikaye anlatımı güzel
-Harita içersinde ilerlerken daha önce gezdiğin yerlerin haritada iz bırakacak şekilde belli olması güzel

15 saat oynadıktan sonra Olumsuz Gördüğüm Kısımlar:

Hikayenin gidişatı gereği bazı anıları oyun içinde kısmi oyun gibi yapılmış bir bölümde yürüyerek yaşıyoruz bu kısımlar biraz kafa karıştırıcı olmuş. Çok dikkatli okumayan birisi önemli yerleri kaçırabilir bu yüzden ana hikaye kurgusunun daha oturaklı ve anlaşılır gitmesini tercih ederdim.

Evet haritada çözmemiz gereken şeylere saygı duyuyorum, ancak bazen işler öyle bir hal alıyorki açılmamış bir haritada resmen samanlıkta iğne arıyoruz ve uzun süre karmaşık haritada o dikkatli toplamak göreceli olarak çok zor. Harita canavar ve boss kestiğimiz zaman bir şekilde kendini oynatıyor, ancak iş kör bir yerde doğru yolu bulmaya geldiğinde o harita iyice yavan bir oyun deneyimi sunuyor, çünkü keşfetmeye değer ögeler barındırmıyor.




Negatif Kısımlara henüz odaklanmadım oyunu tamamladıktan sonra negatif gördüğüm kısımları eklemeyi planlıyorum. İlk defa Dark Souls benzeri bir oyun oynayan birisi olarak indirimde döneminde aldığım fiyatı düşündüğümde fiyatının hakkını verecek bir oyun gibi duruyor.

They had the Dark Souls formula and somehow still screwed it up.

Roll animations are terrible.
Extremely shallow level up system (can't level up specific stats).
Playing with a partner makes the game a complete joke.
Playing without a partner and playing a strength build makes the Ornstein and Smough fight completely unfair due to the fact that both of them have ranged attacks and can stun-lock you easily.
Speaking of which, the armor is basically useless as it does nothing defensively nor does it give you enough poise to properly play a strength build.
If you play a strength or heavyweight build you are stuck fat-rolling for probably the entire game since you can't manually increase your carry weight outside of the blood code that you choose.
The voice acting is terrible (except for Mido, that VA did pretty well) but maybe it's just because I played it in English instead of Japanese.
Everything is so overly dramatic for no reason, the smallest revelation results in a soliloquy that goes on for five minutes when it has been blaringly obvious for the last two hours of the game.

 The important question though: was it fun?
Yes, I did have fun. But Jesus Christ, there are so many mostly minor issues that it compiles into an amalgamation of refuse.

Worth 15$ or less. Don't bother with the DLC.

I almost enjoyed this game. The story is interesting, characters are not annoying and its fun listening/watching the memories fallen and present characters. Its like the other half of the team forgot they had to make a game with a fun battle system...

Story/Characters/Map(good): The story is by far the best thing about this game. If that's all you care about go for it. You are remnants of a human civilization.  Waking up as your own character you've created, you adventure on with a big bosom sidekick. All the characters you discover fit the role are decent in their purpose a few stand out as cool. Surprisingly they didn't mess up the voice acting, I couldn't believe not one annoying voice for 50 hours of this game. Map design looks amazing and with the sound effects give the area its feel.

Gameplay/Map(bad)/leveling: Now this is when it takes a turn for the worst. You start with a weak tutorial and get thrown in a tough game. Their are a bunch of ways to spec your character in, not so much in the beginning but as you get going it gets overwhelming and confusing. Some are limited to certain weapons and moves and while others are just useless. I beat the whole game as Ranger and should be an achievement on its own (I don't recommended). This is how bad the fighting is you need a companion to beat almost anything  and theirs only one that can hang all the others will die in a few hits. Is it my class? That shouldn't be the reason if it is why make so many of them ? Healing can be so dumb, very slow and you have a great chance of being hit again, not fun when your character is made of glass. Attacking can get you locked in a combo so you can't stop and get hit. You have pretty much 3 class of enemies. Grunt style enemies, some tougher than others, Boss fights which some are beyond ridiculous. I'm all about a challenge but when its just broken and not fun, you have to ask what are we doing here ? The third is the map. The bad side of it. They make it where you can fall off, get ambush or be affected by a affliction. Some map designs are beyond confusing  and you can tell that the people who made it need some help with their personal life. Now the final nail in the coffin. When you die you lose your exp. Although you have a chance to get it back but if you die that's it all gone, just like some of your real life.

Inside this madness game play/ map, is a gem of a game. With a revamp in some battle mechanics and common sense things. The specializing and leveling system needs a K.I.S.S. (keep it simple stupid). They have some neat ideas with a solid foundation. I'm sure if they listen, take a step back, look at what should be better/funner, the sequel Code Artery will be a huge success !

Don’t buy it at full price.

So I bought this game during a sale which made it around ~$9 I think. I only bought it because I had just received my Steam Deck and wanted to play a game very similar to Dark Souls, but none of the Souls’ were on sale during the Spring Sale. 

Overall, it is a fun game. The combat is really cool which is really all I was looking for. The different Blood Codes, weapons, and armors are fun to play around with too.

The bad: You know the most annoying parts of Dark Souls? This game has fun levels/areas that take those annoyances and set them to 1000. This game mostly copies the Souls formula, but when they try to be unique, it shows…in the worst way possible. I would’ve liked this game more if they had stuck more to being a complete clone of Dark Souls. Now the most annoying part, the cutscenes. Oh the cutscenes…should’ve just released a companion movie for how long this game’s cutscenes are. I really wanted to watch them but I just could not stand watching a slow-moving cutscene with weird dialogue for 20 minutes at a time. It really did detract from the experience cause the cutscenes usually had important information about where to go next in order to progress. Luckily, google and Youtube exist to help you out there. So seriously, just skip the cutscenes. My only other main complaint was how it felt too easy to get high-leveled and the enemy scaling was pretty abysmal. I would mow through the new areas with a breeze and then get smacked by the boss. The only time the enemies are scaled well is endgame. 

I wanted a soulslike game with cool combat and at its bare bones this is it. But only get it on a deep sale, if not just buy Dark Souls.

Right, Code Vein. What a game. Code Vein is the only Souls-like game I've ever finished... Its fantastic and unique story kept the experience entertaining throughout with each side character and enemies story being explained/developed, some better than others but they are all awesome and really flesh out the world. Its combat is also great with hundreds of abilities without being too overwhelming. The sound design and music are absolutely banging! The setting is post-apocalyptic yet somewhat dull, but this only enhances the world's devastation. On my first play-through, the game was very hard, but on my second play, things became significantly easier as this game rewards you for knowledge of the game and its subsequent combat systems, which can be somewhat hard to understand but after a while, it will feel very smooth. A few nitpicks are the controls, I play on PC and personally, the default controls are horrendous and needed like 20 mins of tweaking to make them better, and there are a few clipping issues with cosmetics and clothes but they are not too big of a deal; The game runs very smoothly with the only lag I experienced was going between zones (Only happened twice). Multiplayer is absolutely crap, but it's a very fun single-player experience. 
Overall I suggest you try Code Vein especially if you're looking for a fun combat system with a good story, probably not the best game to play with friends and try to get it when it's on offer in case you don't like it. (Oh and BTW the customisation is actually mind-blowing!!!)

A very very pretty game that is genuinely awful. Don't even play this if you get it for free, it's just terrible.

The designers once watched a trailer for a Dark Souls game, didn't even finish the whole thing and decided they could make a competent game. Surprisingly, they could not.

Between hitboxes and animations not matching up even in the slightest and absurd levels of damage and HP on enemies, the game just becomes a tedious slugfest.

There is no nuance here, you will just get extremely bored of the repetitive, poorly designed enemies. If you do ever make the extremely poor decision to play this game, save yourself the trouble just load up on a cheap oneshot build or something that gives you the only usable Quick speed dodge - because the iframes of all the other dodges are useless - and brute force your way to the end.

But to reiterate, don't play it, not even for free. Not even if someone pays you.

It's a pretty good game and for the most part it's well balanced. It has good build variety through the blood codes and even with the weapons all feeling very similar it isn't much of a problem. Beyond this bosses generally feel very fair though without a partner bosses become significantly harder but still feel very fair with the exception of the Blade Bearer and Cannoneer becoming pure pain and suffering without a partner. The visuals of levels are pretty good but the optional side dungeons called The Depths are all very samey. Additionally there are just the same copy paste enemies everywhere with versions that have higher stats in later areas which feels a bit lazy but it's still fine as new enemies get introduced sometimes. 

Where the game design fails though I would say is in the three dlc areas which have over inflated stats for every enemy and the main boss of each dlc is equally ridiculous so the dlc definitely gives an air of extreme post game rather than something you can do coming off of the final boss. Which needless to say is not the recommended way to handle dlc without challenges that act as a reasonable middle ground between them. The game's story is flat and the word blood is said every two seconds so it just gets very silly and getting actually invested is hard as such. 

Lastly the best part of the game is the character creator. You can access it at any time from the home base and it is probably the best character creator I've seen in a game whose focus wasn't on character creation. The character creator isn't good for someone who doesn't like an anime style though so it isn't for everyone. That could be said for the entire game actually. It's a good well designed game for the most part but unless you like the anime style an very edgy nature of the game it probably isn't for you. But if you do like that you'll have a good time. It's Anime Dark Souls/10

Not a bad game, it´s just too "meh".

Combat is repetitive, enemies are all the same with little variety. Leveling up or upgrading gear does not make you feel better (stats do change ofc, but the feeling of getting stronger isn´t there). Story and worldbuilding is sort of ok, but anime characters just don´t fit there. However, I´m not denying that female characters were nice to look at...

Worst part is level design. While levels alone are fine but nothing special, world layout does not make any sense. For instance, you are in snowy mountains, then you run maybe 30 seconds thru few hallways that serve as level transition, and then boom, you are in a burning city. If you look around, there is no trace of mountains you were at earlier. After burning city level, you go on foot to sand city and again, if you look back behind map borders where you basically came from, there is no hint of burning city. So in the end, everything is randomly sticked together.

All put together, every part of Code Vein is average at best, and has more cons than pros.

[table]    [tr]        [th]one of the better Souls-likes out there. decent combat, character customization, excellent build variety – buy it… if you can stomach obnoxious anime tropes (I'm not kidding, some characters are dressed *really* inappropriately).[/th]    [/tr]    [tr]        [td]I first played this off Steam when it came out, but stopped after ~30 hours. then, several years later, I must've developed some sort of tolerance for anime nonsense, because I bought the game (on sale), and racked up over 150 hours of play time. no regrets ¯\_(ツ)_/¯[/td]    [/tr]    [tr]        [td]this is a neat game, if you go in with correct expectations, and can get past its shortcomings. many of the weapons have bad movesets, some just have bad stats, but once you start getting the weapons that you enjoy using, as well as decent blood codes (character classes, which can be switched on a whim – another great feature!), everything clicks. in my opinion, Code Vein does the whole "weapon art" thing better than any game made by From Software, since you actually gain the required resource from fighting, rather than it being restricted to a couple of refills.[/td]    [/tr]    [tr]        [td]the story is okay, nothing special, despite the absurdly dramatic presentation and endless exposition (most of which is optional, though). "an average shonen-type anime" – that's a good way to describe it. don't expect anything particularly profound or nuanced. get in the grove, make your character look as edgy as possible, and enjoy the ridiculousness.[/td]    [/tr]    [tr]        [td]a quick note about the DLCs: I recommend buying them, but *only* on sale, and *only* in bulk – aside from new bosses (*one* per DLC) and a few new blood codes, there's hardly any new content. all three expansions are extremely short dungeons made from existing assets, and only the third one resembles an actual level, instead of an extended foyer before the main boss arena. the bosses are what makes them worthwhile, especially the first one, Hellfire Knight – my favorite fight in the whole game, and the only one that feels like it truly belongs in a Souls-like game, since you actually to have learn its moves before you can defeat it.[/td]    [/tr][/table]

Some people may say it's anime dark souls, well, it's half-true. It's more like dumb souls-like like Nioh, where you're frail one-hit dude while all bosses are fat strong tough monsters. It has a bit different mechanics, so you shall to adopt or drop.

Like, first couple of bosses are hard like hell, because you have no good damage, but just bit later you nuke all others till you meet anime Ornstein and anime Smough, and after them - Mido. Lore is good, plot is 'anime friendship'. Like it because I want to like, dislike it by story style. 
Also I see that game is similar to Bloodborne by it's gameplay (but somehow better, looks like devs reconsidered some points of BB mechanics, and made it better), and I can recommend to those who like Bloodborne.

CODE VEIN is a fun and engaging action RPG developed by Bandai Namco that draws heavily from the Dark Souls series and Elden Ring. While the game's combat system and mechanics feel very similar to those of its inspiration, it still manages to be an enjoyable experience.

The gameplay in CODE VEIN is challenging and rewarding, with a focus on exploration, strategic combat, and character progression. The game's difficulty level is high, requiring players to master the intricacies of the combat system and learn from their mistakes to progress. The bosses are particularly challenging, with each one presenting a unique and formidable foe to overcome.

The customization options in CODE VEIN are also impressive, allowing players to fully customize their character's appearance, abilities, and weapons. This adds a personal touch to the game and encourages experimentation with different playstyles.

However, one cannot deny that the game's mechanics and systems feel like a direct copy of those in the Dark Souls series and Elden Ring. From the stamina-based combat system to the bonfire-like checkpoints, the similarities are impossible to ignore. This may be a turnoff for some players who are looking for a more original experience.

Despite this, CODE VEIN manages to be a fun and enjoyable game in its own right. The story is engaging and the world is beautifully designed, with a dark and atmospheric aesthetic that draws you in. The game's co-op mode is also a welcome addition, allowing you to team up with other players and take on the challenges together.

In conclusion, CODE VEIN may feel like a copy of the Dark Souls series and Elden Ring, but it still manages to be a fun and engaging game. If you're a fan of challenging action RPGs and don't mind the similarities to its inspirations, then CODE VEIN is definitely worth a look..

1: The story is pretty much you're basic Anime story trope, If you like God Eater I'd recommend (it take's place in the God Eater universe)!

4: Gameplay is near Fantastic. (I've beat it on xbox and here on pc)
5: Queenslayer items feel too weak for being used to fight the Queen!
6: The world is gorgeous, the weapon's are really dope (aesthetic wise), Graphic's are gorgeous for being anime style.
7: No Difficulty options, so if you hate challenges dont play, but if you love a challenge i'd highly recommend!
8: Campanion's feel a bit overpowered at time's.
9: Animation's at time's feel ganky (if you use mods).
10: Boss's feel like a boss, unless you have a one shot build.
11: the multiplayer can be utter garbage at time's (mostly do to the fact that the developer's pretty much said no updates to the servers), Level design can be a bit confusing, that's why you can send a distress signal.
                 THESE ARE MY OPINIONS! if you disagree please tell me.

Coming back to this game after playing Elden Ring and replaying the DS trilogy, I guess I'm just spoiled by things making sense because this game is worse than Dark Souls 2 in a lot of aspects. Beating this load of shxt for the 3rd time has only cemented my hatred. Don't get me wrong the first blind playthrough was pretty fun, but you quickly realize how empty and meaningless 80% of the content is. Every area uses the same scrub enemies and the same elites. The amount of times you can get combo'd by the environment to death happens way to often. Most elite enemies can completely invalidate you guarding regardless of poise, guard boost, and physical defense. Most bosses have extremely hard to dodge combos that will drain your health before you can roll out of it amongst also dealing 60 - 80% of your health in one hit (even with the highest defense armors) Weapons look cool but are extremely weak or niche in application. You'll quickly find that this game favors strength builds as the "big smackem' do big damage" strategy tends to work the best. The best defense is more offense. I really wanted to like this game but its so frustratingly bad in so many critical areas I just cant see this as being fun.

- Souls-like combat

Cons:

- I feel that stamina should be restoring faster than it is, sometimes I'm just standing there and waiting for stamina to refill

Overall get it if you are desperately looking for different souls-like game, or it's on sale, or you really like style and characters

TL;DR, Had some fun parts, but in the end it's a no for me due to level design and world feel. 

The game started out pretty fun, but lost it's enjoyment after a few hours. I play soulslike's and the combat in this is good, but I think the problem was the level design. the game is actually decently long, and it felt like hour after hour of the same hallways with either rock, or concrete, or ice walls. I think that's why it didn't hit the mark for me. I never knew how important intriguing level design was for me before this. I hate to give any bad reviews but I'm reviewing the games I beat now and this one just wasn't fun for me.

I want to like this game. I really do.

It's main problem comes from the combat being so... inconsistent. 

Sometimes you can backstab enemies by attacking them from behind, Sometimes you can hit them in the back five times and nothing happens. Sometimes you can backstab them from the side or even from the front.

Sometimes attacks do so little damage you can face tank and button mash through a new area, sometimes you get one-shot by an attack with no wind-up. Sometimes enemies have so little health you one shot every thing in an area, sometimes basic enemies take multiple fully charged heavy attacks to kill.

Sometimes you dodge in the direction you are moving in, sometimes you dodge in a random-feeling direction based on where the enemy you are locked onto is. Sometimes you get stunlocked to death after getting hit once, sometimes you randomly don't get stunned at all.

Sometimes the bosses are very fun and feel like a genuine test of skill that rewards studying their moveset and learning from each attempt, sometimes they feel like nonsensical BS where you throw yourself into the meatgrinder until they stop spamming an undodgable insta-kill move... sometimes the bosses are such a pathetic joke that you go "Wait, it's over already? What does this boss even do, again?" 

Sometimes the game is genuinely fun and a great time, other times it is completely miserable. It's a mixed bag, and the good does not outweigh the bad. Just go replay Dark Souls 1 instead.

Anime Dark Souls?
No, these two games cannot be compared, they are similar only in a few mechanics that Dark Souls has. This is a part of God Eater. But the game remains just as atmospheric and interesting, beautiful and masterpiece music, good story, deep and sad character stories, VERY COOL CHARACTER CUSTOMIZATION (I spent 2 hours creating a character), cool weapons (although there are not so many of them), also cool mechanics, well-made game world, which was very interesting to explore, and also from the big advantages you can lie on the lap of a girl.
This game can be both easy and difficult at the same time, if you exclude the help of an ally, then the difficulty of many enemies can be equated to the difficulty of enemies from Dark Souls.
Also, this game has a very interesting mechanic in the form of "Ichor", which is something like mana, but it can be obtained from killing enemies (and backsteps). 
And also a very interesting mechanic called "Blood codes"
Throughout the game, players will unlock what is effectively classes that govern what abilities and spells can be used, known as Blood Codes. Each code offers a set of abilities and skills that can be unlocked for use with other codes in a sort of mix and match style, by either having them equipped with the class or outright buying them out. The codes also affect other combat abilities, such as the armor and weapons one can equip, and what spells/buffs can be used. Essentially, each Blood Code has its own letter grade in a given category and as long as the ability/spell requirements fit, and it has been unlocked, you can use it! Some abilities and spells are just locked to their parent code and can’t be shared, usually for game balance purposes.
I was also shocked by the designer of the location "Cathedral of the Sacred Blood" alternative to "Anor Londo" from Dark souls remastered, but how difficult this location is with mazes, I hope the designer of this level will have a house with such mazes.
In general, the game is very, very good (in my opinion).
but there are also disadvantages like "the character does not feel the weight of the weapon" or "hair is visible in some moments through the clothes" or "you can't skip a scene".
This is only my opinion about this game.

As I delved into the dark, vampiric world of Code Vein, I couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement and anticipation. From the very first moments of the game, I was entranced by the stunning visuals and the deep, immersive lore that surrounded me.

But it wasn't just the aesthetics that drew me in - the gameplay itself was incredibly satisfying. With a wide range of weapons and abilities to choose from, I was able to tailor my character's abilities to my own unique playstyle. Whether I was unleashing devastating combos with my trusty sword or blasting my enemies with powerful spells, every encounter felt like a thrilling battle of wits and skill.

And the enemies themselves were no slouches, either. From hulking beasts to nimble assassins, every enemy presented a unique challenge that required me to stay on my toes and be ready for anything.

But what really set Code Vein apart was its narrative. With a complex, multi-layered story that explored themes of redemption, sacrifice, and the dangers of power, I found myself deeply invested in the world and its characters. And the fact that I could interact with these characters and influence the course of the story only added to the sense of agency and immersion.

All in all, Code Vein was a thrilling, engaging experience that left me hungry for more. Whether you're a fan of action-packed combat or thought-provoking storytelling, this game is not to be missed.

This game is a very good souls-like and while it may not particularly challenging save for no partners, the game is absolutely gorgeous, the enemies, enviornments, and the weapons all have that souls appeal and charm to them whilst being original to the formula. A big thing about this game that's also amazing in terms of quality is the character creator, never have I seen a more fun and complex creator ever in the history of me playing games. The partners AI is...debatable from being either really good or npc in a GTA game that gets molly-whopped. But all of that is well and good because you shouldn't rely on them so much anyways. The story in this game is pretty good too, not the best I've heard but a pretty good one all things considered.

The only complaint I have and that might stop people from playing is the Cathedral of the Sacred Blood, that area is not only massive, but the enemies in there are not the greatest to say the least all of them (except the common bad guy or the large enemy) know how to teleport onto your position, this isn't particularly a new concept but when you run through and several enemies start teleporting onto you and deal immediate damage, to new players this may come off as annoying and frustrating. I personally know people who dropped the game at this exact point because of the enemies. So be wary about the Cathedral.

Engaging narrative and character customization options held back by clunky combat and awful level design.

CODE VEIN is an action RPG where the player takes control of a custom-created Revenant - an undead human who needs to feed on living human blood in order to survive. The game boasts a wide variety of features, such as a fully voice-acted narrative, high-octane real-time combat, multitudes of options for customizing your character, and a wide variety of environments to explore, but only about half of these meet an acceptable standard of quality, making for a clunky and inconsistent experience.

Starting with the things the game does well, it must be noted that the character customization options in this game are phenomenal. An extremely detailed character creator allows players to design almost any type of human they can think of, and a plethora of costumes and accessories allow them to give their characters a unique sense of style. Throughout the game, players will acquire "blood codes" - combat archetypes through which new skills can be unlocked. By obtaining many blood codes, players can obtain a multitude of skills that result in thousands upon thousands of different ways to build their character's combat prowess, and the game makes it easy to change skills and stats at any time, encouraging experimentation.

Additionally, the game's narrative is interesting and manages to stay engaging throughout its ~25-hour main story, in spite of having a silent protagonist. The supporting characters are well-developed and have relatable struggles that they learn to overcome. The blocking and direction of the cutscenes are cinematic, and the voice actors' performances range from great to serviceable. Tons of lines of dialogue were recorded for the player's companions, who appropriately react to the player's actions during gameplay, deepening immersive feeling.

Although it's incredibly satisfying to experiment with different combat loadouts, the actual combat of CODE VEIN is pretty hit-or-miss. Players obtain "ichor" by landing basic attacks on enemies that they can later spend to unleash their powerful skills, which keep battles more interesting than they would be if players could spam their strongest skills all the time. However, enemies deal high damage, move quickly, and many of their attacks launch with breakneck speed and little wind-up, requiring the player to sometimes predict when to dodge in advance of an attack instead of reacting to an wind-up with a dodge, which creates a frustrating experience. Furthermore, many skills and actions the player can take during combat have significant animation locks, easily punished by the quick attacks from enemies, which can discourage the use of many interesting combat options the players have. With practice, players can circumvent these issues, but they create a steep learning curve that feels more irritating to climb than it does satisfying. The game is difficult in ways that aren't intuitive, and learning how to account for this is a long part of the process to "get good" at it.

The design of CODE VEIN's levels are, unfortunately, inexcusably terrible. Aesthetically speaking, most areas in CODE VEIN look aesthetically identical, save for some slight changes to the color palette between ruined cities or monochrome cathedrals. Many levels are very confusing to navigate; although there is a map that tracks the player's movement through a level to help them see where they've been and where they have yet to go, the map does a poor job at communicating vertical differences and there are often very few environmental details for players to use as landmarks as they navigate identical looking empty hallways and corridors. Enemy and trap placement are interesting at first, but quickly become repetitive and predictable due to how little differences there are between one level and the next (with a few exceptions).

There could be a fantastic game somewhere within CODE VEIN's programming, but unfortunately it's muddled by its desire to copycat the industry leader in the ARPG genre instead of standing on its own original ideas and mechanics. Overall, I enjoyed my time with CODE VEIN, but I probably wouldn't recommend it to most players; only to people who have a passion for dark, punishing ARPGs that allows them to look past the inconsistent combat and poor level design.
