There's a lot to love about this game, from the characters to souls-like combat. The game is difficult in all the right ways, combat is tight, skills can make or break fights, and of course, healing has to be done strategically. The character customization makes things quite enjoyable as well with how in depth it goes. Performance wise, I rarely had any issues and could even play it (well!) on laptop, which was a pleasant surprise, and the story is pretty engaging! I bought this during the sale and got my money's worth and more! DEFINITELY give it a shot, if not the game, then at least the demo!

I have close to a combined 1,700 hours in other soulslikes games, mainly those developed by FromSoftware--of which this game clearly intends to mimic--and I can say with complete certainty that Code Vein is an abject degradation of the genre.

What few strengths this game has, mainly character customization and build variety, are marred and shadowed by absolutely atrocious level design, convoluted and relatively uninteresting plot design, canned and forcefully overdramatic dialogue that contributes neither meaningful world development nor character depth, and game balance that veers near the edge of unplayability.

If you are someone coming from another soulslike (probably Elden Ring), I implore you to choose almost literally any other major soulslike title, for this one will, with complete certainty, ruin your mood of the genre and leave a lasting, unforgivably sour taste in your mouth. And if you do decide to buy it, for whatever reason you may have, disregard the rules of "blind playthroughs" and just look up a walkthrough for Cathedral of the Sacred Blood. Trust me.

Bosses range from legitimately fun, interesting, and enjoyably challenging to masochistically absurd and zealously artificial, and usually fall in the banal category of forgettable and unenjoyable. The environmental design and level layout is, at times, a callback to some of the better-designed areas of Dark Souls 1-3 that leaves genuine joy within you to discover its secrets, but most often are either semi-linear at best or infuriatingly confusing at worst, with the majority of areas having the exact same layout throughout the entire zone, meaning your only hope of having even a fraction of a chance of making it to the end is somehow trying to make sense of the barely helpful minimap that has become nothing but hundreds of little dots across a half-graphed landscape of lines and curves that still do not even begin to provide an idea of where to go next.

At its absolute best, Code Vein is a simplified rehashing of a bad Bloodborne clone. At its worst, it's a shameful and incomprehensibly bad replication of some of the greatest games of all time.

Just because Bandai Namco publishes FromSoftware's games doesn't mean they have the slightest idea why FromSoftware's games work.

A fantastic role playing game, whose unique style of models and textures are quite attractive to the eye. The game is certainly a must play if you're a JRPG fan full of epic moves to help take down even the toughest foes while looking stylish! Watch out, though! This game is quite punishing like the Dark Souls and other similar games. The differences between the battle systems and enemies though can throw you off your game however. So be warned! This game is NOT a Souls game. But it punishes you like one.

Pros:
- Interesting game environments that are both beautiful and hazardous. From dreary dungeons full of foes and obstacle to environments that sap your ability to fight.

- Your game, your way. Take advantage of the Blood Codes which act like insta-builds together with abilities from others to come up with your own unique build that can take down even the greatest of foes in one blow, or become a devilish maelstrom taking down crowds of the Lost!

-Charge forth alone or grab other Players online or NPC partner for offline fun!

- Get to know your friends and their stories as you take them through their memories while unlocking their own abilities for your own!

- Challenging yet very rewarding. The game severely punishes you for mistakes, with ever more powerful foes and obstacles. But pushing forward and exploring every nook can yield useful items and powers!

- An immersive story with multiple endings. Determine the fate of you and your friends. Find your tiny bit of paradise in this world-turned-hell.

Cons:
- Game is not optimized well. While certainly playable at max settings on even lower end cards, be wary of CTD over longer sessions. Save frequently via resting at Mistles.

- Story while certainly interesting does leave a number of loose ends.

- DLC, while entertaining, only consists of boss fights with little lore value. Go for it only if you are a fan of God Eater or truly love Code Vein.

- Although the game can be solo-ed, most of the area mobs and bosses were designed with co-op in mind. Without atleast an NPC partnering you, the game can feel very unbalanced and unfair.

Honestly, I started off hating this game, and it still sucks in many way, but there is something about it that kept me coming back. It was the anime aesthetic and best girl Mia.

Bad parts: 
The combat is a good bit worse than dark souls as animations are a bit more stiff, and enemy variety is really limited.
The level design is pretty bland except a couple of the end game areas, best bet is to just traverse the level by always turning left at an intersection.
The story is very anime which might be a turn off for some people but not to me, figured I would mention it here too.
Dialogue proceeds rather slowly and there is a lot of "dead air" between voiced lines.
The game does not respect your time due to above, slow "walking cutscenes" (which are optional) and the terrible time wasting achievements.
There is too much blatant boobage for my tastes.

The Good:
Character customization is really good if anime edge is what you want.
The story is surprisingly heartfelt and engaging, its take on (essentially) vampires feels reasonably unique.
Characters are fun
I personally really like the AI partner system, both in the help they give in battle and the small quips they make during exploration (though you can play without companions, and turn off the exploration quips). 
Creating builds is incredibly easy as there is a ton to choose from, and respecing can be done at literally any time.
Active and passive skills and buffs feel incredibly useful and are a ton of fun (and are flashy and cool, which makes up for the fact that normal attack animations are less interesting).

Overall a solid 7.5/10

Code Vein is not Dark Souls. It lacks the polished combat and stellar world design of the legendary franchise. However, it makes up for these things with its brilliant character customization, a deep narrative with twists and turns, and skills and abilities that challenge the player to defeat enemies in a way they never would have thought of before. Code Vein is a stylish JRPG that just falls short in a few areas. Its inspirations are clearly worn on its sleeve, but it brings enough to the table to stand out on its own. If you're a soulslike fan, Code Vein should be played.

PROS:
✓ In-depth character customization
✓ Memorable story
✓ Gorgeous anime art
✓ Blood Codes and their distinct Gifts offer plenty of customization and flexibility
✓ Interesting level design encourages exploration
✓ Approachable Souls-like with helpful tutorials
✓ Ease of travel between locations

CONS:
- Recycled enemies
- Enemies are too static and don’t provide meaningful challenge
- Clunky combat
- The environmental visual design is meh
- Forgettable boss fights

Anime Dark Souls.

Combat is good, having less weapon types means combat isn't as varied, but the many different abilities/gifts help make up for that. Exploration is good, lots of beautiful post-apocalyptic scenery, with items you find being single use items with some weapons/armors sprinkled around. Graphics are good, though I do recommend installing mods to bump up lighting and the like if you have a decent PC. Has a much more in your face/direct story than Dark Souls. Characters/NPCs are middling at best when compared to the NPCs of Dark Souls, very much your stereotypical action anime characters. Not to say that's a bad thing, but don't go in expecting Dark Souls-like characters. Character creation is great, with my only gripe being the number of outfits to choose from and body types/parameters. Enemy design is good, not as varied as Dark Souls. Bosses are good, I'd say just as good as Dark Souls if not tougher, but lacking much of the charm that comes with the backstories of Dark Souls bosses. 

A good game that'll scratch your Dark Souls itch, or if you like anime, but don't expect it to rival Dark Souls.

Code Vein is a game that promised to deliver a Souls-like experience, but unfortunately fails to live up to that expectation. The quest design in the game is disappointing, lacking the depth and creativity that players expect from a Souls-style game. The developers seem to have misinterpreted what makes the Souls franchise so successful, and as a result, the game feels like a shallow imitation of the original.

Despite these shortcomings, the game does have some redeeming features. The character design details in Code Vein are truly exceptional, and the level of detail in each character is impressive. The intricate designs and attention to detail are some of the best aspects of the game and help to make the characters feel unique and memorable.

The graphics in Code Vein are average at best, and the music is also unimpressive. While the graphics are not bad, they are not particularly impressive either, and the same can be said for the soundtrack. The audio design fails to captivate the player and adds little to the overall experience of the game.

In conclusion, Code Vein is a game that is let down by its quest design and the misinterpretation of the Souls-like concept by the developers. While the character design details are excellent, the average graphics and unimpressive music make the game feel unfulfilling. If you're looking for a challenging and engaging Souls-style game, there are many other options available that offer better gameplay and a more satisfying experience.

However, I recommend it as its brings fresh air to anime-styled games by adding a Souls-like flavor.

Soo first of all I am a huge Souls Fan!
Code Vein is in my opinion the second best souls like I have played just after Hellpoint.

The game has a way more linear map Design which helps to collect items without looking for youtube videos explaining how to get this specific item. If you explore every way you see, you will easily find all the memory parts (used in this game to unlock lore as well as more skills). Although some maps are so damn confusing cause everything looks the same you can literally run in circles.

You dont spend skill points per level up like in standard souls like games but you get more HP, Stamina and DMG per LvL.
Instead your armor (its just 1 armor piece) and the Blood Code (class) you equip determine what weapon or spell requirements you fulfill.
I started with a 1H sword build and switched before the end to a mage build which was way more fun and just better. I noticed that my dmg was utter garbage and my companion was just carrying me through every fight.
You can unlock spells, passives or skills from a specific class and after defeating enemies with that class you are able to equip that spell/passive/skill on a different class resulting in some fun combinations and builds.

The story/lore was keeping me entertained enough that I wanted to find all the memories. Although I wanted them to lean more into the vampire part. 

Character creation is superb and you can build your very own edgelord vampire or a cute anime girl.

The game has some weird technical problems that have sadly never been fixed, nothing gamebreaking though in the 3 years post release it should have been easily fixable. Problems are badly cut cutscenes (they didnt cut them together but made each their separate 5s cutscene which makes the audio cut out between them), the last frame before a cutscene stays onscreen like an overlay while the cutscene plays, which is mildly distracting. Also this game isnt that graphic intense so some of my fellow gamers who want to play in 144hz beware that the elevators dont work! The game engine used in this game ties the elevator movement to frames and well... elevators stop working if you play the game above 90-100 frames so either limit frames to 60 or minimize/tab out of the game everytime you are in an elevator else you will sit there for 10min with nothing happening.
As I said nothing gamebreaking but definitely fixable!

I didnt play the DLC but the base game took me 20 hours while exploring everything on every area.
The game is at the moment of this game 7,50€ and I would definitely recommend this for either souls or anime fans!

Bandai Namco should stop making trees from characters because I am sick of it by now. How many more characters have to be turned into trees before you're satisfied? Shio, Visconti, protagonists of Tales of the World 1 and 2, Karen Travers(Plant not tree but still), and [spoiler]Io[/spoiler]. Turning into a tree doesnt mean everything is resolved. Main characters and important characters dying(Zestiria, Berseria, Xillia 2) doesn't mean good story-writing. The main character here also didn't have much of a presence. You could say for 70% of the story, the important guy was Louis, not your character. Louis would decide on stuff and look at your character. This is bad writing of a silent protagonist. You're like a tool to further Louis's ambitions and you stayed that way till near the ending. At the last part they make your character speak, this is obviously an attempt to recreate the same feeling back in God Eater 1 when your character spoke to Lindow, but this attempt in Code Vein doesn't even come close to how epic the delivery in God Eater 1 was. This is pathetic. A mimicry of a good climax scene. I only felt pity at the protagonist at this moment where he continued to be used as a tool by other people for their own purposes. Look to GE1 or GER if you want to review how to make good silent protagonists. How come you made GE1 and GER but fail on making decent silent protagonists afterwards? This is just sad Bamco.

Gameplay is fine tho. But the writing of the story was so bad, I just can't give it a thumbs up.

I'm re-reviewing this game since I've gotten better. And gotten the DLCs. 

First, I like Code Vein. The Souls like fighting, mixed with using of different gifts and blood veil drastically increases the variety of your moveset. Managing your Ichor is definitely needed to be kept in mind, but it only added good in my experience since It's quite nice to fight the harder bosses on a sliver of health, no companion, an no ichor.

The base bosses can be a little bit hit or miss, most the time they are easy. But there are a handful of bosses that are hard and some of those I think are relatively too hard in progression. (But it's manageable, including the towers)

But my gripe with this game, is the DLC (not because it lacks content, which I'm not bothered with it). The problem is some of those challenges are unfair, and doesn't consider the attack pattern and difference between DLC Bosses. (Especially a certain DLC boss that you have to dodge 5-10 times... Which doesn't sound hard. But because of it's hitbox, you dodge mechanic, it's barrage and timing window. You have little to no chance of completing it if you're a casual player)

Get the Base game it's great, the dlcs it's your choice. But be prepared for a bad time if you're 100% completing the game or just even getting all the blood codes with all dlcs.

People say this is "Anime Souls", and while it's definitely using a similar format and took inspiration from it, it really doesn't [i] feel [/i] or plays like Dark Souls. There are 2 major key difference that makes this game stands out; the character building aspect and companions.

Making a build in Code Vein is very flexible. There are Blood Codes you can choose and find, these are basically character class and niche that dictates your stats distribution and [b] unlockable [/b] skills (passive or active abilities). You can switch Codes freely almost anytime anywhere with zero cost, skills are initially locked for a specific Code but you can "master" them and use them on any other Codes either by using them a lot or use limited resource to skip the process. Basically it is, for the most part, pretty low commitment and you can choose the optimum Code for your weapon of choice. 
You do need to progress some sort of Code level to unlock more skills from that code, but that is done from doing exploration and finding the specific Code fragment, leveling up one Code doesn't really affect your ability on leveling up another.

As for combat, this game is practically meant to be played with a companion. The encounters are designed assuming you'll have someone to back you up (either AI or other players), hence there's plenty of gank ambushes and even BS boss moves that aren't telegraphed well just to trip you up; you can go solo, sure, but that's akin to a challenge run (although by no means impossible since your character can be very overpowered easily). Most of the satisfaction in combat comes from your skills/abilities and how they make you [i] feel [/i] like an anime vampire protagonist, and sometimes from good cooperation with your teammates.

The story is mostly told in a flashback and in Assassin's Creed Unity fashion, you for some reason just have the ability to experience someone else's memories (even the dead). The majority of big events happened in the past and you're collecting the puzzle pieces to get the full picture. While it is satisfying getting things slowly unraveled to you, the storytelling left a lot to be desired because 80% of information are conveyed through glorified moving picture book narrations (with sad music to go along with it!). 
While some might say this is no worse than how Souls games tell their stories (item descriptions), they felt more involved since it's an active player choice to read something completely optional and it's ambiguous nature leads to the players having to fill in the gaps themselves, to theorize and discuss with others about the story. In this respect Code Vein is quite lacking, most of the flashbacks are mandatory and if you're going level up Blood Codes you'll see even more of them, there is almost no ambiguity as well.

There some other weak spots: the map/environment design (it's really just the dreaded white castle maze holy heaven it can burn in hell) can be annoying and confusing (for a game without jumping, there sure is a lot of places where you have to drop to some hidden platforms); you can get overpowered way too quickly, removing any semblance of challenge that one might expect from these types of games, which will often lead to boredom and lost of interest in continuing to play.

In summation; while not perfect, it's a different refreshing take on a "Souls-like" experience, with decent story, fun character building aspect, and flashy combat.

This game has a "souls like" concept. 

You have currency that works like souls, you spend them on weapon upgrades, level up, purchases , etc.. Lose them upon death.
You have a shrine where you can teleport around , upgrade your character etc...
And other things too like limited regens and stuff. 

The game is not too difficult as I thought it would be. Coming here after Sekiro and Dark Souls 1, there is not much challenges in fighting basic enemies, but some bosses can be abit of a challenge, but still easier to get by. 

It has interesting characters in its story and also to highlight, a wide range of customisation for character design. Furthermore, you can change your fighting class at any point of the game without being locked into a specific type of class, as most games would do. 

So far 16 hours in, i am definitely enjoying this game due to its interesting characters and also the story of the game.

 Its definitely worth a shot for those who wants to get a first feel of souls like game without a high difficulty spike.

[h2]The Gist of it[/h2]

[i]Code Vein[/i] is a third person combat heavy experience, designed around the concept of “trial and error”, all wrapped in an Anime aesthetic. Players are constantly walled by tougher and tougher enemies with differing resistances, weaknesses, attack patterns, abilities, and spells. Learning the mechanics and how the game handles even the littlest of details, as well as the visual and audio cues during fights, is crucial for success.

[h2]Isn’t this like...[/h2]

I feel I should preface my full thought piece by stating where I stand with the “Souls-like” genre: I’ve never played a single one, in any capacity, so I have no real frame of reference (for better or for worse) in regards to what would entail a good Souls game. For the sake of this review, even if I did play one, I’d try to explain what [i]Code Vein[/i] is on its own merit, and not just write another Souls spiel. In short, if you’re looking for a review that encompasses what this game does well that others of the genre do and vise versa, this won’t be an informative read I’m afraid.

With all that said, [b][i]if this is indicative of what this genre has to offer, I’m 100% into it[/i][/b].

[h2]A Revenant’s Plea[/h2]

This tale begins with our hero/heroine confined in a void, trapped with a woman. After going through her tutorial, our warrior awakens to the sight of a woman. She is simply called [i]Girl in White[/i] at this point in our story, (her name is Io, and she’s best girl just saying) and both make their way over to a tree of some kind, walking through a seemingly desolate city. Its only moments later, that it becomes painfully clear they’re not alone, and shortly after they become unwilling scavengers.

The game progressively gets more interesting, but this foundation weaves a tapestry of a woeful world fighting to get by day to day. [i]CV[/i] slowly introduces the concept of what our protagonist and most every other living sane beings are: [i]Revenants[/i]. Creatures of endless death and rebirth, constantly thirsting  for blood, else they lose their minds and become one with the ranks of [i]The Lost[/i], which are the creatures that appose our leading [i]Revenant[/i]. In true Anime fashion, the protagonist is the world’s only hope and holds the power to help mitigate the suffering of those who haven’t lost themselves. Through their travels, our hero/heroine and Co. make new friends, and reminisce old ones using one of the protagonist’s many unique abilities. Our protagonist can read latent memories from [i]Vestiges[/i] that happen to be laying around, or from certain enemies. This serves as a decent means of giving both context to what has happened in this world, who was involved, expanding on character lore, and unlocking [i]Blood Codes[/i] which I will come back to momentarily.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2926475524
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2926475379

The story as a whole is… Serviceable. It isn’t inherently bad or doomed to fail and I did enjoy it here and there, I just have a few gripes with how events sometimes play out. For one, sometimes the friendship moments were layered on too thick for my liking. It felt like the writers were trying too hard to make the player believe that these people are truly your friends, and that’s fine and all, I would just rather it not be so forced. Another issue I have is with the progression of the story, with the goal mostly being a back and forth and not much else. There are loads of cool enemies to fight in between, and the story picks up a few hours in though so I was able to cope.

[h2]Codes for Success[/h2]

Throughout the game, players will unlock what is effectively classes that govern what abilities and spells can be used, known as [i]Blood Codes[/i]. Each code offers a set of abilities and skills that can be unlocked for use with other codes in a sort of mix and match style, by either having them equipped with the class or outright buying them out. The codes also affect other combat abilities, such as the armor and weapons one can equip, and what spells/buffs can be used. Essentially, each [i]Blood Code[/i] has its own letter grade in a given category and as long as the ability/spell requirements fit, and it has been unlocked, you can use it! Some abilities and spells are just locked to their parent code and can’t be shared, usually for game balance purposes.

[h2]Overall Performance[/h2]

The game performed somewhat optimally with all settings at their highest value, at 60 FPS. Any higher FPS value and things like elevators wouldn’t work correctly. I didn’t want to keep switching so I stuck with 60, and that was more than sufficient.

Very rarely, aside from the last few levels, turning corners too fast would allow me to see beyond the area or room, until the area loaded in. Rather Jarring, and thankfully didn’t hinder gameplay.

[h3]PC Specs:[/h3]
CPU – Ryzen 9 5900x
GPU – GIGABYTE RTX 3080
RAM – 2 x 16 DDR4
Storage – SSD

[h2]In Conclusion...[/h2]

At the end of the day, I can say I really enjoyed this game. I wouldn’t quantify it as 10/10 or anything like that, probably not even 8/10, but I like this game enough to say with confidence that if other souls games are like this I’m interested in trying them. Most of my disdain at first came from my lack of understanding what this game is really trying to do. I can’t see any reason to not recommend this on a decent sale. 60 USD, at the time of this review’s publishing, is unacceptable and would be the only real reason I’d recommend against buying this.

When I first learned about this game, I was ready to throw my money at it because I like Dark Souls, (non-sparkling) vampires, and post-apocalyptic settings, but after I saw the clothes (or insufficiency thereof) of the female characters, I clicked "ignore."  Fast forward to the 2022 winter sale, I was looking for games to buy and I saw that this was 85% off.  I figured that there will probably be mods to fix some annoyances so decided to give this a try.

[B]Positives:[/b]
-Combat doesn't feel as good as Dark Souls but it's still fun.
-NPC partners are decent in combat when exploring. You don't have to babysit them.  You can also go solo if you want. I played this 100% offline so I can't comment on co-op.
-Photo mode is pretty good. The camera's travel distance is limited, but it could be extended by using a mod.
-Skippable cutscenes and memory sequences. My second and third playthroughs were so much better than the first after skipping almost all of those.
-I used a PS4 controller and the game shows PS4 buttons without having to install a mod. I just had to uncheck "PlayStation Configuration Support" and check "Generic Gamepad Configuration Support" in Steam's settings to make the controller work correctly.
-All achievements can be unlocked with the base game only. You don't have to buy the DLC to get 100%.

[B]Neutral:[/b]
-There are no fixed classes. Leveling just increases HP, stamina, and attack power. Your other stats depend on your blood code (class) and your gear. You can swap blood codes anytime.
-As for difficulty, I thought it's generally easier than the Souls games.  Regular enemies are easy to backstab.  Some late game bosses took me some time to beat but I think I was underleveled. Even then, the hardest bosses here are still easier compared to the hardest Souls bosses.
-Story and characters are meh and dialogue is kinda cheesy.

[B]Negatives:[/b]
-Fanservice. I know that many consider it positive, but it's a huge turn off for me, especially when it's excessive.  Almost all female characters, including the protagonist, NPCs, enemies, and bosses, are dressed either in skimpy/revealing clothing or something that doesn't look practical in combat. If you don't skip cutscenes, unnecessary fanservice will pretty much be shoved in your face every time a female character appears in them. I would have been less annoyed if the male characters are also similarly dressed in skimpy/revealing outfits. I still won't like the outfits, but at least the designs would be consistent. Thankfully, there are mods that allow the female protagonist and a couple of female NPCs to have more decent outfits.
-Silent protagonist worked in the Souls games/Elden Ring.  Here, it just makes the cutscenes with dialogue look very awkward. The other characters talk to your character but he/she responds only with gestures, nods, etc.  It wouldn't have been that bad if you only see your chacter's back, but the camera focuses on your character's face and he/she doesn't say anything.  [spoiler]But after hearing my character speak 2 lines near the very end of the game, I'm not sure if I want to hear more voiced lines.[/spoiler]
-There is an extremely grindy RNG-based achievement.  It took me around 8 hours repeatedly killing one enemy to get those 400 Marks of Honor required for the achievement.  Not sure if it's faster in co-op, but I read that it's still extremely grindy.
-Gift (ability) mastery can also be very grindy, whether you're repeatedly killing enemies to master gifts or you're farming items for automatic mastery. The good news is that you don't have to master all gifts, just the ones you need.


tl;dr - Not as good as the FromSoft games, but the gameplay is fun enough. The experience would have been better if it didn't shove fanservice in your face, and without the extreme grind for one achievement.

Code Vein is a good souls-like to start with in fact, and while defintely not easy for one not used to souls-like games (Like me. I don't usually play Souls-likes at all), it's easier to pick up and play.

Strategy wise, it really is all about experimentation and finding out how you want to play. Code Vein really is a cut above most games in it's niche because unlike say Dark Souls, you can change and mix and match classes and abilities as much as you want, and the game encourages doing so.

Also for a new player it is recommended to play with a AI partner, as they often will comment on things you might miss, and the AI isn't bad at all in fighting along side you. Some say doing so makes the game too easy, but for others it helps a great deal.

All in all it's whateva you fancy playing

Overall good game, quite easy compared to the dark souls series due to having a companion, but richer in story. To me it's an attempt to merge JRPG artstyle and storytelling with souls like mechanisms.

Combat is more versatile, but given the difficulty, there's really not much incentive to explore play styles. Also the move set of some bosses feel clunky - many bosses can be easily defeated in you stay behind them.

The main story is much more detailed, and the overall tone is much more positive. Most characters have solid background stories, and these stories are introduced without breaking the flow of the game.

Level design is fine - I got lost in quite a few maps, but overall, most maps are good - a few feel rushed, but not that much rushed.

Side quests & depths are really boring. Skip unless you are after some achievements.

Music is fantastic, both on its own and in terms of fit. This is partially due to the game being much more explicit in emotional expression and storytelling compares to souls games, allowing the music to be the same.

Lastly, I really like Io, almost considered not finishing the game for her :/ 

Won't elaborate too much as it'll be spoilers otherwise, but I like her not being so much like human, but trying to become one - Human qua human.

Code Vein is a weird one. Back when it was announced it was called the anime-dark-souls. Let's clarify that it's really not. The gameplay isn't nearly as crisp and direct as that title implies. And even though yes levels are somewhat intertwined with shortcuts, they are often illogical and exhaustingly annoying. And let me tell you, sometimes you have to walk A LOT through weird, repetitive floors. It also felt poorly balanced. Sometimes you get basically one shot and most of the time you just tank through your enemies with healing or getting revived by you AI-companion.

But I still had a lot of fun and I'm not entirely sure why, but I DO recommend you playing Code Vein. So I did like the graphics design. It is a fresh concept of steam-punkish cyber-vampires which sounds a lot more cringe than it actually was for me. And also the plot and characters were very solid. Nothing out of the ordinary but I did like almost everything about it. Big parts of the story are told through memories of all the characters you meet or hear of. Those memories are scattered all over the place and even though exploring isn't exactly a lot of fun it is at least rewarding for the plot.

Also worth mentioning is the way of building your character, gearing and leveling up. Most of it is very straight forward upgrade after upgrade. At least it was for me because I played a very simple Dex build. But I did like that you are basically never tied to a class or playstyle because your stats are linked to your equipment and on top of that the memories I mentioned before unlock new skills and there are quite a few skills you can learn. 

And lastly I do feel the love the developers had for this project. Though hard to explain, it is generally a good, well-rounded game with some corners you are either okay with or hate to death. And I really dislike a few things about it. But after playing it through it was kinda cool, it really hooked me and I am really on the edge right now of seeing other endings, trying different playstyles, going 100% and wishing (though not very likely?) for a sequel. Or maybe I just ditch it, because no matter how much I like it, there are a lot of games on my list that easily might be a better time invest.

Code Vein is an interesting take on the Souls Genre, but a flawed masterpiece.

The story is decent, and the characters that help you throughout the story are mostly interesting; the combat is mostly satisfying, although I have my gripes about it.

What I think is that this game fell a little flatter than it should have, it has many great ups, but many low downs towards the end of the game. Most of my gripes are game design gripes with this game, which I will break down below:

The level-up system gives you many paths to follow through blood codes, and you can change many many things about how you want to set up your character, you can get more than one blood code, and mix and match things to make your character better, you can also upgrade them in various ways. This is mostly fine, but I have a couple disappointments with it as a two-handed player. 

The characters that I made wield great swords, but two-handed weapons in this game give a significant speed penalty in terms of dodging that I couldn't help but notice when switching back and forth between my one-handed to two-handed weapons. 

There is a way to fix this problem, but it requires you to dodge the best ending possible in a collect-a-thon that is too long to be thoroughly enjoyable twice solo for me.

The level design half way through this game falls completely flat once you reach the cathedral, it reuses assets throughout the whole environment way too much, to make it more stupid, they reuse the same assets again to build another area later just like it.

The game has various memories and items you need to pick up throughout the game, but the memories are what will give you your best ending, you need to gather all of them. The map will reveal where they are, but you also will need to go into the sub dungeons that you need maps to go to. The game will force you to get everything, if you want the best ending.

The story itself was beautiful, the game had many fun moments, but I don't think that I would want to replay it twice, and I have muiltiple reasons why, but here are my main ones:

The combat while having amazing parts to it, has a lot of repetitive design. I don't feel that many of the weapons in the same style have too many varying features, like in Dark Souls, and while I don't want to compare this game to Dark Souls, I have to compare it on some levels.

The weapons feel identical to each other in this game, but have different skins on them, with a few exceptions, but they don't feel very unique either outside of cosmetic and stat upgrades.

The combat for what it is, is mostly fine, some of the enemies get very annoying, but it's mostly okay.

The art style in this game is extemely beautful, I love the world design when it's not being reused as assets, but even the reused areas have a unique feature that is enjoyable about them to an extent. 

The character creation is satisfying, you can recreate so many anime characters using this game, but I had more fun using the character creation to bring my original story characters to life, I love how the game does justice on customization. If only more character creation screens were this awesome.

I guess another gripe I have is the lack of feeliing unique with my character though, your character is silent throughout the game, forced to follow the collect-a-thon, or ignore it for other endings with no choice in action to define who your character is. I think the lack of roleplaying elements are what bore me a little, but I can't fault the game if it didn't want to do that either, that's just a minor gripe of mine.

Overall a fun game, at least for your first playthrough, fair combat, amazing character customization, and probably even better if you can coop with a friend.

I only got to play coop a couple of times, and usually failed to connect to other players, so that was an issue, but the game was mostly fine.

If I had one last thing that I wish could have been improved on, it would both be cooperative play being better and more rewarding, and either a pvp mode, or something to make me want to continue even after I want to beat the game.

This game lacks any means of me wanting to continue once I beat it, I have the weapons I want to use, but once I even learned about the two-handed upgrade, it was far too late for me, and I just didn't want to go back and do it twice.

Overall, I give this a 7/10.

Not fun. All the weapons, even the lighter ones, feel very heavy and not satisfactory to use at all. Can be kinda fun at times or maybe even later on when you have more stamina/better weapons but I don't feel the combat is rewarding enough early on to motivate me to get that far into the game.

Great game, I'm a fan of "Souls like" games and this one certainly didn't disappoint. As a person who finds they don't play games so much anymore I was pleasantly surprised to find I played this one straight through. It has most of what makes a souls game a souls game. I found myself on edge quite a lot, worried while fighting, terrified by edges etc. 

I did find the game easier than some, I had way more haze (souls) than I ever really needed to use and rarely levelled up (which only affects health, stamina and weapon damage but also makes it slower to master abilities). I had so much haze at the end that I could level up every weapon and blood veil (armour) to +9 and still had millions to lose from death.. Keeping my level low helped keep things fun, I only really levelled up when I struggled on a boss and ended the game at level 90-100 (there are 300 levels if I recall).

I liked the blood code idea and abilities, you don't gain stats from levelling but instead get them from the 'blood code' that you use - which can be swapped easily at a mistle (bonfire). You can swap abilities (4 passives, 8 active) almost anytime. This system works great and gives you a huge variety to play with.

Character customization is good but I did it once at the start and never changed my character after. I am a fan of the anime styling but it's not to everyone's liking. there are also plenty of mods, of which can add more character looks.

Fun game - I think I'll NG+ it at some point in the future.
Game Good

As an overview - Code Vein is a mediocre souls-like with neat ideas but a mixed execution. It's definitely not worth $60, but is probably fine on sale at $15-20.

Code Vein is essentially a souls-like but in reality it's more like a souls-like mixed with a Devil May Cry. The most interesting idea in the game is the idea of changing classes on the fly with abilities that, once mastered, can be mixed and matched. This is a great idea, but even it has weird execution issues. For example, why not also allow the player to create their *own* class with custom stat arrays?  Regardless, it's the best idea in the game.

The game's combat is very meh. Any good ideas are drug down by an absolutely pace-killing special attacks (that either have mini-cut-scenes or, if such is disabled, still stop combat flow). They are a bad idea. The parry system is also an utter mess. While an interesting idea Sekiro pretty much established that good parry systems are those that rely on quick reactions in time with attacks, not long parry predictions based on enemy wind ups. The game is also balanced around constantly having a companion, and for being under-leveled. You actively penalize your ability to acquire and learn abilities while you level, with no information provided about that in the tutorial. All of this combines to a mediocre combat system with elementary errors. It feels like the designers didn't understand what worked in From Soft combat and instead kept making bad decisions.

The actual non-combat game play is average. The game suffers from reused assets very quickly. The environments are also extremely same-y, and a lot of the levels feel like dead space or padding. The notorious cathedral level is a great example of this - it is maze-like and confusing for no real reason and it feels like a lot of asset reuse. And it loses the most important From Soft design philosophy - have the world feel connected (so that you can see where you'll go) and not disconnected set pieces. And if they are disconnected, have them be spectacular (and not "ruined city" part 9).

The game's story is fairly generic, while also feeling slap-dash. Story beats and elements do not flow well into each other, and characters are one dimensional. It feels like the game couldn't figure out how to get it's story in line, and really wanted to add twists, despite never laying the ground work for us to care. At one point a character notes that they hate a villain because they knew them, but at no point prior is this ever brought up. It's just slap-dash and disorganized. The "memory" system is also a *major* pace-killer. While the idea might make sense if handled properly, it is just a slog in its  current state. Any interesting story concepts in the idea are so flubbed by the execution that it is just a chore.

In the same vein, the game is *extremely* fan-service-y for truly no reason. There is virtually no female main character in the game that isn't wearing lingerie or less, and even non-main characters have outrageous figures and nonsensical uniforms. There is *no* male equivalent anywhere. It is so outrageous that it is off putting. If you're going to go over the top on fan service - have it go both ways. Hell, you can't even make a normally clothed female character that isn't in bondage gear or a miniskirt.

The whole experience feels like someone wrote a story for a 12 year old, and then tried to make it "adult" by just tossing every female into lingerie. It comes off as a sophomoric attempt to seem "edgy." In fact, Code Vein could be better understood as a Chunibyo's attempt at an "adult game" with blood, breasts, and battle. Code Vein feels like a twelve year old trying to fit in at the Dark Souls adult table.

There are neat enough ideas to warrant a play through, and I had fun at times. But this is a *deeply* flawed game and if you're looking for something similar, play Dark Souls 1-3, Sekiro, and Elden Ring first. Coming from Elden Ring (as my last 3d souls-like) to this, it really highlights just how *lesser* Code Vein is to that game.

If you can find it on sale (I got it for about $10) it's worth grabbing if you're curious and like Souls Like. It is not worth $60 and it is a *joke* that the game is still offered for that if not on sale.

Personally, I won't recommend it.   Feels like it just should have straight up been a real hack and slash game.  Like Bayonetta or Devil may Cry.    But you are stuck with a souls-like mechanic.  While the enemies get the hack and slash mechanic.   Feels like you just never have any stamina.   And enemies can 1 - 2 hit you at like all the time regardless your health.  Pretty sure their damage is by percent.   And it grows depending on your lvl to ensure you are never getting strong.   There is a special bar that fills up and lets ya do something extra depending on ya build.  Enemies get that too and it fills up so fast for them they basically spamming their super 1 hit kill attacks.   I don't think blocking actually works.   Enemies get shields that block everything.  You get no shield and they can break through your guard and deplete ya stamina in a hit.   Once a hit from the enemy connects ya boned.  All you can do is sit there and wait until the combo is over.   And you'll often have  multiple enemies hitting you with a combo.   Just put the controller down and wait to die.  Cause you not going to escape.  Your stamina was gone the second the combo started so you aren't going to be rolling out of the combo any time soon.   

Visually the game is purdy.   Most the females are very heavily "gifted".   The character customization is pretty cool.  And the whole class customizing did seem pretty neat.  But really , just go play a FromSoftware game.    But if you wanna get into this game.  Try it.   Who knows.   Maybe you'll go gaga for it.   Clearly people like it.

Ever wanted to play dark souls, but felt that it was missing something? More specifically, anime? Then look no further! Code Vein has a little bit of everything for people, even those who suck at souls-likes. With a good character creator, enthusiastic story, and an overall hard but fun time, it can be a fun game to play when you're either with friends, by yourself (Don't worry, you have companions too), or just want to sink a few hours into something new, this will hopefully satisfy those needs. I would personally recommend getting the DLC's as well, as they can serve a tougher time once you've beaten the game a handful of times. You get rewards for completing them too! Mods also exist for this game, but I wouldn't recommend going there unless you've already beaten the game at least once. See you on the battle field, Revenant!

Was going to write a long exhaustive review but came to the conclusion it feels like it doesn't really deserve it. But made sure to call out what in my opinion was important.

Character Art/Design is actually top notion but completely disjointed from literally every aspect of the game, so it's pointless :upsidedownsmiley:
Environment Art is sometimes great but usually bad (Also sometimes disjointed from the game, but no where near as bad as Character Art/Design)
Level design / Enemy placement is sometimes good but usually awful
Combat & AI Design & Engineering: I feel like was brought in last minute and given an extreme and impossible deadline or was a very small team or something there's just a few questionable decisions here and not much work put into Enemies even though you fight them 95% of the time, while a lot of work was put into some of the bosses (Not the final 4 I can tell you that), but ultimately wasted because they are easy and short experiences that make up prob less than 5% of the time playing. Hardest boss was the very last one just because his swings have huge hit boxes and cheap shots but its like 4 attacks repeated, Killed it on my 4th try. All other bosses beat on my first or second try.

This game is fun but I can't in good conscious recommend it over other titles. It would be in my top 10 if its characters were fully developed, this game had so much potential. It dropped the ball in a lot of areas and I think the main one being how they fleshed out characters through the equivalent of holotapes/audio logs. They incentivized watching these in return for skills which would have been fine but this being the only way to learn about specific characters got old. The lack of any sidequests or ways to really bond with this cast of characters make it a struggle to find a reason to care about some of them. Watching someone's memories from the past and not making new ones with them is wasted potential. Near the end of the game I felt disconnected with some of the squad because they hadn't been relevant in the story in such a long time. Jack and Eva were better developed characters than Louis who you meet in the very beginning which is disappointing. Aside from the story the gameplay is relatively good but not fantastic. The general area design is bad but it makes up for it with the combat. If there's one thing this game does well is its large variety of viable weapons/spells/builds. Being able to do things like buffing yourself to do 10x damage or stunlock the enemy keeps it fresh and entertaining. To end on a closing note, regardless of what I've said, if an anime souls-like sounds interesting you should give this a shot. It can be rough around the edges but I'd be lying if I said I wasn't having fun the whole way through. Even if I wished the game to be more than what it was I still enjoying myself despite its many faults. If a code vein 2 ever comes out and they learn from their mistakes I would 100% recommend. I always assume that most souls / souls-like games don't have much emphasis on the story and this game surprised me. The story gets better as it progresses. To summarize:

[b] Pros: [/b]
[list]
[*]Good story. I didn't know this one has multiple endings. So better to achieve / watch all the endings for full impact. Also get all the memories. The characters have interesting backstories. 
[*]For players that are just starting or would like to dive into souls / souls-like games, this game could be for you. Not very punishing. I even finished the game without upgrading the amount of heals I can use because I didn't check there was an item for its upgrade. Also, if you want a challenge, you can opt to play without a partner.
[*]Waifus and nakama power.
[/list]

[b] Cons: [/b]
[list]
[*]There are areas that are badly designed. One I can particularly think is the cathedral. The visuals are pretty but it's just so huge compared to the other areas and can easily get lost. Curse that area.
[*]The final boss is badly designed, IMHO. Tip: When you battle the final boss, don't target lock him. 
[/list]

Weeb Souls 10/10

In many ways, the game is a bit generic. For a souls-like, it's very much on the easier side. Despite me going out of my way to gather everything, it took me a total of 50 hours to finish the whole game. I didn't bother with the DLCs yet, though.

Most of the characters are just kind of eh. They're there, they serve your usual cliche roles and most of them feel like little more than plot devices. Some of their stories are so far-fetched it's just absurd to listen to them explain how tragic they are. Some work okay but the story-telling fall flats when the music is so insanely out of tempo. Somebody could be explaining how they bit their own arm off to survive and the orchestra will go so hard you'd think you're fighting a boss.

The graphics are no more than fine. It looks decent at max but the art style just isn't good enough to really make it stand out. Many environments end up looking cluttered and conflicted as to what they want to pull off, with themes clashing like crazy in the same areas. An area can try to be gothic and epic but at the same time you'll have plain slabs of concrete mixed into it and it just looks plain bad. They also really need to tone down the bloom, it's goddamn everywhere and it looks incredibly cheap.

As for combat, it's fun! Combat is the part I enjoyed most of the game. It's not as tense as bloodborne or as well-balanced as dark souls but it strikes a fine balance between being punishing and being easy enough to feel a bit like a power trip. Throughout most of the game, even when you're learning new things and experimenting, you do feel like you're never really threatened until a boss enters the fray. 

A word of warning though. Hitboxes are frankly awful. I've never had so many moments where I think to myself "Why didn't I take damage just now?" or "How are all these attacks misses? I'm literally inside the boss and they're not taking damage"
It happened far too often to be just a miscalculation, or a fluke. It's especially common when you try to strike an enemy that's on the ground. Even if you do an over-head slash to reach the enemy while they're low, you can miss several hits. Bad hitboxes or extremely long i-frames, I'm not sure. End result is the same.

I didn't play much multiplayer, only in Fake-Anor-Londo, where I summoned a random player in the hopes of them helping me sniff the right path out. (I did eventually manage to find the path and the cooperator helped me fight a bit) 
Multiplayer is nice. It's not as restrictive as Dark Souls, Bloodborne and so on. You can have an NPC by your side and still call a cooperator which is cool. Basic for a souls-like but still nice that they didn't punish you in any way for having your NPC alongside you. 
I didn't notice any major network hiccups during coop play. 

But speaking of the NPC partners... 
I stuck with Io, one of main characters as far as the main plot goes, simply because I figured there might be some kind of secret story arc or whatever. In the end, I'm not sure if that affected the story at all but I did notice that for somebody whose whole gimmick it is to be very quiet, she spoke... A LOT. The NPCs have certain points where they will drop comments on what is happening or what you're looking at and uh, she would comment alright. Repeatedly. Regarding the same thing. Multiple times in a row. Sometimes she had so many comments lined up that she kept talking for a minute or more. This is especially true for the last 2 areas in the game. The partners start talking way, way too much in those two areas and it feels incredibly sudden. Your partner goes from just saying random things like "Oh, you should heal!" and "Do you like traveling with me?" to suddenly dropping multi-sentence voice clips of them explaining how oh-so-eye-opening your travels have been, immediately after shouting in pain and then telling you they are out of healing. 

That's kind of a nitpick, to be entirely reasonable but I started noticing how weird the voice lines got after I went through the snow area and realized the partners will repeatedly comment on this one steel girder you spot upon entering the area, and they will do so every single time you pass it. I walked up and down the snowy slope just to try it and they did legitimately spam the line nonstop if you let them. 

In essense, Code Vein is an okay game. The amount of tinkering you can do with classes and gear, as well as picking partners, leads to a game that despite having a fairly average story length-wise (and quality as well I suppose) it does offer a lot of replay value. Multiple endings, a myriad of combinations you can try in combat - there's a lot to like, even though the gameplay can feel wonky at times. To try everything, you do require at least two playthroughs - some actions in the story lock you out of certain "Blood codes", or classes. 

tl;dr:
It's okay - fun combat, plenty of build-variety in the classes. Some fun weapons too. Story's average. Art-style is all over the place. Music's forgettable, sadly. Genuinely can't remember a single piece of music from the game.

One of the more "meh" souls-likes I've played, I got hooked by the general positivity around this game however I think the cons outweigh any pros.

Pros:
-Nice anime aesthetics and world
-Character creation is really great
-Combat is better than some others in the genre

Cons:
-Storyline is utterly dull, souls games while not having a clear story or alot of dialogue have better story
-Voice acting is eh
-Bosses are sponges with ridiculous stun locks that make them less of a challenge you feel good about and more of a migraine you're just glad to have finished.
-Enemies are either really stupidly easy or just....annoying there is no inbetween
-Level ups are almost pointless, mostly netting HP and scaling is more on weapons/gear you obtain
-You will find more swords seemingky then other weapon types making preferring bayonets and some weapons frustrating.

All in all I really wanted to enjoy this, since the aesthetics were awesome but it just seemed too jank and not "difficult yet rewarding" like the best in the genre. Overall I feel the big thing that gave this game a big jump in popularity is purely "anime souls", while I love anime myself its frustrating to continually get average games at their core with anime graphics slapped on top.

Code Vein is a very complicated game to talk about, being both harder and easier than a typical Souls game, simultaneously.  

It's an uneven experience for sure, with incredibly fast enemies, high damage, and an unfortunately obfuscating UI.  However, it balances that with the companions, friendly NPCs that you can take into dungeons and fight bosses with.  Companions do a lot of damage, crucially, but they can also revive your character if you take a fatal blow.  

I think the game is definitely worth a try if you like the genre.  I found it relatively approachable, almost immediately, but for newcomers, maybe wait for a sale.  Just in case.  It can be a little bit of a culture shock, and the random difficulty spikes will turn off a lot of players.

The Good:

The Bad:
- I personally dont like an npc cuck following me around and i didnt like chunk of the game is balanced around having one, you can turn companion off (which i did right away) but things like invasions and some of multi enemy fights (1 boss fight in perticular) is absolute cancer if done solo, having enemies that spam quick aoe attacks endlessly with no breaks in between (looking at you Boreal Brute) is bad design, especially if you have to fight more than one at a time,
- gameplay wise this is B tier soulslike, despite From Software name on it greatly lacks polish, things like backstabs are wonky, enemy variety is limited, maps are very simplistic and catherdral is the worst one i have ever seen,
- game is way too easy with npc or human companion, yet if you dont use them some parts like few of the  invasions become bordeline impossible depending on your build, the chain stagger deaths feel like a very cheap way to implement difficulty,
- Im not a weeb so the anime style was hurting my eyes a bit, every single character in the game having tragic backstory also made me squint my eyes a bit,

[h1]Quick Review[/h1]
To put this game simply, this is a JRPG with metroidvania and souls-like element, and edgy story.
this game was developed by the God Eater team, so just like God Eater was to Monster Hunter, this game has stronger emphasis on the story compared to Dark Souls.

Difficulty wise, as a lot of people say, this game is easier than Dark Souls, but that doesn't mean this game is a sleeper, this game can prove to be challenging, but fair, so don't expect to run and slash and win.
for people who hates reading and talking, you can skip the cutscenes, but if you do want to care about the story later on, you can revisit those cutscenes in the game.

I'd say just give this game a try, probably grab this on sale if you're unsure if you'd like this game or not.

[h1]Long Review[/h1]
[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
First thing first, I'd like to explain my initial statements in my quick review further.
[h3]A Soulslike JRPG[/h3]
As I mentioned earlier this game was developed by the God Eater team, so I think instead of appealing only to Dark Souls fans, this game was more likely catered towards God Eater fans, or both.
Which explains why this game is more forgiving than Dark Souls.

For a starter, just like in God Eater, you can have an NPC partner in this game, which wasn't a main focus in Dark Souls, yeah you could have an NPC partner in Dark Souls as well, but they're not someone who you can bring with you for the entirety of the game, your partner can also interact with you in this game, so they're not just there and follows you around, but they don't talk too much either, it's just the right amount of talking.

Secondly, it's the leveling system, instead of individually increasing your stats, in this game you only have to manually increase your level. This leveling system is much more easier to understand for JRPG fans where the game usually automatically increases the level and stats for you by experience points.

Another point is the skill system, or the Gift system is what it's called in this game, skills like buff or just offensive skills in general are very useful in this game that it's almost mandatory to learn about them, but if you like the game to be much more challenging you can ignore these skills.

Last but not least is how this game handles the story, so instead of looking for lores in flavor text of the items or equipments that you got, or just by looking around the environment like in Dark Souls, the story is spoonfed to you in this game, it is of course not a bad thing, but I understand if Souls fans hates this type of storytelling, which is why I describe this game as a JRPG because it follows that same formula of storytelling.

[h3]As a Metroidvania[/h3]
People might not realize that Dark Souls is a metroidvania because it only borrows few elements of the genre, but it is, and it's the truth.
But this game is much more obvious that it's a metroidvania, all the stages are interconnected, there are branching paths in each dungeon/stages, there is a map (which in my opinion is a required feature for a metroidvania), there are branching routes (albeit only for the first three dungeons, afterwards it's pretty much linear), and there are backtracking.
There are even border areas, something that Castlevania usually has, short area that separates two dungeons/stages.

Other than the level design, this game also has multiple endings, but unlike in other metroidvanias which if you somehow got the bad ending, you can reload your save, do the things required to get another ending and fight the boss again or something, and you get another ending.
In this game, once you see one ending, you can't fight the last boss again to get another ending, in fact, the pieces that matters for the ending starts when the game starts being linear, not going to spoil anything here, but it means that unless you go all the way back to that point, you won't be able to get another ending, which isn't really possible, so to get another ending you have to replay the whole game.
But luckily, unlike Dark Souls, you can start a New Game+ without increasing the difficulty, meaning you can restart the game while being overpowered, this is very useful for people who only cares about the story.

Another thing that I like about this game is, the variety of the weapons and blood veil (the armor), to me it's always nice to have weapon options in a metroidvania that it's almost important.
And more importantly the weapons for each types aren't just upgrades, it depends on your build, they all do different things and motions, and yes, I'm not lying when I said motions, each weapon behaves differently, so for example if you're more into offense build you might rather take the sword that's faster than the one that's stronger but much slower.

This game hits almost everything perfectly for me as a metroidvania, except for the stamina system. I like to casually speedrun a metroidvania sometimes but I don't speedrun games that has stamina system because it's a system that slows you down and a lot of times it makes speedrunning not fun, atleast for me.
Luckily in this game though, there's a technique which I like to call, Bayonet Backdash Cancelling, which is a traversal technique that doesn't cost stamina, and much like Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow's speedrunning technique, the Backdash Cancel, is something that's easy to do but hard to master, you can make yourself faster by doing this, but only if you do it correctly and precisely.

[h2]Story/Lore[/h2]
I'm not going to talk much about the story here, but let me just say that it's a lot less cliche than I thought, this game definitely has its own thing, a lot of ideas that doesn't exist in other media.

[h2]Music[/h2]
Okay, have you heard of Go Shiina? the GOAT? okay well, you better remember that name now, cuz he only makes bangers, and that includes the musics in this game.
But really, I love the music design in this game, especially the battle music, depending on how many the enemies are and how much in a pinch you are, the intensity of the music will change. 
When there's only one enemy, the music is pretty quiet, and when you're surrounded, or if the enemy is really strong, or if you don't have a lot of health left, the music is going to be very intense.

[h2]Art[/h2]
You really gotta appreaciate how much work has put into making this, some people might not notice and it's understandable, because everything just graphically feels natural, you won't really hear from someone playing this game who said things like, this game feels empty or the environment looks bad or stuff like that, from start to end, all the dungeon/stages were very well designed, especially the Cathedral, the motifs/patterns on the floor, the building design, it made the dungeon less stressful to explore. I just love all the design choices in this game.
Besides the environment, the character creation is also well made, it's much more detailed compared to God Eater's character creator, you can make (almost) any kind of hairstyle in this, making your favorite anime character wouldn't be as impossible as you might think.

[h2]Outro[/h2]
Before I close this review I want to point out some things that I think are interesting, but beware minor spoilers.

[h3]Dark Souls II[/h3]
I like to think that this game took inspiration from Dark Souls II, which is my favorite Souls game (don't @ me) so far, and I'd like to mention some of the similarities.
There's one dungeon in this game in which you're required to gradually falls down into a huge hole in order to enter it, just like that sewer in Majula.
Then the Cathedral, some people might say it's Anor Londo, but to me it's more like Anor Londo mashed with Tower of Flame from Dark Souls II.
Finally, the ending, I'm not going to explain further but if you know, you know.

[h3]Back to outro[/h3]
nevermind, apparently I'm reaching the text limit, so just go grab the game.

If you like the combat depth of FromSoft Souls or Nioh, you won't like this game. The combat and weapon variety is a little dull, the leveling system is very surface level and zones are not very interesting.

Leveling:
When you use points to level, you cannot allocate them to specific stats, you just raise your level.
To change specific stats you must change Blood Code. These are almost like classes and can be changed whenever.
Each Blood Code comes with active and passive abilities called Gifts. To get more Gifts you must find memories, sit through multiple cutscenes, and then master that gift the same way everytime: kill an enemy.

Story:
The story could be more interesting but it didn't captivate me at all. The game is overflowing with long cutscenes that really pulls you out of the gameplay. It got to the point where I skipped everything just so I could play the game.

Combat:
As I said, very shallow. The weapon variety is somewhat lacking. The weapon abilities aren't very varied either. Most enemies can be killed with a backstab and a smack. Adding status effects to your weapons are usually useless as they don't affect bosses much and you'll usually kill normal enemies before the status effect even works.

Enemies:
There is some variety here but in the late game they're mostly reskins of earlier enemies. Most of them aren't very tough which is a strong contrast to the bosses which can be tough or annoying.

To reiterate, if you like the Souls series you probably won't like this game. If you find the Souls games too challenging, you may enjoy this game.

The game itself is fun and the story quite engaging(however this is only for me, as an avid reader of books and stories its a fact that many won't like the same stories I like and vice versa, hence the array of genres we have today), as for criticisms on gameplay seeing as this was released 3 years after Dark Souls 3 I was hoping for it to have the same or as close to as many build variety and gameplay as DS3, the weapon types aren't limited per se but if you've played DS3 for any amount of time provided you finished the game, then to you the gameplay variety would feel limited and lackluster as it was to me, while true the weapons themselves are diverse the WEAPON TYPES however are not, you could easily feel the monotony of just having a "One-handed" Weapon type as compared to DS3's "Straight Swords, Katana's, hammers, etc" many "One-Handed" weapons but by having that SUB-CATEGORY it opened up a way for FromSoft to create weapon arts and animation styles that make the gameplay feel so DIVERSE, Overall the game is still FUN as hell, my gripe over lacking weaponry doesnt diminish that fact so if you have the spare money to buy this go for it, its literally just anime with dark souls-esque gameplay.

This game is a BLAST. Essentially, the game combines the gameplay elements of Dark Souls, with the aesthetic of a Japanese RPG (titles like God Eater, Tales of Arise, and even Final Fantasy come to mind.) But where this game really shines in my opinion, is that it takes these elements and doesn't overdo any of them. You have a fair share of "anime edginess" and goofy tropes but not to such an extent that the game's tone is ruined. 

As mentioned previously, the gameplay is similar to Dark Souls but is more elaborate and statistical. As a result, the game is easier on new players, and the learning curve isn't as severe as DS. The gameplay is very fun, and to a level addicting. You'll constantly be shifting your playstyle, because this game (unlike the original DS) features distinct classes that each have their own "perks." 

The pacing in this game works well with the classes you've acquired, because each new setting allows you to "test-out" the different classes you've acquired, allowing you to refine what style of play appeals to you. 

Maybe you want to swing a giant anime sword that twice your size and makes it look like your compensating (looking at you Cloud Strife-looking ass) and want to stagger your opponents and tank hits. Alternatively, maybe you'd rather go for a traditional DS build that focuses on decent stamina for dodge rolling and parrying. There's a class for every playstyle here, and if you're having trouble with the game I strongly urge you to switch your class (called "blood-codes" in this game) and see if the game is easier for you. 

My main gripes with this game is the level of content and playtime available. I think as an opening to a new franchise that hasn't developed a loyal fanbase, the length is fair. It's not ridiculously short, but once you've finished the game you'll have enjoyed it so much you'll want more and likely feel unsatisfied. 

The other gripe I have relates to a lack of enemies and how small the world feels. Some of the transitional scenes have you walking through memories of the player and other characters and although it provides an interesting narrative often drags a bit and leaves me wanting to get back to fighting ASAP. Maybe offer players the option to skip the walk-through sections in future releases. 

Summary:

Code Vein is a Hack and Slash, Dark Souls-like that in my opinion is a great starting point for anyone interested in playing games like DS. It's less intimidating, easier to learn and you have a partner backing you up who revives you if you go down. In every way, shape, and form- CV is less intimidating than DS. As a fan of DS this is a good thing, because it feels like less of an undertaking than replaying DS and missing something. 

CV=Casual and more forgiving DS. 8/10. Try the demo first.

I am a 45 y/o mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mother to my Son, who is 14 now. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my husband had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Listen, the combat is atrocious. What they were going for was exactly what ds3 was going for, to give you multiple different sets of playstyles to choose from where each playstyle varies your weapons and your weapons vary your playstyle, but what they ended up with was the player not knowing ANY of the details of how these weapons, bloodcodes, and gifts synergize. Probably because none of them actually do. The stats page for each weapon is SO in depth but the range of loot in the game makes it so that you're only ever looking at the damage output for any weapon because the rest of the stuff you'll find is quite literally exactly the same. 

You straight up won't hit any backstabs whether it's because of the pin-perfect precision you have to have to find where the backstab will stab (again, not explained where the hit boxes are or are near at any point and every hit box is different), or because the camera is freaking out so much that you can't see what you're trying to backstab. 

There is only one viable class, and it's the ranger because it gives you more I-frames and you can attack from a distance. Tried the first boss using the fighter code, and I never beat it. The animations are just too damn long on any other blood code, the dodge rolls are dodgy, in that they barely give you invulnerability at all to the point that when I went to look up a playthrough, I was appalled to find that you are "supposed to dodge twice just in case the first dodge doesn't work" - some walkthrough person on youtube idk.

It's really nothing like souls, tbh, it's like dark souls 1 maybe but everything's infinitely faster and more precise than you could ever be just due to the frames and animations of your character, so it feels slow, the "class customization" is linear and clunky with little to no info given effectively to the player, and the bosses aren't just unfair, but unfun. Whereas souls and souls like bosses feel challenging, but like there's a puzzle and a million different ways you can solve them while beating them, these just feel like a bad crossword puzzle. Like "3 letters, animal. Dog" and the game's like "No, cat you fucking idiot."

There's also this problem with inputs, like I'd go forward, but the game'd freak out and make me roll backward if I was locked onto an enemy. It's little things like that that make this feel less tight and yet more constrained than any From Software title.

They also attempted a Sekiro Posture system in this where (and I don't know how you build this posture meter, but I can assure you that I indeed did, somehow) you can do one extra attack that does better damage but sacrifices all your stamina no matter what. It doesn't auto aim even when you're focused on an enemy, though so good luck hitting.

That being said...

I got it for 9 bucks on sale. i'd pay 9 for it for a few reasons:

- It's beautiful. The graphics, voice acting, and character customization options are astounding at every glance. I wish there was an option to adjust my fov, but it never felt motion sickening.
- There's this hub with a bunch of different characters and a couch. Your character will pass out on any surface they can sit or lie on and there's a jukebox that they can listen to while they fall asleep. I'd buy the game if it was just this couch, it's more cozy and inviting than any dreamlight valley or animal crossing house I've ever experienced. 
- They have Black Characters and Characters of Color. Seems like it should just be this way, but I just played Genshin impact for the first time, so I sadly have to give credit where credit's due. Not just that, the character creator is very expansive and fun to play around with. I loved my character I made, too bad they can't fight.
- Great level design with looping structures and secrets to be found.
- I assume the story'd be a lot of fun too, I liked the 5 hrs I played of it. I'm not gonna play any more, but if you're just here for that, it does seem sort of DMC meets Bloodborne.
- The armor system is very interesting. Each armor grants you a special backstab, parry, and heavy attack animation with different frame animations and speeds. I'd love to see this implemented into a better combat system. The same with the companions you find. You have the option to play solo or with people you meet throughout the game. When you die, they have the option to give you some of their health and they each play somewhat differently. I liked the companions, it made me feel like I was playing a solo multiplayer game, which must be what the devs had in mind.
- Overall, the game has a certain charm to it that did really invest me more than most games I play. 

To call this a 6/10 is generous. 4/10 with some flavor bc it's very pretty. Again, i'd pay 9 bucks for it, going in knowing that it's clunky, but I'm not playing it again lol

Code Vein is loaded with beautifully animated, fully voiced cutscenes, some of which I found surprisingly affecting, but the most important line in the entire game is this: "does not open from this side". Because while Code Vein is a third-person action-RPG unabashedly styled after Dark Souls, more than anything, it's a dungeon-crawler. It's a game about collecting keys, scouring maps, fighting bosses and, most importantly, opening doors. If you go into it expecting Dark Souls, you'll be disappointed. That said, I had a lot more fun with Code Vein than I expected, and despite all its faults, I kind of want to play through it again.
