Code Vein is an interesting take on the souls-like genre.
It leans more towards A/JRPG than what you might expect.

Some things to note:
[list]
    [*]+Distinct anime artstyle, which looks pretty good
    [*]+Great OST
    [*]+Interesting story, although very anime logic at points
    [*]+One of the best character creators in an RPG
    [*]+Very good JP Voice acting
    [*]-Prone to rare UE4 crashing
    [*]-Hiccups in obvious loading zones
    [*]-Some story fragments are very interruptive and slow (Both optional and mandatory ones)
    [*]-Sometimes very annoying level mechanics
[/list]

Besides the main point, we need to discuss of course, it being a Soulslike, and it's distinctions:
[list]
    [*]The game is much easier, thanks to the companions, and its more RPG-like elements
    [*]I felt only mostly the late game bosses were well-designed and memorable
    [*]Heavier story focus and linearity
    [*]Mostly linear level design with branching paths(if not it's a hell maze), sometimes tries to be DS1 or Bloodborne too much in my opinion
    [*]Easy class and build changing possibilities, lot of space for experimentation
    [*]Interconnected world with loading tunnels, sadly not bringing out the potential
    [*]Has some interesting and good ideas on it's own, which I wish other games would learn from.
    [*]Pretty short[/list]

[b]As a Dark Souls fan, I can highly recommend the game if you want a comparably relaxing ARPG with familiar elements.[/b]

Anime Dark Souls is a term thrown around a lot for this game and it would be more accurate to say its anime attempting to be Dark Souls.  Its easy to see in that many of the notable aspects of Dark Souls are pretty much just copied into the game and renamed (Undead -> Revenants, Souls -> Haze, Bonfires are Mistles, etc).  

Combat feels like a combination of Dark Souls and Spectacle Fighter games like Nier but ends up worse than either by themselves. Base DS mechanics are pretty much copied in but without understanding the nuances behind them or weren't balanced right with the SP mechanics.  Parry is useful but has a long animation leading to limited windows of execution.  Dodge is there but lacks consistent i-frames.  You can block but still take a portion of damage. Enemies often launch quick successive combo and close distance faster than you can move away.  Many times you will find yourself mashing the dodge/block button while stuck in lengthy cast/use animations.  The game allows for AI companions throughout the game which can help can but is also inconsistent.  Sometimes you end up watching as the AI just solos mobs while others they'll get trapped in a combo and 1 shoted.  This combination can often lead to you frantically running around until the boss changes to the AI so you have time for lengthy recovery animations.  This also leads to you standing at the entrance of the room for the boss to kill you because the companion got wrecked at the start of the fight.  There's also a special attack but again its an extra long cast animation dramatically limiting use.  You can also use it in combo but it aborts the combo and feels out of place.

Character setup is probably where it differs the most from DS but overall feels unpolished.  Throughout the game you unlock what are basically classes which have a different base stats scale skills and abilities.  However most skills/abilities can be "mastered" allowing for use outside the class leading to most classes being left by the wayside as once these are mastered.  Used classes limited to those with the best stats for a build and the select few with unique abilities that cannot be used outside the class.  The high number of skill/abilities lead to some seeming to be duplicates or having the smallest of differences.  The large number ability slots does allow for a nice of selection of choices mixing both buffs and casts.

For equipment you have 3 slots, 2 weapons and 1 armor.  There are 5 category of weapons but weapons in the same category can have different combos which gives a good variety of combat styles.  There isn't an obvious way to tell which combo weapons have and what the swing speed of the combo is.  This can be frustrating in the beginning when you get a bayonet that fire is a shotgun spray instead the expected rifle shot.  The armor piece gives defense but is also determines which of the special attacks you have. However similar to classes the armor share designed to allow an abundance of customization, mixing different stats with each special type so you can have the ranged tail attack with stats better suited for close in melees tank.  This makes trying to find/determine which to use difficult as options can be counter intuitive.  All 3 can be upgrade in a DS manner but for the most part only damage is modified so it really isn't useful for armor if you aren't using the special attack.

The world and background for the story has potential though in normal fashion it consists of a world following a calamity where survivors cling to life, dead roam freely and player has to save everyone with there special powers.  It could be an interesting take but the execution is poor.  Feels like they tried to follow the DS route where the player has to piece everything together from different fragments but still wanted the anime style cut scenes and characters which results in dialog and interactions missing context.  Gives the feeling that everyone but the player know whats going on and the player's character is to afraid ask.  The characters are all over the place where their actions not reflecting events that have happened some of which might be do the game branching at times so they have to react as though things may or may not have happened.  But it wouldn't account for all the inconsistencies and a lot of it seems like they acceptance of events is because the story demands.  The memory collection is an interesting concept to fill in background and details but characters barely respond to their content.  The party is given every reason to distrust/hate a character but then immediately accept them because the story demands it.  By the end the story comes full circle to the Dark Souls comparison with the its own version of linking of the bonfire.

if you don't mind an almost unhealthy amount of anime in your souls-like games, then code vein is definitely up your alley.
 PROS :The combat is good, the soundtrack is great, you have access to a pretty flexible system to customize your character and playstyle. Visually, the game looks nice overall. the partner you bring with you makes the game feel more alive. Yakumo is a real bro

 CONS :The level design is a bit meh, and the story is going to be a big hit-or-miss for certain folks (cheesy anime vibes). The fact that there's only 5 weapon types feels a bit restrictive, altough there's quite a few weapons with different movesets in each types.

 if those things do not bother you (or not too much) then i'd say you should give it a go! the game will run you about 30-35 hours to finish, and there's a few achivements to hunt afterwards for an extra little bit of game time. you can run it again on NG+ to challenge yourself and see the different endings. pro-tip : don't look at the achivements of steam, they do spoil a few things.

There are a lot of other reviews that cover most of what I'd say, so I'll get into the things I liked about this game. It offers a souls-like experience with way more flexibility than the other games in that style that I've tried. Don't like your character class? Change it whenever you want. Don't like your abilities? Unlock other ones and put together the whackiest build you can think of. Is the game too easy? Play it solo without a companion. Is the game too hard? Play it with the AI companion. Is it still too hard? Play it with a companion and a friend. The level of control you have over your experience is very refreshing in this game, and there is never a point where you are stuck in a certain playstyle or tactic. That's the main thing I liked about CV.

This game is dumb, cheesy, completely un-self-aware, has some really questionable design choices (looking at that one pole-dancing salamander hatsune miku boss as an example), and it's excessively anime-y (like there is an early 2010s level AMV midway through the game). But underneath all that is a fun souls-like that really puts you in control of how you get beaten down by its brutal bosses.

To be honest I got this game on a whim during Thanksgiving sale, pretty much only for the character creator. So I get in, spend like 7 hours making characters, and decided "but I want to see them in action :(", and slammed the start button.

Now, I'm not a "gamer". Objectively I am still bad at the game, and there's a lot I can improve upon (what's a parry button?). Code Vein itself isn't a story-driven masterpiece, some things look wacky and the cutscenes are all designed with the player wielding a one-handed sword in mind. That said, the story isn't bad. I'd say it's actually pretty good. 
The best part is that character lore isn't really shoved on you. You can collect Vestiges (memories?) for the abilities and just skip the cutscenes, or watch them all and learn in-depth the story of the character behind a certain Blood Code.
What you choose and what you don't makes an active difference in the direction the story takes, up to a certain extent of course. Collecting all the shinies can make the difference between sobbing and crying happy tears. Conversely, not collecting them causes all sorts of plot threads to go in a different direction.

Is the game itself hard? Yes, I mean it's a souls-like what did you expect? The combat gameplay is golden to my fresh eyes, having never touched anything remotely like this before. Every weapon, Blood Code (class?), and Blood Veil (armor) that you choose directly impacts how you move and by that extent, how you play. The Gifts (magic/skills) you can get are as varied as the Blood Codes themselves, and each Gift or Code you unlock brings a new flavor of possibility. You can also change Gifts, Blood Codes, and Veils on the fly which is pretty cool (and continues to save my life).
Being bad at the game, I of course wanted to give up several times after spending anywhere upwards of an hour beating my head against the brick wall that was map-less navigation or a hard boss/enemy. What kept me going was the NPC dialogue. Yes, you get your choice of (at the latter third of the game, if certain conditions are met) one out of 6 NPC companions to accompany you into the field. Each wields a different weapon, fights a different way, and brings different party buffs to the fight. 

In my opinion, the best part about having a companion with you is the mental support they give, not the physical. Sure having a waifu with a gun or a hot guy with a sword is cool and all, but each NPC will encourage you, calm you down, or get you back on your feet again in their own different way. They don't complain about dying over and over, they talk about finding a solution, and say it's ok to try. Unironically, that same dialogue is what kept me playing and yes I somehow beat the final boss.

Can I guarantee you'll like it? No, the art style, story direction, gameplay etc isn't for everyone. There are some parts I don't like, things I wish were added in, and so on, but the game itself is definitely worth a shot. Take the step out of your comfort zone and let Code Vein bring what may very well be a new flavor of entertainment to your world.
- FragariaNoKami
PS: don't be afraid to send for co-op, oftentimes anyone who joins is there to help you with whatever

The starting area's city literally looks like Crisis City from Sonic '06 but without all the flames and messed up gamma. 10/10, this was my first soulslike (dark souls 1 and 2 can't run on my laptop and dark souls 3 costs more than a heart donor in the black market so I didn't even bother trying) but it's been a good overall experience. The difficulty spike isn't vertical like people make it seem.

True to the Dark Souls formula with an Anime aesthetic to it. Slightly easier since you have a partner through the entire game that can take aggro when you need to flee. The game is of course, pretty challenging and definitely throws some cheap ways to kill you.

The story was pretty decent and teh game offers 3 different endings. The environments are really detailed as well as teh character and enemy designs. The boss designs are really cool looking too. Levels are mostly linear but can get confusing since the devs designed them like a maze that get you to circle back alot. They do feel rather large since most areas transition into each other without a loading screen. Like FromSoft games, the weapons and armors all have unique designs and compliment the characters really well. CodeVein has it's own style though and with your partner, you can obtain special skills from other partners to use in combat.

There were some minor micro stutters here and there but nothing too drastic and I never experienced a stutter during an actual fight. There are a few clipping visuals in early cutscenes with armors and hair, but is just more of a nitpick really. Running also feels sluggish and almost similar to Monster Hunter in a way, I was usually dodge rolling everywhere I could since it was faster.

Out of all the level designs, The Cathedral of the Sacred Blood is probably one of the worst designs i've ever played in a Souls game, let alone any game. The sheer size of it mixed with the massive back tracking, specific keys, hidden pathways, death around every ledge and corner, and teh massive maze like structure, made this specific part of the game a true test of patience. At times I got lost, and other times I found myself falling off ledges and floor holes. Compared to the other levels of teh game, this part took me a better part of 4hrs to do specifically because of how lost I got.

Overall a fun souls game. It's different, but enjoyable, with cool designs and decent story.

Everything this game does is anywhere between ok and atrocious.

• Combat is very anime, but also kind of clunky, which doesn't feel good
• A lot of weird quality-of-life designs. Example: skills are represented as simple, minimalistic, monochromatic icons, and there's a lot of them. Looking for a particular one is like needle in a haystack
• Far too many cutscenes (some of them unskippable!) - sometimes you watch a cutscene, walk 20m and get another cutscene, it just shatters the flow of gameplay
• Enemies and locations are kind of forgettable at best, and some are inspired (bordering on ripped off) by other games (including a scuffed version of Anor Londo and even Ornstein and Smough!)
• A lot of tight spaces and narrow walkways that make too little space for combat with an AI companion...
• ...but the game is balanced for playing with the companion, so playing alone is like hard mode - in a soulslike
• Blood codes are cool on paper, but lack the option of fine-tuning your character - you need a C+ stat for a weapon, but have C? Shame, choose another code, or another weapon. (To be fair, later in game you unlock passive skills increasing your stats)

Anime boobs cannot make up for all of the bad parts. If you care for them at all in the first place.

This game does a lot of things well, beautiful character creation, nice combat feel, interesting skill tree system, world build and general polish, but everything past the first area with the parking lot is terribly, terribly designed. The areas are not made to be fun, they're purposefully made to confuse you with very similar rooms and trap you in empty mazes that you'll run around for 15-20 minutes at a time wishing you could be having fun instead. Another thing I didn't like in this game is you're basically forced to play with an NPC because the areas have way too many enemies and take extremely long to clear without a companion, and it's obviously designed to be played with a companion all the way, but then the game becomes really easy with the NPC and it doesn't really feel like a tactical souls-like when you have an NPC running ahead of you and going berserk on the enemies all the time. This game pretends it's souls-like but it's really just a companion JRPG with very malicious level design.

So far it's been good fun. A "souls-like" combat system set in the lore of a post-apocalypse society where resources have had their inherent values shifted by new ones that are literally must haves to survive and are ever more scarce while everything starts to run out to boot. If you enjoy "souls-like" games or apocalypse stories enough to buy them, this one's a good find. 

If I absolutely had to have a complaint, it'd be that there are a few encounters which were rather poorly planned and end up being a HUGE sudden spike in difficulty for no particularly evident reason. That said, on paper most of them would seem harmless enough at first unless you're running a specific playstyle that matches up poorly, so it's not an overly grievous error in most cases. The exception of course being one particularly infamous fight that isn't even a "real" boss yet makes literally every other fight before it look like a bad joke (it's actually pretty disgusting I'll admit). Dunno what's up with that one, guess someone had an off day at the office or something.

The quick summary: If you like dark souls and anime, this game will likely suit you very well.

The nitty gritty:
As implied above, Code Vein is a souls-like game but in an anime universe. As a person who has tried playing Dark Souls one 6 or 7 times and not finished it once, I can say that Code Vein does things differently, and in my personal opinion it does those things better than Dark Souls (since I continued playing all the way through, unlike Dark Souls).

With that out of the way, the good:
*Gameplay mechanics are quite interesting and dare I say unique. Some things are of course "borrowed" from other souls like games, however there are unique aspects that made it different and interesting (mainly the blood code system and various skills.
Control of your character, unlike in Dark Souls is quite responsive and quick which at least makes you feel like you're more in control of your character.
*Story - while not something earth-shattering, the story is unique and at times quite interesting. 

The okay:
*Character development - During the span of the game I did become attached to a couple of the characters (namely Yakumo and Louis), but some of the other characters I just couldn't force myself to care about. Maybe that says something about me, but I'm leaning towards the writing for the characters. It seems like some trauma is introduced at random and I just struggled to connect with the characters. That being said it wasn't all bad so this lands in this middle section.
*Map design - Whilst generally the maps are okay and have a degree of variance to them, I take particular issue with the cathedral and also extensive reuse of the assets from it in a lot of other maps.

The bad:
*Controls - despite the responsiveness of the controls, this definitely feels like a ported game. The default controls for keyboard and mouse are atrocious and I highly recommend using a controller to play this game.
*Aspect-ratio - it seems Bandai Namco continues to not support 21:9 aspect ratios, which is really odd to me, especially for a game released in 2019 and even more so when support for it is "technically" in the game, but is just obfuscated.
*Optimisation - this game has some bad optimisation issues. Playing on 3440x1440 with everything maxed on an RTX 3070 I would easilly hit my frame limit of 144Hz, but at certain times during regular gameplay this framerate would absolutely crater into the ~60 range with bad stuttering (but would then recover within a fraction of a second). This made the game feel choppy and laggy at times, despite my hardware being fully capable of running this game full tilt.
*Achievements - I hate it when games have achievements that are basically impossible to achieve or are unbelievably difficult to achieve just for the hell of it. This game is no exception and whilst the majority of the achievements are not very difficult to get, there's one in particular that forces you to grind tens of hours to achieve and even more if you dont have a friend to play with. This is bad design.
*DLC - the DLCs really shouldnt be DLCs and should just be part of the base game with how little the add to the game. Dont believe me? Have a look at the individual reviews for them.

Summary:
Overall, Code Vein is an interesting take on souls-like games and I think its worth your time and money if you can get it on sale. That being said, tailor your expectations and dont expect to be blown away by it.

Anime Dark Souls is a fair summary, but going deeper:

[b] Pros [/b]: Combat is nice, character creation is really nice, building is very versatile and the story ends up being different/innovative and cool to see, albeit confusing at times (and I ended feeling like many questions went unanswered). Also, the difficulty is there (definitely not an easy game), but it gets very manageable  after you learn to dodge (even at boss fights).

[b] Cons [/b]: Game is too linear, story drags on for quite some time and only gets interesting from the mid-game onwards (before that you really have no idea why you're doing all that stuff), enemies and most maps are between the boring and the uninspiring. [b] TOO MANY SEXUALIZED CHARACTERS: why the hell is every female NPC wearing rags or super revealing clothes? [/b] Seeing that only in the female characters made me feel like a creep. 
Albeit the skills are very varied, there's not many viable weapons and "armors", so I ended up using the same bunch of equipments for most of the game.

TL;DR: Overall, a decent game with multiple unsolved technical problem. Not entirely unplayable, just make sure you are not very easy to get frustrated if you want to enjoy your time. From my personal experience, I cannot bring myself to recommend this game as it is at the moment. If my opinion change further into the game, I will update this review. (UPDATE: Finished the game, opinion stands).

SPOILERS WARNING.

- Level design: Maze simulator, and not 2D maze, it's 3D maze. Finally lost it after 5 hours walking around in the cathedral. Apparently it is quite universal that this is the infamously most notorious level of this game, so I hope it get better. Quite a few dead-end that does not reward anything (some big empty rooms that have reward worth one trash mob money, for example: I saw quite a few of them to be "Queen Iron" which cost 1k in shop, and you get 970 from killing the weakest enemy type in the level).  Multiple instances of "check point just out of reach". Constructively speaking, a feature that tell player where to go to progress would do nicely here (like an on-screen quest objective with suggestive texts, for example, "Find the mechanism just opened somewhere near the right side of the Cathedral entrance"). "Let" them explore, don't "make" them explore.
- Combat: Decent combat design, questionable implementation. Unclear distinction (or is there any at all?) between counterable and non-counterable attacks, most counters take too long to wind up to be usable with reflexes. Counter boss only stop their combo. Other mobs still continue attacking you while you are in counter animation, and counter have recovery frames where you don't have control and vulnerable at the end of it, so if you counter while face against more than 1 mob, you will get hit. Back stab super inconsistent, and you CAN "back stab" when enemy aware of you or mid-combat (what?).
- UX: Game objectives unclear (Example: I got stuck when first enter Home Base. According to a walkthrough, I HAVE to trigger both dialog with Io then talk to Louis right after. If I talk to anyone else or enter the hotspring in between those steps, the story will not continue. I know this is true, because by the time I found the solution I already know what Io say in both of her dialogues so I clearly had triggered them before, yet Louis still tell me to go rest when I tried one last time before talking to Io again.)
- Story: up to now (cathedral, after Berserker and memory) I can only say it's meh. You don't know who you are, what you need to do, what is your mission, you just follow who ever you meet on the way while helping another person and help them, which make the story go everywhere.
- Challenges: only one I can see so far called "Depth", basically a small level where you farm old bosses for materials, but they do not scale up in any way (yet?), and become redundant after literally one single run for completion sake.
- Replayability: There are multiple "classes" you can build into, and master skills in that class let you use the skill when spec into other classes, which in theory can open up different combat styles when you play the game again. One down side is there are not many weapon/ veil type. The replayability is there, but not a lot as far as I have seen. So far I haven't seen any "unique" gear with interesting stats, like a 2 handed weapon but scale with Mind instead of Strength for example, just in the interest of expand the playstyle combinations.


- UPDATE: I finished the game, and decided to keep my review as is, because of some newly discovered things that I found to be negative to my gameplay experience, plus I can't say the game get better other than maps become less confusing.
     + Bosses are pushover, none of them are challenging, not sure because I was overleveled so much after cathedral but I doubt it will change even if my damage is cut in half. Fist-tried most bosses in the game. (Died once to Breath, and twice to Ribcage).
     + Unclear status effect: sometimes monster enter states where they take what feel like 95% less damage without any indication. The boreus ice armor is a good implementation with clear visual indication and casting animation, but the Canoneer and the Butterfly of Delirium I have zero idea why they take sub 100 damage sometimes when I normally swing at them for almost 2k.
     + Some abilities got unlocked too late into the game, limiting build viability (status effect stacking speed passive get unlocked after the 4th to the last level, and hidden in the depth. I tried venom build, but most thing died before I can even fully stack venom, this one trait would open so many possibility if it's unlocked near the beginning).
      + Tease a highly-detailed monster (the horrors) just for it to appear in ONE cutscene will lead player to think they going to face those monsters down the line. And when the game end before they have the chance to fight it, that is an immeasurable disappointment.
      + Gimmicky unavoidable level design mechanic that flat out negate an entire build option. Yes I'm looking at you, sand.
      + Story flaws:
             = The shortest main villain life time I have ever seen in any media. The dude only get 2 cutscenes and the plot is shallow. "Here is the villain, now he's dead, now you tie the lose ends and the credit roll."
             = I don't know why Yakumo have a relic inside him, but counting that, there should be total of 4 extra relics. I'm guessed those are cut contents. And as the result, we got a weirdly paced story.
             = And what's the deal with Karen? She's one-off character so far, beside that one time in MC memory. And why didn't the villain take her relic? If she have the power to create blood bead, seize that relic and give it to one of his puppet would effectively monopolize blood bead no? And just from that, Silva's Levy system would be broken and the wall is just a matter of time before he run out of blood. (Oh wait, so the villain is scared of the cathedral as well? well that's understandable.)

When first played, I made a few connections to the Souls-borne series, and compared them for a while due to the game-play mechanics. But, after a while, I started to see this as a completely different game, that only drew some elements from Souls-borne, such as some aspects of combat, and how the currency works/ what its used for. Since this is an anime game, their is a cohesive story line that doesn't require deep research to try to understand how the world you enter into is the way it is, why the Bosses are there, charters backstories, and it even establishes a way to make every time you die a normal event. 
Code Vein easily is its own game in its own right, and, is better to me than any Souls-borne game, despite not being nearly as hard.

Code Vein is - a very Mediocre Soulslike.  I am currently at this games O&S and it's crystal clear to me at this point what I don't like about this game.

 I can understand that the story, the constant stop and start of gameplay when story kicks in, and the hokey dialogue are all things that if I were a big anime game enjoyer, I'd probably like but the actual boss fights and moment to moment gameplay is simply so below it's contemporaries it isn't even funny.  

As I get reamed by the Cannoneer and Blade Bearer I see it clearly - Both bosses are fully focused on my partner. I am low on health, I try to heal, the Cannoneer summons a fire pillar below me, I die. I see it clearly. 

A complete and fundamental misunderstanding about what makes these games fun. Dying to bullshit isn't why I play soulslikes - and this game is Bullshit.

You also have a compainion that helps you in your fights and can also revive you even tho they seem to sometimes forget to do that.
There are also quite a few bosses in the game, some of them are easy and some are quite difficult.
I bought the game when it was on discount, it's on discount quite often actually so don't worry about the 50$ just wait for a discount if you don't want to spend that much money. 
That's all you'll get from me, I hope you enjoy the game.

Fun Game. 
Was hesitant to buy based on some negative reviews, but as a "Souls-like" fan - gave it a try when it was on deep discount. 
After 30hrs, completed the game and very much enjoyed it. 
Initially it's a bit confusing with the way codes/weapons/armor/stats are connected- but it slowly started to make sense and turned out to be an interesting twist to the souls like formula. It's not perfect (the way armor/vestiges are handled is just useless/dumb/pointless) but it's the other apects are neat and the system allows for fun build tweaking.
The anime style isn't for me , but yet the game was enjoyable and the art style was cool enough. I skipped every cutscene immediately and didn't care about the story , yet found the game enjoyable regardless.
If you like any souls type game - this should be enjoyable for you and a value purchase when on sale for sure.

I really like this game. I played the heck out of it on PS4 back in the day and bought it here and have been playing the heck out of it on Steam.

That said, it isn't without its problems - The main ones being that parrying is completely worthless, back/sneak attacks feel like a coin toss a lot of the time, and constantly swapping weapons/veils, codes and passives/gifts can get really annoying, especially at endgame. A little more loadout customization would go a long way.

All in all, it's a slightly janky, anime Dark Souls with the best character creation I've ever seen in a game. Story is also anime AF, but under all that cheez, it's got a lot of heart.
It's on sale right now (11.26.2022) and absolutely worth the $8 USD.

👎🏻This game is not made for keyboard play.👎🏻
Even after remapping the keys, it simply just does not work without taking your hand from the mouse to hit additional keys on the keyboard at times. The two shift keys are set independently. Trying to reset one to another while already set does not work. You can not have 'Run' shift and 'Drain' shift + left mouse set to the same shift(like left shift).  The game expects you to use Alt, C and Ctrl. You will also need to use the up arrow and down arrow. You have 8 'Gifts'(skills) keys you need to use in battle, these come preset as Shift + Fkeys. I remapped the 'Gifts' to Q, E, R, F, 1, 2, 3, and 4 with no shift. Even with remapping as best I could I ran out of keys I could hit with my left hand while still using WASD to move and on my 5 button mouse. You will need to hit additional keys while moving in boss fights(item use, weapon swap etc). Get a controller if you are going to play this game. To exit this IS one of those games where 'Exit Game' brings you back to the game start and you have to hit like 6 more keys to actually exit.

That being said about the keys. The game is well done. ❤️You can spend over an hour designing your character, male or female.❤️ 

This is not a game for people who throw controllers or slam keyboards. The combat is for realz.

I've always liked a souls type games and the difficulty around it. Code Vein brought me into a new Genre of games and I'm really happy for it. Where as other games like a souls type games have the basic hack n' slash or magic and tools to survive on your own, Code Vein isn't like that right off the bat you have a introductory tutorial (that is able to be skipped) that explains in detail how to play with the features and buttons of the game. Not only that but it also explains the type of blood codes, veils, and Ichor usages. Also after the tutorial and into the actual game itself you have a partner with you to help you through the begging stages of the game (which also can be enabled or disabled if you like solo play more or co-oping with a bot) that can rez you when you nearly die and other features the deeper in the game you go. After plaything through the game again i am remind of why i enjoyed this type of game it's not as frustrating as souls games like dark souls or bloodborne to name a few while yes it does have it's frustrating moments it's not as bad. The game also has your allies talking to you/your character and saying things that actually help (to me anyway) like "calm down" or "keep cool we got this" all in all it's a very very good game in my book and would recommend it to my friends in fact i have and some of them even picked it up and we've played together. To those returning or freshly joining in this game welcome to the game/ welcome back to the world vein.

Another "Vampire"-game..."yes" and "no". 

As a JRPG - just like Final Fantasy - they share some common things, like sexy-, cute- or chibi-looking characters, a specific type of visuals (models, shaders, textures) and some sort of skill-tree. 
I personally specified myself on 1 of these trees, unlocked most things on the others, so i can use these abilities on my skill-tree and it went pretty fine so far. 


Sadly I already have played the game for a while, but unfortunately could not finish it yet. 
But this surely is something, you won't encounter as well, since i got a questionable individual on my tail, that tries to spoil some games for me by manipulating things - like in this game, enemies (not only boss-monsters) become incredibly hard, though - if i refer to some videos on youtube just as on logic and by using my brain - they can't be that hard, because else they'd be unbeatable and it's not the purpose of enemies in a game to be so - aside from Slender, maybe. 

Currently my char is level 136 already (usually it takes level 50 to beat the final boss in a "normal"-mode game and 75 to 100 in a "hard"-mode)...i play it hard, but struggle with some of the enemies, because that questionable individual remotely manipulates the game's balance. 

I got this proven, since i struggled at 2 pretty decent enemies for a while, then set up my system again, reinstalled the game, loaded the savegame from the cloud and viola, these 2 enemies now were defeatable as they're asumed to be - not to mention with halfway ease for a level 135 character. 
Next enemy though now has been remotely modified again, just like the 2 have been before...on youtube a guy with 900hp less has defeated him easily, whilst my char becomes slaughtered at least, when i got that one to his 2nd form and his hp-bar to the lower quarter. 
You don't have a stupid individual on your tail, so you won't suffer from this mad experience. 


Just saying, you'll surely be able to enjoy it and with the 3 DLCs included, it's worth being bought on discount. 

Sadly i only had it once in a lifetime by now, that playing online and sending a distress-signal was answered by a helpfull player, joining and helping out, so best thing to do, would be, to play it together with friends, so you can help out each other. 
As far as i can tell, there always only can be 2 players in 1 session at a moment, unfortunately there's no real lobby-system, so you can't see, if anyone currently is playing the game at all, making my suggestion above a maybe even more relevant advice, since you can use Steam's integrated messenger to team up. 


I though want to admit, that playing the game, made it obvious to me, that it surely will be easier on a console, since it's originally been designed for.

A pretty easy souls like game and the moves/designs look pretty cool, would recommend for players that would like to get into the souls like genre. 

However I do have some issues with the game, one being the glitches when interacting with npc's, if you interact too fast, the game may think youre still talking to the npc, thus you will be unable to talk to other npcs for abit or until to press esc a few times. Another issues is Cathedral of the Sacred blood. That map in my opinion just looks like the laziest level/map design I've seen, you'll find yourself spending hours going around the same paths up and down the same set of stairs and ladders trying to figure out where in the fk you need to go. That place isn't a Cathedral, its a fken Labyrinth. Lastly, the game doesn't really guide you on how to progress the maps/story, Thus in a way forces you to explore the whole area till 100% til you give up and go to youtube to find out what you should actually be doing.

Overall 7/10

First of all, this isn't just another Souls-like game...Code Vein, unlike other Souls-like titles such
as Dark Souls, Bloodborne, The Surge and even Elden Ring, Code Vein is set in the same post-apocalyptic
world of God Eater. if anything it's a side-story of God Eater, and surprisingly enough to me, D.C. Douglas
aka Albert Wesker plays a couple of characters in this...among them is the Revenant commander, Gregorio Silva.

Now, in terms of gameplay for Code Vein, it play just like any other Souls-like games...with a few exceptions.
Those exceptions being that your weapons, armor & abilities can only be used depending on what class you use.
However, more classes become available whenever you come across these shards called "Vestiges".
They not only reveal narrative to the game's story, but also unlock new classes, and skills to said classes.
The game allows to mix & match skills with other classes to create the ideal build for you.

Beyond that, it plays as good & solid as any Souls game, and the story itself is affected by your completion rate of each map
...and also, depending on how you complete the overall story also affects the ending too. There's 3 endings in total
...anywho, this is the overall summary of my review. I strongly recommend giving it a go. Who knows...you might enjoy it.

[h3]Absolutely recommended if you like souls-like games and anime tropes/themes. I recommend it even more if you played and liked Nioh games, since Code Vein is closer to Nioh than to Dark Souls in general. Code Vein does many things right and despite its shortcomings, I still give it an overall score of 8/10. This game is definitely not for everyone, but it surely was and is for me.[/h3]
[code]
+   is positives
+/- is informational or neutral
-   is negatives
[/code]

+ "Anime Dark Souls" which is basically God Eater, Dark Souls, Nioh and your everyday anime tropes combined into one game
+ NPC and enemy designs are both gorgeous (and in some cases, grotesque in a good/fitting way)
+ General performance is pretty good (I never had performance drops or stability issues like crashing)
+ Story is quite solid when you start to understand it
+ Extensive character creator that is staggeringly well-made and detailed
+ Graphics are very pretty, especially if you get a mod (4K texture mod) to make it even better
+ There is a map! In a souls-like! [b]AND IT'S ACTUALLY USEFUL![/b] (I'm surprised)
+ Voice acting is nothing short of perfect (at least for Japanese)
+ NPC companions have clever AI and can follow you by teleporting if needed
+ You can't roll off a cliff or into a chasm, be it intentionally or unintentionally
+ The ability to use any [b]inheritable[/b] Gift regardless of Blood Code provides incredible build flexibility
+ You can choose to not increase difficulty for an NG+ cycle if you want

+/- Music is masterpiece-tier, [b]BUT[/b] certain tracks get repetitive [i]real fast[/i]
+/- Screenshake can only be disabled by a mod called "Stop Shaking"
+/- Boss fights could have been much better, but I still loved them all (even Oneshot Gilded Hunter / Mido / Skull King and Clusterf*ck The Virgin Born)
+/- Some areas require incredible patience and persistence to traverse
+/- Almost all maps are mazes in one way or another
+/- Many people will dislike the map design (and by extension, the game) because of the previous two points
+/- Gear variety is fairly modest but sufficient
+/- You can get all DLC content (except maps and bosses/fights) if you get a save that has DLC items in it (and that's without owning DLC)
+/- No DLC-exclusive achievements

- The game has Denuvo (get it on a big sale if you hate Denuvo, just like I did)
- Co-op system is [b]ABYSMAL[/b] (especially if you want to consistently progress together with a friend)
- Low replayability unless you go for achievements or do DLC challenges
- Save system could have been better (manual saving is tedious and autosave is wonky)
- Too many cutscenes and walking segments (causes pacing issues if you ask me)
- Teleporting between Mistles gets tedious because of the interface (you have to double-check where you are and where you want to go every time until you learn the location names)
- Some animations are too long for their own (and quite literally everyone else's) good
- DLCs suck big time and add nothing to the story, so they're not essential whatsoever (you can skip them if you are on the fence, check DLC reviews as well if you have doubts or want to know more)


[h2]Other Notes[/h2]

[i][b]ʰᵘᵍᵉ ᵉⁿᵒʳᵐᵒᵘˢ ᵍᶦᵍᵃⁿᵗᶦᶜ ᵃⁿᶦᵐᵉ ᵗᶦᵈ⁻[/b][/i]

[i]Why is everyone's past stories so damn sad? ;-;[/i] Oh, right, the Great Collapse happened.

Teleporting NPC companions spooked me more times than I'd like to admit.

Elevators are a mystery to everyone (even the NPCs).

Dark Souls games have the exact same co-op structure as Code Vein and people complain about Code Vein's. The only difference is how many people you can have in one session at a time. Rest is pretty much identical.

I'm pretty good at noticing inconsistencies in video games and apart from minor environmental inconsistencies, I haven't found any in the story.

A bit of a rant but I wish we could auto-skip cutscenes we already saw just like in Nioh. Considering you have to finish the game 3 times to get all endings, it'd be a very nice QoL addition.

The game constantly tries to pull a sneaky on you with the enemy placements. Enemies around the corners, hanging from ledges, in the snow, on the ceiling, playing dead in a pool of blood... The list goes on. Good part is, you get used to it after the 5th time. Make sure you stab the corpses a few times just in case. Those bastards know how to hide well.

I guess I'm a genuine masochist for liking the map designs, playing through the game 3 times and on top of those, getting all achievements. No one in their right mind would do that, if you ask me.

The infamous [i]Cathedral of the Sacred Blood[/i] is unironically my favorite area. After reading a lot of bad things about it, I was expecting an abysmal experience, but instead I had one hell of a field trip to the 3D Anor Mazelondo. It's as if the map was designed for me. It requires insane levels of patience, persistence and awareness to traverse effectively. Furthermore, it took me 3~ hours to 100% the map (in NG, with 95%+ of the loot discovered) and I struggled very little. Every other map (structurally) was a cakewalk after the Cathedral.

This was a very VERY underwhelming experience. The difficulty can't make up it's mind and is constantly shifting. One boss is extremely difficult and the next can be beaten without any damage taken on your first try. The story was not that bad but the ending was very anti-climactic and just not satisfying

Everything you've heard is true. The f*cking cathedral area is simply atrocious.

Aside from that, it's enjoyable for the first few hours but it devolves into an actual sh*tshow. It really bothers me how generic the story, characters, and pretty much everything is. The story is awfully predictable; it boils down to we are the good guys even though the bad guys had a good reason to do 'bad' things, but no, we are the good guys because we're good. This is just Sword Art Online Dark Souls Edition. Also, you're not even the damn MC, Kirito is! Or whatever the main emo guy is called. It's just painfully generic I don't even know the characters' names. Moreover, they force you into this arsewipe unskippable walking cutscene part when you discover a character's memory! Yes, you read that right! It's not even an actual cutscene! It's the part where you walk soo damn slowly doing boring sh*t, in this case, to trigger a dialogue of a static diorama. It's like Fallout 4's memory den section but way more awful because you repeat this every time you want to unlock classes which grants you new unlockable abilities. The blend of generic characterisation and this will make your arse clench soo hard that you'll wonder if whoever comes up with this sh*t is intentionally causing a worldwide haemorrhoids pandemic, but luckily, most people are smart enough to not buy this game.

My verdict is to save your arse before you contract Code Vein-induced haemorrhoids.

Inept storytelling. Terminology is woefully esoteric for no really good reason (there is no way worldbuilding becomes better because you called clothing "blood veils"). Clunky level design. Unfun bosses. Pointlessly excessive control schemes.

I had my share of fun with Code Vein, but mostly 'despite' than 'thanks to'.
The game somehow grasps Dark Souls game loop pretty nice, but that's one of the few good things, regrettable.
So many things in the game rubs you in the wrong spot (just like Nioh if you play it not looking what your character is wearing). Where defeat in Dark Souls mostly triggers the feeling "yeah, that's my fault, but I'll persevere", the only thing Code Vein's many bosses, enemies and locations did manage is to get me question it's game and level design. The last boss emphasises almost all bad things the game design has.
The story and characters are bland, the only redeeming quality from that side is that the game doesn't shy its fanservice design - but everything else proves it to be more of a hindrance than a feature.
There is nice music, but overall OST is inconsistent, there are some orchestral+choir pieces, rock, 'sad piano anime music', and whatever else. And when the last boss appears it sounds like a parody on a Star Wars theme.
Unfortunately, I can tell many more bad things about the game. But, once again, despite everything I had some fun, and even managed to finish it.
So, not recommended other than on a massive discount (and even then think twice).

One of the best "Dark souls" like games with anime style.

Yet another but not that mediocre Dark Souls clone, but this time in anime style. Code Vein got everything you love (and so do I): a simple combat system that hasn't changed much since Demon Souls; cute girls with big tidies; Warhammer 40k style weaponry - extra huge and pompous guns and melee weapons that the Emperor himself would envy; and STALKER themed respirators but with a bit edgy design. 

There are lots of features that were kindly used from Dark Souls series, besides PVP(there’s simply no PVP). If you’re keen on souls like games, then this game is a good choice especially if you don’t mind anime, and its cliches like extremely unnecessary nudity, impractical weaponry and armory, and way too big anime boobies. However, if you’re fed up with anime related stuff and especially its ecchi, then it’s better to refrain from buying this game. But if you’re looking for some not that hard and punishing souls like coop game without PVP, then this game is a fine choice. 

Overall combat, animations, cutscenes, lore, plot, soundtrack and especially character customization are really nice. The game’s soundtrack and character customization worth a separate review. Of course, the lore and characters’ backstory are not that deep and well-written in comparison with Dark Souls franchise, but still, I can’t consider it bad, just not that memorable, but good enough to immerse you in the world of Code Vein. In short, I do recommend this game for ppl who are looking for good, but not that challenging coop experience. 

Advantages

-Way too beautiful soundtrack that highly suits to the game’s mood. (I personally think this souls inspired game has the best ost among souls like clones)
-Smooth and various combat animations, the animations are nicely done overall. Each weapon has unique several animations, not to mention some active attack gifts for each Blood Code and different finishers. 
-Quite unique lore and characters backstory, you may think the game’s story is meh, but
you’ll find out the game’s world building is above average if you delve into the story.
-Various builds that may diversify gameplay a little. You can also easily change to another build at any time due to simplicity of leveling up your character. 
-Good voice acting. Well, it’s no match to Dark Souls level, but still VA actors did really descent job. Many voice options in character customization.
-Extremely content rich character customization, that offers tons of ways to make your character stand out amongst the others + has great potential in cosplay making. You can easily spend a few hours in creating a character of your dream or your favorite character from tv show.
-Well, it may be controversial, but the game has its unique aesthetic which is far from either medieval design of Dark Souls series or steampunk style of Bloodborne. Art style is strongly inspired DMC & God Eater series, but may be a bit edgy.
-Brings in the new concept of blood veils, that allow to use special drain attacks within their normal attacks to get their ichor back, which is used to cast magic and use special abilities. 
-You can change your build anytime you feel like it. If you’re done being typical tankie swordsman, then you can easily change your build for another typical rogue play style or focus on magic or become a gunner thanks to free-class-changing and no-stat-points system.

Disadvantages

-Way too easy bosses, most of which have quite mediocre look with extremely unnecessary oversexualization. Most of hostile npc have quite varied design, but then the boss appears to be another gigantic, half naked woman with big tidies.
-Excessive nudity, most of outfits, bosses, both hostile and friendly npc are wearing way too revealing and impractical clothes. I don’t mind boobs but cute anime girls with big tidies are ruining immersion of the game’s apocalypse, making it impossible to take the game seriously.
-Like it was mentioned before but the visual part of the game itself is also its problem, as the allegedly gritty story and hopeless world are being wrongly depicted in anime styles, which has its common problem - fan service. Code vein failed to combine something gritty and dark with cute anime girls in sexy outfits, swinging sledgehammers bigger than themselves.
-Quite inconvenient map that can’t be adjusted. You can’t move the map and adjust the elevation, which makes it difficult to navigate in some areas. 
-Character creator lack some things like modifying body shape: no sliders for hands, legs and especially breasts; there’s no option to add muscles, abs and etc. Your character can be just a cute teenage girl as a female or just a skinny teenage boy as male. Character creation requires much more diversity when it comes to adjusting body shape. 
-Poorly made map design in certain locations. Some locations are way too frustrating, grey and monotone, repetitive and far too long. Sometimes during your gameplay, you may 
feel like the devs were too lazy to use more than very few textures. Overall, the game’s map isn’t that bad, but it’s not as genius as Dark Souls. 
-Edgy fashion. Despite the game has its own unique aesthetic strongly inspired by God Eater and DMC, I personally find the game’s fashion quite unfitting to its overall lore, cuz fairly neat and tailored, spiky, sexy and yet edgy girlish clothes are a bit out of place in the gritty, ruined, full of despair apocalyptic world. 
-Allegedly interactive memory cutscenes aren’t interactive at all. You do nothing during the cutscenes, but walking through linear level with depressing music and no less depressing blue lightning. With the time it’s getting more and more boring.

Interesting souls-like where fixed classes have been replaced by "blood codes", which can be replaced at any moment during the game when not in combat. Each blood code has unique stats (STR, DEX etc) and also a unique set of gifts (=skills and perks). After "mastering" these gifts by using them enough, you can use them with other blood codes as well. They way, you can customize your character a lot more than in other souls-likes.

There are a few different styles of weapons in the game, including swords, axes, halberts and bayonettes. Especially the latter is interesting, because you can actually fire a bullet as well. Weapons can (temporary) be infused with different kinds of damage (stun, poison, ice etc), making them more effective against certain types of enemies and bosses. Nice thing is that weapon infusion increases resistance against this type of damage as well. 

The combat is good. Not "From Software" perfect, but lots of fun nevertheless. The difficulty isn't too hard. You're being accompanied by an AI partner all the time, which gives you time to heal when health is low. Some of the boss fights are really frustrating though, mostly because your AI partner dies too soon or because the boss has attacks with a huge range that are hard to predict. Beating these bosses felt more luck than skill to me.

The most significant issue I have with this game is the story telling: the story is mediocre and the characters and cut scenes are very boring. There's also the monotone level design. Most of the levels barely have variation in textures and colors, making them extremely boring to explore. This is a huge disappointment after playing the Souls games with their impressive level design. You're also fighting the same enemies over and over again, once again something that From Software does so much better.

Despite these issues, Code Vein is definitely worth playing if you're a fan of Souls-like games.

While anime style could be a turnoff to some (including me), if you could look past through it, Code Vein brings yet another non-Souls, fresh and fun of hardcore game format to the table. You will begin with simple attacks, but soon you will grow and earn both passive and active skills to equip ranging from physical, magic, and buff. They are mixable with your regular attacks almost seamlessly. The game has a very convenient build system you could switch around at will, though perhaps a gear loadout would be a nice company to that.

Character creation is a bit unconventional; could seem a bit limited at first, but your creativity can go a long way with it. The cons is that the matchmaking sucks balls.
Absolutely worth it.

This game is essentially anime dark souls and I love it. I haven't touched Dark Souls once in my life but I love this game. Character creator gives you free rein on what you can make. Whether that be your waifu (that's what I did) or make the edgiest character possible. Great gameplay, really cool story and lore. 10/10 for me.

The best way to summarize this game, is yes, anime dark souls. However, they do make it a bit more accessible to a wide audience by implementing the ai companion feature. However, if you're looking for a challenge, you can opt out of the companion. Although I would not recommend it until you feel extremely confident. The combat is really in depth, fast paced, and the customization you can on the fly is insane.
 Yes, the cathedral is annoying, but there are several guides you can look up to get through it. I promise the games pace picks up very quickly after that. The story is decent, especially if you're into anime. The different endings do keep it fresh for each play through and conveniently, you can opt to either enhance or not enhance the difficulty on the new game plus modes.
 The DLC, while adding a bit more content, is rather disappointing for a souls game. But if you're wanting end game content with extra loot, and some challenging bosses then by all means, purchase the dlc. All in all, if you like souls games, like anime, and like endless build paths, then get this game, you will get a lot out of it.

This is a anime style soulslike. Pretty fun, very challenging. I feel like only the fastest weapon class is viable though. I didn't play all the way through because the Cathedral of Blood was insanely annoying to me. I recommend using a walkthrough for that part.

Look, I'm gonna be real here: are most of the reviews correct that say this game has some big tiddies and the Cathedral kinda sucks?  Absolutely.  Play it anyway.  

Code Vein was rewarding, the right amount of challenging and the multiple build options for your character (with the ability to change them up at any time!) mean you always have an option to fit your playstyle or you can just change it up if things aren't working.  The story features some excellent moments, though your mileage may vary there.  The more "anime" moments thankfully didn't feel too over-the-top here.  Visually, CV has some gorgeous areas, effects and direction.  

Is it flawless?  God, no.  There's model clipping, some dull spots and a handful of "how do I deal with this" moments in the gameplay, including some late-game areas that were a bit of a chore to navigate (looking at you, burning city), but I wouldn't trade my experience for anything.  I'm not a "beat my head against the wall" hard game fanatic, but CV had just the right amount of everything I wanted from a game like this without feeling unbeatable or too easy.  

If you're on the fence, pick it up, on sale or not.  I don't regret any of the 60+ hours I spent with it and I'm even working on a LVL1 Challenge Run because I enjoyed it that much and because learning the game makes that feel surprisingly doable.  If there's ever a Code Vein 2, trust that will be a day 1 purchase.

6/10 Mild Recommendation. 
This game has a great first 15 hours and as systems and enemy types expand the game becomes less enjoyable.  Some of my favorite souls likes have you learn monster move types and boss patterns.  This game isn't so much about that.  

Other downsides are the horrendous level design that makes up some of the area later into the game.  The cathedral is both massive and the absolute worst area I've ever played in any souls game.  If that was the only bad area it would be one thing but the game has others.  

The story disappointed as well.  I love that this tried to tell a more direct story but I can't pretend that I got invested in the games events. 

So when its all said and done the first 10-15 hours of this game was super fun...probably an 8.5/10...the later two thirds just felt worse and worse to the point where I basically forced myself to finish the game.

This is proving to be really addictive, not as soulslike as I was led to believe (but I consider that a good thing). Great art style. More later as I dive further in.

EDIT: Still think about returning to it, but the game eventually did get too "soulslike" for my tastes. A shame, its very cool otherwise.

for someone who's not good with any souls-like games, i actually had fun with this. the combat's responsive and just feels nice, the companion's AI is a damn treat, and going solo on any boss is actually challenging, and the character creation's just like the wacky ahh Skyrim mods i had that i'm quite ashamed to admit.

I'm going to have to recommend against Code Vein.

The anime look comes out alright and the Blood Veils (armour) look snappy enough, but the soundtrack is largely forgettable. The variety of weapons and monsters is not terrific, but for a shorter game it's adequate.

The story wasn't very good, I'd rather play a Dark Souls or Elden Ring with minimal story than a game with a poor one. The Blood Code memories in particular were self-indulgent and pretentious. For all the time they took, they explained very little of the backstory. I wish you could just fast forward though these.

People accuse Dark Souls 2 of having disjointed areas but that game has nothing on this. You finish climbing a massive set of fantasy medieval towers and arrive at...A modern battlefield? What? The largest area is also the most convoluted and poorly designed, should have called it the Cathedral of the Lost.

As far as battle mechanics go, it's just a stripped down and less well-polished version of Dark Souls. There's a couple of decent little ideas here but it just isn't enough to hold up an independent title.

The game is moderately challenging, but it's not particularly hard for a Souls-like. I was always running out of healing just before the next rest point, and the last few bosses took a few attempts, so at least the difficulty level wasn't too uneven and ramped up appropriately. 

If you're really craving to play another Souls game, it won't exactly disappoint, but it's not the high point of the series either.

Ritmo.

Eso es lo que más disfrutarás del juego, un mundo interconectado, una historia que en lo personal fue la razón por la cual me entrara esta fase de obsesión con JRPG's, unos personajes cuyos nombres no puedo olvidar (y eso que suelo olvidar los nombres mucho), una progresión rítmica prácticamente perfecta, una vez lo agarras, lo entiendes, no lo sueltas, no puedes soltarlo. 
El combate es muy soulslike al inicio que necesitas ser más cauteloso porque los enemigos no perdonan, pero recuerda; ritmo, el ritmo será lo que te salve y te empezará a dar más libertad para que tomes velocidad, con el agregado que esto es un anime y no estás solo. 
Vas a obtener power-ups divertidos y compañeros que mejor te convengan dependiendo de tu estilo de juego, además que no te castiga por no llevar a todos tus compañeros o usar o no un tipo de arma distinto, nah, el juego entiende que todos somos diferentes y no todo es para todos, pero ahí está por si quieres variedad, ahí están los demás personajes por si algo se te complica o por si simplemente lo quieres volver a jugar de otra manera.

También el juego tiene un arte que encuentro particularmente precioso, que por andar inmerso en la historia se me pasaron muy buenos screenshots (lo cual sólo me da otra excusa para volverlo a jugar).

El sentimiento es personal, más grande que en otros juegos del género porque es tu personaje y no uno predeterminado (refiriéndome a los JRPG's).

Tiene un excelente soundtrack envolvente, una ambientación que se siente como casa y neta unos personajes que jamás voy a olvidar. Sólo estoy agarrado en la silla esperando que se anuncie la secuela porque si no existe va a dejar un enorme hueco en mi corazón.
the only thing i dont like is the fact that you can only play with one other player

(summary: "Me angi") With a heavy heart I have to say that I cannot recommend this game. It has some cool concepts with how you can spend Ichor (points you use to do attacks) to use moves without using Stamina to continue your barrage of attacks, or how you can mix and match the different characters skills in the game to make a custom build. But those systems are just about all the game has going for it in my eyes. The characters got really boring and cliche really quickly, and their backstories were unbearably boring to watch mainly because they never change how the memory sequences look. Its always the same Dark Blue and Black color pallet and usually takes place in some kind of run down or abandoned building. Besides for that the areas in the game look interesting on the surface, when you actually start exploring them they just tend to loop around on each other over and over and over again. The Cathedral of Blood for an example is an area in the game that has that exact same issue. Its a maze like level that loops back on itself, gives you "Shortcuts" you never use, a painfully boring atmosphere with the entire areas design being "haha white and spikey". The bosses are no exception either, they are either stupidly easy or they are so artificially hard that they take like 20 minutes of just you wailing on them to even take down. With all of these combined things of the story being mid at best, the overall poor design of the bosses and dungeons, and the cliche characters I will not be playing this game again. I tried to stick it out to see if the end of the game makes up for the rest of the game, and while I did beat it I can say that it just didn't make up for it in my eyes. The only piece of this game I can well and truly compliment is the character creation, thats it.

Really really great game!! I enjoyed it a lot. In a sentence, I would define it as anime Bloodhorne. The story is really good and emotional, I cried a little bit during the game. I love the art decisions of the game and how they chose to deliver the story. The thing that I didn't really like is how that when the player resumed their memories in the cathedral, there was no reaction from our companions when we got back and we just resumed exploring as if nothing happen. Even a simple: hey, are you okay? You spaced out for a little bit would add impact to it. It was one of the most important moment for the player, when they found out who they were before the game and how their abilities are so special. I was sure at least Louis will say something, since he commented before that the abilities of our blood is similar to the blood of the queen. 

I just feel like some scenes were rushed and not written fully. Like the little timeskip at the end of the true ending, where we spoke to everyone at our home. It's like we were comatose for a long time and they shared with us what happened instead of us actually experiencing those moments. Such as everyone turning into normal and coming to our homes. The world becoming a bit of a better place to live in due to Io's sacrifice. How the rest of the world is surviving.

This is a flawed but fun take on the Dark Souls series, which features half-naked anime women with absurdly large breasts and ever-so-slightly unrealistic jiggle physics.

What you need to bear in mind is that this might look and feel like a Dark Souls game, but you cannot play it like a Dark Souls game. You'll gain "Blood Codes" that function more like jobs in a Final Fantasy game, changing your stats and giving you access to different offensive and defensive "Gifts". Master a Gift and you can use it with other Codes, and switching between Codes is like completely resetting your build in Dark Souls. The game is designed around you changing your Code, changing your Gifts, and changing your equipment to best suit the bosses.

Ah, the bosses. The difficulty level of the areas you explore gradually increases throughout the game, with the layouts becoming more convoluted and challenging to navigate, whereas each boss is accompanied by a difficulty spike almost as enormous as some of the female characters' breasts. You will likely get absolutely destroyed by them on your first, second, and third attempts; they're all fast, aggressive, unpredictable, and can kill you in 2 or 3 hits. Almost every boss has a save point nearby, so it's not like you have to travel far to get back to them, although throwing yourself at them time and time again isn't really going to get you anywhere.

Having trouble with a boss that uses poison attacks? Equip armour with high poison resistance, keep an eye out for any Blood Codes with Gifts that protect you from or let you cure poison, and explore the areas to find items to boost your healing ability. That doesn't make the fight easy, just a lot more manageable. I was ready to give up on the final boss until I thought "Well, if it resists all of those, then why don't I use..." and I thrashed it on my next attempt. That's just how the game is designed, for better or worse.

My one serious issue with the game is how you are punished for over-levelling. As I mentioned before, Gifts can be mastered and used with other Blood Codes. Defeating an enemy earns you Gift experience... unless you're at too high a level in a particular area, in which case you don't earn anything. I stayed at as low a level as possible throughout the game anyway, however I can imagine a situation where a player is struggling with a boss, keeps dumping all their souls-sorry, "Haze" into levels to get past it, and then finds that they're stuck with limited move-sets for their Blood Codes, until they move on to an area with a higher level cap. There are items you can use instead to master gifts, but it can be tedious to farm them from enemies.

Overall, I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys Souls-like games, as long as you go into it knowing that it's going to be lacking polish and there will be times when you get frustrated by some sloppy design choices. And there are pretty anime ladies with huge boobs, did I mention that already?

Solid game coming from a dark souls player, even if you're not interested in the story moving through the levels is fun and challenging. The bosses are pretty casual friendly in my opinion, half of the bosses are first tryable and you'll never really get stuck on a boss. Three tries is generally enough to beat the harder bosses. 

The combat feels good to me as a dark souls player, however there is not a good relatively fast but high impact weapon similar to the katana in dark souls, so to me super light with super fast dashes is good, and heavy high impact weapons without fatrolling. If you're intimidated about the extra abilities, dont worry, if you're not a spellcasting type dude you can get by easily with light and heavy attacks and proper rolls and put buffs rather than attacks on the ability slots.

Besides the gameplay the character customization is dope, spent a good hour on this as there are a ton of accessories to recolor and apply.

Code Vein starts out strong, but quickly turns into Chore: The Game. The character editor is a lot of fun and allows a ton of customization, and the beginning of the game feels like you're about to play something good. Maybe not a masterpiece, but certainly a good game. And it stays like this for about the first third of it all. The combat system feels nice, has quite some variety. The world seems cool, the story is intriguing.

Then you get to the cathedral, which has absolutely abysmal level design and sets the tone for most of the rest of the game. After that behemoth of a terrible level, most of everything just blends together. Level design is needlessly complex, often doesn't make much sense. Has too many branches, more than half of the loot is terrible. There's also the depths, which is even more filler content that just exists to pad the time but ultimately feels like a chore to go through.

The final nails in the coffin for me: some of the late game boss fights feel unnecessarily overpowered. And there's a "good ending" that you can miss easily, because the requirement to reach it isn't fully explained. It's not exactly hidden, but still easy to miss one of the steps.

Code Vein could have been a real treat, but in the end, I was just happy I was done with it.

[h1]Anime Souls[/h1]
Good game with an excellent character creator, many weapon and skill options and interesting characters.
It's well worth the experience when the game is on sale. I wouldn't recommend it that much at full price though.
The character creator and the anime aesthetic in a souls-like game are probably enough to justify the purchase, aligned with good side characters and story. However, the game's combat is not that good compared to other games of the genre and the difficulty spikes might cause a little frustration.
It's a great game and a brand new IP that has it's own uniqueness. It has its flaws, but considering that it's a first take of the studio on a souls-like game, they did a good job and a second game has a lot of potential to become one of the pillars of the genre alongside Nioh and Dark Souls.

[b]Good:[/b]
[list]
[*]Excellent character creator. Can create your own Souls waifu; There aren't many games with anime character creators at this level and I've seen amazing creations on the community hub. 
[*]Interesting story and characters with great designs and their own background stories. The character's visuals alone are probably why you're buying this lol
[*]Many types of weapons, skills and builds that can be changed at any time. Can also inherit skills from different Cores to others. Depending on how you build, can change the results dramatically, especially when dealing with bosses.
[*]Satisfying progress and leveling, as expected from a Souls-like game. Deep exploration and puzzling with many forks leading to different areas or interconnect previous areas.
[*]Good PC Port. Runs perfectly at 1440p60 Max on a RTX 2060 Super. Graphics and art style look really good and the frame rate is smooth and stable. Stutters just a little bit when loading new areas but that's a very known Unreal Engine problem.
[*]Takes about 30 hours to finish. I know it has multiple endings and a lot of missable stuff related to the story. I ended up watching the endings on YouTube, but there's a NG+ that carries over everything to unlock the endings.
[/list]

[b]Bad:[/b]
[list]
[*]Memory vestige restoration is incredibly boring, where you just walk and look at static objects with voice which represents the character's past. The stories looked interesting though since it's an important part of character development and better understanding of the story, but the way it was executed made me feel like skipping a lot of it.
[*]Combat is not a prime example of the genre. It's slow and a bit clunky. Healing is the worst part of this game lol
[*]Difficulty spikes and balancing issues are real. It's not that hard overall, but some bosses are very cheap with amazing range, speed and damage while others are very easy.
[*]Relies a lot on the companion's help and damage output to play effectively.
[*]Most of the items you get through exploration are useless.
[/list]

[h1]Code Vein.[/h1]

[i] Relevant for the Steam version of the game. The absolute majority of the game was completed in a co-op with[url=steamcommunity.com/id/androidsentbycyberlife/] my homeboy[/url].[/i]

[b]Cons:[/b]

- Atrocious tutorial, which immediately dumps an enormous amount of information on the player, but at least gives you an opportunity to test everything in the process. Thankfully you can return to the tutorial later on and read text notes about how things work, nonetheless such an introduction to the basic abilities is unacceptable for a 2019 game.

- You're very likely to get lost in a few locations.


[b]Neuter:[/b]

• Just another soulslike with all the usual suspects: bosses, shortcuts, bonfires (mistles), stamina, souls (xp points), etc. You can probably fill in the rest of them by now.

• The game's storytelling is far more comprehensible in Code Vein than in other representatives of the subgenre.


[b]Pros:[/b]

+ Without going into confusing in-game terminology, the player can switch between character classes an unlimited number of times on the fly, whenever they want, even during the fight. Not only it creates infinite replay value and opportunities for experimentation with the build, but in general it's nice to have such a wide variety of choices.

+ Convenient online co-op, which allows you to summon specific players by setting the same password.

+ The combat system is deep thanks to a flexible character class management system. As long as the player fully grasps the nuances of the combat system, the fun is almost guaranteed to be had.

+ You can go on a solo journey through the game, or team up with a friend online. You can also bring AI companions with you (both in solo and co-op modes) and they're hella useful: they can single-handedly dismantle the majority of the enemies and, what's really surprising for a souslike, they can also revive you multiple times. There are 7 companions in the game and you can switch between them at the mistles. Some of them are better, others are worse, but each of them makes tangible contributions not only during the fights, but outside of them too: they react to everything that's happening in the world and make their remarks, and thus participate in the storytelling.

+ Some abilities are unlocked by collecting certain items and by watching mandatory interactive scenes, which shed light on the past events. This is a rather interesting concept, especially for the fans of the lore and players who get invested in the characters. For those who don't, there is an option to skip these cutscenes with memories entirely.

[b]Code Vein is one of the best representatives of the soulslike subgenre with its own story presentation and gameplay features, which unfortunately doesn't make it any less unoriginal. At least give it a shot.[/b]

[i]Recommendation - use a controller for a better experience.[/i]
