I'm not a big fan of Soulslikes (so take this review with a grain of salt). But Code Vein is at heart more a hack and slasher, so I gave it a go. Also, let me admit that I felt no guilt in going to Nexus and downloading a few mods to up the fun. The Partyspawner Mod was great because I could actually play with all the characters that appear in the cut scenes, and it made the fighting a lot less stressful (and the story a tad more immersive). But even by making myself relatively OP, this was kind of a chore to finish.

The Good:
Beautiful environments and sexy anime character designs.
Great character creator.
Good voice acting.
An amazing variety of possible loadouts to fit various play styles.

The meh
The combat is...not bad. It kind of depends on your preferences. I enjoyed playing with the bayonet, but it never got as much fun as I'd hoped.
The ending wasn't bad. But I just felt kind of empty.
Not a lot of enemy types and a few too many baddies overall. I honestly think a few memorable sub-bosses would've been better than this avalanche of samey bad guys.

The bad
The story is written very poorly and cutscenes are pretentious and maudlin and drag on forever. Every time I chose to do a memory walkthrough through one of those vestiges, I regretted it. Such a waste. And being a (mostly) silent protagonist made every cutscene even more awkward. I mean how many times can you nod earnestly in one game?
The Cathedral of the Sacred Blood is a huge blindingly bright maze of a level that is most likely the most irritating couple of hours I've spent in a video game in recent memory. And looking at other reviews, I think I'm not alone in hating this.
And that music. The BGM is technically quite good - dramatic organ and operatic vocals - kinda reminded me of Dragon's Dogma. But the same whiny theme plays constantly throughout the game - and is particularly annoying during the almost comically melodramatic flashback scenes. By the end of my playthrough it might be the music that I was most happy never to experience again.

The verdict: Modding made this tolerable. I mean I was able to finish it. And I only scratched the surface with possible builds. I can see how some people might be able to forgive the terrible, depressing story and just focus on building an amazing badass of a character. But as for me, I couldn't wait to finish this so I could play something else.

Gameplay: Solid. Different types of weapons, each with their own trees of attacks, skills, passives and actives.
Plenty of mechanics to keep you immersed and focused in the action, with tons of customization in terms of your builds, weapon sets, equipment, and play style. 

Environments: Lackluster. Lots of winding, splitting corridors and multi-layered floors. Some areas have decent aesthetics, some a bit boring in terms of layout. Fortunately not so massive you get hopelessly lost, wandering around getting ganked on repeat until you find the way forward, but sometimes confusing due to some areas feeling repetitive. Suffers from "Ambush souls formula" in too many places.

Bosses: Multi-phase monstrosities or intimidating humanoids, just like you'd expect from Soulsborne titles. Slow but unpredictable combos with varying enders, fast lunges with misleading hitboxes/points of impact, wide ranged magical spells the coat an area and keep you running around to avoid them. Plus a lot of them have Tiddies. Honestly the high point of the game in many ways.

Story: If you don't like Anime/Anime-style works, or have seen too much Anime, you're going to see a lot of clichés and tropes that fail to land, are predictable and uninteresting, or surprise you and hit just the way you need them to in order to stay invested. Typical silent protagonist that stares blankly and nods when addressed.  Can be rewarding.

Characters: Mia is okay. Nicola isn't a character. Yakumo is boyfriend. Jack starts off SUPER edgy but chills out quickly. Louis is the bro. Coco is a more mature Cindy Aurum. Rin is fun. Io is Wife.

Basically, game good. Got flaws, but game good. Wait until it's on Sale.

Wonderful game, although the combat is of a faster pace than what you would expect from a traditional Soulslike. 
The world-building is not as in-depth as what you would expect from a traditional dark fantasy, but it is enjoyable and does not take away from the story in any way. 
The companions are fun to have along and all have their own respective personalities and tendencies in a fight, therefore, bringing someone who would complement your own fighting style makes the game all the more enjoyable, immersive even. 
Each individual map is a sandbox. Much like the game Crusader's Quest, CodeVein's levels can be fully explored (by which they mean all the items have been collected) or left as is. Whether the levels are explored or not does not affect the story as a whole. 
Exploration is also encouraged by the existence of mapping as well as teleportation being available from the get-go. 

Regarding player freedom: 
- You are able to customize your character's color scheme and clothing whenever you want in the game, however, the character's features (their body type, their face style/shape/size) cannot be changed after the starting customization 
- You are free to explore maps without the game or story prompting you to do so. Exploration is highly encouraged. 
- (For those who are concerned with the story) You are able to rewatch cutscenes
- You are free to choose between a few companions to better complement your preferred fighting style, as well as switch them out anytime at any savepoint (you may also choose to play solo) 
-You are free to switch between different fighting styles anytime you desire
- SOS signals can only be sent in the vicinity of a boss  
- Like every Soulslike, the difficulty is what you choose it to be 

TLDR, 
Good game, decent story, nice graphics, exploration encouraged, player can customize character anytime.

Either way, if anyone is looking through reviews trying to decide whether or not to download this game and you enjoy souls-like games, I'd highly recommend it.

As something that was my first souls-like game, this is a god masterpiece! I probably spent 5 hours on the avatar settings. Got all the endings, lots of different emotional endings. And i gotta say, if a new sequal comes about code vein, then it will go to my top wishlist.

Gameplay is intruiging, and I respect the devs for their innovative thinking with changing classes on the fly whenever you want and the partner system is actually pretty interesting, but it doesn't save this game from its incredibly unpolished combat system.

None of your attacks have impact at any point and it genuinely feels really clunky. Backstabbing is a constant inconsistency at every point because sometimes it works and sometimes it just becomes a regular attack despite the fact that you're pressing the same button at the same position as you did last time and made sure that your enemy wasn't in any form of stun.

Speaking of story, the game really REALLY wants you to be invested in it so they force you to go through a "memory lane" sequence every time you upgrade a class(which you can thankfully skip, but you're still going through 2 loading screens and potentially a conversation based on which upgrade you got so it's still a massive downtime). This is the only game that does this and it's definitely nothing to praise it about. This also happens when you beat a main boss but that gets a pass because THAT makes more sense.

Clusterfuck of mechanics, the game doesn't know what it wants to be. I can't recommend it, sorry...

Very fun. Code Vein has similar founding mechanics and movement to Dark Souls, but also has other traits that link it with games like Scarlet Nexus. The world-building is coherent and probably warranting some sort of sequel to fully realise it, characters are all likeable and befitting their roles, combat is fluid, areas are very distinct, character customisation is some of the best I've ever seen, build variety is through the roof thanks to how many blood codes (and how easy it is to switch them) there are, and the partner AI is better than most other games.

The soundtrack isn't particularly expansive, with no real music in most areas (like the Souls series) and the same battle themes re-used a lot. There are a few amazing tracks, which you'll know when you get to hear them. At some points it feels like it doesn't have the budget it should've gotten, because if it did then it could've easily had the "polish" Scarlet Nexus does. Still, it doesn't detract from the experience too much.

Definitely worth playing if it catches your interest prior to buying it.

I very much enjoyed the game despite its obvious flaws. Mainly, cliche storyline and some game mechanics that are a bit janky.

Overall, it's pretty much what you'd expect out of an anime Dark Souls, for better or worse. Character customization isn't bad and the overall gameplay loop manages to be satisfying. Main downside is that there really isn't any real endgame after the story ends and the game has some very sudden and jarring difficulty spikes.

I'm not a big fan of anime, so I knew that this wasn't quite the game for me. However, Souls-likes are my shit, and a lot of people keep recommending Code Vein - especially for the difficulty of its bosses and fluid combat. So, I thought I'll give CV a spin and at least enjoy the basic gameplay loop. I gotta say, I'm massively disappointed - and the anime-booba stuff and ham-fisted story-telling is not the part I dislike the most by a good mile. 

The level design is uninspired, boring, repetitive, and unnecessarily drawn-out. Rarely has a game world unintentionally felt so, for a lack of better words, 'video-gamey'. Boy, do these levels grate on me. It was okay in the beginning, but ever since the Cathedral of Running-in-circles-forever it got worse and worse. Most of the mobs boil down to variants of "dude-with-armour", and sometimes, for some reason, there are monkeys. I'd take a 10 minute level with decently challenging enemies and good atmosphere any day over this mess. 
The combat is fluid-ish, but the weapons don't have a weighty feeling to them nor do hits feel in any way satisfying or impactful. Walls and pillars are also only somewhat consistent as to what attacks they actually block, nor do they work in breaking aggro. In short, the combat can be entertaining but it also often feels janky.
Now, the bosses. So far, the Butterfly tore me a new one, maybe due to me being a bit overconfident after the joke that is good ol' Olly C. After that I have mixed feelings. There were some decent bosses, even though many of their designs are rather uninspired. The only design I really liked so far is the Gilded Hunter who is a superb DPS test. The Ribcage, on the other hand, looks great but the fight is a mess of diarrhea christmaslights and horrible mechanics. Still, I probably keep at least going until I see Blade Bearer & Cannoneer, their famous comparisons to OnS was the main reason I picked up this game in the first place. 

I know a lot of people like this game for its anime aesthetics, and that is all good and well, however, it does nothing for me. I could not care less about the story as well. So, in short: If you're not into anime and the whole weeb stuff, and just want to play a good Souls-like, I can not recommend Code Vein. My guess is I'm about half-way-ish through the game now and, so far, it is an uneven and often lazy mess.

Small update: 
I've now finished the game, and towards its end there are several cool bossfights to be had, but those aren't the norm and basically every single time you're confronted by a caster boss expect camera and sight issues. Still, fights like the Skull King or Juzo Mido are pretty cool, and BB & Cn surely are one tough duo, but that is not enough to change my opinion on Code Vein as a whole.
Has it's fair share of goofiness (dear god fuck the Cathedral) but overall pretty enjoyable (fun combat and you can make the anime goth girl of your dreams).

The only con here is.. the cathedral.. I hate this place. Levers, doors, keys absolute headache. The map is complicated and speaking for myself the difficulty from there really went ^^^ (took me 7 hours to get out of there).
Overall I rate it 9.1/10

From what I played so far,

I mean, it's definitely a "clone" made in Unreal engine and it definitely shows / plays like it.

-Combat is wonky (some of the abilities are cool but default attacks are very lackluster. Also, a lot of the times I got hit, nothing happened to my character, it was like there was no effect other than my health bar going down. No knockdown, no stagger, no animation to indicate that I was hit)

-I honestly really like the bloodcode system they have

-The bosses are uninspiring and not difficult at all. You don't get any satisfaction beating them because their move-sets are more annoying than actually challenging. You don't adapt to any of their moves, you just more or less have the same combat scenario every time.

-Majority of the maps are very plain and not really memorable. The 'praised' Cathedral area is just a lazy copy & paste maze that is more annoying than anything. Felt like the designers rushed that area

-For a large sum of the story bits they will give you 4-6 separate cutscenes that explain / show the same exact thing as the previous cutscene did

-Story is okay at best

-Soundtrack is beautiful however, you'll constantly get the same two tracks in a lot of the cutscenes

-The companion characters are honestly my favorite part of the game. Their interactions are great and I love them! I absolutely love Louis and Yakumo! All of the English and Japanese VA's did a great job!

The main appeal of this game is just anime weeb-souls but is very much lacking in the souls part. To even call it a souls game is disrespectful for the soulsborne series.
I can't recommend this game at it's current $59.99 price point. Def would pick it up for $20 or lower.

I'm going to beat this game, so the opinion here may change, but thus far it's been a very middling experience. I'm leaning towards positive but I have a lot of gripes. 

As a Souls player, the half second between input and when your character actually begins to dodge-roll was a lot to content with. I'm more accustomed to rolling to dodge when a hit will land, while Code Vein has you dodge when your opponent starts to swing. I can deal with this, though. For the most part, mobility isn't too much of an issue. The only other area where it bugs me is how your character comes to a standstill when they block, but with more play this may not irk me so much. I don't really rely on blocking unless necessary. 

Thus far, and I'm only three bosses (plus the three optional repeat bosses) deep, the aspect that's bugged me the most has been the environments. They're not particularly confusing layouts, but the scenery is so same-y that I found myself getting turned around a lot. There's a handy-dandy map in the corner to help out, but it still left me wanting more visually from the scenery. 

Combat is satisfying. I'm playing with great swords, so attacks are slower but do heavy damage. Finding the right openings can be a bit more of a challenge but I like that. The thing I'm less a fan of is the lengthy 'backstab' animation. The launch attacks and ripostes are also exuberant, but they feel earned when you pull them off. Backstabs are comparatively very easy, on the other hand, so you'll be seeing that 7-second animation of your character's face getting wrapped in black bandages before they strike A LOT. It stops being cool before you're done with the tutorial.

- Level design such as Cathedral of Sacred Blood should be avoided. We're here for the combat and progression experience. Not to waste our time dancing around in mazes. I almost quit due to this level. It serves no purpose to the game.

Verdict

The only great part about this game is the character creator and the overall artstyle/asthetic. other than that, I didnt really enjoy the gameplay much. The enemie types are the same throughout the game, the combat is really stale, the level design is just really forgetable and way too confusing. The story line is just below average, The characters have a really 'meh' personality really. Not much to say besides this. I bought this game just to create my fav characters in 3D and that works so I didn't have much expectations in the first place.

Finished the game. Quite easy for an experienced souls-like gamer. would not play it again for a long time.

The game has great visuals, and a lot available customization in character creation. Level system is simplified where you level up your character in general and not only in strength, dexterity etc (from what you choose). You rather use desired blood codes, blood veils, and weapons for your character build.

Combat needs to be improved as it is very noticeable that the game "forcefully" makes it harder by adding AOE to many of the enemies, especially bosses. Bosses gives you almost no time to replenish your health, and that takes sbout 3 or so seconds to do. So, basically you are almost fucked all the time and have to rely on your partner to distract the enemy until you have healed enough.

Furthermore, the areas could be better designed because there where so many unnecessary roundabouts and long corridors, and the some areas are almost designed as a maze. I also want to mention that some areas needs elevator maintenance.

Otherwise, I didn't feel  that I had to grind anything, the game is pretty much straight forward and entertaining.

I would not buy this game unless it's on sale.

First of all, I must give a shout-out to Elden Ring, as without it (my first souls-like) I wouldn't have enough skill or patience to play this. For Code Vein, now I'm done with my first playthrough, and about to head into NG+ for another ending and I'm loving it.

I wish other souls-like would be more like this story-wise. Yes, our character is speaking only through written lines, but here it feels like he/she is truly relevant and part of the story, not some random someone. What's more, mixing the slow unveiling of the world through cut-scenes and dialog and still adding some details in equipment descriptions works much better for discovering the world imo. Add to it the "Vestige" system and the music coming with it... Awesome.

The game certainly could've been longer if it's about the story itself, but I'm not regretting farming the "Depths" (repeatable side dungeons), as maxing out gift (skills/abilities/spells) proficiencies and experimenting with different builds was fun in itself.

The Blood Code, or rather class system is innovative, though I can understand that some players may be annoyed by the prospect of "farming" proficiency, especially with something unfitting their playstyle...

The world we can see in-game is... It's not anything that new, but it certainly is able to add to the atmosphere and remind us of the situation we're in. Although, I must critique few indoor/man-made levels as they're little too confusing to move through...

Now, onto the DLCs, for which I feel very conflicted. I got them while the game was available with Season Pass and at a discount... And I wouldn't pay full price for them. Each DLC is a Depths/Dungeon area with 2 mini bosses (reskins), 1 new boss... and with difficulty automatically turned to NG+ level even if you play for the first time. Despite the description, the only new "story" is 1 vestige memory per DLC for ONE class. (Yes, you need all 3 DLCs to get through short side-story divided into 3 parts...)
As for the bosses themselves... Annoying, though mainly due to health pools being over 100k each, but certainly doable. The achievement system for them is somewhat rewarding and satisfying... But most importantly, some of the abilities of new Blood codes/classes they bring are insanely powerful.

All in all... Yes, I certainly would recommed playing this, though mainly because of the story and anime-style. For those unfamiliar with souls-like games... It's not as difficult after all, but difficulty spikes every now and then can easily discourage some people.
Skip character customization for now and blast through the first 30 minutes, it gets vastly better after the first boss. You can re-customize after this boss as well.

Code Vein has been sitting in my backlog for a few years now. I always knew that it was "souls-like" but with ANIME sprinkled in for the weebiest of weebs, and gosh darn was it true. After finishing Elden Ring, I decided to tackle Code Vein and was generally surprised with how much fun I had playing it (I finished the game 4 times). The story is acceptable, and the endings do well enough to convey a satisfying tone, wrapping up MOST story arcs. 

The Souls-like comparison makes sense. Think of it as Bloodborne for weebs (Blood being a central theme) with a lot of anime tiddies (Seriously), but if you can look past the aesthetics, you'll be rewarded with fun combat that offers flexibility and player choice since you're never really locked into a specific build. 

Throughout the game, you can have an AI partner, which honestly diminishes the difficulty by a huge amount (they can revive you if they have enough ichor and the skill is not on CD).  You can opt for a solo playthrough but be warned that some parts are not really balanced for solo-play albeit still doable. 

All-in-all it was a fun journey for me. If you want to try a souls-like game that's on the easy side, Code Vein is a good starting point.

My first Souls-like game, I heard the difficulty of this game is punishing, it's true but once you learn the gameplay it's acceptable and fun. At first it might be frustrating to grasp the gameplay but eventually you'll learn how to build your character and the fun starts.

Graphics, story, gameplay definitely 9/10 for me
If you never play souls-like game before, Code Vein is a good start especially if you love anime artstyle

-badly designed bosses and badly designed enemies in general

-getting revived by your partner only to get instantly killed again because you couldn't move while being revived and the enemy is still doing its combo
-the game mostly throwing you one or two enemies at once because the devs pretty much knew that you mechanically cannot handle more enemies due to their aggressiveness, hitboxes, stagger and damage output
-a bunch of mildly useless skills
-a class and attribute system that pretends to be complex and deep with all the amount of stats it throws at you
-all the anime stereotypes you already know inside out if you've seen more than two anime shows
-uninteresting story set in a somewhat interesting world
-lots and lots of needless cutscenes (especially the memory ones where you have to walk)

Should you buy this game? Yes, if you want to kill time.

[b]Pro & Cons:[/b]

+Great character creation; made a post-apocalyptic priest with an afro.
+The home base has some pretty cool aesthetics.
+Fluid combat, especially with bayonet.
+Sweet music

-Not really challenging, AI holds your hand all the way and 0 achievements for soloing.
-Bosses take only a few tries at best before you make 'em keel over.
-Maps are basically one colour, nothing sticks out. I even got to a map where the AI points it out.
-Every female in the game is scantily dressed. The game revolves around it; it's a generic souls game, but that's the one part that sticks out, it's goofy; the most prurient minds were conjured up to take the Souls formula and barf on it and they surely did.  

Overall, don't even get it on sale; if you like anime, use the money to buy a subscription to an anime streaming service, or a ticket to some anime convention. Buy the dog some snacks, or buy yourself six months worth of coffee. Buy yourself some new track shoes and enjoy the weather instead.

Combat needs work game play gets old  over time 6 / 10
It's Dark Souls except anime and everybody's a vampire instead of a zombie. Also noticeably faster paced; your dodge game needs to be on-point.

If you are a fan of souls game then this is definitely worth playing, it is as much like souls as it is different.

The game is more story driven then souls games and you have the ability to customise your character and change from wielding a two handed great sword to using magic. The world however is not as interesting to explore. The map expands as you progress through the story and different "classes" also known as blood codes are locked away behind the story and some are locked behind different story path. 

One interesting aspect of the game is the option of getting an AI NPC to follow you around. Most do a good job but when you are fighting a boss the AI doesn't hold up all to well. Can also make things worse as the items you are able to carry in to combat are shared. So you can find yourself with an AI blowing through all of your items in a difficult fight.

The bosses are well created and have different variety. Most bosses are challenging and you cannot always just stand back and observe the boss and wait to attack. Depending on your play style you can be stubborn and stick to one Blood Code or change up as you go depending on the challenge.

The Blood Codes can be enhanced to unlock new abilities which adds variety and allows for customisations to create your build and playstyle.

If you have never played any souls games then this is also a really good game to start playing and get an idea why soo many love soul games. The tutorial gives you fair amount of information and you are allowed to change your build, try out any and all weapons, change passive and active buffs and skills however you want.

Only recommended if you get the game on sale, otherwise wouldnt buy. I got the game when it was 15 Bucks and honestly I wouldnt recommend spending any more than that for a pretty standard storyline and okay gameplay and graphics.
Overall the bosses were challenging but not impossible, though there was a pretty big decrease in quality and a pretty big increase in enemy spamming later in the game. The Level design is terrible, some of the bosses require you to walk minutes if you die to them to challenge them again. I liked the visual style and the characters, but their stories and interactions are very cliche.

One of the worst most frusterating JRPGs I have ever played. The most frusterating part is the combat system. It is absolutely clunky. Try to dodge? Guess what? You are still gonna get hit. Your swings or shots will not register on the enemy at times. Like 3+ powerful enemies attacking you at once in chaos with you instadying? This is the game. Its crazy how you have to have a NPC side kick just to make it through this game. Like no, its almots like you are the side kick to the NPC bc of how many times you will die compared to them. Good luck going it alone. Camera angle is bad, combat is very clunky, Bosses and regular enemies have ZERO cool down, zero stun, rarely can you cancel their attacks, but guess what? They can cancel your attacks, 2-3 hit combo you until you are near zero health. Oh and no sense of direction in this game, level design is just horrible, have fun wondering around figuring out where to go with this weird combination of platforming mixed into a JRPG mixed into the game, literally I somehow ended up skipping a entire section of the game that I was suppose to go to first and went to the 2nd Boss fight, beat the boss and then realized that I skipped the first section with the first boss. Oh and the over the top sexualization of female characters , like i've played many JRPG games, but my goodness the creators of this game went out of their way to make nearly every female character barely dressed and female parts protruding in a way its almost cartoonish, like the character models are disproportionate. At least Nier automata had a good story to tell. I guess the developers of this game thought they could just make a NSFW RPG game with a half baked story and  could get away with it. Worst JRPG I have ever experienced. I got this while it was on sale, still not worth the money. You'll end up paying full price for a new controller or keyboard and mouse if you're a rage gamer.

The story is well-made, the graphics are also nice, and it pays many attention to details.

The game is fun, don't believe IGN. The combat is a bit dull due to a lack of enemy types and weapon types. However I rarely find myself bored when playing since the maps are usually quite big, exploring them is pretty fun. There is a wide variety of "Blood Codes" for you to choose, each offering a different playstyle. The best thing about this is that you can take active skills and passives of different Blood Codes and mix them toghether creating your own perfect build. The story is pretty slow in the first hour but it picks up pretty well after that, but this doesn't mean it will blow you away with its writing or anything. A BIG plus for the game is its character creation, you'll spend about an hour trying to create your perfect waifu/husbando. LOTS of replayability potential so I recommend the game. PS: the characters are pretty cute

Wants to be a good souls-like. It really does. However, the maps are very blah, and the autosave feature is busted. If you die, it will for sure autosave. Pretty standard, no one's mad here. But if you beat a boss and sit through 30 minutes of mediocre, moody, anime cutscenes and then when they're finally over, log out (through the menu). Nope, you're back at the last time you died, better buckle in.

I'll be honest that's when I quit. It was less of a rage quit, and more the realization that I fundamentally did not care enough to replay that section when I could do literally anything else. The difficulty isn't nearly Soulsborne level, you don't need to try that many times to succeed, but it also doesn't really come with the same payoff.

The mediocre settings makes the souls-like grinds feel way worse, and the Blood Veil system wants to be good, and maybe it is, but it never clicked for me. 

The pros are that you can change "class" on the fly, and unlock more classes with different abilities as you go. It's a great concept, but it still feels like it falls flat in the end. I picked this up on a whim for $12 on sale. I'm not mad at that purchase, but full price would be robbery.

Weeb Souls is a game for Dark Souls fans who have played enough DS1, DS2, and DS3 such that they're scraping the bottom of the proverbial barrel in terms of what those engaging and rewarding experiences have to offer.  It's like the bubblegum pop of DS clones, far simpler, very "tween" vibes.  If Dark Souls is a heavy metal album, Weeb Souls is an anime official sound track.  The combat isn't nearly as engaging or balanced, the leveling takes a second to understand but it's incredibly simplified.  You never feel the same level of "high stakes risk for reward" that you do in DS.  I suppose there's probably an actual anime this game is based on, so I guess it'll appeal to fans of said anime as well.  I wish I didn't have to choose between "thumbs up" and "thumbs down" the game deserves a solid weeb out of 10.  If your looking for a good Dark Souls game, just play one of the many Dark Souls games.  Got it on sale to play coop with a friend, never could get it working, playing with rando's worked flawlessly though, even on a 100kbps connection.

Pros: 
- Adequate for a soulslike.
- Deep character customization.
- Easier to play mindlessly while you listen to a lecture or watch a documentary or something.
- Deep modding possibilities.
Cons:
- Only just adequate for a soulslike.
- All that character customization and you only get six outfits to choose from, plus it gets covered up with these super annoying and ugly "blood veils", gas masks and these backstab masks, what's the point of customizing a character if your forced to wear generic armor that clashes with any color scheme that isn't "red and black."
- Super uncomfortable to play with M&KB setup, controller is almost mandatory if you want to play the game how it was designed to be played, and even then the fighting feels unintuitive
- Mods can only be found on Nexus mods, which means you have to create an account.  Unreasonable, unacceptable.  Screw Nexus and their mandatory account creation, Somebody should add the "remove ugly masks and armors" mods on Steam Workshop.

Dumb anime story but fun.  Dark Souls but with distinct "classes" you can swap at any time, lighter, no messing with stats.  You can mix and match skills easily.  

Biggest qualm is that NG1+ is extremely unforgiving, about equal to NG+3-6 on dark souls.  This makes novel and unique builds immediately become useless for replayability, favoring the same few meta builds that utterly negate scaling whatsoever.  By the time you've neared the end of the game you're already going to one shot the first 66% of the game, and while the game allows you to replay the game at the vanilla difficulty, it's fairly meanignless.  Catch 22 of being gimped or playing the same copied pasta's meta everyone else does, or replaying at starting difficulty and being blatantly overpowered.  

Good price on sale, don't get the DLC as they are very small limited dungeon content with a couple new bosses and not much else.

The graphics settings don't seem to match up with what the game is actually doing. 60 fps cap? nope actually running around 75-90 usually, if its not one of the many area's in the game that causes random and massive framedrops. Had to rollback and reinstall my drivers to play again.

A faster, looser Dark Souls. Combat is fluid almost to the point of being jank, but it still manages to be fun and addicting. Be warned: some boss encounters will make you want to chuck your controller/keyboard through the nearest window and/or monitor.

My recommendation of "Yes" comes with the strict caveat that you're playing this game for fun and fooling around, and not for a quality gameplay experience. Sadly as someone who willingly subjects themselves to the entirety of the God Eater series, I did not want to miss out on this latest me-too from the developers that could only dream of riding Monster Hunter's coattails and are now, of all things, attempting to apply their formula to the Dark Souls category. Once again all the familiar post-apocalyptic story tropes from GE are present here as well, including their uninspired takes on slavery, sacrifice, and survival, all robbed of their drama by largely taking place off-screen.

If you play this game, remember that it's by the same devs behind God Eater, and all that entails for how jank, uneven, and unforgiving the gameplay will be for the sake of development expediency and "anime style". For a game that pulls you so close into the action, the controls lack a lot of nuance, demand high commitment, and are extremely punishing in a very unrewarding, unintuitive, and uneducational manner. It's a fun romp with a friend, especially if you're a sucker for anime stories and characters, but the chore of grinding Awakes and unlocking Codes is a heartless one for how little is on the line and how little reward you receive for wagering it. The levels are linear in their structure, predictable in their malice, and lacking in their spectacle. This may make for an interesting challenge for hardcore players who want to wrangle an uncooperative camera and dishonest hitboxes, but it's largely an exercise in masochism.

As a cherry on top of a pile of chocolate ice cream, Shift continues to disappoint on another key front as well for four games running: your character's tits cannot be nearly as big as the NPCs'.

It's a rather nice hack&slash game. A bit difficult for the genre, but playable.

What? You mean it's Souls type game?

Hahahaha.

Wait? You are serious?

Let me laugh harder. HAHAHAHA.

It's a hack&slash. Pure and simple.

Let's go through attacks.

You have basic attack, which is your go to attack.
You have heavy attack... for some reason? I mean, it deals 25% more damage than basic attack and takes twice as long, so I guess it's there? 
There are special weapon attacks... They are there. I mean, I saw them myself. But they are just basic attack level of damage, so... why would you use them when they are slower and more annoying to use? Guess you can use them if you like  pain, or something.
There is a special attack tied to the armor you are wearing. I swear it's there! It's very flashy, very cool and very much useless. The wind up time takes so long that if I didn't have to hold the buttons to use it I could make myself a sandwitch before it can fire. Oh, and once you charge it you cannot move, so all enemy has to do is fire a projectile, or stay away from its range.
There is magic as well, hence my hack&slash designation. All good hack&slash games have magic and this one isn't an exception. You can fire bolts of stuff. Bullets of stuff, balls of stuff. All kind of stuff. It obviously costs mana, which you get by smashing people with basic melee attack, or that fancy takes-so-long-you-die-from-boredoom attack.

Now defense.
You have dodge. Very slow dodge. Your character moves as if they were 90 year old grandma with rheumatism. Oh, and enemies have auto-tracking, so good luck dodging to the side. It's only away. Pray that your dodge gets you away from melee range of enemies as it not always happen.
There is block. I mean, I saw block on key bindings list, so it's there, right? All it does is making you die slightly slower as it costs stamina and doesn't eliminate the damage. Might as well try to dodge.
Finally there is pary. Pary is based on those super slow speshul attacks tied to the armor. And just as those super speshul attacks it's very, very slow. Only gives a tiny window where you negate the damage and allows you to instantly kill enemies if you DO get it right. So you can learn how to perfectly press one button, or just mash basic attack until what's in front of you dies.

The final Mechanis That's There To Make It Look Different Than Other Soul Games is focus. All focus does is stun you (or your enemies) and interrupt your combo if you take enough damage. Yeah, it's supposed to help. If it happens to my enemies, not me. I could play the game without focus just fine. It also charges up when you dodge an attack, I guess? I think the game said something about it, but it has never happened to me so I can only relay what game said about this mechanic.

There are sneak attacks, but if you play on mouse&keyboard you won't be able to use them because people forgot about 'walk' button, so good luck sneaking while running. This is not Sekiro. Oh, and half of the time if you DO get behind someone your character can just forget how to attack. Or if you are in front of the enemy, or beside him. Essentially being near the enemy can cause your character to forget how to swing your weapon.  Even if your stamina bar is full.

Leveling.
The leveling system is rather bare, you just increase level. That improves HP, stamina and weapon damage. There are also dozens of statistics that should be at school not in a video game. I don't care that my Strength got C+ on that math test, I want to know how much damage I will do with that weapon.

Character classes.
Yup, they are there. Not sure why when skills can be used outside class that has them, but they are there. I guess you need them to unlock new skills? A bit roundabout way, but hey - they needed something to look different than another Diablo 2 clone.

Character design.
This one is great. Tons of options, tons of accesories. Tons of disappointment. After spending an hour crafting my cute character all of that work was wasted because my awesome clothes were covered by some ugly armor and the face was covered by a gas mask.

Gear.
The biggest complaint about gear I have is lack of DPS statistic. Different weapons have different attack speeds (also not mentioned anywhere I could see it), so you have no idea if grabbing that sword that deals 50dmg more will increase DPS, or lower it. This missing feature is a huge oversight.
Customization sadly is a bit lacking, you only have one armor slot. I guess that's due to money saving on character design as more slots would need more time and money spent on graphics. You have two weapon slots you can switch between, and that's it. A bit bare bones, but I guess you can't have everything.

Gameplay.
It's hack&slash. What do you expect? Difficult enemies? Grind levels and weapons. Maybe grab better skills, or spells. 

Graphics.
Meh, never cared about those. Just look at the pictures if you are curious.

Overall, it's a Diablo Clone in 3D! But without ability to jump. I guess 90 year old grandmas do have trouble jumping, so no surprise there.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

This anime soulslike game not as hard as Dark Souls, but still consider as hard. The story gameplay needs 20 - 30 hours to complete except you're a speedrunner who keep moonwalking. There are 5 types of Weapon and Blood Veils, which affect the drain attack. Every weapon has it's own unique "attack" and sometimes it needs ichor. And Blood Veils has variety of drain attack, parry, backstab, and that focus attack (or anything, I forget the term for that). There are The close-ranged "Ogre". The long-ranged tail "Stinger Blood", "Hound Blood" which good for parrying but heavies among of those, and lightest Ivy Blood with unique Charge Drain and the "Area of Effect". There are also "Blood code" that will affect the statistics and the Gift (spell) some of Gifts can be used on every blood code which needs to maxed out the Proficiency first, also there are some Exclusive Gifts that can only used on specific Blood code.

[h1] Story [/h1]

Starting from an apocalyptic event "The Great Collapse" which almost caused humans to become extinct. However, there are some scientists who have succeeded in making cells that can turn humans into "Revenants", the Vampire-like creature. Revenants do not eat human food, they drink human blood and will experience a Frenzy phase if they do not drink human blood. If they have reached the Frenzy phase and are still not given blood, they will become Lost, which is a monster who is our enemy in this game. You, the main character will wake up without memory next to the unknown white girl. And the journey start from here. There are 3 endings which you can achieve with [spoiler] either restore the Successor's Vestige or not [/spoiler]. The Good Ending can be achieve by [spoiler] Restore/Repair all Successor's Vestige before fighting them [/spoiler]. The second Good Ending can be achieve the same way with the first, but you'll need to [spoiler] restore all Eos Vestige too [/spoiler]. The Neutral Ending (probably most of people got this ending on first gameplay) can be achieve by [spoiler] Restore/Repair some of the Successor's Vestige [/spoiler]. [b]My Score:[/b] 9/10

[h1]Prologue[/h1]
Parasite, by definition a being that lives in or inside another organism and takes its food from it without giving anything in return to its host and often even causing damage to the host. This definition includes the Biological Organ Regenerative or to summarize BOR, a parasite that attaches itself to the heart of its host and feeds on the blood, until the day when, due to a threat that humanity had no chance of, it was modified, becoming powers their vampire-like host, these new hosts came to be called Revenants. ^^

As soon as the Revenants took over the battlefield the tide turned, as they had power superior to any human and were nearly immortal, but at the cost of regularly needing human blood. Trying to solve this problem, humanity tried again to modify the parasite, through a project known as Queen, but something went terribly wrong, causing a part of the city to be isolated from the world by a wall of giant thorns and a red mist that is deadly to anyone, revenant or human. In this place isolated from the rest of the world and with limited resources, an revenant wakes up from its sleep, not knowing how important it will be to this place. ^^

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ An excellent character creator that allows the player great freedom to customize the character's appearance, thus giving a very unique appearance to the protagonist.
+ Very devastated and dark world from cities to mountains but at the same time with lots to explore and interesting companions to help in the mission of trying to bring hope to this world.
+ Great use of music and silence to create the atmosphere, both in the moments of struggle and in the quieter moments of exploration.
+ Beautiful anime-style graphics, personally I think the graphic style of the characters, clothes and equipment matched a lot with that of the created world.
+ Great Japanese voices for the characters, both main and secondary characters.
+ Frenetic and fun action with good commands that make the battles fast, while we attack and dodge the attacks of the monsters.
+ History of the world and its very interesting universe. Completing with three different ending options.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Although for me it is not as difficult as other Souslike games, it is still a game of this genre, so expect a good degree of difficulty. I myself don't remember any boss that I didn't die a few times before I managed to defeat them.
- DLC dungeons are not interesting and do not impact the game's story.

[h1] Game mechanics[/h1]
In this shattered city where the main revenant of our story wakes up without memory, it is necessary to fight to survive, because human blood is limited and the revenants are thirsty, luckily after the city was sealed, a mysterious white plant appeared that produces a fruit known as blood crystals that work in the same way as human blood, unfortunately many of them are guarded by revenants that have not fed in a long time and have become aggressive monsters that need to be fought with weapons such as swords and axes, in a true Souslike style, collecting the essence of defeated enemies to strengthen yourself. ^^

But it's not because it's a gray world and without much hope of a way out of this ruined city that this journey should be lonely. Because throughout the battles and exploration, from ruined cities to snow-covered mountains, we find revenants that want more than just to quench their thirst, in search of some way to improve the world, and with the help of our protagonist, make day to day at least with a little more hope. But little do they know, that they will soon discover much more than what was revealed to the population about the Queen project and more. ^^

[h1] Art and sound[/h1]
Produced by BANDAI NAMCO, I must say that the graphics of the game pleased me a lot, managing to pass both in the animations and in the maps a gray world and without much reason to hope while presenting its characters in anime style, with their big eyes, more clothes and well-detailed weapons, combined with a character editor with a good variety of colors, hair styles and everything else, in my opinion having combined very well. As for the soundtrack, another point that I liked a lot, due to the great use of the songs, or in this case the lack of them, because in several moments without battles, we only have the company of the sound of the wind, giving the feeling of emptiness and isolation. , with only the sounds of the creatures and our partner breaking the silence, I even need to quote the great voices of the Japanese version of this work. ^^

[h1] Conclusion[/h1]
CODE VEIN was a game that I pre-purchased without much information, and I must say that I don't regret it, because from beginning to end I wanted to explore this world from beginning to end and see all its history, even though I didn't being a big fan of Souslike style games before. It's a game that needs a little patience because the monsters will give the player a good challenge, but I guarantee that all the work will be worth it, especially when reaching the good ending, precisely the most difficult of the three endings, but without any doubt the more rewarding. So this is a work that I really recommend, both for fans of Souslike, and for those looking for a more different story and to become a revenant in this gray world that still has salvation. ^^

bougth the game back at it's vanilla PS4 release
and never finished it, don't even remember why
got it now on some steam sale and finaly finished it, and by "finished it" i mean i did most things you can do

a) i'm realy not into anime, manga, etc. and stopped caring for the genres when my puberty ended some two decades ago
b) soulslike is a stupid-term. do enemies and you consumables respawn at a rest point? yeah. but other than that the term usualy is just a standin for "action-rpg" and that's what Code Vein is

typical japanese rpg-cringe aside the plot, characters and general tone of the game are pretty great. it takes a while to get going, but that also means that things develope. don't expect a full fletched jrpg narrative with extensive cut-scenes and dialoge, but there are actualy cut-scenes and there's quite some dialogue especialy for a game tagged as "soulslike".
the plot is not cryptik, you pretty much get all the details, lore, etc. along the way and both the start of your journey and it's end (multiple endings) are clearly explained and shown.

where the game differs a lot from usual soulslikes is the way the rpg-mechanics work. you still gain levels through exp earned by killing enemies, but levels do not increase your attributes (STR, DEX, MIND, etc.) but instead generaly increase your health-pool, stamine (slightly) and your attack stats (weapon damage and spell damage), but not by much. you can sorta power-grind, but it's not like spending 50 STR in a STR-build in Elden Ring. the impact of levels is less noticable, but levels combined with gear upgrades and the right setup make a hughe difference still.

the real meat of the mechanics is more akind to FF-Tactic's job-system. you equip jobs (Blood Code) each offering active and passive abilities, which you unlock permanently by getting kill-exp while having the corresponding job equipped. 
thus you can mix'n match a total of 4 passive skills and 8 active skills in your build. 
additionaly jobs define your general stat scaling (similiary to From games shown as letters, aka "S" or "C+", etc.), your base weight limit, hp, stamina and ichor (mana) pools. 
every weapon and armor has the same scaling statistics, which offers a nice amount of complexety. it just takes some getting used to. 

another "special" feature is the way mana (ichor) is handeled. even on pure caster jobs the pool ain't hughe, but you get nummerous ways to fill it on the fly. apart from straight up using consumables, you can either backstab (even mid-fight), counter/parry or charge attack to get ichor back. later on you also get the ability to expend health for ichor or a physical statistics debuff while you passivly reg ichor. sounds more complicated than it is, in reality once you get the hang of it, the whole combat feels realy great due to how your combat choices actualy have effects on your whole build, ressources and kill speed. it's a nice little dance between expending ressources and getting em back. or you can straight up equip the larges 2handed sword forget ichor and just build for smashing things. 

there's a surprisingly large amount of jobs, active and passive abilities, armors and weapons to be found and used in Code Vein. standing at the end of the game and looking through your inventories is pretty impressive and so are the potential build options (even though it might take a while for the average person to realize it, like myself). quick 1 handed buffed up damage dealer, 2 handed cleaver, perma leeching caster or gun wielding sharpshoot, there's quite a lot here.

the grafics still hold up quite well, Bandai Namco produced quite some good looking anime games in recent years and Code Vein is definitly amongst the best. on max settings it's a very clean picture, with nice textures and great animations/effetcs. about the only downside beeing that some enviroments are a bit repetative.

the english dub is top notch and so are the sound effects and music. conversations aren't minutes long but transport what you need to know in a pleasent pace. there's still the typical anime-cringe, but compared to other entries in the genre the game should be manageable for people more used to western rpgs. 

the dlcs however are absolute throw-away content. typical for Bandai Namco. they produce great, sometimes even amazing core-games, but have a horrible track record when it comes to dlc..and Code Vein is no exception. it's basicaly 3 mini-dungeons, endgame material, that offers little but more combat, items, gear and jobs/skills. 
if you get the game as a package take em, but i would never recommend buying the dlcs seperatly. 

all in all a great action-rpg, with some Dark Souls mechanics, but defnitly more a j-arpg.

When I first wrote my review for this game, I wrote it off as dark souls for weebs. It still is, but I've grown a deeper appreciation for its systems. 

There are no set jobs/classes that you pick at the beginning, and you don't level specific stats, you strengthen the character as a whole. 

In this game, you have a selection of classes that you can change any time you aren't fighting, and these classes change the scaling of your equipment and skills. Pair these classes with the armor, weapons, and skills of your choice to create your preferred playstyle. 

I've enjoyed an up-close and personal aggressive playstyle with light-weight guns, high-cost spells, and stacking poison that allows me to get out of dodge and step back if things get hairy. Another friend of mine has taken to a hard-hitting tank with a big sword and an absurd number of buffs that let them stay firmly planted in the enemy's face. 

There is one locale that will look vaguely familiar to veterans of the Souls series, and when you first hit it, you will feel right at home if you know what I mean. Other than that, the environments of Code Vein are all their own. It offers light mini-dungeons and challenges to unlock more jobs/classes and give you deeper insight to the characters that share the world with you. 

The game features multiple endings that are affected by your choices throughout. The jobs/classes you gain through the game are also affected by your choices, so if you want to unlock all of them, multiple playthroughs are required. 

The DLCs are interesting options. They are all extra mini-dungeons, but much larger ones than are featured in the main game, and each one has a powerful boss monster. On top of that, they feature challenges to complete during the repeatable boss fights that grant new armor, weapons, and jobs/classes... as well as some cosmetic things that I personally don't care about. The challenges will test your abilities and your game knowledge more than anything else in the main game. 

The Wikis for the game are horribly unwritten. They don't cover nearly enough information, and it feels like the people that wrote them might not have even finished the game, which is frustrating if you're trying to find information that they don't cover. 

Overall, good game, would recommend if you are a fan of From's work.

I've spent 30 hours on this game (at the time of this review), and I could not be happier with it. Code Vein offers a very strong story that holds up to most of modern anime, has some of the best character customization of any game in its league (with a few exceptions regarding a lack of clothing), and a strong level system designed at bringing your character up in every class possible to make them as strong and agile as possible. While the combat and level system lacks the depth of the Souls games it clearly emulates, this game is a must for anime lovers and Souls fans alike as it takes the two strongest features of both and compiles them into a single emotional, story driven RPG.

Personally, I enjoy this game to the point where I’ve done a solo playthrough quite a lot over my recent memory (Actually one of the games that I still play up until today ever since I started playing a year ago on console). Alright, moving on to the game’s features that I’d like to talk about the most.

The Bosses: There’s no boss in this game that I outright despise. Though I find some bosses to be quite annoying or the fact that the game has one of the hardest bosses I’ve ever faced, they are still doable with the right strategy to face them. Also, 6 of the bosses in the game are some of my favourites, where I’d rate them 9-10 in terms of fight quality. And frankly enough, 2 of my favourite bosses in the game belongs to my top 10 favourite souls-like fights. 

Challenges: One of the things that I love the most in the game, ranging from Level 1, Gifts Only, No Gifts and more. I love Level 1 in this game, mainly because of the big potential of creating numerous builds even at low levels to the point where it doesn’t feel too restrictive in terms of creating creative builds. Beating bosses with no gifts also felt like a fun endurance challenge to me, especially against the likes of the fun bosses in the game

Character creation: Though it’s pretty lacking on the clothing selection department, the other parts of the character creation are amazing, notably the hairstyle variety and the accessories. 

Weapon/Build Variety: Like I said before, it’s diverse especially in Level 1 playthroughs and I like the blood code system because of that. For the weapons though, I’d wish there’s more variety added into it, like having Axes as their own weapon type whilst adding more of them, Twin Blade weapons or even fist type weapons to punch your way to victory.

Maps: They’re visually beautiful and I especially love the maps involving castle-like structures like Crypt Spire and the final map. Though there’s one map that felt too long since I got to memorize the pathing to get to the bosses without wasting time but it’s one of my favourite maps visually.

NPC Partners: I couldn’t say much about it since I played the game solo most of the time but they can be pretty fun to bring along, especially in Photo Mode but other than that I just soloed the game since I just find it more fun to play the game that way.

Photo Mode: I love this feature. This is one of the first games that gave me a chance to try out in-game photography and I can say that I love what the game provided in photo mode. 

Story: Story-wise, I find it interesting since I feel like the game has more than just one story to tell due to vestiges being able to tell stories of various revenants before the main game story even began. My favourite stories out of all of them are mainly from the Successors’ PoV.

DLC: I find the DLCs to be a missed potential. If anything, I’d like a DLC where we get a chance to fight the actual Queen but now I can only wait for the modders in this game to make it possible. The bosses in the DLC felt like it isn’t really unique since they are based from Hannibal, Marduk and Dyaus Pita from the God Eater series but they have their own charms (Hellfire Knight is one of the fun bosses in the DLC though I’d give it an 8 due to previous experiences of having fought something very similar that’s one of my favourite enemies in GE)

That’s pretty much everything that I’d like to cover about this game. Though there are some downsides that I feel like it could’ve been better, the upsides are what made the game replayable for me.

Code Vein is an amazing experience, and for me, one for the record books. There's a lot to admire about this game, and it all kept me entertained for a solid 800+ hours. There are too, however, a few areas where this game falls short, and I will cover everything I can think of. Of course, I am not much of a gamer, so take it all in with a grain of salt. If you are not one to entertain the ravings of a fanatic, refer to the bottom for a TL;DR.

Graphics: 9/10; I bought this game expecting decent graphics. In reality, I was blown away. Short of a few inconsequential low-res textures, some visible polys, and a few clipping issues, this game looks incredible.

Combat: 8/10; Overall, the combat in this game was enjoyable and challenging, but frustrating at times. I played one character on one save for all 800 hours, so I'd like to think I have a good feel for everything; I have experimented with a great variety of builds and combat styles. All of them had their shortcomings, strengths, and one thing in common: they were all fun. However, the combat left a few things to be desired. For one, your gift resource (Ichor) is difficult to recover and too easy to burn through. For another, a lot of offensive buffs don't last nearly as long as they should to be effective. Finally, and what is in my humble opinion the biggest flaw in the combat system, your drain attacks via parry and back stab do NOT have enough iFrames. There is a split-second discrepancy between when your iFrames expire and when you regain the ability to move, dodge, and attack. I know that doesn't sound bad, it is sometimes enough time for enemies around you to wait for you to be vulnerable and attack just in time for you to be defenseless. A small part of me thinks that may have been intentional, but I digress—it was annoying. 

Character Creation: 10/10; In all my life, I have seldom experienced character creation kits that were as intuitive as Code Vein's. It was refreshing to be able to make a unique character with the abundance of customization features! I only wish that there were a few more outfits.

DLC: 5/10; I've got to be realistic: I was disappointed with the DLC. The new weapons, blood veils, and partner skins were pretty cool, but the blood codes were fairly one-dimensional. The boss fights were challenging, but for the most part, the rewards get cheesy once you've unlocked the new equipment/skins. My biggest complaint, though, is the lack of additional story content beyond one vestige track with a heartbreaking backstory. I only say that because Code Vein's main story line is too fleeting. However, I do have to give credit where it's due, given that I use equipment from the DLC on my main build. For what it was meant to be (new dungeons with unique rewards), the DLC is okay. Still, I was hungry for more content.

Story: 8/10; It could have been better, but it also could have been worse. For all intents and purposes, you're basically a special vampire among vampires, and you play the role of a deus ex machina in a dying world that was clung to by a thread after a detrimental disaster. Personally, I really enjoyed it. The lore and the NPCs were all interesting. I also appreciate the room that was left for a sequel; even after having completed the story and knowing everything players were supposed to know, there is still so much mystery surrounding the state of the world that I am hoping will be covered in a sequel. My biggest complaint is that the story is too short. Still, and to reiterate, I liked it.

World: 7/10; First and foremost, the maps were beautiful (as beautiful as ruins could be). However, it is all too clear that several corners were cut in production. For one, the vast majority of the ruined buildings look similar. Of course, this is a niche detail for most and hardly a game breaker; just because it bothered me doesn't mean it will bother others. Still, it was noticeable to the mildly trained eye and, for me, bothersome. The last and final complaint I have is that the maps are quite small and can be cleared in mere minutes if you understand the layout. That said, I feel it is important to make one clarification: when I first started, the maps felt a lot larger, and some of them required several hours of playtime for me to clear them. In that respect, it could be said that they are adequate in size. It isn't until you understand the layout that you realize just how small they actually are. 

Multiplayer: 4/10; I would not consider rating the multiplayer system for a predominantly single-player game were it not for the fact that you have to do it for an achievement. And so the multiplayer in this game is atrocious. To my knowledge, there are no dedicated servers for it, so you are running off of the host's router. Often, there are rampant connectivity and latency issues that make combat annoyingly difficult. This is sad because I find a lot of replay value in playing with others and helping them by absolutely shredding bosses that used to give me trouble. Sadly, making a solid connection to a host is rare (at least it is for me), so lag is a huge issue. I'll end this section with a PSA to my fellow completionists: if you are after the achievement for reaching the multiplayer rank, use the Tower of Trials dungeons to earn marks of honor! It is the quickest and easiest route. Multiplayer is quite fun when you have a reliable connection to the host. Sadly, though, this is seldom the case.

Overall: 8/10; Despite its few flaws, I enjoyed the game thoroughly and continue to do so. At the time of this review, I have invested 800+ hours into it. Despite my harsh criticality of the multiplayer system, I find a lot of replay value in helping others by absolutely shredding bosses that used to give me trouble on my lower NG cycles. Sometimes I can feel the gratitude of these newer players without really needing to see it, and for me, that is quite rewarding. 

Finally, this game has my loyalty, and if and when a sequel is announced, I will be among the first to buy it. In the sequel, I just hope that some of the aforementioned flaws are addressed (particularly a better multiplayer system), and that we are able to bring our characters from the first game over and go on an entirely new, revamped adventure with them! 

TL;DR: This is a wonderful game in almost every area. The character creation kit alone is an instant sell for a lot of people. Code Vein is worth every penny.

+Of course as you expect from soulslike games, you can expect excellent gameplay. It has it all from bonfires to iframe dodges to making u want to throw your controller on the wall from sheer frustration. The skill requirement is evident and this game rewards consistency on top of getting good.

+The combat of the different weapons is quite different and it helps with finding how you want to engage the battle. There are weapons that cater to everyone's liking and you have two weapon slots so you can swap weapons on the fly if suddenly needed.

+On the same note, just like other soulslike games, you can build your characters anyway you truly want. Personally I just went for a guard build with my two-handed sword and it carried me throughout the game. 

+The character building portion of this game might be the funnest part honestly. There are so many ways to customize your characters to the way you want to play its actually insane. I didn't bother experimenting with other builds but there were so many possibilities. It also helps that haze isn't hard to come by so you can easily make other builds on a whim. I was happy with my guard build no matter how scrubby and corny it may seem to others as it definitely did the job

+These games aren't souslike games without their frustrating bosses that can just kill you. Punishment on dying is present in this game as well and nothing makes me want to quit more than dying on the way to picking up my lost haze. These games really are about learning and adapting the opponents moves to avoid death rather than just brute force button mashing.

+The dam bosses deserve their own special shoutout. They were all unique and really fun. I am pretty sure besides the first few bosses, I did not first try any of the bosses. Some bosses may be more frustrating than fun but it just adds to the satisfaction of finally beating them. My favorite and at the same time least favorite boss fight was the Cannoneer and Blade Bearer fight. That fight was so dam stupid and it's so hard to deal with them simultaneously but when you do get it done the feeling is unrivaled.

+The soundtrack is amazing. Really makes you feel in danger when you hear the battle themes. Outside the battle themes, the soundtrack helps really make the world seem really dark. Honestly the soundtrack did give me some anxiety when it stayed in battle theme when I couldn't see opponents or when it transitioned to it when I couldn't see opponents.

+Exploring the different dungeons really tells you how the world is like. I really like this on top of the soundtrack in soulslike games. This really goes to show you don't need a ton of dialogue to develop a world. The way the world is devastated is clearly seen in the different areas and I was happy to explore the different places as they were all unique and fun to explore (except the cathedral). My favorite place was definitely the City of Falling Flame. It looked amazing and I mean it may seem obvious but the city was in flames and it was cool to see.

+The companion does help in exploration as there are so many surprise enemies and they do help tank the damage in exploration. They also helped me by telling me what to do as I got lost pretty often in this game as for the most part, I wasn't paying close attention to dialogue and the narrative kinda flew over my head for the most part.

+The companion did carry me through a fair amount of fights and maybe it was dumb a fair amount of times (a lot of the time). It was not any dumber than I am at least

+Io

-On the note of you don't need a ton of dialogue, this game has way too much dialogue and the cutscenes are boring. I wish they just stuck with just exploration as the main drive for telling the story. The story itself was boring and way too edgy for my liking.

-Visually this game would make you think its from the early 2010s but actually it was made in 2019. Why is this game so ugly compared to earlier games.

-I found leveling up near useless. I wish there was more stats it upgraded for its cost. It doesn't seem too worth to level up over getting more gifts.

-The cathedral level was awful. Frustrating, boring and way way too long. Definitely will just run around in circles here all day long.

-I found that the companion does a bit too much in combat and you can honestly let them do a ton of the fighting. This did lower the difficulty a fair amount especially with my guard build. This wasn't honestly a con for me. The real con is the fact that the companion won't stop talking at all. At least you can remove them.

Wouldn't say its a must play but definitely give it a try if you want a new souls-like game to play and you have played the other ones.

It really is a Good Game

Pro:
- A lot of customization. You can create some cool builds! Also, the level of character creation is top notch. Some of the best I've seen in a good while. 
- Difficulty is fair. There's some cool boss battles. I usually prefer to do things solo, but for this game, I really loved the collaborative aspect. You can either play with friends or have an AI companion help you out. 
- Looks great aesthetically. 
- Combat is fun. This is the main thing that made me keep playing the game. 
- If you dig anime anything, you'll feel right at home. 

Con:
- Honestly, the story didn't hook me in at the beginning. This made it difficult for me to stay invested throughout. I tried really hard to get into it. I even made sure not to skip any of the "memory" cut-scenes to try and understand the side character stories. At the end, I just didn't really care and that sucks. I usually love the typical anime story, but for whatever reason this one didn't grab me. 
- Some of the level designs and maps just felt, I don't know...bland? They looked cool, but I think it had more to do with the mapping layout. It was just too samey to me. 
- The music is great for sure. I just felt that at some point, the same tracks were being overused. Going back to the "memory" cut-scenes, I can only recall 2 tracks being used. At some point, listening to the same thing over and over again just becomes a drag. There are at TON of these cut-scenes too. Would have loved it if each character's story had a different theme/motif. Maybe that might have helped me with trying get into the story. Music for these types of games is important!
- There's one particular thing with the combat that was annoying and that was the lock-on system. It just felt off at times. There would be instances where I'm trying to attack an enemy and my character loses line of sight of that enemy. This causes my character to swing at nothing. My reaction usually is to focus the camera (right joystick) towards the boss, but you have to make your character turn (left joystick) and have line of sight of the enemy again. The number of times I've died just to this is absurd. I mean I've played all the SoulsBorne games and believe me, I have my own problems with the camera, but this one just felt unique to Code Vein. 

Overall, it's a solid game! I had fun with it even though I have issues with a few things. It's a 7/10 for me.

First, the positives:

	In terms of difficulty, Code Vein is easier than a FromSoftware game. This does not make it inherently better or worse than those titles (I personally prefer more difficulty), but it may be more appealing to people who find those particular games too difficult.

	This game also has a very interesting take on soulsborne progression. Rather than leveling up by allocating stat points, Code Vein has a number of classes for the player to choose from. Each class has it’s own stat-line distribution and starting abilities, making them the equivalent of different builds. Classes can be switched between freely whenever you are not in combat, which gives you much more flexibility to explore different play styles than a traditional souls game. As you meet various npc’s and defeat certain bosses, you will unlock classes associated with these characters, giving you access to their signature abilities and play styles. You can also find special items when exploring the world, which allow you to access class abilities that were previously locked off. Progression in this system revolves around spending Haze (the game’s equivalent of souls) in order to raise your character level, which raises the stat scores of all your classes. Haze can also be used to make the abilities of one class available for use in others. This allows the player to mix and match abilities and stat-line’s in order to create one or several builds that suit them.

Now for the negatives:

	Combat is stale and uninteresting, because it never requires thought or adaptation on the part of the player. Most enemies operate very similarly to each other, so they don’t pose unique challenges that force the player to consider alternative avenues of approach. Once you find an effective combination of abilities, you can simply repeat it for every encounter in an area and succeed. Only bosses feel like they have unique mechanical identities, but even then the variety of their move sets is fairly limited compared to the soulsborne games. Compounding this issue, both health and Ichor (FP) restoration are readily available, so you rarely feel in danger of running out of resources. This means that you are not forced to think tactically about when and how abilities should be used for maximum effect, and instead are incentivized to simply spam every ability off cool down.

	The game’s narrative is weak and uninteresting, full of overused tropes. It also has a crippling inability to communicate anything to the player except through cut scenes. There is no environmental storytelling or meaningful npc interactions, something the Souls genre is famous for. You will also quickly grow tired of hearing the word “blood” and its variations, which are said a comical number of times.

	Perhaps the most frustrating aspect of this lackluster storytelling is how they tied it to the progression system. The in universe explanation for how you learn new abilities is by absorbing the knowledge and experience of others. This idea is fine in of itself, but the way they choose to represent this idea is that every time you unlock a new ability, you are pulled into a dream/memory sequence about one of the character’s pasts. These are not cut-scenes, so they are not skippable, but instead you are forced to walk very slowly through a part of the characters backstory. Once you finally get through this dream sequence, you are immediately thrown into a mandatory conversation with the character in question, which is again not skippable. This means that it can take several minutes of nothing but walking and talking to unlock just a single ability, and there are dozens of ability unlocks in the game. This turns what should be one of the most exciting aspects of the game into a dreaded chore. Bizarrely, these dream sequences don’t even necessarily relate to the character you get the ability from. The game has a preset order of dream sequences based on the order they seem to think you will unlock abilities in, but there is no restriction on what abilities you unlock first. You could easily be unlocking abilities for the Atlas class but getting dream sequences for the character associated with the Prometheus class or vice versa.

In conclusion, despite Code Vein having many features of a Souls game, it fails to deliver a true souls experience, which is why I cannot recommend it.

A great game all-around that performs excellently on PC.  If you're in the market for a Souls-like game with an unapologetic emphasis on anime aesthetic, great visual polish, satisfying combat and a haunting OST, then Code Vein is the game for you.  It's optimized well for PC and runs smoothly with medium to high graphical settings, which can always be adjusted lower for better performance depending on one's system.  The Blood Code system works in conjunction with the Blood Veils to allow for a good degree of build crafting, and it's taken further by the fact that you can inherit and carry over certain skills from other Blood Codes once you've mastered them.  Bandai Namco are onto something with this take on the Souls formula, and I hope they release more entries in this series in the future.
