This game is best described as what would happen if a bunch of teens with chuunibyou (Eighth-grader syndrome for you non-weebs out there) made a Souls-like. The aesthetics are unapologetically anime and the story is melodramatic to the point of absurdity at times. Yet there's this sincerity behind it that makes it all strangely endearing. You might find yourself getting attached to a character or two in spite of how ridiculous the story can be at times.

But at the end of the day, Code Vein is a Souls-like, so chances are gameplay is what you're here for. What sets Code Vein apart from the rest of the sub-genre? First, Code Vein's combat pacing is fairly fast, encouraging a fair bit of calculated aggression from the player. This game was made by the developers of God Eater and it shows in this game's DNA. 

This game also encourages experimenting with builds a fair bit with how simple it is to make and switch between them. You don't distribute stats on level up, instead your stat distribution is determined by a mix of your Blood Code, which is essentially your class, and your Blood Veil, which is your armor that also determines the nature of your Drain attacks. Each Blood Code has a set of Gifts, which are essentially skills, both passive and active. Most Gifts can be mastered by beating enemies with them equipped or by using some haze and specific drops, allowing you to use them with other Blood Codes, though some have stat requirements to prevent you from going TOO nuts with them. With fast enough menu-ing, you can even switch build mid-fight, as shown by Challenger Andy's Gift only run on youtube. You start out with three Blood Codes and accumulate more as you go through the story and explore the world, and there are four types of Blood Veil, which affect how your drain attacks work and the speed of your parry.

Ogre-type Blood Veils have you manifest a set of claws on your arm for your drain attack, are light to medium in weight, and boast the fastest parry, but are lacking in range. Stinger-types make a scorpion-like tail for fairly far-reaching drain attacks, have decent defenses, and are medium to heavy, making them kind of like all-rounders. Hound-types manifest a pair of wolf heads to bite into the enemy. They tend to be heavy but have very good defenses, so they're made for more tanky builds. Lastly are Ivy-types, with a charge drain that you can control where they hit from, allowing you to hit enemies from far away, along with being very light weight, but they also tend to have the lowest defenses. Each veil type also has a distinct silhouette, allowing you to recognize what type a veil is at a glance; Ogre-types are half-capes that drape over the left arm, Stinger-types are longcoats, Hound-types are jackets that are worn like a cape, and Ivy-types are scarves.

As for downsides to this game, there are a couple of parts that are just a pain. The Cathedral of the Sacred Blood is a chore to navigate since everything looks the same and the area itself is absolutely massive, there's a fight in the Depths with two Boreal Brutes that is just downright nasty even with the right tools for the job, and sometimes you can't find that last Vestige to finish restoring your new blood code. The enemy variety is also somewhat lacking. Overall though, Code Vein is a fun game and I'd dare say a good way to get into the Souls-like subgenre.

Level design was mid. It's nice that there is so many environments but it lacked that something. I hated the sound my feet would make when running in the snow area.

Never touched co-op so couldn't tell you that experienced.

All in all 15 bucks for a 40+ hr game is a nice steal. Despite the small misgivings I never had any problems booting or running the game with a 3080 and there was something interesting enough about the game to make me play it everyday until I beat it.

Code Vein is not a bad game, but it desperately tries to be like Dark Souls, and most certainly fails to do that. You see, soulsborn games are not only about having clunky controls, beating big scary bosses and dying a lot. They are about exploration, mystery, character building and accepting the challenge in form of various enemies. Alas, Code Vein has neither of that.

First of all, exploration and level design. All locations are absolutely huge (so you spend a lot of time simply running around), but pretty much linear (even more so than in Nioh) and don't have a lot of secrets to discover. Actually, for secrets the game uses the same trick over and over again: find a spot to drop below, walk on a ledge or through a tunnel, then get up using ladder and discover a valuable item or purify mist (unveils part of the location on the mini-map). The game so desperately and often uses this one trick that it become really cheap after just a few hours. It doesn't have that intricasy and interconnectiveness of Dark Souls locations (among the clones, only The Surge managed to achieve that to a degree), it doesn't even come close to that. And visually locations in Code Vein are also quite bland and boring, though anime stylistic makes them a bit livier than your typical gloomy soulsborn game.

Secondly, the mystery. Do you remember reading item descriptions and talking to all characters in DS just for a glimpse of the game lore, because it was interesting? Au contraire, Code Vein has just the opposite. Cutscenes upon cutscenes after cutscenes, long boring dialogues, and too many characters you couldn't care less about (half of those characters have huge boobs, and it doesn't help the story at all).

Thirdly, character building. You could argue that Code Vein does this better because you can switch all your stats (blood cores) and abilities (gifts) at any time, completely changing the gameplay experience , but I think it hurts the game, because you just don't feel a connection to your character, can't really make them your own. Besides, all weapons of the same class (one and two hand swords, halberds, bayonettes, and hammers) have the same moveset and differ only visually and a bit in stats. Sure, some weapons have special attacks like creating an ice spikes in front of you, but generally they don't feel too different within each class.

So there's little to no discovery, no looking for the weapon that suits your playstyle the best, it all feels the same. Moreover, the difference between quick and slow mobility (roll) is so miniscule it makes much more sense using heavier armors and weapons and blocking than trying to evade attacks which often are completely unexpected and unpredictable.

Then, challenges and enemies. 90% of adversaries (including bosses) are humanoids with the same attack patterns and weapons, and compared to bestiary of any From Software game this feels absolutely underwhelming. Only a few bosses are actually fun to fight, the rest are the same as common enemies, just with higher damage and bigger health pools.

I also want to mention AI companions that work similar to shades in Dark Souls. While they do help (they can even resurrect the player character!), their vocabulary is very limited, and listening to the same 5-10 different phrases really breaks the immersion. I mean, the game has dozens of cutscenes with tons of dialogues, was it too hard to add more variety to companions' phrases? Hearing "oh, you have sharp eyes, I didn't see that" for the hundreds of times when you pick up another item from the ground doesn't make the game better, believe it or not.

Last but not least, performance. I have 12900k, 32 GB RAM, 3080Ti, 980 EVO Pro, and the game failed to consistently achieve 120 fps@1440p. Moreover, when playing above 100 fps, there are some bugs (like elevators not working). And even with 60 fps limit it dropped to 55-57 sometimes when streaming in new data. So yep, this proves again that Japanese developers and PC is a bad combination even when they use UE4.

Overall, Code Vein feels like a very bland and generic DS clone without bringing anything unique to the board. Again, you might argue about blood cores, but I didn't think it was a good mechanic for the reasons above. Still, you can get the game just to scratch that Dark Souls itch you might have. But even in that case try to get the game on sale and don't buy DLCs: it's just plain grind.

I want to like this game, but it feels like the devs feel otherwise. I will continue to play it in order to get more value out of it and get the remaining joy that it has to offer, however as it stands, the game is a 3/10.

Pros:
- Souls-Like, not saying it does this well, because it doesn't, but the genre itself is a plus from me.

- Flexible Build system, you aren't stuck as the build you've been making throughout your play through. Whenever you feel like it, you can change up your build, experiment and play around doing whatever you like.

- Unique "drain" mechanic, allowing you to perform some pretty cool attacks for some bonuses.

- Graphics. The graphics are pretty good, though it's nothing amazing.

Here we go...

Cons:
- The most intentionally bad multiplayer system I've ever encountered and it is genuinely more frustrating than trying to set up your own server for a game from 2007. If you want to play with a friend, you need to send out a "distress signal" with a set password and then your friend needs to "search for distress signals" with the same password. Once that happens, you can no longer use certain items from your inventory, you can no longer use mistles, you can not teleport to mistles, if your friend dies, they are kicked and they are required to join again. If you die, they are kicked. If you kill a boss, they are kicked. If you go to scratch your balls, they are kicked. The game likes to orient itself around team work, but punishes you for indulging in it. If you want to play COOP, play on the fastest SSD you have, because you'll be going through a lot of loading screens if you're not the host.

- The combat is just bad, like, really bad. It's the same thing over and over again, poor choreographing from enemies, inconsistent timing, iframes just... don't work half the time. This game's version of increasing the difficulty as you go along is just throwing more enemies at you without any thought. The devs seem to be under the impression that the relationship between enemy count and difficulty is entirely linear, which it is not. If you use the lock-on feature (which you'll have to if you want your hits to actually land, but even when it is on, you have to pray for it), you're going to be stunned locked into a corner and your camera will be covered by some 10 foot tall knight.

- Terrible bosses. Some of them are fine, but most of them are just stronger versions of existing enemies except somehow even buggier. Queens knight reborn just turns invisible meaning the advantage of information is just taken from you, the only thing you'll know is where they are if you're using the lock-on feature. None of the bosses are particularly exciting either. Skull King is probably one of the easiest bosses in the game, despite it being the (sort of) final boss of the game.

- Cut-scenes. The game hates letting you play. 90% of the time you'll spend on this game will be the loading screens from all of the stupidly abundant boring cut-scenes in the game (that you can't disable). I once counted 8 consecutive cut-scenes, all to entertain the boring, generic non-engaging plot. Not only that, but some cut-scenes, that if skipped give you an entirely different ending to the game, preventing you from fighting the final boss. 

- Hidden statistics and mechanics. This game LOVES hiding as much information as possible while still giving you a little glimpse about the statistics of your character. Instead of using something logical like, say, numbers to represent things, they decided to use letters that have a maximum display value, also meaning that the precision of the stats you are shown are abysmal. If you like min-maxing, this game doesn't like you.

- Abysmal level design. The level design of this game is the worse I've ever experienced, and I played hunt-down the freeman (pirated of course). On your first play through, most of the progress you'll make in a lot of levels will be entirely accidental. You will feel not sense of accomplishment or achievement upon reaching the next mistle (if the level is generous enough to give you more than 2). But by far, the worst level I've ever played of any game ever, is Cathedral of The Sacred Blood. Think of a maze, now imagine that maze has vertical levels, now imagine that you have to jump off the sides of walkways to get there, now imagine that you have to make a giant loopty loop around the entire level to get 10 different keys to unlock a single door that leads you to more of the same stuff. The errors of the level design of this game aren't excusable simply for the fact that these poor choices aren't something that can be chalked up to not being a good designer, these levels are intentionally this way, it is a fundamental part of the level itself. Cathedral wouldn't be as bad had it not been the longest level in the entire game and the most boring (you'll find more enjoyment in the training area). The whole level is walking down pathways with the occasional teleporting enemy.

- Terrible partner AI. I would rather teach a toddler computer science than spend another minute with these stupid AIs. They make the poorest decisions and play like blind grandmothers. Instead of making careful choices, they just run at the enemy, attack, get hit, die and beg you to sacrifice YOUR HEALTH to revive them.

- Refresh rate issues. I play on a 144hz monitor. This game LETS you use a refresh rate greater than 60hz, however the game will drill a screw into its head when you do. So many things break and you will encounter more issues than your money's worth.

- Price. This game's price tag is absolutely laughable. If you want this game, wait for a sale, otherwise you will never EVER get your money's worth.

- Cringe worthy stereotypical anime stuff, nobody who lives above ground would enjoy it.

- Overpriced DLC, the content is alright, but for the price it's nowhere near enough content.

i cant really recommend an ARPG with an edgy/clunky combat system.

Fun gameplay in a post-apocalyptic and intriguing world, a shameless souls-like game that merges the genre with hack and slash elements and anime art.

The game is easier than any souls game, additionally, you have the option of having a partner in your journey, sadly this partner is overpowered, being able of killing solo any normal enemy, healing himself, and even with the ability to revive you, diminishing much of the souls experience if it is what are you looking for, you can remove it but at the cost of losing the smalls but valuables scripted dialogues in your run through the remains of the world.

The story and lore are excellent and the background stories of the characters you know in the world are touching, despite this, most of the characters are unidimensional, being or kind and full of virtues or corrupt and selfish, without points in between, ergo there is no growth of any of them in the development of the story.

Is worthy to mentioned that the game implement a mechanic to swap between different builds without penalty, allowing you to try different strategies and gears depending on the challenge, making the gameplay even more fun, which in my opinion is one of the strongest points of the game.

One look at a screenshot and you know what this is: An anime soulslike that looks (and sometimes feels) like a JRPG with its maze-like hallways, too-earnest-for-its-own-good atmosphere and long-drawn, overly dramatic cutscenes. 

You can "solo" the game but it gives you an A.I. companion by default and seems to be designed toward this artificial coop-feel, even adding to the JRPG comparison. While this fitted the story better than running around alone, it impacted boss fights in a severe and sometimes infuriating way, since bosses randomly switched their aggro from you to your buddy and back again,  making the whole ordeal more chaotic than necessary. It just never felt as good to defeat a boss as it does in the From Software games, somethings just missing here. And: The true final boss makes a mockery of the otherwise grandiose build diversity of this game. I managed to beat it after many many attempts but it definitely left a sour taste. 

However, in spite of all these more negative points, the game was just fun to play. The skill system is interesting once you get the hang of it, there is a nice upgrade system for your gear, it's nicely balanced, has the right length and despite the sometimes clichéd story the world-building elevates the whole thing maybe higher than it should be. 

This could easily have turned into a negative review, so be careful. Having said that, I hardly ever finished a non-From Software-soulsike because the quality differences to the originals were just too high. 

For Code Vein, I stopped playing my other SP games until I finished it.

Code Vein tries very hard to be a dark soul clone, hence the tag "souls-like". For DS veterans, here my observation:
- CV copies mechanics of DS, like stamina bar, weight load, confusing stats, bonfire, estus etc
- CV copies frustrating features of DS, like annoying & unfair enemies, tedious side quest, crappy camera etc
- CV character creation is far superior than DS. The game comes with a dress up simulator
- CV has switchable classes, which allows players to adopt different playstyle in different situations
- CV combat is more interesting as compared to DS. Unpopular opinion:- DS is a rolling simulator   
- CV map design is far inferior compared to DS. Every map is designed to punish players
- CV isn't an open world game. It's more like a dungeon crawler with infuriating mazes
- CV story/lore is straightforward. Treat it like an anime, not a dark fantasy

Spoiler free review:

[b]Pro:[/b]
- Character creation and clothing customization are surprisingly fantastic. Anime haters will yell cringe
- Control and mechanics are straightforward. There is a bit of learning curve but nothing overwhelming
- A variety of classes, weapon, skills which are switchable throughout the game. Allows room for customization, either for player's preference or adopting certain situations. 
- Decent English voice acting and script. No cringey anime main character yelling power of friendship.
- Graphic are decent, probably better than most try hard games out there 
- Companion system. People that does not have friends in real life (like me) can finally experience friendship
- NG+ promotes replayability. However the difficulty spike is so intense it feels like SL1 or NG+7 runs in DS. Most enemies can and will one shot you. 

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Incredibly horrible map design. Everything is: lazy copy and paste; confusing mazes; routes that are easily missed; ledges you can easily fall off; enemy ambushes/invasion etc. People who designed the maps as well as people who enjoys playing should be locked up in the deepest part of an asylum and have the keys thrown away.
- Ugly weapon design. Most of them are too long and huge they look unnatural, not proportional and unrealistic to the extend of cringe worthy (even for people that binge watches anime)
- Boss fights has significant RNG element and hence luck dependent at times. The final boss is an amalgamation of the worst elements of DS bosses. HP and skill set like Midir, camera like Nameless King, unpredictable like Soul of Cinder. Put them together and speed up the fight by 2x times, make the enemy attack hitboxes 10x wider, halve the enemy charge time and recovery time, and give the attacks insane tracking. There you go, "souls-like"! 
- With the exception of a few great soundtrack, 99% of the time there's this low humming, ringing sound on loop. No area specific BGM. Boss fight music isn't epic or memorable either. 
- Lags, every time when you enter a different area. On rare occasions I have encountered stutter, FPS drop, screen freeze, delays etc. No game breaking bugs or crashes so far. 

[b]Summary:[/b]
- By being a DS clone, this game carries over lots of flaws from DS (which toxic fans of DS refuse to admit). There are some areas which CV improves, at the same time some areas CV mess up so bad you want to punch the developers in their face. Worth a try on sales, but do not set your expectation too high. This game is fun and entertaining but please don't expect it to be revolutionary or change your life. I did not bother with the DLC, as the overwhelmingly negative reviews turned me off.

I would recommend this game to other players.   Combat and story are very good.  Graphics are average. 
 Options and variability in play styles are also very good.  The one problem I have (and which I have with all anime style games) is:

1.  Cut-scenes can be ridiculously long and unnecessary; however, some are important to understand the overall story.
2.  The girls and women look bizarre the way they are represented with minimal clothes and watermelon chests - just saying it is weird.  Anime games for some reason just can't seem to make a woman who doesn't have barbells up top or a skirt that is one inch lower than their crotch.  
3.  The other weird thing is your player (the one you create) has no voice.  Sort of weird since everyone else talks in the game.

However, I give the game a thumbs up for the game play and the evolving story.  The rest of pretty blah - buy this on sale like I did.

Mia and Nicola are excruciating. not sure I jive with Io or the attendants, it always seems to devolve into "waifu serves you" territory despite sometimes threatening to critique that exact arc. overall it does try to be interesting though, and the characters and their personal stories are mostly alright. it's got that anime-ass dialogue though, which is to say atrocious.

the balance is way off. to dismiss any ideas that I'm just bad, I beat this game like, 7 times. I 100%'d it. literally, I have all the achievements (including the stupid one that's only approaching reasonable if you can co-op the depths with someone for several days). For a laugh I ported a NG+3 character into a base-difficulty playthrough to see if I could just sweep through. Regular enemies still killed me in 2-3 hits sometimes, and bosses could still 1-shot me pretty regularly. that's offset by companions being able to revive you, but the bosses especially will throw out these long combos where every hit is death, and half of them can cover the entire arena or track you, and the companion revive is on a cooldown, and when you get revived there's a delay where you don't have i-frames but you can't move yet, and so you can pretty often get revived into the middle of a combo or a tracking aoe or whatever which instantly kills you again. and then you gotta walk back. usually the walk back is pretty short, but the amount of times I had to make the trek up to Mido are hours I'm not getting back.

anyway, if you're the kind of masochist that actually enjoys dark souls and you don't have anything better to do, you might have fun with this. I'd recommend doing something else though, play fallout: new vegas (2010), pick up a new hobby, look for some new bands, try to learn a new language. all of these are better ways to spend your time.

I would recommend passing on this game. It wants to be a souls like, and I have over 100 hours in Elden Ring, but this combat is frustrating not because of some learning curve, but because its bland. Enemies 'wake up' and lumber towards you and get killed before they start a single attack, or they are around a corner and instant jump you unless you are careful, which just means looking around every corner and making a slow game even slower. Dodging is really finiky and sometimes just doesn't work, i-frames are really inconsistent, weapon variety is non-existent, bosses just deal tons of damage and have tons of health but nothing in the world seems very reactive, everything is somewhat on rails with a very poor 'run straight at the agro target' AI. Dungeons (from the few I actually explored) can be pretty, but it's just a long tunnel with no real exploration, just keep going down the only path possible. See a breakable box? oh boy, secret item. Not really hidden since they are the only breakable objects and look absurd and repeat in every environment. It's a shame really because the home base is a gorgeous setting... but lifeless like the rest of the game.

Bland enviroment and design concept, bland story with aweful delivery (walk slowly for 5min for to listen to 2min of spoken dialogue), controls are unresponsive and a mess, as are hitboxes (the backstabbing and parrying are so random, it's a cast of the dice if you pull em of or not), bosses and enemies are unimaginative at best.

Clearly someone wanted to make an hack and slash title with anime vampires, but was told to go for a soulslike instead because that's the fashion those days. So they half-buttocked a barely functional game and focused instead on the intriguingly detailed character creator, so people could at least design their perfect waifu.

From the perspective of someone who haven't touched any of the God Eater series, this is a massive W and can be played without knowing the God Eater lore. One of the easiest souls game I ever played, in-game companion is just cheating for a souls game (in a somehow good way). The game encourages you to switch styles (blood codes) a lot and use what you see is the most fit to your playstyle, it's definitely one of the most entertaining aspects of the game. Game can be a bit clunky and buggy sometimes but overall doesn't really destroy the experience. Did I also mention the banger OSTs of the game? Yep. They're damn good, the voice acting (I played the JP va) is also splendid. The story is just mesmerizing, one of the few games where you get attached to a side character's story you met a minute ago so much and tear-up because it's just too good by seeing their past memories (vestiges).  

Overall, I highly recommend the game to everyone!

The game has a great potential but an extreme failure. I absolutely advice not to purchase the game. Others compared this game to Dark Souls but it will be a crime to do so.
- You can not REALLY choose a class such as fighter, rogue or similar. (The game has something like this but does not function properly)
- There is a pointless class-like system but nothing changes and matters. Maybe 3% damage.
- Skill are ... nothing to say. Nearly all of them are garbage. There is a leap forward and strike skill. If you can not adjust distance, you may (teleport and) strike behind enemy. Sometimes in front of enemy.
- You can not choose armor, shield and such. Can not choose according to your liking.
- Enemies are nearly all same with no AI.
- Your weapons cover 25% of the screen. When your companion starts striking enemies, you see nothing. Some sword swinging visual effects cover the screen and see nothing. 
- When you lock on an enemy, lock on does not continue when enemy dies.
- Game is like an 90s beat em up arcade game. You just swing your weapon (most often) randomly.
- The game does not have pause. When speaking on the phone, your companion (NPC) just kills everyone.
- I feel bad about the money I have spent for this game. I will e-mail producers to get a refund. Probably they will not even reply but

The game is not bad. It's just not good either. This game is the embodiment of "for everything good, there's something bad." Tl;Dr: I don't think anyone should buy this for more than $10 USD. If you really want a 3D souls like game, go buy remnant from the ashes instead. Much better. 

Good: There's good music. Every track is pretty good, some I'd even say are great. 
Bad: Shame they play so many times that you get sick of them.
 
Good: Lots of build variety between weapons, bloodcodes, gifts, and bloodveils
Bad: You'll be grinding for hours to get the gifts you want, and you better not over level because then you'll stop earning gift EXP in the zone you're in

Good: The companions add a nice breathe of fresh air to the otherwise isolating experience that souls likes are known for
Bad: The game is balanced around this and if you want to go solo, you're in for a bad time
 
Good: The gameplay is fast, and rewards usage of all mechanics
Bad: You die in about 2-3 hits, only get 10 heals by the end of the game (that only heal 33% of your HP at this point), and you can be stunlocked to death. So play perfect, or die. 
 
Good: Story/lore is very intriguing and the world they've built is good.
Bad: The characters are painfully written, the stakes do not feel high, and the level design is soul suckingly bad.
 
Good: General combat is very fun and there are multiple weapons to choose from, with varying movesets within each category to suit many styles.
Bad: The enemy and boss variety is incredibly lack luster to the point of bosses being repeated in many cases, or them just being incredibly uninspired in their mechanics. I can count on 1 hand how many GOOD bosses there are.

Good: The character creator potential is really grand. Probably where a lot of the budget was blown.
Bad: The art direction sucks. It just straight sucks. The lighting is crap without a reshade, the colour palette is so flat and monotone in many areas, and it just feels depressing to look at.
 
So yeah... for everything good, there's something bad, and sadly the bad things are much stronger and harder hitting imo. So I cannot recommend this game.

This game was a pretty fun way to scratch that "non fromsoft souls-like" itch. 
The customization is pretty amazing, so much so it's sometimes overwhelming.
Fun exploration, although the level design certainly gets pretty annoying during certain areas. So much so that a second playthrough seems completely impossible in my eyes, don't want to go through that Cathedral torture again. 
The music is pretty amazing honestly, loved almost every track.
The art design is pretty on point too. Some of the bosses/boss arenas look absolutely GORGEOUS. Eva stands out in my mind.
You get rewarded constantly and the progression feels fluid. You're always getting new weapons and outfits to try out, leveled up accordingly, encouraging you to try out everything. 
There's a lot of different weapons and play styles to choose from, everything felt pretty viable.
The story is interesting and easy to follow, I never felt lost or confused as to how to progress. 
All the characters are fun although pretty goofy at times, sometimes trying too hard to be taken seriously and it was hard not to burst out laughing. You, the main character, doesn't talk so It makes for some super awkward interactions, especially when it's supposed to be emotional. Some story lines don't truly conclude either so the ending I got at least felt pretty weak. That being said it was always pretty charming though, made me want to continue playing.
The game is pretty challenging, especially towards the end. Some later bosses life pools seemed waaaay too large for the variety of their movesets in my opinion though. It gets pretty tedious. 
Some of the "challenges" where dozens and dozens of enemies come towards you of course were pretty frustrating too LMAO. They always felt pretty lazy to me.
Only other gripe probably are some of the animations, there were some super strong boss attacks that gave minuscule tells and felt pretty cheap, but that just may be because I've gotten spoiled by Fromsoftware quality. Which I don't necessarily see as a bad thing, we should thrive for that type of quality, they should never feel cheap of unfair. 

Overall, the game looks good, sound great, and plays pretty good too. It was enjoyable and I found myself excited to continue playing, invested in the story and characters. I'd say wait for a sale and get It to try out. 7/10

If you like a game similar to Souls series games + anime style graphics then I recommend this game. FYI - This game is in the same universe as God Eater but on a different timeline. Meaning, if you aren't familiar to God Eater then you might find the story a bit confusing and hard to digest at first since you know nothing prior to when the story in the game begins. 

So the question is, Will the game care explain you what had happened in the past? or will you be able to enjoy and immerse yourself into the story even without knowing the event prior to the current timeline? The answer is Yes, absolutely. The game will tell you about the state of the current world you're in, the situation of the remaining survivors including yourself and what's going to happen in the near future. You'll be able to understand all of that even without the knowledge prior to when Code Vein starts. The side story of each characters was written pretty well, combined with the the impressively heart touching OST. It will make you almost cry at some point.

Now, about the OST. If you're an OST fanatics like me then you'll really really love this game! It contains an absolutely amazing OST! Unlike Elden ring or Dark soul main menu theme, Code Vein main menu OST has a really really strong opener and it will make your heart soar like a rocket! As if that wasn't enough, The OST in tutorial really caught me off guard. Two amazing OST in a row! and in a span of few minutes at that! I'm not gonna talk about other OST since it might be too long but they're equally amazing and fit perfectly well with the story where they'll be using at. 

I have no problem with the gameplay and control(PC) Some says that Code Vein is much more easier than other Souls series games but I don't know about that since I really bad at this kind of game. Even then, still enjoy the game nevertheless.

In this game, your stats solely depend on your class and passive skill. Contrast to other Souls series where you farm souls from monsters to increase your stat as well as your level. The only thing you get from leveling up your character in this game is your increased Hp and stamina. But to compensate that, The game gave you so many classes/passive/active skills. So you can try mix and match or explore your preferred synergies which is fun and refreshing!

This game is super cool, really fun, but only if you're into the niche of anime style games that have the souls play style. It isn't 100% like a souls game either mind you. Look into it before you buy it because I promise you it isn't gonna be a cakewalk.

Code Vein is a "softcore" souls-style game. The game uses an "anime" style - both in character design and in the writing and storytelling itself. If you are a fan of Shonen anime, you'll enjoy the story in this game. The gameplay is enjoyable, although I would say it has more of an "arcade" feel to it than the slower paced, less forgiving combat of a true FromSoft title. The game is challenging, but I wouldn't call it hard. It gives just enough difficulty that even the regular enemies keep you on your toes. The character and skill customization is the most detailed and unique I have ever used in a game of this type. I've never even played a AAA title with the depth of character customization that's available in Code Vein. Similiarly, the blood codes (or classes, to keep it simple) can all be mixed and matched, allowing you to pick a skill from a hunter and run it on your berserker, if you so choose. I would say this game is a great entry point for those looking to get in to more challenging character action games, and also a must-play for anime fans.

Imagine NieR: Automata except a Souls-like... and instead of machines and oil, it's the Lost, and blood... lots of blood. That's CODE VEIN. And it's amazing. Short version: if you like Dark Souls, Elden Ring, NieR: Automata, or any such similar game, just grab this and have fun.

Long version... coming into this, I didn't know what to expect. I've played hundreds of hours of Elden Ring and NieR: Automata, and I loved them both, so in hindsight it's easy to see that I would love this game. But gameplay aside, it shares a lot of similarities with both games too, such as in the way the narrative is delivered; that is, you learn about the story in bits and pieces, and the characters are very interesting, diverse, and easy to become attached to. Also, like NieR, you have a partner (who you can change at will) who helps make combat more interesting and approachable. And similar to Elden Ring, different abilities, weapons, and gear have an enormous impact on your battles and chance of success. You can choose to be a tough tanky fighter, a sneaky assassin, a long-range "mage" caster, and lots of other things, and you can even mix & match to your liking after becoming proficient in different Gifts.

If you appreciate a great story, a beautiful world, interesting characters, and most of all a tremendous challenge, play this game. But be patient with yourself! As in any Souls-like, taking your time and thinking things through leads to victory. It's definitely a very rewarding experience!

Hard to really recommend this.

It feels like it's bogged down by the Souls formula and would play better as an action RPG with Darksiders-esque combat.

The partner system makes most of the game a joke (reminds me of a permanent Elden Ring summon system) and while you could just turn it off, you then run into the problem of multi target fights being overbearing.

Many of the weapons do not have more than a 2 attack chain making them feel really awful to use. On the topic if weapons, only melee truly feels impactful. Damage is pathetically low for bayonets and you can supplement melee with casting with no real penalty.

It suffers from the typical anime dialogue of explaining the same thing 2-3 times worded slightly differently.

The memories are cool for story/lore reasons but would have been better off as cinematic cutscenes like what you get in the snowy mountain portion of the game.

New Review:

Won't admit defeat so I played again, twice (7 additional hours). Turns out at first I played for 'neutral' ending which is the most boring ending (and shortest). This time I went for the 'true' and 'bad' ending which is significantly more beautiful with longer scenes. Though, I'm still mad at the maps especially the cathedral, good thing is I memorized most of the paths and skipped all the fighting. 

Exploration: Stay at 1/10. Still got lost and slowed by stupid hazards. Monkeys would chase me to the edge of the map, so is the fat elite with giant axe that sprint faster than me. Elevator got stuck unless I lower the fps. Occasionally stopped sprinting despite I still hold the button.

Combat: 7/10. Not as slashy as nier, not as fleshy as souls, but once you knows a few tricks, it won't be as bad as your first run. Weapon choices doesn't matter, I picked a random sword for my 2nd and 3rd play and it does equally good as others, since all weapon with same type has same moveset except its heavy attack which is useless, so the RPG element is not so exciting here. Having ally is a must here otherwise it's harder than souls game. 

Story: 8/10. Not much to say but seeing more endings feels good. This rating includes characters rating which boost the score. They're good fellow.

New Game Plus: 2/10, no exclusive contents? exactly same run just to watch alternative endings.

Still wouldn't recommend unless they shrink the maps or have better navigating system, minimap doesn't help when you get lost.

This game is a huge maze, the map is unnecessarily long and confusing. Got my first ending in 30 hours without guides and I don't want to find all those damn vestiges again just to see slightly different cutscenes.

Combat: 6 / 10. Most melee moves are useless and get cancelled pretty easily. Bosses moves too fast, doesn't give any personal space and would jump to you when you heal, regardless distance. Target lock with not so good hit box. Ranged/magic build is ok. For melee, just normal attack is fine..

Story: 7 / 10. Not counting the damn slow walk speed when restoring memories. Nothing particularly new but each characters got some interesting memories.

If From Software is your only experience with the souls-like genre (as was the case for me), this game may turn you off initially.  Weapon reach didn't feel quite right at first, but once you get into the groove of things it's not a big deal.  Loading screens take a long time even with a good computer.  If you get engrossed in the story then I'm sure the cutscenes are great, but I'm a bit impatient and just wanted to fight things, which makes the excessive cutscenes accompanying Vestige unlocks a bit of a nuisance. 

Overall though, the fighting and class customization is solid.  Haven't experienced any BS insta-kill traps or stupidly difficult bosses.  If you optimize your build, then every boss is doable.  The game is also generous with gear upgrades, allowing you to find quite a few good weapons just from exploring.  8/10 game though, because It's fun and engaging despite those flaws.

Are you like me? You tried countless souls, and yet... to no avail? Can't git gud? 
Well then, this game might be your introduction into getting gud and preparing for true souls.
My my my, where do I even start?
Always found souls character creator kinda ugly? Worry not, here you have to try to make an ugly character, no matter how hard you try, you either get a waifu or husbando nonetheless. You can even recreate your own waifu from your fav anime series, mostly, costume choices in this game are incredibly limited, but face and hair customization are to be admired. 
Then comes the gameplay... Parry kinda exists, just don't try it alright, it's incredibly janky and not worth the effort. Roll is your best friend. 
Blood code system gives you an opportunity to try every build on the same character and the amount of spells and buffs is akin to MMO. You can make so many builds, that even after 10th playthrough things can be fresh. 
And here comes the greatest part: You always have an NPC summon with you. ALWAYS. Makes your journey through post-apocalyptic world feel less lonely and scary. Once you feel comfy enough, you can disable companion and make things hard. 
And once you have overcome that, congrats, you have been vaccinated from being a scrub, time to try some more souls-like games.
At least that is how it worked for me.

When Code Vein was first released, I and what I imagine to be many others wrote it off as just "Anime Dark Souls." And honestly that generalization wasn't too far off. Its got a universal currency that you mainly acquire from killing enemies, it has a very "anime-esque" art style and world, its set in a punishing grim world that will require lots of death to be overcome, and it has the classic roll, parry, backstab, and stamina system Dark souls is so known for albeit with a few minute differences. That's honestly where the similarities end though.

For how much Code Vein is like Dark Souls, it brings so much to the table that sets it a part from the series that very clearly inspired it. Without going into spoilers the story, while simple, is really interesting in its own right because of how interesting the world its set in is. The cast of characters, who's backstories you explore via their bloodcodes, are so interesting. Learning how the state of the world has affected them and how they came to be where they are in relationship to you and the enemies and bosses of the world was honestly such a joy to go through the first time. 

The combat while very souls like is very fun and fast paced. The attacks can feel sluggish at times and the hitboxes feel strange but overall was very doable with time. Blood codes are probably my favorite thing about the class and combat system. Unlike Dark Souls where you level individual stats with your souls to create a build, Code Vein has Blood codes. You just use your souls to level up as often as you'd like and the blood code you equip changes your stats instantly to suit that class. The only thing that's asked of you is to use Haze to unlock the abilities that a certain Blood code or "Class" has available. And when you master certain abilities, you can use them on the other Blood Codes you unlock. Its a really neat system that does a fantastic job of promoting experimentation. Never at one point did I feel stuck with whatever class I was playing because I knew that I could just go put on a different blood code and kill some enemies in the world to get some of its abilities.  Blood Veils also add a layer to combat even if it does feel more aesthetic at times than anything. Certain bloodveils work better for certain blood code types such as magic, strength, or more dexterity focused builds. It was really fun trying different classes and seeing how my aesthetic changed, it really made playing different blood codes enjoyable on a visual level as well as a gameplay level. 

The other thing to note would be the bosses. Each boss felt extremely unique and fun in their own way, especially a lot of the later bosses. I also absolutely adored how each of the bosses worked on a narrative level but I won't elaborate for spoiler reasons, I would suggest finding out for yourself. Figuring out the timing for dodges or taking different approaches also made things really interesting. This goes back to the bloodcode system as well. If you're hardstuck on a boss maybe swap bloodcodes and spend a bit of time grinding. Maybe one boss is sort of resistant to magic, just swap to a strength or dexterity bloodcode and get to swinging. You won't be punished for it nearly as badly as other souls like titles.

This game does have its fair share of issues though I won't lie. My main issues being some bosses are absolutely trivialized by certain blood codes or abilities. Strength blood codes are truly the culprit for this. Strength just feels so insanely strong against basically all enemies because you can just knock them over or stunlock them to death with a big weapon and strength abilities. And the same bosses I said were extremely fun to figure out is a personal bias. Some bosses have attacks that have such slim dodge windows that they can almost feel unfair at times. And in the same breadth, as much as I love being able to swap bloodcodes at the drop of a dime to make certain bosses easier, I find it annoying that some bosses are so much harder with certain approaches. I guess one of Code Veins greatest blessings is also a bit of a curse. But that's just how games work. I would hope that none of these problems I had dissuade you from the game, I just felt compelled to include them because I didn't want to seem like this review was pure praise even though I do really love the game.

There's more to this game that you can find out for yourself but it is definitely worth the money. If you can get it on sale even better. I guess I'm just asking that you don't write this off as "Anime Dark Souls" like I imagine so many did. 10/10 would play again.

This was not a great Soulslike, but it definitely was a fun SoulsLite. It takes the typical souls formula, and adds a big load of special moves and options to the combat system. I dare say there are so many options that they can become a bit confusing. But in the long run, all those options are rather "nice to have" than "must have" as Code Vein is never overly challenging. I would not call it an "easy" game, but compared to the Dark Souls games, or Nioh, this here feels a bit like a walk in the park. Two or three boss fights still granted me my share of yells and screams and curses. 
Which actually didn't directly have to do with the bosses, but with the controls of my character. Don't get me wrong, the combat controls are swift and responsive. But certain things just take forever. Drinking a healing potion feels like it takes forever. It's like my character performs a Japanese green tea ritual before finally taking the potion after finishing an ongoing character animation. Switching weapons takes forever too but healing is the most critical part. In the later game, you won't be lacking healing potions, but time becomes your worst enemy. 
Sadly, the bosses are... pretty lame. I have to admit, not one will stick to my mind. They are neither unique nor original nor spectacular. Most bosses can easily be defeated on first or second attempt. The harder bosses follow the same cheap formula that all weaker soulslikes use: teleport moves and oversized hitboxes. All boss fights take place in an open arena where the bosses can  happily warp from one side to the other. So actually the only real difficulty is to find the right time slot to heal, which takes a couple seconds in which the boss can teleport-finish you.  
Second on the down list for me was the level design. It could be compared to the Nioh levels. Code Vein has no open world, but the world is fragmented into labyrinths. Literally. Graphics are generally pretty, but the levels are quite obviously designed to be mazes which at later levels can become a bit tiring. Like that cathedral where you spend a big deal of time running through criss crossed corridors that make no sense at all, searching for the way to proceed. At least check points are set very fairly so that you'll usually find a spot to rest when you really need it. 

Third on the down list is the story. There is one, so that's nice, but it's being told via dozens of superbly boring memory sequences. And at the end of the game, the sum of all those story fragments still left me with an "Aha. Ok." 
But yeah, all in all it still was a fun game. Combat works. The AI of your companions is actually worth its name. And your companions, and generally most NPCs, are interesting enough to spend some time figuring them out. It's fun trying different weapons or armor, taking different companions on your trips. It's fun trying to find secrets. The camera does its job. 
For those looking for a less punishing souls game, with fun action and pretty, Manga-style graphics, I'd say give it a try.

Pro: Fun game, fun combat. Pretty much Dark Souls lite with easier build customization because you can slot in new builds on the fly. The items are more difficult to sort through for how to make a build, but there is a combat training area so you will be able to get a feel for a build before going into combat.
Con: The player character is silent. Not voiced, no dialogue trees, nothing. A lot of party members and side characters will talk to the protagonist about the situation or their problems, but the protagonist just stares at them blankly. It is very disconcerting and makes it difficult to get invested in anyone's story.

first of all: [h1] damn cathedral [/h1]

I want you to know that you are reading a review from a person who has never played Dark Souls before (and probably never will).

Why did i choose to play code vein? because of the gameplay? No. because of a semi-naked waifu that follows you all the time? No. because am I a damn weeb? Definitely NOT. I just bought the game because of the character creator, the style of code vein characters has a badass aesthetic, it just bought me.

Code vein is a poor copy of dark souls (although I've never played the DS series, I know the game well), it's just pretty much the same without any innovation in comparison.

The story is decent and captivating, simple to understand and always makes you want to know more (if you're not a DS fan boy and/or code vein hater).

The game is extremely short, most of my gameplay was in the cathedral (now I understand some of the comments that spoke about it).

Some negative reviews you read talking about "the game is just straight corridors", this is almost true, you will notice these corridors in "extra" maps called "depths", which are recycled maps from the main maps, with bosses you already faced. (Japanese games recycle a lot of maps and mobs).

the game's multiplayer really leaves something to be desired, I simply agree with the negative reviews about it.

the companions that help you during the game (npcs allies), have a decent AI, will save your a*s a lot. I wish the Tales of series npcs were as good as the CV ones.

It's not a very difficult game, I found the difficulty ok, some bosses I won on the first try, others I just need to try 2 or 3 times (this includes the boss duo, whoever played it knows what I'm talking about).

I can't understand the reason for so much rage about DLCs, the bosses have a decent difficult challenge but not impossible, however, the DLCs look like the "depth" maps, they are extremely short, it is possible to finish them in 30 minutes, so I highly recommend that only buy on promotion and if you really like the game.

In my opinion, this game could have puzzles in maps just like the legacy of kain series. Yes, don't expect any puzzles, just walk and kill.

Overall, I thought the game was good, I would personally give it a rating of (6/10).

PT Br:

quero que saibam que você está lendo uma analise de uma pessoa que nunca jogou Dark Souls (e provavelmente nunca vá jogar)

por que optei jogar code vein? por causa da gameplay? não. por causa de uma waifu semi pelada que te segue em todo momento? não. por causa que eu sou um maldito otaku nojento? NÃO. Simplesmente comprei o jogo por causa da edição de personagem, o estilo dos personagens de code vein possui uma estetica "fod*na", isso simplesmente me comprou.

Code vein é uma cópia pobre de dark souls (embora eu nunca tenha jogado DS series , eu conheço bem o jogo), é simplesmente tudo muito igual sem inovação alguma em comparação. 

A história é decente e cativante, simples de entender e sempre te faz querer saber mais (se você não for nenhum DS fan boy e/ou alguém que simplesmente odeia CV).

O jogo é extremamente curto, boa parte da minha gameplay foi na cathedral (agora eu entendo alguns comentários que falavam dela).

Algumas reviews negativas que você ler falando de "o jogo é só corredor", isso é quase verdade, você notará esses corredores em mapas "extras" que se chamam "depths", que são mapas reciclados dos mapas principais, com bosses que você já enfrentou. (jogos japoneses reciclam muito mapa e mobs).

o multiplayer do jogo realmente deixa a desejar, simplesmente concordo com as reviews negativas sobre isso.

os companheiros que te ajudam durante o jogo (npcs aliados), possuem uma AI decente, vão salvar muito a sua bund*. Gostaria que os npcs da serie Tales of, fossem tão bom quanto os de CV.

Não é um jogo muito difícil, achei a dificuldade ok, alguns bosses eu derrotava de primeira, outros eu precisava apenas tentar umas 2 ou 3 vezes (isso inclui a dupla de bosses, quem jogou sabe do que eu to falando).

As DLCs não entendi o motivo de tanto rage, os bosses possuem um desafio difícil porém não impossível, porém, as DLCs parecem os mapas de "depth", são extremamente curtas, é possível termina-las em 30 minutos, então eu altamente recomendo que só compre na promoção e se você realmente gostou do jogo.

Na minha opinião, este jogo poderia ter puzzles nos mapas como os de legacy of kain series. Sim, não espere nenhum puzzles, o jogo é apenas andar e matar.

No geral, achei o jogo bom, eu pessoalmente daria uma nota de (6/10).

Well, after 120+ hours in the game and getting all the achievements there is no way I would not recommend the game to other players. 

Hardcore Souls fans might get dissapointed because the game is easier than a souls title even without the partner - main reason for this is the extensive Blood Code (character class) and Gift (magic) system which allows you to change your build on the fly, which opens up some extremely broken combos that basically trivialize most content. But it is also one of the games appeals - there is something in here for everyone.

The gameplay is satisfying enough to keep you coming back - definitely check out this game with an open mind and don't try to compare it to Dark Souls or Bloodborne every step of the way. Yes there is not a lot of enemy variety, like in the souls title, but I don't think that's the point - the gameplay is much, much faster than a souls title so you kinda don't get bored fighting the same guys since you move and progress fast in the area and I have to say the areas look stunning - especially for fans of post-apocalyptic settings.

The story is good. Kinda cliche and predictable at some points but good enough to keep you entertained. The memory sequences are a highlight as they are done very artistically (for example: the setting dissolving around you and then building itself back again - very cool) and every single one of them is unique. The soundtrack is awesome and helps you get involved into the story.

No, really, give this game a try, even if the anime aesthetic is not your cup of tea. There is no "extreme anime" like silly faces, blushes and the like - the game takes itself seriously and will appeal to many people

Not very good. They try their hardest to shove story into your face. That doesn't work with superficial plot and shallow characters. I will note however, companion system was a good idea. Fighting mechanics are decent but map design is lacking most of the time.

The RPG where you're the companion. Very little of the story revolves around you or your decisions, and in combat your companions can pretty much solo everything while you hide in a corner. If you do try to enter combat, they will often throw so many enemies at you, that you have to play defensively while your companions do all of the work anyway, so even if you wanted to join in the sluggish, unresponsive (missed KBM inputs, and insanely long swings with no dodge cancel) melee combat, and you'll just wind up regretting it. None of the gearing / stat decisions you make seem to matter as they're just minor or incidental bonuses and your companions will do most of the work anyway.

Its just a slow slog through very repetitive dungeons and minimal purpose.

6/10

Pretty fun and good game, however in my opinion it lacks replayability value so if you want it, it's probably better to buy it on sale. 

THE GOOD STUFF: 
- Similar in general vibes and playstyle to Soulsborne games, so if you like the challenge and combat, you'll probably like this. It's also much easier to get into and master than the Soulsborne games, so it's very beginner-friendly. 
- Not the most comprehensive character creator, but it's very simple and intuitive, with more than enough options for most people. 
- Super easy to switch between multiple playstyles and builds within the same playthrough, without having to create a separate character. While it's good, it has its downsides too. 
- Pretty customizable in difficulty. If you want the experience, use the companion system. Otherwise, solo things for a bit of a challenge. 
- Boss designs and level design are cool and vibrant, keeps things fresh. 

THE NOT-SO-GOOD STUFF
- Kinda gets boring after the first playthrough because it feels like if you've done it once, you've done it all. 
- While bosses are very interesting and varied, I think the enemies could do with a little more variety. Very often, enemies in a new area just feel like reskinned versions of previously-fought enemies (i.e. all you have to do is switch to a different element, that's about it). Doesn't help that they're all very humanoid. 
- Enemy movesets and strategies get dull after a while too. Some enemies go "me swing at you" and others go "ME BIGGER SWING AT YOU". Bit of an exaggeration but you get the point. It would be a little more interesting if maybe some enemies were more susceptible to being hit on the head, from behind, maybe some are invulnerable until you smack a supporting enemy hidden somewhere or something, etc. 
- Since you can play different styles on the same character, there's no need to create a different character to experience things differently. 
- Balance seems a little meh. There are some blood codes and weapons that are obviously strong or superior, while the rest are just outclassed. There are no niche uses or reasons to equip anything but the absolute singular "best" caster or "best" tanky bloodcode for your specific playstyle.

First blind playthrough takes about 30 hours or so. I had fun playing, and will likely continue at some point in the future. There are multiple endings, and they're really only near the end of the game before what you do matters. Never played a Souls-like before, and was able to beat this albeit with an in-game partner ai assisting me. There are a handful of different ai characters you can choose from to travel with you once you acquire them.  The bosses are the most fun aspect of course. Common enemies could use more variation, though I never got bored of them my first play-through. Some mild difficulty spikes at the halfway point of the game. You have the option to co-op with a friend as well as a partner ai if bosses are too challenging for whatever reason (Fire/Ice Duo boss later specifically) Character customization probably ate up an hour or so.  Music is lovely in-game and some really nice storytelling via collectible vestiges that work like interactive memories. I would recommend to those who love anime and challenging boss fights, despite a few flaws here and there.

- Fun game with interesting boss mechanics.
- Has a story that you can follow.
- Great customization with a wide array of abilities to pick and choose from. 
- As others have said - Anime inspired version of Dark Souls. (Not a detracting factor for me)

Anime Dark Souls + Vampires = Excellent.

Changing my review to fit my actual opinion on the game. 

This game is okay but it has severe issues with variety and overall fairness to play style. It felt more like a dungeon crawler than an action adventure game. The areas all were beautiful or visually stunning in their own ways but all feel mostly the same gameplay wise other than one or two locations. Each area is packed with enemies which are fun to fight at first but quickly become stale and annoying as their attacks just hit harder and harder and ambushes get more an more frequent. The enemies themselves as well get repeated quickly. Each new area should have a new enemy type to engage with that correlates to the area's overall feel but all you get is a reskin of the previous areas' enemies. Not to mention the dlc which I haven't played but have watched, which is mostly the same garbage. Cramped area with no roaming with reskinned enemies and bosses. 

The way the game approaches blood codes is cool but some blood codes become useless after specific parts of the game. Some status effects or enemy attack types stay within a certain part of the game and once you get through that area there is no point in going back unless you want to grind for cash or xp or something. Poison gets introduced early and it doesn't really come back past the beginning of the game making the blood code abilities for it pointless to have. Grinding for blood code xp doesn't make sense at times either considering you max some out in mere minutes. Then right after you finish the area and don't need that ability anymore. 

Stats are confusing and locked to blood codes or the few outfits you get, nothing new is explored anywhere. Bosses have too much health for their own good and the majority of the tolerable parts of this game are sitting through the cutscenes. This game has almost no re-playability and certain obstacles in the game are so unfun that you feel disgusted at the thought of having to do them again. A big one for me is the cathedral section, its confusing and just downright sucks, especially as early into the game as it is, not to mention how you get there in the first place. 

This game would've been better as a dungeon crawler or a standard jrpg, not whatever the hell this thing is.
A solid entry to the Souls-like subgenre. Cute anime characters and neat enemies come together with fun combat and abilities. Must play if you love Souls and like the anime aesthetic.

I enjoyed Code Vein way more than I ever anticipated. I think it's worth full price, but I got it on sale for around $12.

The story is passable and the dialogue can be a bit weeby at times, but I had a great time playing this. For some reason playing Code Vein was very nostalgic for me, like I was back in '98-'99 and it's 2 a.m. Saturday morning and I'm grinding the hell out of Final Fantasy 7. Not because there are achievements, but just because I wanted to see everything the game had to offer. Code Vein isn't perfect, but the combat was solid enough and the level design was good overall. The levels are linear but there are a bunch of branches in the path for you to check out if you want. I had no trouble getting the good ending and it wasn't tedious at all to find the stuff I needed for it, but if you're just rushing through the game you can definitely miss the things you need. I felt like it had just the right amount of challenge for me. I wasn't looking to be frustrated but I didn't want to breeze through it and it really hit that sweet spot. If you want more of a challenge you can always dismiss your companion. A lot of the mini bosses felt way harder than the main bosses, which was kind of disappointing but not really that big of a deal. I really loved that I was able to switch my build whenever I wanted. The skill system is very similar to Dragon's Dogma.

I couldn't help but laugh at some of the character designs, though. Everyone dresses like Hot Topic is the official sponsor of the apocalypse and some of the women have comically large breasts, which might actually be a selling point for some of you. Their shirts are literally ripping apart because of their size, and there is no more fabric left in the world to mend them because Hot Topic needed it all to make more belts and handkerchiefs that can hang nonchalantly off of your belt loops.

I definitely recommend if you're looking for an ARPG. I hope it gets a sequel.

It's got a pretty good story with the endings feeling different, and the ability to replay the game at the same difficulty to speed run the other endings if desired. While at the start it isn't the most diverse in Blood Codes as you go along you start getting pretty unique ones and the abilities can almost be used anywhere with the right Stat increase passives. 

All in all, my entire time playing this game has been a joy and I would say if you see it on sale and want to dip your toes into what a souls-like game feels like this is a good option.

Code Vein

Design the perfect waifu and embark on a bland souls-like that completely is completely devoid of the satisfying game feel of a souls game.

Full disclosure I played this after Elden Ring and my expectations are hugely inflated, I know it, but it is what it is, I played it now not before.

The game play has all the features you'd expect and far far too many more. 
Combat and enemies are janky and very repetitive, your hits feel meaningless with zero feedback. You have dozens of abilities based on your current core and all of them are ambiguous, was it a buff? Can I even perceive the difference it produces?

Stealth almost never works and far too many corners have a cheap ambush behind it. So many stealth kill opportunities are just bait for ambushes. I know these cases are parts of souls likes... but 10x less often and far more subtle.

The level design is literally and figuratively a mess, areas are tend to be mazes made of post-apocalyptic junk strewn around. You wander around fighting the same 2 enemies over and over until you find the same large enemy which then progresses the story/level in some way.

The graphics are plenty good but the art design is weak and uninspired. 

I got to an area early on that you wade blindly, in waist deep water which further slows and cripples the already weak game play... and that was about it for me. I never died which isn't a complaint, I'm just throwing it out there to avoid any of this review sounding like a rage quit.

Surely I've barely scratched the surface of the game at only around 3h of play at the time of this review, maybe it gets better, but I have no inclination to find out. 

Try it if it's really very on sale.

After playing Sekiro, I found this game to be a very pale and disappointing comparison. Everything just felt like a way less polished and interesting gaming experience. The story is boring and convoluted, and also contains an insane number of watered down and unnecessary cutscenes. The combat system is unpolished, buggy, and downright frustrating. In particular, the camera and lock-on systems break constantly. There are a ridiculous number of classes and abilities that will completely overwhelm you, along with weapon types, stats, upgrades, tomes, etc etc. The theme of this game seems to be quantity over quality. The level design is boring, the NPCs aren't particularly interesting in any way, and the boss mechanics are just unrefined and cheesy. Finally, there are a number of really dumb bugs that haven't been fixed, such as elevators not working, and being stuck in a trade menu with no way to close.

Overall I wanted to enjoy this game, but found myself just wanting to beat it so I could move on to something more interesting. This felt like Michael Bay designing a video game. It felt like watching Transformers 2+. Way too long, terribly storyline, garbage characters, and pretty CGI. I could see some hardcore anime type people or stats nerds liking it, but to me, it's not even in the same universe as a game like Sekiro.

I feel like it is a mix of a monster hunter world type game and a souls type game. For reference, I like this game and hated Monster Hunter World and only ever played Elden Ring from the souls genre. It is more difficult than a lot of games but easier than Elden Ring. You do have a similar dodge and parry mechanic as Elden Ring and a system similar to runes/souls that you drop on death. You go on mission maps similar to monster hunter world. You are looking at ~5-10 min boss fights or maps instead. Open world, you can grind and over level. Have not finished the game, it may get more difficult. I want to be specific on the time frame making things easier. Keeping your timing for 5-10 minutes is a lot easier than doing it for 20-30 and you lose a lot less time per failure. Also easier to manage if you have kids as long maps and boss fights are harder to fit in. I really like the anime graphics, animations, and feel of the game. Definitely recommend.

Without mods: Not recommended
With mods: Recommended

If you also have difficulty progressing the game for the story, consider visiting nexus and installing "Precision Enhance" and/or "Queen Aura" (Version with updated TimeMaster)

Precision Enhance: Boosts an ability in-game called Precision to a degree which makes it last for very long and makes every attack you land on an enemy stagger 100%.

Queen Aura with TimeMaster: Lets you Freeze/Slow time for everything except yourself (or yourself if you want) allowing you to time out mid battle to either heal or just completely end your foe. I've mainly used this for stress healing or to nuke unreasonably difficult battles/bosses. Like that time you had to fight the same boss twice for story reason instead of giving you a cool fight cutscene for the second battle. With this you can just say, nah I'm not doing that.
I recommend setting the slow for enemies to 0.2 instead of 0.05. If not every hit you land in slow mode will freeze your character for a good few seconds. Z is the keybind for the TimeMenu and T is the toggle for slow/freeze mode. It can't be used unless you visit homebase everytime you boot up the game.

If you're a hardcore souls fan, you're probably not going to enjoy this game very much.
It has a lot of issues, including uninspired level and enemy design, streamlined RPG mechanics and the companion system which takes away most of the challenge in the game.

That said, I'm giving this game a thumbs up just for the fact that unlike most soulslike games, I actually had fun with this one. It's nowhere near as unforgiving as other souls games and the combat system is really fun to play around with since you have so many different blood codes with all kinds of abilities and weapons.
The story is also pretty good and much easier to follow, alongside a cast of likeable characters

Overall, if you're looking for game that scratches the same itch as Dark Souls or Elden Ring, this game ain't for you, but if you're just looking for a solid, fun action RPG, you should give it a shot!

I wish Steam had something between "Recommended" and “Not Recommended.” Code Vein does a lot of things really well, but it also does some critical things quite poorly, and some people will be more bothered by that than others. Ultimately I can't recommend this game because I don't think it's worth finishing, but there’s enough to like here that you may want to play the game anyway.

[h1]The Good[/h1]

I’ll start with the things Code Vein does well. Code Vein has fantastic core systems. Instead of allocating your stats directly, you pick a “Code” (kind of like a class) which allocates your stats for you. For example, the Berserker Code has high Strength and Vitality, whereas the Caster Code has high Mind and Willpower. Associated with each Code are “Gifts,” active or passive abilities of which you can equip a limited number. Gifts are initially restricted to the Code they’re associated with, but you can “master” them over time by using them, and once a Gift is mastered it can be equipped on any Code. These systems offer a ton of variety and customizability, far more than any other Souls-like I’ve played. You can also change your equipped Code and Gifts at any time, making it easy to tweak your build to suit the challenge at hand.

Code Vein also includes a “transformation” system for gear akin to the infusion system in Dark Souls 3. By using special materials, you can add elemental or status damage to your weapons in exchange for reduced stat scaling. You can similarly transform your armor to change its resistances. Code Vein makes it easy to swap transformations, meaning you can tweak your weapon’s damage type and your armor’s resistances to suit the challenge at hand. Code Vein also makes all transformations available from the start, provided you have the materials to perform the infusion. This is in stark contrast to Dark Souls, where certain infusions aren’t available until close to the end of the game no matter what materials you have on hand.

Finally, Code Vein’s gifts are fueled by the “Ichor” system. Ichor functions like mana - you spend it to use your active gifts. Ichor is regained by dealing damage to enemies, which encourages you to play aggressively rather than defensively when running low on Ichor. If you’re in the middle of a boss fight and a key buff runs out, you don’t retreat and chug from a flask like you would in Dark Souls 3. Instead, you go on the offensive and take the Ichor you need.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]

Unfortunately, that’s where the good ends in Code Vein. The core systems are fantastic, but the actual content of the game is lacklustre. This means that Code Vein is fun initially as you experiment with its core systems, but starts to drag as you settle into a build and get further into the game.

The first issue is the lack of variety, both in areas and in enemies. Most of the game’s areas are variations on the same “ruined city” theme. The fire area is just a ruined city that’s on fire. The desert area is just a ruined city that’s been partially filled in with sand. And etc. There are a few areas that deviate from this theme, but they’re few and far between. The same is true of the enemies. You’re going to spend a lot of time fighting the same basic grunts. Almost every area uses these grunts, just with varying health and damage numbers. Each area also has a few “unique” enemy types to spice things up, but even these enemy types are reskinned and reused multiple times. The number of unique enemy types in the game is quite small.

The second issue is the boss roster. By and large, it’s lacklustre. There are a few standouts that really require you to buckle down and “git gud,” but they’re few and far between. Most of the bosses are quite easy and can be beaten in only a few attempts. There are also a handful of stinkers in the boss roster, with insufficient telegraphs and unfair mechanics. All in all, it’s a pretty disappointing collection of bosses.

The third issue is the story. Code Vein does away with the atmosphere and mystery typical to the genre and instead opts to tell a more straightforward story with straightforward characters. Code Vein also puts a much larger focus on its narrative than most Souls-likes. The problem is that the story and the characters aren’t compelling enough to carry the larger narrative focus. The characters are mostly stock anime tropes, as are most of the major plot beats. Over time the story and characters become predictable, and consequently become boring.

When you add all three issues together, you get a game that grows increasingly dull the further into it you get. The enemies are initially dangerous and exciting, but you eventually master them and start hungering for more. It’s fine that the early bosses are pushovers, but the difficulty curve doesn’t rise with your skill level. While it’s fun to indulge the cheesiness of the story early on, it eventually grows dull and your motivation to see it to the end fades. By the end of the game, there’s not a whole lot left to compel you to keep playing.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Ultimately, I can’t recommend Code Vein because I don’t think it’s a game worth finishing. That being said, I did actually quite enjoy my time with Code Vein. I really enjoyed experimenting with its core systems in the first half of my playthrough, and I don’t regret playing the game. If you don’t mind not finishing the game, it may be worth picking up Code Vein despite its problems.

I really hope the team behind this game gets a chance to make a sequel, because I think the game’s core systems attached to a world and enemy roster with more variety could make for a really excellent game.

V Cons V

If you're looking for a game to play with friends I do not recommend this game what so ever. The multiplayer works in very weird ways. Sometimes the other player joining you gets a bug where they can not pick up items, or climb ladders. Other players do not get shared loot from for example chests. After each boss kill they get sent back to their world and get no "Haze" which is the needed balance to level up your character and weapons etc.. Whenever you die they get sent back to their own world, you also can not rest at "Mistle's" which are basically "Bonfires" to heal up and regain your healing items / mana.. So for multiplayer though it can be fun to just mess around I'd give it nothing more than a 3/10.

Sometimes when you go into a dialogue with npcs to exchange, buy or sell things you get stuck in a screen you can't back out of and you need to restart the game.
