Honestly this was my first soulslike game, and holy crap was it a great introduction. Anime + Dark Souls + Vampires n' Shit = Fun as hell. As the game progresses and you become increasingly badass, it becomes really rewarding collecting vestige fragments and opening up more more lore and blood codes. Each code has a fun and unique playstyle, and with the ability to cross-tree abilities, you really can build however you want basically. The combat in this game feels really responsive (Use a controller if you can, I find that much more intuitive to play with)

Plan to spend like an hour on character creation because there are a TON of options if you really wanna get detailed with it. Make your badass vampire waifu/husbando and go to town.

The learning curve is challenging, but not painfully so, because then the only real kerfuffle comes from new enemy types who grind you into paste until you learn how they behave, bosses included. Maybe you bang your face against it a few times, adjust your build, and boom, dopamine when you clear the room. Although, I will admit, the dual-boss fight near the end of the game (folks who've done it know exactly the pain I'm talking about), messed me up good until I figured it out. I had no friends and I was determined to play by myself and beat it, and after many grueling tries pulled it off.

The characters are fun and interesting, and unraveling the lore and mysteries throughout the plot is easy to digest, but has a lot of depth if you're an emotional person like me. The song that plays inside the Vestiges is friggin gorgeous, and it alone has made me cry. The story is fleshed out, and a lot of questions are answered as you play through the different endings.

So, if you like anime, and enjoy a bit of a challenge, this is a great intro to soulslike games. (I tried to hop into Elden Ring and found it almost needlessly difficult and sluggish in comparison, (Basically why bother having a health bar if you're just gonna die instantly most of the time. But I'm a filthy casual so xD) 

If the things I've said above resonate with you, grab the game, you'll enjoy it. Also, there's a demo, so feel free to try that before jumping in if you're not sure.
Controls are awful and the mechanics are like a bad DS knockoff. Nothing is balanced, and there's no real way to get through opponents with skill.

There's none of the haunting environment of Dark Souls, the eerie atmosphere of Bloodbourne, or the breathtaking world of Elden Ring. The levels are just very generic and repetitive. The story is not terrible but very cliched and not memorable. I found myself just skipping through the very long cutscenes so I could get on with the game. It was difficult to make myself care about any of the characters or the plot.

Overall it just feels like a mediocre game. I think an anime Soulslike can work, but Code Vein drops the ball on a lot of things that makes the games that it takes inspiration from great.

My friends called this "Anime Dark Souls". As someone who can't get more than hour into any SoulsBorne game without subsequently dying and raging, I'm here to tell you this game isn't as hard as Dark Souls, however, you do have to time your attacks and dodges juuuust right. Also, the first boss, for me, for some reason, was the hardest boss of all of them. Took days of attempts, but I could finish most of the other bosses in the first 3 attempts. Also, there's more colors than gray-scale in here. 

The character creation was amazing and in-depth, and you can re-customize your character once you're out of the prologue at any time. I can be a pink-haired girl with cat-eyes, which was cool. I wish your character was voice acted to the extent of the other characters tho. The "class" system, which allows you to switch between classes between excursions, based on your needs, is pretty nice. 

I'm not sure if it qualifies as "open-world" since it operates very similarly to Dragon Age and Legends: Arceus in that there's one "base" and several very large "rooms" for you to explore. However, you are free to enter and leave them, and explore the extent of them, to your heart's content, as soon as you unlock them (through progressing the story-line).

The story-line was nice, a little predictable, but really nice. It's definitely trying to be on the "heavy" side of things with tragic backstories and injustices. I'm glad that it doesn't feel like a "vampire game". 

Performance wise, it ran great! I could run it at normal graphics on my old Radeon 570, and could stream it on low graphics with it (though the cut scenes lagged on-stream, as expected). I did not encounter any bugs, personally. 

If you're interested, but on the fence, I recommend playing the demo! It's exactly the prologue, nothing more, nothing less. It helped me make my purchase decision and didn't take away from playing the whole game. It ultimately didn't spoil any of the story for me.

Code Vein is a Souls-Like that is very obviously inspired by Dark Souls and Bloodborne. Many things were taken directly from those games, and if you like those games you may like Code Vein. However, I think the game is flawed enough that I cannot recommend it.
The real issue with this game is that the level design is awful. One of the things that many people don’t think about, but what makes the souls games amazing as they are is the level design. The interconnectedness makes things like backtracking and opening shortcuts feel natural. It also makes it much easier to form a mental map and know how things are connected. None of this is true in Code Vein. Often the way forward feels unintuitive, and the levels feel like laboranths. This is not helped by how the environments are very bland with no distinguishing features within them. Within an area, one hallway or ledge looks the same as every other passage and ledge in that area. The worst offender is the Cathedral, which is the largest and worst area, and is one of the most painful areas to explore. 
The level design is inexcusable how bad it is, and I think it alone makes it really not worth playing, because it is ever present and something that can’t be ignored. However, there are more issues. The enemies and bosses are often alright, but they don’t compare to the quality of other similar games. Often they are just a little too basic, with a very limited moveset, that doesn’t really make good use of all of the possibilities that come with this genre. 
The weapons are often very cool looking, but there is not much variation within types. The swords feel pretty identical no matter the sword, and so it is preference on what it looks like.
I think a persisting issue of this game is that there just isn’t enough variation in order for the game to feel full. The weapons, enemies and levels all mush together, without there being enough of a compelling reason to continue. However, there are anime girls and you can wear a towel so maybe that is enough for some people.

[h1] Hello folks. Before we proceed to the critiques, we must say that this game worth its coin if you are a fan of grinding and souls-like, story rich games. [/h1]

- Game has a rich story with slight expanding moments with every collected [b]blood vestige[/b] 
Those vestiges are basically shiny red crystals containing some memories of a character and some update to their abilities. Unlike other characters, main character has an ability to change their class. This classes are coming with vestiges or proceeding with story and interacting with other side characters.

- Game has several endings: Bad, neutral and good. To finish the game with good ending you must [spoiler] collect all critical vestiges that has a connection to important side characters(Vassals of Queen relics). If you miss a vestige you might no be able to save a side character which has no replay [/spoiler] and the game automatically will end with neutral or bad ending, depending on the next acts. The key to good ending is to [spoiler] save all of the vassals after you defeat them in a boss fight. [/spoiler] Yeah it sounds kinda complicated here but dont forget to check wiki sites.

- Game requires grinding to collect somekind of souls to update the level of the main character or unlock some abilities of classes. [b]Unlike souls you can not increase the stats manually you just level up and other stats go up accordingly[/b]. As it was mentioned up ahead, we can change the class of the character anytime. There are around 24 classes that are being unlocked with continuation in story, collecting vestiges or interacting with side characters. Some classes has weapon restrictions or debuffs, be careful. Each class has their own skills that can be inherited to other classes by filling their gauge by killing monsters.

- Graphics are cool, general ambiance kinda resambles to [i]Darksiders[/i] if you have ever played it. Character design and graphics similar to [i]Devil May Cry[/i] but slightly different.
- Musics are epic, especially main menu theme. Character voice and game language settings are separate. Which means you can keep the game in English but the audio in Japanese or other language.
- Gameplay is giving players cancer sometimes. As it was mentioned before this game is Darksouls-like.

[b] Io is the best girl <3 [/b] Have fun playing.

Code Vein is much like dark souls, just far less punishing AND with a linear story (AND WAY MORE ANIME T1TS). I believe the story is what sets this title apart from other souls likes. You get to know not just the protagonists but some of the antagonists stories (perhaps through the view of the protagonist but it does explain a few things).

My main gripe with the game is how they have named different things. A vein is armor. A gift is a spell. A blood code is a class. It may be in line with the story, just not needed.

The main gimmick of the game is blood codes (class) you have to play the game with a blood code equipped to learn different gifts (spells). Some gifts are specific to a class meanig you have to have that blood code equipped, others, once you've learnt them are inherited. Meaning if you have the prerequisite stats you can equip them to any other blood code. NOT ALL blood codes can have ALL gifts, Heavy duty caster/ranger skills can't be applied to a greatsword wielding tank and vice versa. Still you can come up with some good builds if you take the time to grind out unlocking each gift by playing that blood code till you've unlocked said gift. Gifts are action based requiring ichor (mana) or passive meaning they just do what they say permanently. You get 4 passives, which are normally stat boosts, though some allow extra equipment weight, reducing your health to 1 instead of a fatal blow and others that restore ichor (mana) based on other requirements. You also get 8 actions. Actions range from combo moves to +defense, +attack or imbuing your weapon with an elemental debuff or defense against the same debuffs. Personally i relied on items to do these things, especially once later fights negate elemental properties, so buffing attack vs buffing elemental becomes negligent.

You can upgrade equipment, for the most part any weapon will scale to any other weapon if it is max upgraded. Meaning if you like the way a weapon looks by all means upgrade it. Weapons dropped from bosses are slightly more powerful but i do mean only slightly. You can also permanently imbue weapons with elemental values, this i don't recommend, even bosses that will get severely hurt by elemental attacks, you're stuck with that weapon, just use items (they drop frequently enough or are sold by coco). You face the next boss that is immune to the element, you're dealing 5% damage, vs 100% with just attack power.

As an addition to the main campaign there are Depth (Dungeon) maps. You need to find the corresponding map to access them in the game world, but they don't take alot of investigation to find. These Depth maps consist of 2-4 areas each with a mini boss and key, upon which you return to the starting area and fight the real boss (bosses from the campaign just stronger). According to other reviews the DLC is just another 3 depth maps with 3 new bosses, whilst 1 is directly from God Eater 3. I didn't purchase the DLC, instead i got God Eater 3 on sale for less than the DLC cost (I mean, i'm gonna be playing 1/3 of the DLC in GES3 right?). 

Next, the ridiculous parry mechanic. If you press the parry button just before an enemy attack you go into the parry animation, Which is at least 10 seconds long, you refill your stamina, but enemies have had the chance to reposition, so they are behind or next to you. The game doesn't pause. I have finished the game using nothing but dodging. Block and parry can honestly be ignored.

Combat is what you'd expect, though there are probably too many 'gifts' you need to use in a fight so button mapping on M+K can be tricky, i'm sure theres enough buttons on a gamepad though.  

The story is quite short, so if you're expecting the same amount of gameplay you got from a dark souls, well no. You do get the NG+ option, keeping everything from your last save and starting on higher difficulty....but....meh. Seen the story. THOUGH i hear there are multiple endings....if that's enough to make you play it again.

All in all i thoroughly enjoyed code vein, will i play an NG+? maybe one day, but attempting it back to back, there wasn't enough there.

P.S. My gametime could have been halved for a single playthrough, i ground out levels expecting Dark Souls, but i was over powered by the final boss fight. Don't spend too long grinding. The story isn't that long.

Game has artificial difficulty that is more about how cheese the enemies and bosses. Bosses have unfair move-sets and don't telegraph their attacks in a manner that feels fair. Enemies group gank you instead of being unique and posing a real challenge. A not non-significant portion of the game has long path ways the loop around for no reason at all which leads to some terrible map design at certain points.

The game did have a lot going for it but it focuses on being hard for the sake of being hard which just leads to artificial difficulty that does not feel rewarding when you overcome it. The story was not the best but it was fun and interesting enough to keep my attention. The graphics are good and the character designs as pretty good.

At the end of the day I just felt disappointed that in its quest to differentiate itself from dark souls it failed to incorporate what makes it good and to get ride of the bad parts. I will look forward to a Code Vein 2 if they chose to make it in hopes that they can improve on what they have here.

In general I think that this game is definitely fun if you like souls-like games. It is a game that experiments and does some interesting and cool things with the souls formula. I also do like that they fully embrace the absolute edgy weeby anime side of things. I find that sort of thing always respectable. 

However, I do think it is rough around the edges in terms of combat, graphics, story and I really don't like most of the bosses. Which I will mention in a positive/negative comparison down below based on the mentioned categories.

Combat:
In terms of combat, it is still very souls like. There are certain weapons types that have a different attack patterns. It has light and heavy attacks. It also has a very cool backstab/execute mechanic (which I will go over in more detail soon) and has pretty cool dodge mechanics. But it also has a lot of abilities (also known as gifts) which if mastered can be used with any build you wish. To activate these gifts, you need to have enough of the resource ichor, which can be aquired by attacking enemies or performing backstabs. The armor in this game doesn't just give you defenses, but it also increases your damage, scaling and gift power. On top of that  because of its weight system it has a rolling and running speed for your two different weapons. For example you can have a weapon with normal speed and a seperate weapon with a slow speed and still have a normal running and rolling speed with the normal speed weapon.

The first combat mechanic I mentioned was the backstab. It's one of my favorite things to do in this game. To perform a backstab as it is self explanitory, you go around their back and use a light attack on them, like any other other souls like game. However, not only does the backstab deal massive damage, it also fills and increases your amount of ichor. On top of that, you get a really cool animation for it aswell, like a glory kill from doom 2016 and doom eternal. Do beware that like a backstab, it doesn't automaticlly kill. It just deals a whole lot of damage. 

It does some interesting things with the dodge mechanic with its focus meter. For example if you dodge a enemy attack at the right time, your focus meter goes full. Giving you things like instant refilled stamina (there are a few other things but I forgot) rewarding you for dodging properly, which is surprisingly rare in a souls game I must say. Also, if you have a armor piece that gives your weapons quick speed you can basiclly dodge like bloodborne, which is really cool and interesting.

I do think that code vein has a lot more variety in terms of ability usage then DS or BB with the blood cores and gifts. When you master an ability from a different blood code you prefer, you can use it on your most used/best bloodcode instead. It is really fun too find a build that fits me in order to progress through the game and you can also combo with the attacking gifts.

Story:
My opinion on the story and graphics is around the same. Both the story and graphics to me are around the rough. 
The story tries to tell a deep and meaningful story, but I end up laughing at how cheesy it is and the plot holes it creates depending on the ending you get. Don't get me wrong, I was somewhat invested in the characters. (Spoiler coming up) Like Mia's story arc ending depending on you restoring Nicolas memory, I found it sweet (or bitter sweet depending on you restoring nicola) and a nice conclusion to that arc. But I just laughed throughout most of it because of how anime and stupid it is.

Graphics:
In terms of graphics and the world, they are pretty rough around the edges. I just think if they polished them a bit more, I would find it more pleasant to walk through the world. Like seriously, (spoiler alert) I had a hard time navigating though the giant white castle shrine looking place because it all looked the same and the bright lighting didn't help at all. Or the fact that whenever I am on some rubble it is obvious I float slightly above it like jesus on water.

Bosses:
There were only three bosses I really liked and that were the invading executioner, the queens knight reborn and the skull king. But that's about it really. I just think the bosses are artificially more difficult and are designed to do with a partner. Which I just think is stupid as hell. Because you then have to deal with a boss which is on you 24/7 while it is dealing massive damage and potentially one shotting you even when overleveled while having massive amount of health. 
My only suggestion is to strip away some of their health (Like 15% -20%) or get rid of the damage reduction all together, that's it, those two things is what frustrates me about the bosses. 
They have damage reduction on top of a lot health. Making it artificially difficult and making you using a partner when you don't want to. Which for most early game bosses is fine, because they don't have as many mechanics to deal with when fighting solo (except for the butterfly, god I despise that thing with its damage over time debuff). But for the late game it isn't fun for me in terms of soloing bosses since they are aggressive as hell on top of a ridiculous amount of health and damage.
I liked the bosses i mentioned at the start of this section since they have much clearer telegraphed moves that punish you enough when hit. But the same rule falls under them aswell, too much health for a damage reduction to be necessary.

But that is about it, they have tried to do experiment with the souls formula and there are some obvious ups and downs to what they did (Like what I mentioned) but I really enjoyed the game overal. 
It is fun to walk around the levels and killing enemies, the home base has some funny things that make it very anime. The character customization is very anime (which is a win for me) and the photo mode is pretty cool aswell.

Code Vein is a proper and engaging soul-like that has a lot to put on the table and there are many reasons for this but for ease of the reader I'm going to put this in bullet points.

Pros:
+The game has what are essentially classes with their own unique abilities but it also allows the player to use abilities from one class on another after they've become proficient in it. This allows for hundreds of different build types and unique playstyles.

+The story/plot is engaging with each character having their own backstory. Some of the information is hidden sadly but the dialogue, cinematics, and memories stitch together a well made story that is sure to get the player interested and invested.

+The bosses generally make for some really entertaining fights that either make you put up a fight or have unique effects and abilities that make it seem like a proper boss and not just some really buffed normal enemy...usually. There are a few bosses that are exceptions to this but I won't get into that.

+There is a map that tells you where you've already been and also displays how recent you've been there by the size of the dotted path marked on the map. No one likes getting lost in mazes so this definitely makes it easier to see where you've already been but this doesn't mean there aren't any secrets you still have to look for.

+There is a demo. I personally haven't tried it so I can't say how much of an idea it would give you of the game, it's better than nothing.

+Beautiful animations. The abilities have nice visuals and great effects. Then there is of course the parry and backstab animations which are well made.

+The requirement to run this game isn't bad so most people should be able to play with little to no issues.


Cons:
-The parry and backstab animations can get extremely repetitive later on but there is a setting for this

-The co-op is limited to you and 1 other friend which is less than ideal

-There isn't any PvP so if you were hoping for that, you're out of luck

-The game is still $60 and considering many people would enjoy this with friends, as much as I love this game and enjoy seeing new players get into it, this would probably be best to pass on if that's your goal.


Massive thanks to anyone who has made it this far for hearing me out. These are my personal takes on the game and the overall review is subject to change. I was pretty tired at the time of making it so there may have been something I missed but regardless I hope this helps you decide whether or not to get it. If you have a question feel free to comment on this review or message me on steam ^_^

[b]Who is This for?[/b]
But in all seriousness, this game is a great game. It's definitely a good entry point into the souls-like genre with a pseudo easy/easier mode by providing companions. That being said, companions don't make the game all that much easier.

[b]How Long is the Game?[/b]
For a playthrough where you just beat the game, you're looking at around 20 hours of playtime, but unlocking all the different skills and finding all the items would definitely clock more hours.

[b]What's Great About the Game?[/b]
The variety of skills and weapon types allows for a variety of unique builds, which definitely helps with freshening up the game on a new play through. And speaking of playthroughs, definitely finish the game more than once, because the story is filled with so much, that it all can't be explored in one playthrough.

I don't think I can recommend this game, even though I did overall enjoy it. However, the high points when it comes to the game itself are just not as high as the ultra low points that this game manages to dip into multiple times. 

The combat is passable and laughably absurd, but the mechanics behind parrying and counter attacking feel so janky. In a game where being hit can be incredibly punishing and lead into you being repeatedly staggered, having the player be punished for being slightly off an incredibly strict timing is frustrating. Timing on parrying and counter attacking doesn't feel satisfying, as if the window is too short to allow someone the ability to learn how to perform these vital defensive strategies without experiencing frustration. This is a razor-thin balance that requires care, for if the window is too big, the game is easy. But if too tight, then the player just relies on the AI companion that is ever present in the story. Additionally, the tutorial just flings everything at you at once and leaves you trying to sort it all out. One of the things mentioned in the tutorial is drain attacks, but I've never found use in them since they seemed to be more risk than reward. I don't think this makes the combat bad, because I had a lot of fun with it, but I did experience frustration a lot. I think the combat opens up many opportunities for a vast wealth of character customization, but falls short with being mechanically deficient. It is such a shame because the boss fights are fairly well designed and fun.  

Something worth noting is that i-frames are totally broken and are the way to protect your character. 

Speaking of character customization, this is where this game really shines. The character customization is incredibly extensive, to the point where you could spend hours just tinkering around trying to re-create your favorite characters from other franchises... and you most likely could! But like combat, even this high point falls short with a lack of clothing, which is what you're going to see your character wearing for the entire game with no exception. There are about 5 options for each sex, and the female options are (of course) mostly skimpy. Even the named female NPCs have very skimpy outfits, with one essentially wearing rags and having multiple boob windows. For a game that lets you manually place where you want your braids and how big they are, it is sad that the clothing options are so thin. There should have been more and a great place to start would have been allowing mixing and matching of pieces. 

For the final bit of deep lows, I have to point at level design. This is why I am DNFing Code Vein. Some of them are all right, but not super exceptional. Others are so incredibly short they pass by in a blink. These levels are fine. Even some of the longer levels like Ruined City Center are fine because they don't outstay their welcome.

Then there's the level that made me quit: Cathedral of the Sacred Blood. 

The only other level that compares in poor quality is Howling Pit, for how much of a slog it is to get through because your movement speed is cut down sharply. Both levels more than outstay their welcome. Pit is a truly bad level not just for the cut in movement speed, but in how long it is. Both levels are long and tedious. But Cathedral is somehow even worse! Whoever designed Cathedral needs to never be allowed near level design ever again. It is borderline sadistic, being a series of long and boring corridors where you spend 95% of your time running in a straight line and probably backtracking because of the maze-like design. As if such an overly expansive waste of space wasn't enough, this level is where the difficulty curve doesn't even become a spike. It's more like a cliff. And you have to grind, die, grind again, die again in order to progress. Even then, you will likely get stagger chained and have to run back to heal at the nearest "fire" (if we're relating to Dark Souls here) because you got chunked for 65% of your health... or more if you just got here from Dried-Up Trenches! 

I intended to finish Code Vein, but with how 2 of the 7 levels I played were unbearable slogs, I decided that it's not worth it. There is something pretty good here, despite the weird jankyness with combat. I've gotten through plenty of games that are diamonds in the rough, but level design can make or break a game. In this case, two truly horrible levels ruined the game for me. As I result, I'd say the game is a 3/5 or 6/10. It could be enjoyed by the right people who could overlook such a flaw, but I'm not one of these people.

Code Vein is a creative divergance from the original dark souls formula. It has all the basics; dodging, iconic boss fights, similar loot mechanics, however it does some things that i've never seen in the souls formula. For example, you are given the choice of playing through the game with an npc partner. This makes the game much, much easier but sometimes the game feels like this is how its meant to be played. On top of its creativity, it has a smooth performance, even on less powerful software. I only have two issues. My biggest issue is that level design is not varied in this game. Almost every level is just a set of hallways or small arenas with a miniboss placed in; compared to other games of the genre that occasionally break off into large explorable plateaus like darkroot basin from Dark Souls. My second is that the game is generally quite slow story wise. Most cutscenes are fountains of exposition, so much so that the exposition flows into gameplay, when you have to walk through the memories of fallen characters. Overall I'd say that the game is worth playing, if not for some slow story progression.

Code Vein is a Soulsborne that bucks a fair few of the trends. For one thing, the Companion helps a considerable amount (but IS optional if you enjoy the challenge) Offensive Magic is weaker than it's counterparts (cast times and damage values are tuned that even at maximum level with all possible stat boosts, one-shotting enemies will be a rare occurrence though half-healthing them is not out of the question) and it shows you the story rather than expecting you to go find it in items and sidequests.

That being said, it's still an Anime-esque game so expect a lot of tropes and a few... failed deliveries.

Also screw the Cathedral.

You play as an avatar of your creation (great character customisation) who is amnesiac and also a Revenant, people that are infected with the Red Mist and need to survive with human blood. Succumbing to the effects of the Red Mist will turn the Revenants into monsters known as the Lost which are riddled throughout the world you are in. With your big tiddy anime girl and other characters you'll meet, you will venture through this cursed world in order to fight the Red Mist and also its source.

This game has a reputation of being an "Anime Soulslike". There are lots of gameplay mechanics inspired by the Souls games such as bonfires, intricate level designs, enemy placements, traps, and ambushes. The only difference is Code Vein is more cutscene heavy featuring a tale of Revenants you are in and the world you are fighting. And also the difficulty although is hard at first, will reach to an acceptable difficulty once knowing where the threads are. This is coming from someone who only yet played Dark Souls 2 SOTFS. 

The story is good once you accept the cheesiness of it. Cheese in story is when plot is not good but the execution of it is masterful (atleast thats how intepret it). Being in the world of Revenants where living is pain and dying will only bring you back, the story can be sometimes sad and depressing. But in each sorrowful moments from the game there are many hopeful messages that kinda hit me more than other story driven games. The story here is something I will remember for long. 

The artstyle of the game is beautiful aesthatically. You can customise your characters full of whack or an awesome OC of your creation. Other character designs are also nice. Boobies galore. Big tiddy honka honka. Maybe the downsides are that the female characters clothing are, hmmm, lets just someone's fantasy out there is being fulfilled. 

Took a while to talk about the combat since the story of this game hits more than the combat. Combat here is more fluid than what I experienced in Dark Souls 2 (obviously). You have the traditional light and heavy attack with guard, dodge, parry, and heal (or use item). You have a variety of weapons you can use from the heavy Greatswords to ranged Bayonettes. I personally mained a Greatsword, since big damage made me harder than Eren's hardening abilities.

To aid you in combat you can also equip classes, like job systems in JRPGs, called Bloodcodes. Bloodcodes have their own stats and skills you can equip. Each skill can be leveled up to a proficient stage that canbe used outside the Bloodcode. Basically the Final Fantasy V Job system. There are a variety of builds you can use and play.

Speaking of combat and anime tiddies, you will also encounter bosses that have anime tiddies. Bosses are okay. The initial bosses gave me a hard time but knowing the threads made me first tried all the other bosses. During fighting or exploring you can also have one companion to aid you. This is by the games' design since some bosses needs you to have a companion to aid. Companions can carry you as they carry. Those who want a hard mode can just switch to not having partner at all.

The soundtrack of this game is great. I'm becoming more interested in Go Shiina's work. All the songs are amazing to listen to especially the main theme.

On to the downsides, although this game are beautifull aesthetically, but the assets in this game can be repetitive. There are some unique and notable areas, but most of them just have the same copy and pasted "Ruined City" vibes. I know this is postapocalyptic, but atleast have some unique spots or landmarks in the already repetitive gameplay-loop. It doesn't help the fact that the side content to grind materials is just an inferior version of the main maps which made the copy paste nature of it so transparent.

Which brings me to side content you can engage with in this game. You can go to alternate areas from the mai campaign to grind for materials, which features the most arcadey, mind numbing, tedious objectives to do. You have to go to a number of areas, fight the bosses, gather the keys, open the door that leads to the final boss of the area. You have to do this almost TEN TIMES. Since this is not really mandatory and just a side thing, there are important plot items in these areas that I wanted and will not achieve until I've done all of them.

This brings me to the third flaw, the sidestories. This is not really a flaw and maybe a nitpick since I didi find out about this until the end, but there are plot items called Vestiges where you can explore the memories of the characters you know. These are payed as interactable cutscenes where you walk and explore the memories of the Vestiges. The stories in this memories are what amazing and fleshes out the story and the world more. But, having many more than maybe 20 Vestiges meaning you have to watch all these cutscenes to see it all. I spent an hour just experiencing these individual cutscenes that are although enjoyable, are sometimes a drag to get through. Also these Vestiges will also unlock locked skills so another reason to experience it all. You can SKIP it, but that beats the whole the story of the game.

Overall, I love the story of the game. The combat is fun. Some flaws but overall a good enjoyable game.

4.5/5
overall it's good, but the map design is just terrible.

If you are looking for an experience similar to Dark Souls you won't find it here, this game really likes to just spam ambushes every corner and it has one of the most boring level designs I've seen. It's just the same enemy layout over and over and to spice things up they just throw multiple enemies at you all the time, this can be fun but most of the time if you get hit you will get stun locked for 90% of your health or hit from behind by some guy you didn't see since other 4 guys are chasing you. Even if you parry an attack when you are against multiple enemies you won't get time to heal since the remaining enemies will spam you with attacks the moment the i-frames end.
The bosses are a joke they are designed to be fought with an ally so if you try to fight it solo you will get overwhelmed with overly aggressive bosses and hitboxes that do a 360 on every attack and on top of that it does 75% of your health, very frustrating and not worth it in my opinion, I like hard bosses but this is just lazy since all bosses just have like 3-4 moves and the typical 3-4 hit combo, It just feels like all bosses have the same move set.
Enemy variety is a joke, they just reuse the same 4 enemies and re-skin them like it was no big deal, you have the guy with a big sword, the guy with a gun, the guy with a big axe, and the very big guy with a mace that's it, they even re-use most of the bosses ib the depth dungeons.
I wanted to like this game because the combat can be enjoyable at times, the gift system is cool and the abilities/combos you can do feel very good, the soundtrack is good and I like the way they tell the story through the vestiges but the longer I played it became very apparent they just copy-pasted the same thing over and over.
If you are looking for an action RPG with a good story and enjoyable characters and don't care about the janky combat I guess you can give this a try but it's a no for me also make sure to get it on sale, this game is not worth full price. I believe the overall experience of this game would be 100x better if you ignore all the copy-paste side content AKA the depths dungeons and have the opportunity to play with a friend also stay away from the DLC its just more copy-paste dungeons with the same enemies but they have more health now WOW!

I enjoyed this game quite a lot, it was a very fun soul game but with anime characters. The combat is very satisfying and I loved the styles you could change, based on the blood code you have. I haven't played a game with such a mechanic before so I personally find it unique how you need to work on the way you want to play, playing fast with a fast weapon or playing heavy, with the so called zweihander.

The map design is bad, I absolutely hated Cathedral of the Sacred Blood, and I'm sure I am not the only one who hates it. Some zones felt repetitive with no entertainment, which ruins the exploration on this game. You don't need to explore that much, but still takes a bit to take a few stuff that are important for yourself and maybe for an ending.

The bosses were decent, let's say it's balanced even without any partners being with you. I do have a problem with Blade bearer and Cannoneer. The lore is actually pretty good, I love that it's very straightforward, which makes the story very easy to understand. The memory idea was a nice bonus if you are interested in the lore and characters story, I suggest you to not skip it. Nothing much to say to lore.

Overall, it's a good game, I would give it a 7/10. You should buy it when it's on sale, I don't find it worth full price, but if you're an anime fan and a soul lover, you should give it a try!

Bottom line:
Code Vein is a frustrating unenjoyable grind that ultimately led me to burn out and quit the game.

Code Vein is a Dark Souls clone that fails at almost every aspect of what makes Dark Souls great. Combat is fun at first, until you realize the majority of enemies in the game are re-skinned copies of what you fought 10 hours ago. Itemization and progression is very lackluster. Exploration is an unbelievable chore, and always leaves you feeling as if you'll "eventually find something cool." I always felt as if I was waiting for the game to pick up and finally become great, but it simply never happens. Level design is easily this game's WORST aspect -- In short, level design is frustrating, uninteresting, bland, and often very confusing. You'll traverse massive areas where NOTHING is distinguished and EVERYTHING looks the same, and yet you're suppose to be able to navigate your way through these labyrinthine complexes . Gameplay involves elements such as: you just pulled yet another lever for the 11th time that looks identical to all other levers and opens a door somewhere that looks like all other doors. Hmmm where could this door be this time? After searching for an hour, perhaps you'll find it.

The only enjoyable aspect of the game is the boss fights, which are challenging (if playing solo without AI) and very souls-like. However, they're so few and far between that I simply can't justify spending hours and hours grinding a terrible level design just for an OK boss fight.

TLDR: Don't waste your time. Definitely don't waste your money. If you've played Dark Souls, love it, and are looking for more souls-like action, then seriously go replay Dark Souls again. It's a much better use of your time.

I'm not going to rant about the minutia of the game because I only played it at a surface level, but I just wanted to leave a review for others who like the Soulslike lore but don't like the frustration of it.
After dropping Bloodborne and Nioh due to aggravation with the stress of it, Code Vein caught my eye due to the partner mechanic. Your AI friend will truly be your best buddy as they pick you back up from a random mistake here and there.
If you want a more authentic git gud experience, you can go solo, but this was the first game where I felt like I was actually able to enjoy the game instead of sweating over it.
If you want to try a souls like and the difficulty is a main deterrent, give this a whirl. You may find a new game to love.

I really enjoy this game, and I'm glad that I got the chance to play this for my first souls- like game. Since it has an anime art style, this game is up my alley even though it is challenging at times.

Amazing game. The story is a satisfying take on souls genre since this one doesn't have you dig for information or lore. The characters and emotions here are real. This game should be called code Pain.

The game is a 8/10 if you're after a more chill anime Dark Souls kind of game.

Gameplay wise the game gives you a variety of different powers and every weapon has something between 4-6 different attacks you can perform. The game relies heavely in its system, where when you level up it gives you points in every status, and the uniqueness of your build resides in the different powers and passives you mix together. Some might see this as a bad thing. Personally, it gives you the possibility to completly change your build to deal with a boss or if you just want to test it without penalizing you for it. 

The story is ok and the side characters are all unique and interesting. The game also offers a lot of customization options for your character and you can change it at any point of the game.

Code Vein is a game which tries to appeal to a variety of kinds of players, it can be a hard or easy game  (you can play without a partner, making the game MUCH more hard) and it's not too grindy. The game also gives you tools to speed up some of the grindier aspects, allowing options to those without too much time to spend in the game.

As much as I wanted to let this game immerse me in its universe, it just doesn't seem to cut it for me.

The anime platitudes, the aesthetics, the sluggish gameplay, the weirdly sexualized representation of women (especially some of the earlier bosses)... it all seems to add up into a boring experience at best, and a frustrating one at worst. 

It's clear this game tries to emulate some of the mechanics made popular by the Fromsoft games, but it does so at a very shallow level; you have your parries, your dodges, your "bonfire" checkpoints, strength builds, dex builds... but it seems to kind of not go any deeper than that; your stats are tied to the "class" and armor you equip, leading to very one-dimensional builds (and leveling only grants you a flat bonus to all your stats at once; you can't really invest all your points in HP or a damage scaling stat, you're locked into just becoming a tiny bit stronger every time)

I wouldn't recommend this game.

Probably the truest to form souls clone out there. This is what dark souls would be like with an easy mode, only from the sense that you can change your build at any time outside of combat. Stuck on a boss; change your build, challenging invasion; change your build. The game was designed with co-op in mind as well as being able to have a npc partner at all times (which you can also change out at the games bonefires for an npc that is more suited to the task at hand). It's also very easy to end up over leveled if you find a build that you like and stop buying extra gifts. Is all that a bad thing? Given that I bought this game 80% as a break from Elden Ring while still wanting to scratch my souls itch, I would say probably not.
It's not perfect but I'd give it a 4.5/5 if its on sale its worth picking up.

I'm just gonna be straight forward and say this game sucks. I can't believe this game has a very positive status cause it really is so boring and dull. First off, the environments in the game are absolutely generic, linear and incredibly boring and just not appealing to the eye. Most of the colours are dull and just ideally one colour. There's no point of exploring because all the maps are extremely boring to traverse and there's nothing ever cool or useful to find unless it's just consumables. The weapons are alright but nothing incredible. The blood veils are an interesting concept but very stale and I wish it could've been expanded on. There's no incentive to levelling up either because the game essentially cripples you if you're pass the level cap for an area. Most of the maps just have a linear path and a maze like path, they just basically went safe making this game. And don't get me started on the bosses, it's such a HUGE jump in difficulty at the beginning like it's so unrealistic. The shop in the game is completely useless because they only sell weapons and "armour" you find and usually people don't toss away what you find so it's only there for upgrades and even then upgrading is really slow. Customisation in the game is pretty cool except for the clothing, there's I think 3 total clothing and only two nice looking clothing and that's it you can't buy or find more clothes. Next thing is a mechanic called Focus and basically focus is a bar you can build up by getting hit a lot or parrying or doing perfect dodges and once the bar is filled you can't get staggered and you're basically suppose to be OP, HOWEVER THIS APPLIES TO EVERY CHARACTER IN THE GAME, INCLUDING ENEMIES AND IT BENEFITS ENEMIES WAY MORE THAN YOU! I have not once had my focus build up and go "Wow that really was clutch there" It never ever works in your favour, by the time your bar fills up the enemy is dead, but the enemies focus bar fills up so much faster so they get to utilize it more than you and the bosses can still stagger you even when your focus is built up and all the bosses just have huge range for whatever reason. Only good thing about this game are gifts and gifts are basically your abilities you can unlock and use in fights. Overall, if you're a souls lover like me this is not a game you wanna play. They basically took the style of souls games and just completely took out the good mechanics and visuals that the souls games have and just made it plain and boring and gave the areas no incentive to explore. I would highly not recommend buying this game and to clarify I even bought the deluxe version sale when it was 28 dollars and I wish I could get that 28 dollars back.

TLDR: Code Vein is, to some extent, a good and fun game, but as a Souls-like it sucks. The only redeeming factor (for me) is that it's Big Tiddy Anime Vampire Souls-like.

============
The good
============
Character creation: it's definitely better than the Souls games but Nioh 2's character creation and transmog mechanic makes customization better. Still, really good looking customization options for anime characters.

Build customization: There's a lot of "classes" and skills to obtain. You can even borrow skills from other classes, so there is a whide range of play styles possible. This reason, plus character customization, is the reason why I have maybe a dozen characters now.

Interesting story: as of this writing I haven't finished it yet, but it has the familiar nuances that comes with anime stories. There was a part of the story that made me cry but I'd rather not post it here. Yes, the game's been out for years but just gonna leave it out for those who haven't been spoiled by the internet.

=============
The bad
=============
Dodging is way harder to do than in the Soulsborne games. Heck, I could dodge way better in Nioh 2 and that game is way more fast-paced than this. On the flip-side, the quick dodge animation is awesome, though.

The combat is clunky, even one-hand sword attacks feel slow. If you initiate a fight with an attack you will most likely get hit back, so you always have to wait for the enemy to make the first move if you don't want to take damage.

The parry mechanic's timing is horrendous. I'm bad at parrying but at least in the Souls games I can see the parries connecting or not and it makes sense visually, and the parry window activates almost as soon as you press the parry button. In Code Vein there's still a second or so before it can actually parry.

The backstab mechanic is inconsistent. The chances of you getting a proper backstab is less than 50%. In the Soulsborne games, if you were behind an opponent that can be backstabbed it's almost guaranteed that you will get a successful backstab.

Staggering bosses does nothing. Yeah, it gives you a small window to go ham but by the time you get that window you probably already exhausted your stamina and/or ichor, or your attack skills are on cool-down. At least in Elden Ring you can riposte most staggered bosses.

The ichor mechanic is shit, to some extent. If you want to increase your ichor pool you need to connect drain attacks and that's easier said than done. The easiest way would be to connect backstabs but I already mentioned how the backstab mechanic is shit. The next easiest way is to connect during a combo, but there's a lot of problems here. If the enemy dies you can't connect with the drain attack. If the enemy doesn't get flinched by your attacks, you will get hit and your drain attack will possibly get cancelled. The next way to obtain it is via charged drain attacks, but charging takes forever and if you get hit you get staggered out of the drain attack. And then there's parrying but parrying is shit in this game.

The targeting mechanic is shit.

My final thoughts
================
I still think my purchase is worth it and I have no regrets getting the game, but I'll still give it a downvote. I still think it's fun to some extent and will probably put in a couple hundred hours into it, but it just sucks as a Souls-like.

If you love big tiddy anime vampire waifus and hunky anime vampire husbandos then get the game, but I would suggest to get it on a sale. The original price is not worth it.
If you want a game you think you'll have fun with, that depends on your patience on clunky gameplay mechanics. And still get it on sale.
If you want a good Souls-like, don't get it. It's not worth it.

I beat Code Vein and got the good ending. I had a lot of fun. I don't recommend it unless it's on a Midweek Madness sale. 

I'll explain: 

There is so much jank and lack of polish that you actively have to learn the game's strange, strange logic to make sense of it. Ranged attacks like the gun from the bayonet have a 5 foot range, enemies don't see you unless you're within 10 feet of them (which you can use for your benefit). Even with maxed out weapons and armor, you do pixel damage to bosses, while you can die in two or three hits even from generic enemies. Each map is a maze, so unless you know to look at below for connecting platforms and you're willing to retread the same map 500 times (to collect vestiges, items, etc), you will have to have a lot of patience and memory.

However, the character creation system is great, the game is hilariously edgy (I recommend if you're a fan of so-bad-it's-good cheese, or Shadow the Hedgehog), and Io is my wife. There's certain quality of life things, such as the fact you can have a companion helper who takes aggro/heals you when you're at 0 hp, and little dots on the minimap showing where you've been and larger dots for where you've just been to help avoid going in circles (though you will anyways).

Get it on sale, like I did, when it was like ~$15 dollars for the full deluxe edition. I got about 40 hours in for a generous Good Ending playthrough where I reached level 135.

Another tip: use the map markers and lights if there's a fork in the path you want to revisit later. It will save your life.

Don't go into this game expecting dark souls.  Both have their own feel to their respective games. It has similar mechanics like stamina, exp currency, and passives that you can equip to enhance your playstyle. It however skips the stat allocation and uses blood codes for stat setups you can swap on the fly. Nice for the fact you can swap your playstyle art any time, given you grind out the materials that allow you to inherit skills. 

Game balance is kind of all over the place. You can play this game with and without an AI partner, which can make fights much easier, though the aggro system is weird at times. I think overall the game was fair, except for a single boss fight where you face two bosses at once. That fight is really up to the individual to decide whether it was a unfair fight or not. You can use 5 catagories of weapons, one-handed and two-handed swords, axes/ hammers, pole-arms and bayonets. You can also learn skills that can buff. cast spells, or enhance your partners. Mana in this game is restored by attacking or consuming items, or using your special drain attack. 

Story is typical anime flair, our world is now inhabited by vampires called Revenants. Our protag works with other revenants to find a better alternative to human's being used as slaves to feed on by revenants. The main enemy are the Lost, who are revenant that have lost their mind from lack of blood being consumed.

I do like the character customizing but the lack of outfits is quite saddening and would have made this game stand out vs other souls-like games in terms of fashion had they only added more. 

Overall, i can reccomend this game if you like anime games and souls-likes.

Anime action-adventure RPG with some soulslike characteristics, I personally wouldn't consider it a soulslike.

Some important things to note based on my own experience: 
- The game can be played alone or in coop mode.
- An AI companion can be selected between 6 different characters and they can assist the player throughout the game. There can be only one AI companion active at the time and not every companion is available from the start. I recommend playing with a companion if the player wants more immersion while exploring. The AI is good, so no need to worry about it getting stuck or falling off a cliff.
- The AI companion talks to the player while exploring dungeons, reacting to different situations and environments adding immersion to the game, the main character is not very talkative tho.
- Fighting with an AI companion gives the player plenty of time to heal, switch items, etc.., ultimately making the fights way easier. If the payer wants the game to be challenging turning off the AI companion is obligatory.
- The enemies drop a great amount of Haze (souls), there's no need to waste hours farming.
- The playstyle is dictated by the Blood Code, which is interchangeable. You can change build whenever you want, wherever you want.
- The level design is intricate, at times it lacks variety. The different areas might be frustrating to some players. I personally love maze-like maps and I loved getting lost in the different areas, it really gave me the feeling of "getting lost in a dungeon and not knowing where the fuck to go, ultimately feeling frustrated".
- Hitboxes are good (surprisingly).
- There's a minimap.
- The character creator is good. Unfortunately it's impossible to change every single face feature (chin, cheeks, nose, mouth).
- The OST is AMAZING, featuring anything from powerful choirs to rock to emotional piano.
- The Japanese dubbing is good.
- Avoid buying any DLC, just burn your money instead.

Yet another souls-like game that relies on random chance.

Graphics are great. The environments look and feel like bizarre landscapes partly destroyed by war and massive spikes. The character models look good as 3D anime characters.

The audio is good. The soundtrack ranges from eerie music while exploring the environments to pretty epic or heavy metal music during battles and cutscenes.

The storytelling seems slow during cutscenes and while going through memories to unlock vestiges. The cutscenes are like watching a 3D anime which would be fine, except it's in between intense combat. The memories force you to walk and the dialogue takes so long you could take 5-10 minutes to get a tiny tidbit of lore. Both cutscenes and memories feel so slow compared to the rest of the game that it makes you want to skip them.

The subtitles sometimes have spelling or grammatical errors, and sometimes don't match the dialog at all, at least in English. These errors don't seem to be a problem in understanding the dialog as far as I've seen. There are also some errors in texts throughout the game like the hint text during loading screens or in a hint window.

There are bugs which ruin the combat at times;
Sprinting at an enemy and attacking, expecting to do a thrust attack, but your character suddenly turns 90 degrees and misses the target (uncommon),
Rolling in the opposite direction your moving (uncommon),
Targeting an enemy in the distance instead of the one in front of you (rare),
Being revived by the companion, or trying to revive the companion, and it shows that the healing ability was used, but the revive never occurs even when my companion or I have full or near full health (very common),
Holding down the sprint button but your character doesn't sprint even after the normal 1-2 seconds delay if you're in combat (common).

Most of the game is easy, just dodge, block, parry, or level up some more, but there are a few bosses that are insanely difficult. A couple boss battles are against 2 bosses which have too many advantages. The bosses switch targets randomly meaning you have to avoid both bosses instead of attacking. The bosses have attacks that can attack both players so you have to avoid attacks from a boss that's not even focused on you. Both bosses can fly forward practically instantly so you can get hit by either boss at any time. In one boss battle, both bosses have ranged attacks which damage on impact and also explode so if you dodge the attack you can still get hit by the explosion.

That being said, the leveling system seems a little easy. You can farm levels very quickly especially later on in the game where relatively easy enemies give about 10,000 Haze each. Relatively easy, compared to the bosses in the same areas which you could spend 5 hours trying to beat, thanks to random chance, just for 100,000 Haze.

This is not technically a souls like game, at least not in a presence, depth or feel sort of way. They implemented a few similar mechanics (like bonfire and souls collecting - aka mistle plants and haze....), but it doesn't really feel like a true souls game. It's more like a super arcade-y version of one.

A good way to explain it would be to compare it to games in the racing genre. Demon's Souls is Gran Turismo and Code Vein is Ridge Racer. Both great games, but one could easily enjoy one and hate the other.

The world and ideas are actually pretty great, I just didn't enjoy how the story came together, especially combined with the incredibly easy gameplay and mostly linear level design. It's 90% grab a weapon and spam attack. This is a disappointing pass and I regret spending $15.99 on it.

The elevator pitch for this game is "anime Dark Souls" but don't let that sell you short - this game is engaging and fun with a deep character customisation system. Blood codes function like classes in other games and give access to magic spells called gifts, and once you master gifts by defeating enemies with them equipped you can use them with other blood codes, which makes for a combinatoric explosion in the number of options.

If you're the kind of Dark Souls player who does SL1 club runs there's plenty of challenge available simply by dismissing your AI partner - that alone will make the game quite a bit more difficult.

TLDR: Don't buy this if you want to have fun, this game will literally torture you right until the end, leave you unsatisfied, hoping you never ever have to touch it again, and make FromSoftware look like they were taking it easy on you. 
If you want a game for story, look elsewhere, if you want something that has fun gameplay, again, elsewhere.\
For the time and effort this game wants you to put into it, there feels to be almost zero reward. 
For the actual gameplay, you have stats that can be altered by gear and 'blood codes', these will affect the 6 choices of weaponry you have, plus the light/dark spells damage output, but ultimately this does not matter as regardless of your level, enemies and bosses will scale with you. 
When it comes to level design i'm positive the design team made the first three areas then just reskinned textures and enemies and said: that'll do for the next 12 stages, except as you progress level design goes from being boring and tedious, to just outright unfair. Pitfalls with no way distinguishable difference to surroundings, wall traps with no way around other than just tanking the damage, enemies designed just to push you into the never-ending pitfalls. As you progress you will find the level will have only one spawn point, being at the start, nothing that bad, except now when you challenge the poorly designed boss and get killed by their completely unavoidable attacks, you now have to spend 5 minutes getting back there, and no damn well this will be a recurring pattern in the second half of the games because the developers don't know the difference between challenging and stupidly un-finished gameplay.

CODE VEIN is basically a Dark Souls knockoff that takes away the leveling system, difficulty, and atmosphere in favor of Anime Dress-Up.

Combat is pretty underwhelming. Hits lack any significant impact, and weapons just look like plastic toys with how effortlessly your character wields them with one hand. Even the huge axes, hammers, and swords look so unconvincing that you could swear your character's just pretending they're heavy. The English voice acting is just as bad as any other dubbed anime, and the story is nothing more than passable.

The game isn't even difficult. Your companion character is super powerful and will do most of the work, congratulating you on a well-fought battle despite you doing barely anything. The beginning character customization is the only part of this game I had any fun with. The other 4.5 hours I spent forcing myself to play this was not even remotely interesting.

This game seems to take the core concept of souls-like, slap an anime filter on it and call it a day. It does have some interesting ideas in terms of character mechanics (gear, abilities and the like), but the very core of Souls gameplay is lackluster. 

The world is interesting and pretty. The actual maps - repetitive, uninspired, quite boring quite quickly. 

The game also insists on never telling you what your actual objective is, even if you're aware of the post-it note on the map. The guides are vague, to say the list, and sometimes progression is locked behind talking to the same NPC 6 times in a row for no reason. I've stumbled blindly along the same paths of the map I've cleared 6 times already hopign this time I find the thing the game wants from me - until I gave up and googled what's wrong. I've done that twice in the first two areas of the game, at which point I lost interest. 

Bosses - admittedly I've only seen (I think?) two actual bosses - the butterfly lady makes no sense to me. I beat here multiple times - at neither of these I felt I knew what was really going on. Meh/10

Overall, and I say it with all the love, if you're looking for an easier souls-like experience, and the anime filter is enough of a substitute for the actual level design - this is a game for you.

The only redeeming thing about this is the combat. You get a lot of strong options and variations to the few weapon types that they give you. But despite the decent combat, which is a shame because of how bad some of the boss design is. 

Overall, I can recommend the game, it is a fairly easy souls-like game to get into and have a interesting weapon system. Buy on sale and you probably wont regret it?

Some of the gameplay is fun, but the difficulty is all about enemies overwhelming you and bypassing your dodges and parries.  The mechanics work most of the time, but when four enemies attack, one of them will hit.  And sometimes a single enemy will have so much time on their attack animation that even if you dodge, you still get hit by the end of the attack.

 Bosses tend to completely change it all up and it just becomes a massive aoe fest that you just sort of stumble through until you get lucky and win the fight.

 The story is decent, but for replayability they have four endings.  One ending is like one word different from one of the others.  And three of the endings require you to either be blind or play badly to manage to get them.  The ng+ is okay and some people must like it, but I don't see it as really giving any additional challenge or replayability because as I said, most of the difficulty is just enemies swarming you or attacks that can't really be dodged.  That isn't really going to change in ng+.

 Overall, I am playing through it, but youtube is going to satisfy me for the extra endings.  There goes a couple achievements but the game isn't good enough to make me play it twice.

It's a soulless coomer-bait ripoff of Souls-like games which incorporates the worst game design elements from the Souls/Nioh games + an unhealthy dose of Japanese infantilization and autism.  Everything is spelled out in laborious detail.  There are cutscenes every 5 minutes which could be completely omitted and nothing would be lost.  There is a 5 minute long tutorial before the 5 minute long intro before you can really take control of your character.  The enemy AI ignores your party members and makes a beeline for you.  Your AI party members are incapable of hitting the enemy (I watched one party member shoot the wall above an enemy 5+ times in a row).  Party members do not shut the fuck up.  I have three hours of gameplay (I left the game on the main menu for almost an hour), and I already have the achievement for having an AI companion talk to you 50 times.  I do not play games to have women constantly nagging me about every little thing that is happening.  There's a bug where the mouse cursor recenters itself and becomes active when certain menus pop up, and it sets focus to whatever is under it.  You will push a button on the controller, the menu opens with "A" highlighted, and then it will immediately switch to "B" before your button press registers forcing you to reopen the menu again.

One positive thing I noticed immediately upon starting the game is how snappy the menu is.  It's not quite Haydee levels of snappiness, but it's definitely up there.

I gave up after I entered an epic-looking chamber, saw the next save point, ran towards it, and then another stupid cutscene started containing a two minute monologue on eating onigiri and "are we even real?"-esque thoughts.  Really disappointing game.  I only got it because I saw it favorably compared to Souls, Nioh, etc.

First review, so bear it with me.
For starters, it took me 54 hours to complete my first run, primarily because I was trying to get everything (and failed). This is also my first Souls-like too, tho this isn't the reason why I bought and played this game.

First off, starting with the obvious point - this is very anime. If you don't like the anime aesthetics, you probably won't like this game. It's a bit of a slow burn in the first 2-3 hours if you are someone who is going in blind.

The story is meh. Very straight forward like in a typical anime. Not necessarily bad, the plot is actually great if you think about but it really feels like the story is there for the sole purpose for it to be there. Honestly, building your relationships with the characters themselves and the journey to the end itself mattered way more than the story itself.
If you try to dig deeper, you might find some lore/story elements that the game doesn't explicitly tell you but that's up to you to figure out, if you are into this stuff.

Decent character creator, you can spend hours on making and customizing your characters. This is probably one of the best and most detailed anime character creator out there.
Although I think that there is still places for improvement. For example, lack of clothing variety (only 6-7 clothes choices with the options to remove stuff like sleeves for example) and the hairstyles choices feel rather inflated (as half of the hairstyles are really just a mirror variations). Also, sometimes hair clipping through your character's face or hat can happen too, especially during cutscenes and it doesn't look good IMO. If this game ever gets a sequel, I really wish the devs would try and improve on that....

Weapon and armour designs, on other hand, are up in my valley.
Level design is meh, I guess. I really don't care about that, with the exception of the Cathedral (which admittedly can be a pain in the ass even on later runs).
Class builds system has a huge potential and you can switch them on the fly, although be aware that you won't get all possible classes right of the bat. That being said, it is perfect for virtually any play-style.

Combat system is a bit of hit-or-miss. Stuff like parry and backstabbing takes awhile to master.

The voice acting is okay. Sound, music and OST is okay too.

TL;DR:

Overall, a solid 7/10.

I suggest buying the Deluxe Edition when on sale. I made the mistake of buying the standard edition only. Also don't bother with the DLC

Dark Souls but anime. 

The story is pretty weak for me compared to Dark Souls. The characters all have motivations and goals but don't actually do enough to endear me to them. The plot is fairly predictable. And there's a 30 minute cutscene near the end about how the power of friendship is your real strength--not, say, the dozens of hours you've spent building your character's power. 

The combat system is standard Souls fare, with small changes. No shields (or off-hands of any sort, actually), but you can use your weapon to block. And dodge rolls feel a bit different. But the same general principles apply.

The real game changer for me was the blood code system. Each of these is basically a class you layer onto your character. Your level is separate from your blood codes, and applies stat increases to each of them based on their scaling. This makes it much easier than in Souls games to try out different builds. The game encourages build swapping further by allowing you to unlock the skills you've mastered in one blood code for use in another (provided the other code has the requisite stats to use it). As someone who loves trying out different builds, I found this to be a massive breath of fresh air compared to Souls games, where you typically have to either roll a new character or use limited items to try a different build, and the only reward for doing so is that you are now a different class. 

If you like Dark Souls, but don't mind a lackluster story, and wish you could swap builds more easily, try this one out.

I wanted to try a soulslike and this game was on sale. Two years later, I have strong enough emotions on the game to write a review. Take some of this with a grain of salt, as of writing I've sunk about four hours into this, and this is going to be a deeply subjective breakdown of why I feel this game completely failed to connect with me.

TL;DR, this game feels like a solid experience at heart, but gets lost for me under its unwillingness to embrace its setting and plot completely, poor writing, and a lack of an engaging or believable world in exchange for weeb nonsense.

I'm no expert on these sorts of games, but combat feels pretty solid, though I don't suggest playing this without a controller. Fights for the most part feel fair, but punishing if you mess up, and although there are quite a few enemies that like to ambush you in one way or another, it doesn't feel like they're so common to be either frustrating or predictable. There's also optional companions, which I found helpful in getting into the game initially. I'll give the game credit in that there do seem to be more complex systems in regards to classes, equipment, and skills, but it hasn't been something I've gotten to sink my teeth into.

Character customization was something that sold me on this game initially, and it certainly was in depth. This is the sort of game where you could spend a long time getting every detail perfect, and if I were more in love with the art style, I'm sure I could have gotten lost in there forever. Unfortunately, that ties into where my issues with the game begins. 

So, I don't love anime, and unfortunately this game feels completely buried in the tropes of that medium. The character creation is certainly in depth, but when it comes to clothing choices, you're stuck with few choices, all of which feel straight out of any generic anime MMO. Playing a woman in particular leaves you heavily exposed; the most combat appropriate outfit I could choose was a skin-tight leather bodysuit. 

It's not just your character, of course. NPCs wears outfits that make no sense in a literal apocalypse, with many of the men wearing suits, while the women are in outfits that would make more sense to go out clubbing in than anything else. If that's partly what you're interested in with this game, more power to you. Go make your anime waifu and enjoy. But it was really weird for me because almost everything else in the game plays your situation straight. All of my playtime has been in this ruined wreck of a city, surrounded by the remains of civilization, fighting my way through the twisted victims of this calamity... but my character looks like she forgot to put on real pants and my companion dropped straight out of Genshin Impact. It feels like none of the characters belong there, including, despite my best efforts with the character creator, my own. I would have liked if the art team had embraced the post-apocalyptic setting in regards to character design and creation options, because I actually like the enemy design. They even have you wearing gas masks outside, but apparently that's about as far as the art style was allowed to go.

The art style made this worse for me, but I could have forgiven it if it had told an interesting story, or had fun characters to just be around. Unfortunately, it feels like the writers came up with the reason for the apocalypse and the basic plot, and then phoned it in. The character list features gems like: leader, guy who misses his dead friends and doesn't like having to drink blood, girl who wears tattered clothing, naive guy, bandit leader. The character I related most to was my own character during cutscenes, since her dead, glazed over eyes and blank expression perfectly mirrored mine once an NPC started talking. Seriously, I can't remember a single name of a character in the game except for Louis, and that's just because his name is Louis. Everyone either feels like a stock character I've met a million times before, or just a way of pushing exposition or plot points at you. They aren't even fun to have as companions, with very little to say about the world around you and a burning need to comment on almost every action you take. Speaking up every time you pick up an item or shouting concern every time you take damage isn't done in a way that seems to show off any personality, and got on my nerves super quickly.

The plot itself is... there was an apocalypse, people now need to survive on blood, and apparently you're the only one who can purify the blood trees you find on your journeys. I'm absolutely missing details here, but I genuinely don't remember much more than that because it get delivered in exposition dumps during cutscenes and I ended up tuning everything out. You're rarely given the opportunity to organically explore and wonder about things because an NPC has infodumped on you in a cutscene as soon as it became relevant, alongside a bunch of information you may not have even cared about. Its frustrating, because the experience of learning about the world is poor, but at the same time you can't turn your brain off entirely because the NPCs want to keep you up to date on everything, and will stop the flow of gameplay to lecture you.

I appreciate this game because it introduced me to the soulslike style of game and showed that I could definitely get into it. Unfortunately, mechanics alone don't make a game, and everything outside of that, the story and characters and everything that I remember well after playing, all of that stuff is just... poorly done and tonally dissonant. Gonna pick up Bloodborne when I get the chance.

On the plus side, there's a hot spring where you can make your animes take a bath and take pictures of them, so its objectively a great game. 10/10.
