To go into detail a bit more.

The character creator is one of the best ive seen in a souls/ souls like game ever. There is so much you can do to really create your anime character in the game. 

Regarding Combat in this game. You will definitely find similarities to the combat you find in Dark Souls, but it feels a lot different. For one you have a system called gifts in this game that act like special powers you can use by building up your Ichor gauge. There are many different kinds of Gifts. Some of the Gifts increase damage, some can make your defenses better, and some are special moves to devastate your foes on the battle field. Regarding hit boxes in the game. Sometimes the hit boxes are really generous for you, and sometimes they are really generous for your foes. You can really notice this in the boss battles. Regarding boss battles some of them are really fun and enjoyable while others i just wanted them to end the moment i realized what type of fight it was gonna be. Sometimes the boss battles are really annoying just because the enemy is able to hit you so easily, and not really telegraphed all that well. Some of this is off set with the permanent companion that is with you throughout the whole game. You can choose one of side characters that joins you on your travels to solve the problems of the world. They can help you fight enemies, and revive you when your lose all your health.

When it comes to graphics and level design this is definitely one of code veins lows. The Graphics arnt awful especially when it comes to character designs, but some of the areas bland, and make different areas look like the same zone a bit too much. The level design also isn't awful its very similar to how dark souls level design works, but its the same issue with graphics where a lot of the areas just look similar to each other that its sometimes hard to tell the 2 apart.

To move to a positive note of the game i will mention the music. I LOVE THIS MUSIC IN THIS GAME. i would buy the OST of this game easily. It has such a great collection of rock music mixed in with a small amount of sad music for when the story goes that direction.
 
Now to mention the story. In comparison to dark souls a story that is arguably not in for face pretty much at all. Code Vein has a story that is very much in your face, and you for the most part will be able to understand whats happening from beginning to end without doing a lot optional story things. I do recommend collecting as much of the "vestiges" as possible while you are progressing thorough the game though, so when you reach the emotional moments of the game you will have a much more emotional experience. The story has its flaws, but for the most part it accomplishes what its set out to do.

Overall i enjoyed my time in the game, and thought it was a fun one time experience of what a Anime Dark souls could really be like. I just hope if they do another one that it feels a bit better to play then the current iteration, and looks a bit better. I would recommend this as a 1 time playthrough to anyone interested in these types of games.

Side Note - If you decide to play this game on a controller you will find another thing that is a bit jaring coming from playing dark souls. Instead of Light and heavy attack being on the right bumpers they are instead on X, and Y. You can change this in the controller keybindings to solve this, but its still jaring.
Very good.

I've had to withhold my opinion on the game for quite a while. But I'll try to keep this as short as possible.

If you're into branching or deep stories or maybe even into environmental storytelling, you won't find anything that impresses.

The DLC isn't terrible as people would lead to believe, but the amount of effort that was put into them is on the low side. I only really recommend them if you A) Love the game and its combat  B) You found the DLC or the Deluxe/Season Pass version for sale.

Gameplay-wise, the combat system seems to be quite simple, it is anything but due to some mechanics not being explained and it is up to the player to discover what works and what doesn't. You can play the game by "bonking" everything in your path, but it will only get one so far by doing so. I would like to note that there is a lot of customisation, so one may start looking into "builds", either made by yourself by being creative, or simply try the existing ones which serve their intended purposes. It is here that the game shines even if there is obvious jank here and there. Just like with anything else, it takes getting used to.

Another thing to note on the customisation side of things, is the character creator. It is decent although has a few limits in place, it is enough for the majority of players, but some may find very creative uses for it.

This game is challenging enough and may frustrate some players, but it is just all the more rewarding this way. It is just a shame there is no "real" incentive to play the game by handicapping your character. (Other than the unexplained mechanic of gaining more "Gift Mastery" via enemy dispersal)

Co-op features are very welcome, albeit lacking in several departments. Such as no ability to accompany the player in more than just combat areas as a standout example. Due to slower loading times, having either player "disperse" means going through a lot of them. The biggest issue is there is no Cross-play with console users due to use of separate "handshake" servers, even though the game's networking feature is P2P based (Peer-to-peer) for connectivity. There are some exceptions for MS/Xbox Game Pass players.

Music is okay, but is nowhere close to Nier: Automata or FFXIV levels of goodness. It simply works for the tone of the game and that's it I suppose. The regular combat tune will get annoying, fast. Your personal enjoyment may widely vary. (If you feel like playing an even harder game, do what I did, just play your own favourite music and disable game SFX)

Game has a photo mode, which includes shaders. Very welcome for people who like making screenshots. It's just a shame you cannot play with the shaders/effects real-time.

Modding... It exists, granted, it is still limited, though visual replacements are all over if you prefer eye-candy over what the game gives you.

The game has a semi-hidden community of avid players (myself included), both on console and PC, finding them was probably the best thing going into this game if you're into discussing many aspects of the game.

Truth be told. I personally found more enjoyment out of this game than the Dark Souls series in one aspect and that is due to how the entire combat system gives you a lot of freedom to play around. But for everything else, there are games that did things much better.

PS- SN for Story / CV for Gameplay, 'nuff said.

Story is pretty rough, but the gameplay loop itself is alright except for the anor londo clone which is a labyrinth with drop puzzles you should honestly just google yourself. Expect to use the skill system a lot, or you will suffer greatly.

Reviews for this game frequently describe dark souls.  But what if you only have a vague idea on what dark souls is like I was when I started this game?

So here's how it works:
You change your class on the fly, it remembers your skills you selected for each so that's nice.
You need to change classes to learn cross class skills, or spend items on them to max out your experience with those skills instead of using the class (blood code).
All basic enemies act like they have cheat codes.  Even the biggest sword will rarely stun them.  Most of them move really slow and usually telegraph an attack if you are paying attention.  But since they spawn all around you, it's a bit harder.
When you start the game, you will probably be using up your healing often.  If you take any hits before the boss from regular enemies, your not ready for the boss.
Bosses are super speed unflinchable one hit kill monsters that can spam AoE.  They are really hard.
The levels are all giant puzzles with enemies that respawn every time you save your game. 

The character creator is excellent.  Especially the accessories section which lets you do pretty much anything.
Your AI companion is competent, often more than you at the beginning.

I do recommend the game.  But be ready for some frustrating bosses.
Anime dark souls fall guys

First of all, the game doesn't do everything wrong and I enjoyed some parts of it. I am a huge fan of souls games but this game could have been a lot better than it is.

The good:
- Amazing character creation!
- Great build diversity and easy to change builds quickly.
- Visuals are 10/10 
- The elemental weakness triangle is allright.
- Great mana system in the ichor.
- The hellknight dlc is one of the most fun souls type game fight i have ever experienced and redeems some of the bad fights. 

The bad:
- the 10/10 visuals cover the whole screen, its like they dont have LOD for FX's so they are less present the closer they are to the camera.
-the enemies are repetitive and a little boring at times.
- No gear set systems or favorite marks to put on gear you want ro quickly swap to, always have to look in the list of gifts and passives to find what you want.
- I wish the weapons and veils transforming would be more meaningful.
- The companions the game is built around either die all the time and are useless or just destroy the whole level for you, no inbetween.
- The range of most spell abilities are pathetic at best.

The Ugly:
- The level design is to put it nicely, dogshit. When compared to other souls games it is filled to the brim with cheap deaths that mixed with the bad enemy design creates a gameplay experience so predictable and yet unavoidable that I want to tear my eyes out. Every single level of this game has tiny ledges with no railing, enemy hidden in the corner or in a snow pile that has launch move to send you flying or some. Its like the devs played through Sen's forteress and only took out the worse elements to craft the environment of the entire game.
- The directional inputs. Dodging in this game is garbage, most of the time the boss will dash backwards and suddenly your character is dodging in all the wrong directions and spamming dodge just makes him fly in every direction when you are keeping the thumbstick on the same side the whole time. 
- On the note of bosses jumping. I don't know who thought it was a good idea to make sure the enemies would take of in the air fucking up all the camera angles and dodge inputs every 5 seconds but goddamn. I feel like I was coming up on a seizure with so many abrupt camera turns.
- There is no exposition on missed rewards. I get that its to promote more play time in new game+ to get the different blood codes but I unknowingly blocked myself out of the blood code i wanted while playing blind and now have to do ng+ to get it and to be honest i don't think i will for all the reasons mentioned in this review.

The Demo already reveals the problems the main game already struggles with and that is functionality.

Coming from an ultra polished game called, Nioh 2, this game is a disaster in terms of combat: how it operates, behaves, and interacts. The user interface is everywhere, disorganized and unlabeled - this reality also exists within the progression lacking a sense of guidance, or even a indication of completion. 

The story is enough to hang on to this game, but DO NOT BUY FULL PRICE.  The ratings on this game are FAKE -- Snapping the player model to locations to interact with the environment; hell, the Back-Grab jitters when an input is spammed. There are technical problems that I would expect fixed prior to release.  It is clear optimization and polish are a thing of the past.

###################
Update #1 -- This game is garbage in design. The stat scaling and attributes do not make any sense nor do they appear to work. The game functions in 4 core aspects: Weapon, Parry Costume, Spells, Stat Presets.

Weapon: 
Weapons in this game function in their own unique way.  They all reduce a certain number of damage before it penetrates through to your Health.  This block is independent of your " Parry Costume" (armor).

Parry Costume:
In the game this is called a blood veil, but it really just serves as a costume. Although there are descriptions that describe these items as armor, all it does is affect the damage amount of your parry.  You can't discard this item nor do you need it if you plan to never parry. This item changes character's visual with an annoying cowl or coat. 

Spells:
The spells are nearly all the same with a different visual flash.  It requires "ichor" (mana) that can only be regenerated by taking damage or dealing damage.  Yes, pew pew then you are forced to melee combat when you have no mana-- why have projectile spells in the first place? It is clear the Buffs are more robust making magic spells a optional preference. A caster will be forced to fight up close anyway.

Stat Presets
The game calls them Blood Codes. A player CANNOT allocate their own stat points because there are none. Instead you find presets during your campaign, and 99% of these presets appear to be made out of someone's @$$ because they didnt want to work their job correctly. Spoiler: the second  "Blood Code" (preset) you obtain is THE BEST IN EVERY POSSIBLE STAT. Forget about armor, the great sword is the SHIELD. 

Update 1 Summary:
Due to its lack of Design, all the features this game offers contradict or bash each other into deprecation. If one plans to use a Great Sword which has the BEST block value, who needs "Armor". Blocking gives you mana, so why go magic?? Melee attacks and Parrying are the primary way to gain mana so why use projectiles?  Melee Skills also use mana, again why be far away? These circumstances leaves no purpose to use any form of projectile based damage because there is ZERO sustain, forcing a player to fight Close Comabt anyway. The stat presets are the laziest idea I have ever witnessed.  

Let me Rant and ridicule this game for a bit to depict what i mean:

Mage Preset how cool!  30 Mana doesnt sound bad, uh.. my fire ball is 5 mana. I can only Fireball 6 times and Im out of mana. Oh Wait, I have to go and swing a melee weapon to get my mana back... well F@#%, my melee damage is disgraceful.  Oooo a range preset,  nvm rifle bullets take mana. Im going to fight up close again.  Dude, a tank PRESET! Hell yea...  wtf,  any preset can wield a great sword and tank with it?!  Forget about swinging a Single Sword as a warrior, I can go Mage for the high mana pool, block forever and use my great mana pool to use Melee Skills, Vanish, buff the F)($ ton and when im out of stamina, I can parry then block again and repeat.  Another mage preset with a different name. 16 mana? No thanks.

16 hours later...  still using the same preset, same weapon, I dont get why i even have to parry, why isnt there a naked option? Time to fight a boss again,  ill try it solo,  this fucking boss is spamming the same move!!! i''m Dead.  Back to summoning the companion.

THAT IS CODE VEIN in a nut shell.

######################

Never played a "Souls-Like" game before. I appreciate the mechanics, and the combat. This is a fairly fun game to dive into and feel good about your own growth, tactics, and experimentation with your build. It's nice that you don't need to feel tied down to any one style, either; If long-range, evasive, or ailment-based combat isn't doing you any good, it's trivial to equip some heavier armor and complimenting abilities, and go in swinging. Overall, the gameplay is good and that makes the game recommendable.

The story and dialogue are lacking, however. The visuals are beautiful, the character customization is top-notch, and the overall level design is nice! ...It's just.. I feel like I'm coming home to a parody of a post-apocalyptic teenage dream, that's populated by dramatic-sounding, but ultimately boring dolls. The game's whole setting revolves around these characters' memories and revealed pasts, but the player's a mostly silent protagonist with dialogue that matters in no way, and whose only true decisions involve walking in one direction, or pressing a button. But hey, at least they're darn handsome.

Let me start by saying I greatly look forward to a Code Vein 2 that hopefully builds off the cool innovations and world this game sets up. Setting aside whether you like anime or not, this game's really cool "blood code" progression system isn't enough to save it from extremely monotonous levels full of copy/paste enemies strewn about winding, tight corridors. You may feel the urge to ask, "but doesn't Dark Souls have those problems too?" Sure, but it's really kicked up to 11 here. I mean most levels are literally straight hallways lined with predictable monster closets, and they're all the same brown and tan color pallet that would feel at home in a mid-2000's Xbox 360 shooter. None of these levels really force you to change up your playstyle, nor do the enemies, who only pose a threat when ganking you in large mobs. It's not by any means a terrible or unplayable game, I just have better things to do with my time.

This game contains a fair amount of hokey, Japanize, anime weirdness. I’m not the type at all, but there is some earnestness to the characters. I don’t hate them, and they may not be super fleshed out, but the do a serviceable job of being ‘people’ in a crazy world.

The game play is mostly good, early it’s really good because it pushes you in interesting ways. You feel weak and low on recourses. Later on, enemies become predictable and bosses quite easy.

Then late and post-game, bosses and many enemies become sponges for damage. If you do the DLC-bosses get ready for some tanky and cheesy bosses with insta-gib-mechanics that rarely feels interesting or fair.
The end game kind of needs to throw away the stamina bar to be enjoyable. Way too much dodging hit three times and then wait for that bar. In most early and mid-game fights this feels more natural, but the end game has some tonky ass bosses and enemies. (Maybe my build sucked?)Duller, than interesting stamina management. I think there is a gigantic difference between when stamina management becomes a chore, like the end game, and when it’s done masterfully and becomes a fantastic mechanic: Monster Hunter.

It’s alright, as a game, maybe skip the DLC if you don’t really, really like the end game as it is. Also be ready for hokey anime people ^^

Dark Souls but Anime


Seriously though, I enjoyed this soulsian a lot. It's a more character and story driven game with a very interesting memory mechanic to delve deeper into the characters past. The gameplay is tight and the graphics are pretty good. I do have many problems with it tho which I will list below, but overall 7/10.

The lore and worldbuilding is a core part of this game. The way its delivered in the beginning is awful. You will be told the lore and your current objective at least 3 times, without interacting with optional npcs. The characters names are strange, with unamed revenants having an adjective assigned to them. This is really weird because the adjectives will not match with the overall characters personality / mood. 

As well as characters with actual names only appearing when their name is introduced in the dialogue, unless you have their name from the start. These weird decisions can be seen throughout the game, just hinders the experience in general. A good mechanic is the hot spring where you can look back on lore, both character and world wise.

The level and enemy design are good, grew on me after a while. The mechanics of combat and equipment are also great, although the responsiveness of the doge roll can be iffy. My biggest problem is that after giving you all of the stats like dex, str, mnd and such the leveling system helps with none of it. Like if you're combining exp and currency into one, that should have a meaningful purpose. It feels like they put it in there because sous-likes have it without understanding the meaning and worth it carries.

Why have a combined exp and currency system? If blood codes give you the stats and leveling only upgrades stamina, health and damage why have it there? Upgrading the weapons and veils already exists, with classes giving gifts along with different resistances and stat levels. Why not just have a currency, with upgrades to health and stamina being like the regeneration upgrades: ones you pick up as you progress.

Why have a level up feature? The grinding mechanic is already there with the mastery of certain class gifts, the farming for materials to upgrade your veils and weapons is there. What is the point of leveling up? One of my fav games which is also a souls-like is Hollow Knight; here there's no exp because leveling up that way makes no sense. You have your stat upgrades with items you acquire throughout the map, only being able to get some of them with abilities gotten later. 

The sense of progression is not created by an experience system and I think Code Vein would be much better off that way as well. You can choose which stats to upgrade in Dark Souls giving you a different build, while Code Vein is more about the gear and gifts. You need to level up certain stats in Dark Souls to equip something, while Code Vein just needs a compatible class. Maybe its just me but I don't see the worth of having Haze, when better more compatible systems of progression are out there.

Anime Dark Souls. If those 3 words don't appeal to you: Anime ARPG. These are the most succinct phrases I could use to describe this game.

Graphics are great with very few visual glitches, and the soundtrack is appropriately epic for bosses. Unfortunately there isn't typically any BGM playing while you roam, so the world does feel stale and lifeless, which I imagine is the point.

The worldbuilding in this game is decent and, in true Soulslike fashion, frustratingly vague. Yet you will be able to understand just enough of the story to know which way is forward... Most of the time.

Level design is a nightmare for some stages, and while it is certainly intentional and it can be rewarding to explore, there's no denying that at some point you'll probably have to look up a guide on how to progress. And that's a bummer.

Character creation is fairly detailed and you can certainly customize your avatar to your heart's content. There are characters here with massive boobs, sure, but there are also characters with normal chests, hunky bois, and fem bois too. No need to be turned away by a little boob jiggle physics, there is definitely variety here.

Finally: Combat. This is, of course, the highlight of the game and what we came here for. It is Soulslike with a heavy emphasis on positioning and dodging, while blocking and parrying are also defensive tools at your disposal, though they require a lot more skill to utilize. Unfortunately, unlike Dark Souls you do not have full autonomy over your character's combat style and stats.

Stats are determined by the Blood Code you equip, which then determine the passive and active skills at your disposal. Leveling up only increasing your HP and scales the difficulty of the enemies up. In theory, this would mean a "Level 1 Run" might actually result in the easiest version of the game, but I haven't had the guts to test that theory.

You may carry only up to 2 weapons at any time, and you may not dual wield them. This, coupled with the fact that there are no shields in this game, pigeon hole you into an all-out-offensive playstyle with the only choice being your flavor of carnage.

Overall a great 8/10 experience with notable design choices that keep it distinct from Dark Souls.

So let me talk about my experience.

The game is boring as f*ck i saw more cutscenes than my gameplay itself, the monsters and bosses were too easy that required literally 0 skill even some weabo with no gaming experience could beat the game while just pressing w and spamming left click. I started playing the game after the first cutscene and after a while again, saw some talking boobs and ass ive immediately smashed my head to the table to atleast keep playing the game. The map design is so cruel that my friend with claustrophobia jumped out of the window because he could only move 1 step right/left in the maps we've played in. In the first map there's some insane weabo's that turned into demons i guess? and you can literally just kill them even though you get 10 hits by each one of them because the game is made for whose just wants to be anime protagonists.(Well i like being the strongest in some games but after a while you'll prob just get bored like saitama.) yeah, what a coincidence i like anime too? but still dont like the game.

Lets talk about in-game experience of mine.

Ive started the game, created my character then immediately saw some anime boobs played i mean uh, thats cool and all but im actually talking about real talking butts, while some npcs were talking i was only seeing their butts or boobs (or prob ive just focused on these- hopefully.) And ive got into the game there was the city map with no exploration at all made and some non-strong enemies to make me uh what, ready for the boss or learn the game mechanics? No, i mean thats what i thought but boss was literally the same level with those monsters. The first city map was only some car junks and some boring buildings/enemies. Thats all, yeah. After ive got to Firelink Shrine (Whoops wrong game) I thought game would finally start but get this! Ive had lots and lots more dialogues/cutscenes the only good thing was the Rock music that ive found in the jukebox. Then the guy said oh lets go back to the first map! And it literally got painful after that. (mentally, because i was bored haha get it?) Then i accidentally pressed alt+f4 and uninstalled the game thats why i cant play anymore nor cant refund the game because ive played this boring as game for 5 hours because i thought it would get "Better".

Oh and lets talk about good things on my experience. uhhh-
Anime Boobs
Rock music on the jukebox
Soundtrack
Epic intro on getting into the game every time you start
(Notice how im only talked about the music for 3 lines? because i couldn't find any good things that i remember from the game.)

In conclusion.

[h1]“IMAGINATION!!!”
~[i]Shashō, Ressha Sentai ToQger[/i][/h1]

Imagination. Kinda hard not to notice that at this point, the world desperately needs more of it. I mean, seriously, think 'bout it. In theaters it's either remakes or another [b]Fast & Furious[/b], in video games it's either another [b]Call of Duty[/b] or [b]Assassin's Creed[/b] and even when it's about Japan, it's hard not to notice lack of the imagination. Instead of creative new stuff, we're getting more and more generic shōnen manga from [b]JUMP[/b] and tons of flying lolis in anime. I don't know about you, but personally, I'm [i]so-o-o[/i] tired of all that copy / pasted content. It's like marketing destroyed all the creativity. Like, there's no art anymore, only products. And consuming those feels like eating those cheap hot dogs from [b]Costco[/b] instead of a proper homemade meal. Kinda helps you to keep going, but doesn't have much taste and is also bad for your health. Why am I telling you all that? Well, because that's the thing about [b]CODE VEIN[/b]. It lacks the imagination.

Don't get me wrong, though. The presentation here? It's absolutely beautiful. You enjoy watching anime? You'll love the presentation here. The visuals combine Gothic elements with post-apocalyptic stuff and our usual anime-like approach, and the result looks very impressive. Of course, we've also got great voice acting (don't know about English one, but honestly, if you play Japanese games with English dub, there's something seriously wrong with you) and some awesome songs. Talking about songs. Aside from very touching original tracks, we've got licensed tracks from [b]VAMPS[/b]. Yes, [i]the[/i] [b]VAMPS[/b]. That stylish Japanese duo that includes [b]K.A.Z[/b] and [b]HYDE[/b] from [b]L'Arc~en~Ciel[/b]. And it's really, [i]really[/i] cool. For two reasons. First – you can rarely hear [b]HYDE[/b]'s awesome voice in video games. [b]L'Arc[/b]'s [b]Drink it Down[/b] was used for [b]Devil May Cry 4[/b] (in [b]Japanese[/b] version of the game you can hear it during the installation process), [b]Don't be Afraid[/b] was used as a theme song for [b]Resident Evil VII[/b] ([b]BIOHAZARD VII[/b]), while [b]Mirai[/b] (the first single in many years) was licensed for [b]BANDAI NAMCO[/b]'s [b]MMO[/b] called [b]Blue Protocol[/b]. That's pretty much it about [b]HYDE[/b] and video games. So, having a new game with his voice? It's cool.

The second reason is, of course, the fact that it's [b]VAMPS[/b] we're talking about. And, unlike [b]L'Arc~en~Ciel[/b], [b]VAMPS[/b] never aimed for true art and creativity. [b]VAMPS[/b] were always about the show. About two “bad” boys showing off. With tons of vampiric costumes, lyrics and motifs. And guess what? [b]CODE VEIN[/b] is a game about vampires. Well, technically, those are called [b]Revenants[/b] and there's somewhat complicated story about how things work about them, but long story short – those are just post-apocalyptic vampires (vampiric abilities included). And naturally, it's a perfect match for [b]VAMPS[/b] and their songs. Especially since, unlike [b]Devil May Cry 4[/b], this game would actually use those songs in the process. And seeing your guys fighting while listening to [b]VAMPS[/b] in the cutscene? It's just awesome. Even if you're not really a fan (again, what's wrong with you? Everybody should love [b]HYDE[/b], [i]everybody![/i]). Like I said, presentation in [b]CODE VEIN[/b] is great. The game has a deep atmosphere of infinite sadness, it has a lot of tragedy, it has a lot of emotions, etc, etc, etc. So... it's a great game, right? Well... not... really, no. Because that's where creativity ends and our usual copy / pasted stuff begins.

First of all – all the vampiric stuff aside (because yes, it's cool and comes with a lot of style and symbolism), it's our usual [b]BANDAI NAMCO[/b] stuff. You know. The old world lies in ruins, there are monsters running around, and, of course, there's a group of young people to do something 'bout it. Reminds you of certain something, right? Yep. It's a bloody [b]GOD EATER[/b] all over again. Everything's here. The ruined city, the home base, the silent girl with white hair, tsundere with a huge weapon... It's all here and it feels [i]exactly[/i] the same. So much for creativity, huh? And you know what? When it's about the gameplay, the approach is exactly the same. I'm not trying to say that this game has the same gameplay with [b]GOD EATER[/b] games, of course, but yes, it's a copy / pasted bull too. Except this time [b]BANDAI NAMCO[/b] copy / pasted things from [b]Demon Souls[/b] / [b]Dark Souls[/b] series. In other words, it's like this - take [b]Dark Souls[/b], replace setting and characters with what we had in [b]GOD EATER[/b] and [i]voilà![/i] Here's a new game from [b]BANDAI NAMCO[/b]. That would be [b]$59.99[/b], thank you very much.

But OK, creativity or no creativity, maybe gameplay here is very polished and satisfying? Nope. The battles come with a clunky and cheap aftertaste (you've played [b]GOD EATER[/b] – you know what I'm talking about), while level design... well... I can't say it's bad. Actually, I enjoyed it quite a lot. Just because I do like complicated levels. I like looking for keys and trying to figure out how the current map works way, [i]way[/i] more than just running forward through corridor-like levels (like in [b]Nioh[/b], for example). The problem is – level designer here is an ass. The maps in [b]CODE VEIN[/b] are full of “ha-ha! You're dead!” traps (technically, those are not even traps, you'll just fall a lot because maps are designed in a way that prevents you from seeing pits before falling), the game will change the rules quite often (again and again you'll be stuck because the game will introduce the new kinds of level design without even trying to properly introduce them to you) and so on. In other words, the levels here are just... unfair. And not in a good [b]Souls[/b]-like way, but in a cheap death one. Let's just admit it, everybody hates cheap deaths. And this game? It sure has 'em. Cheap deaths, being stuck for hours just because nobody told you that you can do certain tricks... That's [b]CODE VEIN[/b] for you. And there's nothing special in all that. This game? It's just that. A low budget [b]Dark Souls[/b] in [b]GOD EATER[/b]-like setting with clunky battle mechanics. The end.

So, how to feel about all that? Naturally, it's up to you. There's sure a lot of good in this game. Dramatic story, awesome presentation, licensed tracks from one of the most badass Japanese duos out there, complicated level design, [b]Souls[/b]-like mechanics (online included) with some unique twists and vampiric motif, and so on. But on the other hand? On the other hand we've got a low budget aftertaste, clunky mechanics, cheap deaths and, of course, copy / pasted setting and characters. Personally, I have no idea how to rate all this. Did I have my share of fun with this game? Kinda. Especially since, as you've already noticed, I'm a big fan of [b]HYDE[/b]. But do I consider it to be a worthy product? I... don't think so, no. And since there are way, [i]way[/i] too many [b]Souls[/b]-like games on market... I can't say I recommend this one in particular. Just because there are [i]way[/i] better alternatives. Then again, it doesn't mean that it's a bad game. You like both [b]Dark Souls[/b] and [b]GOD EATER[/b]? You don't mind copy / pasted content and low budget aftertaste? You may as well go for it. But personally, I don't think I can give this one a thumb up. Dixi.

This game isn't good. It isn't terrible. It's mediocre with good elements and glaring flaws. Where the character creator, combat and systems are relatively good, that's kinda where it ends. 

The story is kinda meh. It's just kinda there. There's nothing interesting about it. Characters decide to have random backstory dumps at odd times, which can be very jarring at points. Where the game seems to somewhat care about the characters, it cares very little about the world itself, giving a paper thin backstories as to why the events that we've seen have happened, but completely neglecting to explain why you're running around an apocalyptic metropolis that looks like it has been hit by every natural disaster known to man, at least once each.

There's very little in terms of outfits for your character in comparison to other character elements (to begin with at least), which is pretty disappointing given the many options for other aspects of your character. The game gives you the ability to toggle individual elements or an outfit on or off. This at least allows you to make all the overly extravagant outfits into something a bit more minimal. This doesn't really solve the lack of options for outfits.

A lot of the enemies have weapon swings that reach significantly behind them on both sides, meaning you practically have to roll for every attack and there are no reliable "safe spots". Some enemies have stupid long attack ranged with melee attacks that you expect from a boss, not an early game mob. Each level has a small pool of enemies, maybe with a couple of different weapons if they use them. which are copy-pasted everywhere in those levels, which results in very little variety and pretty boring gameplay. The game gives you NPC follower to help you throughout levels, but I often found that where I played cautiously, the NPC would jump in and kill everything. Backstab angles are far more forgiving than DS. A lot of the issues with the combat result in either feelings of "wat" or "well that was so easy it was boring". 

All the feelings of excitement and adrenaline you get from playing DS just aren't here. If that's what you're looking for, look for something else. You won't find it here. If you're just looking for another action RPG, then this exists I guess, but there are better options. If you're looking for a co-op game, then you should know that this game functions similarly to DS. It's a bearable co-op system on top of a mediocre, yet very flawed game. No matter what angle you're coming from, my recommendation is still to look somewhere else (unless you're just looking for anime dark souls, in which case, guess this fits the bill on an aesthetic level).

Do you LOVE Dark Souls?  Do you LOVE post-apocalyptic anime?  Only if you can say yes to both will you enjoy this game.  If you kinda don't like one or the other, this game will be a boring slog for you.

I waited for the opportune time to by this game from my wish list for a while and fate would have it that it was on sale for the winter sale so here goes....

When starting out learning the system is pretty easy, the story if you are into the narrative is entertaining, I could customize my character with varied options, the class system is a build your own setup. That is the major positives for me.

However...... The Vestige Memory System is a hell of a drag, Literally spent an hour just going through memories to fix class abilities, if you go to heal and restore supplies the enemy re-spawns immediately leaving to choose to press forward till you find a new checkpoint or master combat without using many needed supplies, most things in this game are fairly cheap or over priced, the trade system for points seems like a possible drag as well seeing as you never know when you will find an object meant for a certain character. I honestly despite those flaws am enjoying the game the best I can.

I would recommend it even knowing what I know now. If you like anime and darksouls this defiantly a game you can appreciate.

Perfectly accurate to how anime would be made into a game unoriginal 90% filler and 10% actual content.

A few things from the game also feel like watered down version of things from darksouls with the swamp needing to light fires and some of the bosses felt like watered down versions of bosses from darksouls.

Speedrunability – 1/10, almost impossible, only at some points can you save time, but you can skip cutscenes and there’s a lot.

Achievement Hunting Difficulty – 6/10, all achievements can be done solo and would require more then one play through.

Game Difficulty – 7/10 if this is your first “souls-like” game and you even get a companion, which makes the game not as difficult. If you really wanted to make it more difficult. You’d have to get rid of your companion and play at level 1 with the starting weapon. Otherwise, it’s like a 4/10 for veterans of this game type.

Story – 6/10 – I don’t really play games for story and this one especially is fairly predictable, especially if you’re familiar with anime/mangas.

Level Design – 6/10 – Some maps are well designed and some are just headaches that just break immersion. Some transition points between maps just seem unnecessary… such as climbing down a 20ft ladder, walk 6 steps just to climb up a 30ft ladder. Some parts of the map are just there for appeal with no functionality.

Character Design – 7/10 – Could do with more character customization, but otherwise it’s acceptable. Also, if you’re familiar with anime/manga… you can get a rough estimate of predictable support characters.

AI – 6/10 – Enemies are pretty predictable with their attacks and can’t do much about your companion’s AI. You’re not really supposed to depend on them. The only thing that makes them difficult is that some have an “activation” animation where you can’t hurt them, or when they just spot you.

Gameplay – 7/10 – It’s more or less an anime themed dark souls with flashy attacks.

The positives:

[list]
    [*]Art and design: beautiful character models, weapons, character customization
    [*]Good idea to show your footsteps in the mini-map, I wish more games did this
[/list]

The negatives:

[list]
    [*]The level design is ultimately boring. Without spoilers, you have ruined cities, deserts, fire and ice. That's pretty much it. You have a limited colour palette through the entire game, I imagine this was a conscious choice by the level designers to create a certain ambience, but I didn't care for it. It was depressing and boring.

    [*]The blood code AKA class system. You unlock blood codes throughout the game. Some are not obvious, you have to talk to NPCs without any indication you should talk to them. You then unlock skills within these blood codes. It's unclear when you will find certain items to unlock these skills. Then you have to level the skills themselves inside the blood codes to 'master' them so you can use the skills whenever you want, given you meet the weapon requirements. 
This all felt very convoluted - there are repeating codes (like Power Up), useless codes that I can't imagine anyone using. Navigating through these different codes and seeing which ones you have levelled up was incredibly annoying. What stats do what is also unclear unless you do some googling. 

[*]Ichor, the "Mana" of the game. This resource feels severely limited unless you optimise your build for it or use the drain attacks of the game. The drain attacks restore Ichor instead of your Hit Points... A game where you're a VAMPIRE. Ok, I guess. 

[*]The story. Rather, how it's told. Unlocking skills from blood codes requires gathering memory stones. Each memory stone is you being teleported to a colourless level and being spoon fed dialogue from a character you don't really care about. One. Sentence. At. A. Time. You can skip the entire cut scene, but there is no option for being teleported to the level in the first place. Just let me get my skill, please.
The main story was pretty boring. I didn't find any of the characters memorable or wanting to root for them. Just meh.

[*]The PC port. As console ports go, this wasn't too bad. But you can instantly tell this game was made for playing with a controller. As I'm used to playing with M&KB, the gameplay was frustrating. The keyboard layout is not great, also navigating through menus is not intuitive at all. Again, this was clearly made for console.

[*]The expansions. For their price, they're not worth it. If you buy this, wait for deep discount or skip them altogether. They are basically one small level (called Depth), you can get some items from them and a new boss, that's it.
[/list]

What to say? It's dark souls with anime vampires.
It does have some bugs that rank from annoying to potentially life-threatening, examples of those both extremes are some relationship items being deleted when changing menus for the former and the game not recognising mouse input at random during fights for the later.
Beyond that, backstabbing is really satisfying, the fights are entertainingly challenging, the environment is beautiful and the soundtrack is great. Also you can take amazing screenshots.

I really recommend it overall.
Dark Soul in anime style and easier than Dark Soul, but it is still hard for me.

The game is a Souls-like with decent mechanical depth, variety of builds, replayability combined with a JRPG inspired storyline and much more focus on storytelling and cinematics as compared to most other souls-like titles. Graphics are a bit dated when it comes to textures but the aesthetics are good enough overall and get the job done. Gameplay has a few bugs especially during online co-op gameplay but nothing game-breaking.

Overall, worth a playthrough or two if you like this genre of game.

The game is an average game, that I'd recommend if you do like games with 'anime' aesthetics.
The gameplay is not bad. The customization, both of character appearence or the character "class" are great. At the end of the game you can make based in anything you like; magics, elements, weapon type, movement, range or melee etc.

The Story could be much better. Tbh I tell my friends this is a flashback simulator. Tho it may be boring, the world itself is interesting. I hope they make a sequel of this just to explore more this world.

The visual are awesome if you like anime/cartoon like things. This is an action game with cartoonized character. BUT, as a RPG player if really felt it missed the visual appealing of classes, which does not change ANYTHING. The only changes in visual you have in the game are: Changing character model, Changing Weapons, Changing the Cloak you wea (which you can just turn off and see the character original clothes all the time). Where the cloacks kinda are 'linked' to a type of character build, you pretty much will only use like, 3 cloacks, all the game (when you have all of them). One if you want to have quick movements if you're with light weapon, one based on your strength (most of time) because strength scalling weapons are heavier, and one based on magic damage, if you want to play mage. That really disappointed me, but made me create a different character for each playthrough.

The musics are just... Ok.

The difficult on high levels (new game +) are the type of flawless or death. Not really based on the machanics.
The game is a good hack'n'slash, but tbh, a very bad souls-like.

The DLCs are a bit more difficult. Not because it's new mechanics or whathever, but because their bosses have "trials" which may be tiring if you try to complete all of them.

While the gameplay is fun and the character creation is pretty, CODE VEIN is, and I hate to use Dark Souls as comparisons normally, LITERALLY Anime Dark Souls.. The downside is that the level design seems to be aimless mazes rather than having any sort of direction, like Dark Souls has. This results in you running around lost for hours before you just so happen to stumble upon where to go. This is not fun.. it's not fun to look at, it's not fun to wade through. Maybe I'll change my mind as I keep progressing, but so far the level design is is so lackluster it's dragging the rest of the game down with it. You'll be seeing glowy veins for quite a while before finally arriving at the Anor Londo clone.. Except that this Anor Londo clone is terrible compared to actual Anor Londo. While in Anor Londo, the path was set for you, and you only had to figure out how to get there, This game literally just twists and turns with the same fucking set of stairs as the last set of stairs.. Fall off here and.. aren't I just back where I started? Let me check the map... WHAT? 10% This level is HUGE.. and not in a good way.. It's huge, but it all looks the exact same with washed out color and endless staircases EVERYWHERE. The enemies aren't even difficult compared to what I gotta look at while fighting them. If you can get over this, or use a guide, the rest of the game has many mechanics and features that I really do enjoy. Combat is fun, if not a little weird.. Hits don't really feel like they connect unless you're using a heavy weapon, but dancing around enemies smacking them with a hammer is so fun I kinda just wanna keep doing it. So why do I recommend this game if I have so many bad things to say? It feels like Dark Souls, but you can go really far with the character customization.. And I'm into that. It was one of the few things I wish Dark Souls did better. The game is definitely worth a shot, ESPECIALLY if you can get it on sale. I don't think I could justify spending $60 on this, but the 8$ I spent made this buy pretty spectacular. I will end up beating it, and if anything changes in my time from now til then, maybe I'll adjust this review.

I bought this game on release but didn't play for long before leaving it to collect dust in my Steam inventory. Now, over 2 years later, a friend asked if we would coop if he bought it, I said sure, and man I'm glad I picked it back up.

First, the obvious. I'm a huge souls game fan and if you are too, you will feel right at home. The game also has great QoL features both in and out of coop, and due to the way the leveling works, you are free to switch up your builds on the fly as well, which is awesome.

Story is honestly really good in my opinion, the game has multiple different endings and the characters in the story are honestly likable and fun to be around. Story even got me emotional in some parts. It took me and my friend 25 hours to beat the game, 100%:ing each area and playing through them twice so the game is decently lenghty as well. Haven't touched DLC yet though, and only done half of Depths (kinda like simpler Bloodborne Chalice Dungeons).

In case you care about character customization (like I do), the game's got you covered there as well. Honestly it's MMO tier, and having spent literally 50% of my 12 hrs on BDO in just character customization, this game's is honestly really close to being on par with BDO's, which in my experience has been the best char customization in any game I have played.

TLDR to those of ya'll who just want the clear verdict: It's anime dark souls. The combat feels similar, map design is similar, and overall it just really is *best non-souls, souls-like game* in my opinion. The game's bosses felt REALLY EASY apart from like 2, but the overall progression in the game is around souls -levels of challenging.

The game is honestly very good, and definitely worth picking up on sale, or even when it's not on sale, if you just want a good souls experience.

With nearly a hundred hours of game play, and multiple play through, I can say that this game does follow typical 'souls game' mechanics. When I say that, I mean artificially inflated difficulty (IE monsters and boss hit very hard, HP sponges, clunky control mechanics), but also with that comes the ability to stack this into your advantage as well by exploiting collected blood codes once mastered to create nearly one hit wonders against boss fights. 

I haven't played since the last couple fixes, but there were some very annoying bugs that could cause one DLC to break entirely and become unbeatable as well as other bugs that would occasionally cause very annoying setbacks. One such is that I have completed all blood codes and story lines, but a bug keeps me from getting the achievements for such without replaying the game from the very start....and I don't like the game enough to do all of that again just for two achievements not working.

The over all style is very anime, so if that isn't your thing then player beware. The character creator is very well done for an anime style, and you'll probably spend a good deal of time making the right kind of look for your character and again later as you unlock other options. The one downside to the character creator is that it has assignment points (IE you can only wear so many combinations due to engine limitation), but this shouldn't hinder the creation process too much.

Biggest learning curve will be your parry system and understanding just which blood codes best suite each other to include weapon types to use with them and proper armor. You will only get so much stat gain from leveling up, the main of your damage, defense, and survivability will come from your weapon, armor, and blood codes you use. Just cause you earn a new blood code, does not mean you get to use everything from it right away. They must be unlocked and mastered before you can combine some of the passives using a different blood code. You will not get all blood codes with only one playthrough either. Some of them are very dependant on choices you make during the game and some choices don't become available until after at least one or more playthroughs.

I'll recommend the game if souls style game is your thing, and simply because I like how the story ties into the God Eater universe/lore. However, if you think this game looks cool and will be fun just to play I would highly suggest trying the demo first. This game can be very punishing if you don't learn how to adapt to the mechanics of the game and try to rely on slow/clunky dodge mechanics instead. Knowing how to parry is very crucial in this game for various reasons, not just to avoid damage but also to increase the pool for using blood codes.
Tutorial could be better.  I do like the story though.

I love Remnant from the Ashes, I love God Eater. This game is a great fusion of the two with a ridiculous amount of edgy anime.

It's soulslike, but I don't think it should be compared to Dark Souls. It wants to empower the player, give you worth, and enjoy some absolutely cringe tier dumb anime content like:
A, a female sidekick wearing next to nothing at all times
B, childishly angsty questions identity
C, ridiculously over the top combat moves that somehow don't insta-gib enemies

It's also all about the combat, while 'Souls has an element of navigation and problem solving. Which is why I think it's fairer to compare it to Remnant. Sure there's no guns, but the core loop is about going to a map, enjoying some tense but empowering combat, then returning to a home base through fast travel to level up and talk to NPC's.

Because of the soup that made this game, 1 part God eater, 2 parts Remnant, 1 part dumb anime, I can easily recommend this game to people who enjoy those things.

Spent about 3 hours on the Butterfly boss. I have almost 10 thousand hours in all the Souls games combined and nothing can make me comprehend why:

1: This boss has so much HP. Way more than the first boss.
2: The wall of enemies to even get to her.
3: The vast expense of antivenom items because of course this boss inflicts poison that's basically guaranteed death.

I was enjoying it up to the boss, and no. I'm not going to summon, I'm not going to use AI partners. I've played every Soulslike solo and I very much intend to keep it going, and if you are gonna force me to do so, then I'm just gonna stop playing.

I'm furious. I'd like to experience the rest of what the game has to offer but sorry, 3 hours on ONE boss, THE SECOND boss, is enough.
